Foxhole is a game where individuals actively work against each other in order to defeat the enemy. In fact, one of the paradoxes of Foxhole is that while every individual thinks they're the best on the faction with the worst luck, the faction is far worse than how good any individual thinks they are. This inescapable skill cap can be explained by how every time you play anti-infantry, your anti tank sucks, and your faction loses, and every time you play logistics, your QRF sucks and your team loses. When your teammates try to point out that you're the common denominator, you could ignore them completely because they don't speak the same language.

Foxhole tries to be too many things and ends up being bad at all of it. Too many aspects deserve to be refined. I don't design nor develop video games so my opinions are largely invalid.

The developers do [b]NOT[/b] value your time nor sanity, and many mechanics take exorbitant durations and/or effort. The developers try to introduce some Random Number Generator based things in Foxhole to increase relevancy of teamwork and tactics (instead of pure "how-fast-I-can-snap-my-mouse-to-head-shot"), but just end up making the game feel unfair. Not only this, many underlying mechanics that the player base should be able to understand for a fair playing ground is not explained in any way, and community management and communication is nonexistent except for a stream every third of an year and vague patch notes without solid numerical data.

Every bit of respect for the developers and their work but with the state of the game, it can not be recommended with good intent and sound thought.

My experience with this game has been a mix of enjoyment and disillusionment. The gameplay itself is fun and addictive, a grind at times but enjoyable with friends. However, this enjoyment is overshadowed by the negative aspects of the community.

The toxicity within the community is a significant issue, particularly for women and LGBTQ+ folks. You will have to deal with sexism, ableism, slurs, death threats, stalkers and nazis with little to no support from the larger community. 

Joining regiments and interacting with people on both sides can be an experience‚Ä¶. A lot of these regiments have your average gamer brain person with no short supply of slurs and using mental health or disability related terms with negative connotations. Toxic vets (high ranks/long time players) that set the behaviour of regiments and the faction as a whole creating a reinforcement loop for everyone around them to act in bad ways. You are expected to ignore the abuses going on around you, if you stand up for yourself you will be outcasted from the social circles or have to exile yourself.

Regiment drama and inter personal relationships will have your head exploding, leave the community servers and hubs its not worth it for your mental health. Devs need to add a way to disable world chat as it will have you questioning why we even got out the primordial soup.

For new players, the learning curve can be steep, with some veterans displaying a lack of patience It's awful to keep seeing new players shouted at and reported for being alts rather than guided and supported.

It's difficult to address these issues when the bad actors seem to be in the majority. The current state of the community leaves much to be desired, and it's unfortunate that such behaviour is tolerated and even normalised.

Find a good bunch of people to play with try not to let the foxhole brain worms infect you. Winning or losing does not matter, have fun, be kind to each other üò≠

Very fun sandbox type game with a pretty chill player base considering the type of game this is. You can hop around different roles and work in different areas and it makes the game fun since all roles are extremely important (logi, infantry, artillery, armor, facilities, etc.) Regiments also will help you and most people are surprisingly newbie friendly. 

I will say if you do start (and well even for vets), just know every piece of equipment you use is created by other players. They mined, crafted, and transported EVERYTHING so treat equipment well and try to avoid stealing if someone clearly is trying to save something for their own operations.  

That being said, there are some clear flaws to the game that include:
-[b]IMMENSE amounts of alt accounts used that has been actively ignored by the developers that steal, grief, and ruin queue : in it's current state, so many parts of the game become unbalanced and unfair ON BOTH SIDES since of course alternate accounts are not designed into the gameplay and is technically banned by the rules, yet there is no form of ip banning or any type of system to fight this so it is inevitable unless developers actually want to lose their alternate account game sales[/b]
-Server instability 
-Bias of developers and interference
-Quality of life for logistics and bases (maintenance supplies can be produced 15k+, yet can only be transported in small batches; logistics in terms of gameplay is severely lacking more complex systems and streamlining that make it nearly unplayable)
-Collision problems with terrain and jankiness with water (you will get stuck often)

UPDATED REVIEW: 
After spending some more time with the game I realized I just got a bit unlucky with whom I was interacting with. Honestly a majority of the players are pretty relaxed and more open to help then anything. This game isn't perfect; but it's certainly unique and for that I would have to recommend giving it a try. I would also have to advise that it's a bit tedious though; a lot of the game is waiting on menu's. Unless they are going to add among us like minigames (which would be worse) not sure how they could solve this issue. At least a fill until full option would be a nice quality of life feature for logi players. The servers also tend to have issues sometimes, not sure if this has to do with the new boats or if this has been ongoing for awhile. The combat also feels kinda jank, where it's mostly RNG. Bayonet's should not be the best weapon for mid/close range but all you have to do is get lucky and you can kill someone with an smg by charging them. To be honest I think it's a combination of the way aiming works and the server delay that makes bayonets stupid. If someone is running full charge you basically have to aim a bit forward to account for the delay, ontop of server delay this becomes just basically luck. Pretty sure my soldier with pistol would have at least finished off the guy he just shot three times before getting stabbed. Like point blank; how the hell do you miss a man running right at you, it's one of those things that just feels super stupid when it happens. Oh right because it's a lottery system. Make the combat feel more skillful and realistic and then I think I could recommend this to everyone. All I can say about this game is it's good parts are good and it's bad parts can be really bad. Whether you'll enjoy the good parts over the bad that's for you to find out. I think it's worth picking up to try out and just return it if it's not your cup of tea.

"Foxhole is a game where many players are encouraged to work together in a sandbox environment."

The teamwork doesn't improve the situation naturally, it is controlled artificially. When an algorithm, or an adult decides that you have teamworked correctly, the game makes you successful. If you want to win the game, tell other people what to do, or follow other people's orders. If you just do your own thing in your corner, you will be bullied by people that are paid to bully you until you join other people. Its a game of herding people or being herded.

The shooting is simplistic. Logistics, artillery, tank gameplay is boring. There can be strategies, but not in the world chat because some players use multiple accounts to spy on the other side. There can be strategies inside a regiment, but it will be made successful / unsuccessful by whatever adult is in charge of deciding if you teamworked correctly or not. And by the way you have to teamwork the way that the game wants you to teamwork, expecting other players to fulfill other roles will be made to not work.

The best you can get from it is the feeling of being part of something bigger, but in fact its the same as being manipulated into being part of a Cult. The rules of the game limits your gameplay into a style and reinforces it with psychological manipulation.

Its a game that might've been corrupted by Canada's sponsorship for videogame development. A propaganda machine. Many veterans have left since the Inferno update, which I guess was when the "teamwork" changes were made.

I thought that maybe I was wrong and tried really hard to find ways to enjoy it, but I've had enough experience to have a strong definitive opinion about this game. I wouldn't use videogames to propagandate my kids, and surely not with those ideas.

Its a game that had values, but has sellout to larger money-monsters. Vote with your money, don't buy this game.

All the cool stuff is behind a massive grind fest of logistics that I'm pretty sure most players don't give a F about. I certainly don't. It's too in depth. It's probably a reason why the game's pop is dying drastically. People just want to play a persistent war, not a persistent logistics nightmare. I don't think most are interested in the logistics, but if you want a tank, arty, a decent rifle, ammo, bandages or anything besides a pistol and 2 mags, you have to create everything from scratch. It's honestly annoying and far too in depth. 

I thought the game looked interesting and bought it on a whim because friends play sometimes. But with the 2 hour return window, you will NOT have enough time to understand this game and if it's something you'll want to continuing playing. I found out that hard way that Steam changed the return time window. I haven't requested a refund in a long time and with only 5.9 hours they denied me. I think 5.9 is reasonable. Now I'm forced to find something I like about it to get my monies worth and I despise Foxhole and Steam for it. 

Do not buy this game at full price. It doesn't feel polished nor popular enough to justify the price since it relies soully on a dedicated community to actually function. I don't think it has enough of one. I'd wait for a sale of at least 50% or more off if you really want to try it. Also watch a ton of video. I mean hours worth of tutorials and guides to see if the logistical grind or anything is worth it too you. 

Game would have been more fun with minimal logistics mechanics if it needed it at all. 

Also, Steam can go screw itself for the 2 hour return window. With how games are today, most need a 6-8 hour return window.

Like most of the multiplayer warfare simulators on the market, Foxhole suffers from its poor design of the player feedback loops. You want to win the war, but you are meant to figure out the short-term goals, motivations and rewards on your own, as the only systems the game offers for that are 'commendations' and the 'ranks', neither of which have any mechanical effect on gameplay.
It also, like most of the multiplayer warfare simulators on the market, requires unrealistic amounts of coordination from mostly random strangers, and the only systems the game offers for that are 'map markers', 'squads' and  'regiments', all of which are very primitive and feel like an afterthought.
It is naive to expect every player to be able to, to know how to, and to want to communicate with other players verbally all the time, and it is very sad that Foxhole's devteam chooses to add more weapons, more vehicles and more complex features, instead of bringing the basic player experience to an enjoyable level.
The game is IMMENSELY fun when played as a large (10+ people) group of friends, where you can compensate for the lack of in-game features by organizing and communicating externally, but you as a potential buyer are statistically unlikely to have that many friends, let alone that many friends willing to buy and learn a new game.

P.S.
Logistics are boring and un-rewarding, infantry combat is wonky and frustrating, and there are also no plans to add EU or Asian servers that I heard of, so as a Eurasian player, you are stuck with a 300+ ping Canadian server, in a game with one-hit-deaths and full friendly fire.

With years of development time, newly named developer 'Siegecamp' has created a unique war game that offers countless hours of gameplay within the Unreal engine. Unfortunately, the game lacks the proper polish and balance due lack of community engagement and development changes.

Pros
+Player built structures allow for diverse strategic options
+Worldwide 24/7 servers create unique and engaging experiences with other players
+Player-run economy allows for in-depth logistical planning and tactical choices
+Private squad/regiment system allowing you to group up with friends or other teammates

-Lack of direct-communication channels with players/veterans to improve the game
-Lack of moderation and tools to counter cheaters, exploiters and players alting (switching teams to hurt that team)
-Lack of an up-to-date and proper tutorial
-Lack of quality of life game features (notably in logistics; i.e. more automated systems to ease logistics burden in late-game when resource costs and travel times are high)
-Lack of in-game options for team planning / communication
-Best vehicles are locked behind the construction and maintenance of a facility (large base) requiring a considerable time investment (making them unavailable to majority of player-base)
-Developers have removed useful features  (i.e. XP progress bar, end-war leader-boards)
-Many combat issues including reload bug, terrain glitches (stuck locations, invisible walls and terrain assets), random disconnects (typically at borders or high population areas) and many more


What Foxhole offers as a unique game experience is a valuable piece of content for anyone and is worth the price of admission if it's what you're looking for. You'll no doubt leave with some unique experiences, however, you'll undoubtedly be sucked into an endless grind that cannot be maintained due to the lack of supporting systems and player intentions. If combat is your goal, then be prepared to spend countless hours sitting in queues, dealing with game bugs/exploits and driving lots to do so.

I have had a long time with Foxhole, but I have also realized that the game has shifted in favour of relying on a greater time investment from the player and a lack of gameplay polish/features. 

This game and the developers need some serious help.

Torn on this, but I must vote down on recommending Foxhole. The game is well made, stays true to the idea of being only a mere soldier, and offers a gameplay experience that you don't often see for war games.

But being a lone soldier that can't impact much of anything at all, just doesn't feel fun. You will die constantly, respawn at a base nearby, and repeat the same drudgery for hours trying to make even a small impact.

The most fun I had was running into random groups or clans that let me tag along with them. Then you get to experience tank brigade rushes, or hopping on a ship and working with a crew to actually blow the hell out of the enemy positions. But unless you are committed to constantly joining groups, and coordinating on a bigger scale, there just isn't a single-player version of this game that feels very satisfying imo.

This game is for people who like cooperation, clans, and working with coordinated teams. This game is not for someone looking to go rogue, out on their own, or feel powerful as an individual. That's ok, but it's just not my type of game.

Foxhole has great deep going game elements, you have resources collected by players, then players have to traffic logistics by truck/train/boats, process them to materials for building defences/factories anywhere, crafting weapons/ammo, or vehicles/boats/trains. All these actions you do together with your faction. You even have a faction tech tree, that slowly progresses over multiple days while gradually unlocking more and more advanced stuff. The map is semi-persistent, with that i mean, a war will often take multiple weeks (20~80 days) depending on the faction succes. You start out with early slaugtherhouse infrantry pushes, and end up with tactical-nukes and tanklines pounding level 3 concrete bunker defences.

The controls can be a bit hard to get used to, as you are not aiming like a 3d shooter with a croshair, but more like a 2.5d topdown kind of view. It will take some time to adjust to aiming like this. But in the end it adds to a feel that really fits this game.

The community's in this game can be very big, with some clans having lots of people in their ranks. You can also play the game solo, which is fun to learn some of the basics, and getting a bit of a feel on the front-lines, and maybe some basic logistics.
But don't expect to solo build a big bunker or facility complex quickly, since it requires a lot of effort and also maintenance to not have it decay. (Especially in the lastest patches, solo play became more limited and harder overal) Besides that, the community can be very toxic if you touch their stuff, or build non optimal things. I have not had much issues with this, but there are lots of stories from solo players getting kicked/shortly banned by clans, sometimes with decent reasons, but also often for no clear/good reason at all. Dont expect the game staff will do much about it if a clan picks on you.

If you want to get the most out of this game, i suggest you to play with a clan at the current state of the game, and make sure you have at least some time to play for a few hours a few times a week to be able to get something roling.

If you are planning to go solo, i will not recomment the game in the current state, some things that could be done solo before, have become very difficult now. Also most groups don't simply add solo players to fill party slots, since they will be scared of you potentially stealing or losing their expensive stuff.

Considering the game has become more and more limited for solo play with the last years updates, i will for now not advice the game for the general public. I might change my opinion if there will be changes that will allow solo players to do more things as well, or that allow them to more easily co√∂perate with groups.

And while first thing can be justified by this being an MMO, second thing just gives you a headache. Please DO NOT buy this game, maybe then developers will actually start to hear their community

This is the most rage inducing MMO I ever played. And I played War Thunder so it is very difficult to top that one. You will develop love/hate relationship and you will enjoy all different aspects that game offers...for some time. I consider it a pretty highly addictive game, and believe me, it's like a drug. And drugs are no good for you buddy. You will ask yourself why i just found this game now, where was it all along? This is the greatest MMO ever man! But... after a while you will start feeling consequences of this bug infested glitchfest of a game. Unfinished product that still HAS great potential. Unfortunately, I think it will never be something more than that. If you ask me, this is still an early access game.

And yes, everything is good and dandy until the burnout kicks in. How to avoid burnout? Impossible. Btw, this is the only game that I regularly exited with Alt+F4. No game can beat that! On top of that, balance issues, toxicity and teamkills is a regular, especially in the situations when your faction is losing a region. Then pure chaos ensues and... well, things happen.
On top of that you will die in all the ways possible you could imagine 10 times in a row in a span of 30 seconds, just to look 45 seconds of that annoying death screen after every death. On top of all of the above add the fact that most of the time you died, you died because of the bugs and poor design decisions. Some of these things are impossible to fix. I'll just mention a few things that are horrendous and will never be fixed (probly):

-queue bugs (waiting to enter another region for 10-15 mins in a truck full of bmats just to get disconnected and thrown back to the menu screen. You have to redeploy, and probably lost everything)
-queue time (because, time matters, life is too short to watch youtube adds and wait to join in game FOXIHOLE)
-respawn time (especially after a teamkill or some other death you could not control at all, you should have shorter respawn time)
-stuttering (minor nuisance but happens quite often)
-getting stuck in trenches, foxholes, trucks, bases, literally everything.
-getting stuck in jump animation after getting unstuck from trenches, foxholes, trucks, bases, literally everything. (You basically have to go back to the previous spot where you got stuck in the first place and start all over again)
-If you switch to your secondary or tertiary weapon after use of primary weapon too fast it won't load. Basically you will not equip it. (very annoying if you need to throw a grenade pretty fast or use binos after mortar fast) 
-Make WIDER roads.
-Inability to check activity log while dead
-I want to be able to check map when driving without stopping. I didn't use a brake for the love of god, just wanted to check the map for one friggin second! (Especially annoying when trying Logi)
-REMOVE BARBED WIRE from game!
-friggin LAG, this thing is the worst. This is the main reason for that rage inducing part I mentioned.(And it's not on me).
There's more stuff but this is the most annoying thing. 

For now this game is a NO NO. If devs fix some of these things i'll change my opinion as well.

Edit: Nothing ever changed. Maybe just my mental state. I returned to this crap of a game. The game is literal cancer. Artillery is cancer. Everything You will do, that could and it will turn against you. Every bmat you worked for, every flank you did, every action you carefully planned will be nullified by this cancer of a game. If I had a chance to bring the time i lost playing this game I would be happy. If I could I would sue devs for making this cancer of a game. It is a long story to write and I'm not going to do it. I will literally delete this game from my steam, so it would never remind me, that time I wasted is priceless and I can't never get it back. I wasted thousands of hours on Football managers and CIV series, Europa Universalis and similar Paradox games, even on WoW and I don't regret it. But this crap... Even War Thunder was worth it. There, I said it. 

Devs if you read this, don't take it seriously. It was a great idea but terrible execution. The only thing you executed perfectly is the time of my life that I will never get back. Please find a new job and cancel this cancer project you call a game.

Thank You!

DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME! The concept of this game is really cool, the artstyle is nice, the game on paper sounds great. But trust me, it is not worth your time.  If there is a way I could describe it is that it is -a waste of time- And I mean that literally, not as in the game is bad: Achieving anything in this game takes INCREDIBLE amounts of time, time which is spent doing painfully boring, tedious, and mildly inconveniencing things, little tiny frustrations, be they due to lack of cooperation from developers and an unsportsmanlike community or sometimes just bad game design which add up into hours spent preforming miserable tasks, for the promise that by the end of it you'll get a huge reward. The problem is that after getting all of those 'chores' done, the game simply lays out even more obstacles in front of you (and I don't mean it in the fun, intended obstacle way) the tiniest of things you could never have accounted for CAN and WILL happen to stop your plan dead in the tracks even after you've done everything to ensure it works. Even some of the simplest things to do in this game result in the appearance of 20 different problems you have to solve before you can do those things, and after those problems are solved, and you've jumped through 12 figurative hoops to get here, something can still go very very wrong: *The enemies you spent hours setting up artillery to bomb have retreated by then./The hundreds of rockets you've been stockpiling for a barrage get destroyed by partisans (infiltrators behind your lines) the exact day you were going to launch that barrage./Spent 4 days grinding to build your facility? A regiment (people from YOUR OWN faction, that you should be COOPERATING WITH) destroys it because they wanted to make a rail line that only they would use trough there.* These are all examples that happened to me and my friends during our time playing this game. The whole allure of this game is that after doing hours of what are essentially virtual chores, it will give you some big reward for them, except it won't. I am not a religious person, but I swear with my hand on my heart and my eyes towards GOD when I say: this game does nothing but waste your time, it is intrinsically tied to how the game is designed. It makes you run 40 kilometers and jump through 20 hoops for the promise of a piece of candy, which it will crumple and step on in front of you once you're done.

Hello I‚Äôm CmdrConrad, Brigadier of the warden army and leader of the Clover‚Äôs Rifle or better known ‚ÄúCR‚Äù 

1.4k hours spent almost in this game... I cannot somehow recommend Foxhole. In Fact i have to advise against it.Your safety and well being should be prioritised. I've made it clear I don't care about death threats. I‚Äôve already experienced it all In game and Discord. 

My rank and hours don't matter, its just a dumb gesture to show "Hay I played the game" that's all it should be! not a way to dictate your opinions. Just because you have 10k hours in the game doesn't give you the authority to dictate whether someone else enjoyed this game or not. 

The Community has had some wonderful people and individuals, who were lovely to me and my Regiment. However the "clan man bad" meme is too true, Fun isn't a concept unless your winning. Winning is the only acceptable way for fun. If you disagree you will get yelled at you will be ridiculed and hopefully dismissed. 

Where does the community truly shine? The front line soldier! Fighting in open fields or at bridges and hills for hours on end is truly fun. The people make it even better I can look pass buggy features and terrain with a fun time. 

Unfortunately the game is plagued with middle aged men and veterans that will treat this like a real life situation not even in a larp way just dead serious which is weird because its a game chill out enjoy the experience have fun???

Paranoia is extremely high in this game about alt accounts. The community is also very hostile to twitch streamers due to "they are leaking map intel" so if your a streamer looking to play this don't. You will be hassled to get map covers or just straight up told to not stream the game at all. 

Logistics isn't meant for everyone if you do insist on playing Foxhole do not get pressured into it. No one cares about the rank above your head, the dopamine isn't even worth it. I've been there and I'm extremely guilty as charged for it. 

Tanking has never been fun since they made those new defences and tanks that can one shot Ironhides. Wars will progress to a point where infantry will become nullified and you will require tanks. 

I'm very sad that I was ridiculed for using the "Noble Widow MK.XIV" or as I'd like to just call it the Warden Hetzer tank. Just like the Ironhide it was one of the regiment favourites. So when updates kept rolling which made both these tanks more obsolete even in the prime tech time. 

The Ironhide is an upgrade to the Devitt MK III. Before inferno update you could make these in the garage if your faction researched them! however in the new update. You were required to use facilities to get certain upgraded tanks... Which locks out most casual players

Facilities! I cannot stress how stupid this update was. They should of been to make the super tanks nothing else. I was fine with the idea you needed a massive coordinated effort to make these super tanks. However mixing them in with tank upgrades killed the game for me.

I was a casual player running a mostly casual regiment, however as inferno came out we had to take this game way more serious and that's when CR was officially disbanded. The Clovers rifles that started in Port of Rime during the glory of battle ended in a fucking factory... 

I still standby everything I said before and now the fundamentals of the game will never change. But I'm no longer a reliable source I don't have the game installed anymore I don't go in to just check things out I'm done with Foxhole. 

Thank you everyone for the support, I'm sorry that I'm not able to write a better review anymore. The game has changed much but I don't want to be stressed or plagued with anxiety anymore, but thank you all for being kind and respectful in the comments. 

I'm CmdrConrad over and out.

This game presents numerous flaws, ultimately leading to a lack of recommendation. While its primary allure lies in promoting cooperative play and large-scale operations, these aspects often result in players facing long queues or frequent disconnections. Additionally, the player-built equipment feature, which emphasizes real costs and logistical strategy, is undermined by tedious tasks rather than the in-game resources. For example, loading a freighter with supplies requires 40 non-idle minutes of constant clicking every minute, while loading ammo into a tank is a slow, manual process. Despite ongoing tweaks aimed at balancing artillery, tanks, AI, and other elements, it appears that these adjustments only serve to preserve stalemates. Most wars seem to be decided by whichever side gets bored first, highlighting a significant gameplay issue.

Furthermore, the prevalent problem of players purchasing the game multiple times to create alternate accounts, known as "alts," solely for the purpose of team-killing exacerbates these issues. Their malicious actions not only erode motivation to engage with the game but also render hours of dedicated progress futile for legitimate players. This rampant exploitation of the system by cheaters undermines fair gameplay and leaves the community feeling powerless and demoralized. Overall, the game offers an experience fraught with imbalance and minimal rewards, failing to deliver on its potential for engaging gameplay.

This is one of my all-time favorite games. It's incredible watching players from across the globe work together for the singular goal of defeating the enemy. That being said, I cannot recommend it in it's current state.

          Rampant server issues prevent even the smallest groups of invaders from getting into certain regions by sea. Imagine spending hours of your time collecting materials to construct the largest and most formidable ships only to lose them because your crew has been disconnected from the server leaving an empty ship in enemy territory. To add insult to injury, the ship is now too close to the region border to deploy from the home region (sometimes you do appear where you were before disconnecting, but this rarely happens), making it impossible to re-crew the ship after a mass-disconnect.

          At the time of this review the developers have known of these persistent issues for multiple weeks, yet nothing is being said or done about it. This game is amazing and I cherish the people I've met and the experiences we've shared playing it and I would love to leave a positive review for a game that has so quickly captivated me with it's shear breadth of content.

          However, these issues prevent an entire branch of a factions military from being used in it's current state. This puts me into a very difficult position, because despite my adoration for Foxhole, I definitely cannot recommend it if you are interested in buying it. Hopefully in the near-future I can change this review into a positive one because I honestly do love it and hope more people play it.

In good conscience to people their time and effort... Combined with the Dev-team being near utter silent on gamebreaking bugs such as but not limited to:

* Seaports Inventory breaking
* Ships disconnecting
* Mass disconnections during Operations
* Server crashes causing structures to respawn in
* Entities when destroyed able to delete entire units of the map
*...

I can NOT recommend this game. Whilst still playing due to addiction. To people who value a Developer that listens to their customers. Siegecamp is not that. Not untill they address these issues in a professional and composed way.

Save yourself your money, or buy it at least during a sale... No matter how tempting the game is.

Sincerely signed,

I have to start this review by saying that every few months, I come back and have fun. Then, two weeks later, I get reminded why I stop playing this game for months at a time.

Some context: I work full-time in education. I come home exhausted and want to play a fun game for a couple hours before I go to bed and have to repeat the whole process. I WANT Foxhole to be that game, and in many respects, it is so, so close to BEING that game. Time after time, though, I am reminded that Foxhole is not for people like me. You know, the working class. Get ready for a small essay of a review below.

I find the combat mechanics frustrating. I echo some other reviews where you will go up against a veteran player who has managed to figure out how to button mash WASD while also keeping their aim very stable. It is incredibly frustrating to play against one v one. I have seen squads of four players fall to one person using this strategy. Call it a skill issue, I call it discouraging to new players wanting to get into combat. The re-spawn times drives the stake in completely. Why am I punished for 40 seconds, only to potentially get shelled and have to then wait even longer, upwards of a minute or more to get back in the game. Hell Let Loose makes you wait no more than 50 seconds, and it's often not even that long.

That's not even coming close to my largest complaint. I found combat frustrating, so I went to the back-lines to do logistics instead. I find the process of logistics in this game incredibly fascinating and, for at least a week or so, fun.

However, in no other game have I considered installing a TV in my room above my desk for the sole purpose of playing a different game while playing Foxhole, because if you want to gather resources for you and your friends to be able to play (say to build a tank or some jeeps), the game is quite frankly disrespectful to your time. I just weigh my mouse button down with a stack of taped together quarters and play a round of golf in Switch Sports, just waiting and hitting metal with a hammer. "Use a sledge" - Yes, the sledge is faster. I still am just sitting there, positioning my player in the middle of several resource nodes while it takes slightly less time to accumulate resources. "Use a harvester" - Oh boy, am I going to lay down some fun facts for you, if we want to pretend that driving a slow, tracked vehicle around nodes of salvage (or worse, components) is fun.

A Harvester takes 90 Processed Construction Materials and 25 Assembly Materials IV to create. Don't know what those are? Tutorial Island certainly won't help you. As an honest reply to the insane number of materials you need to recall if you decide to make buildings, just ask for help in the chat. The wiki is somewhat out of date and there are no official resources, but the community really can be the best part of this game and most people are generally helpful. Ignore the turds that talk down to you or mock you for not knowing - stupid people exist everywhere.

Back to the problem at hand. Let's ignore the time you need to set up and upgrade the facilities and buildings you need to make these items and just look at the amount of time it takes to create one single harvester.

One Processed Construction Material takes Three Construction Materials and 20 Components. You need 90 in total.
--- One Construction Material takes 10 Salvage to create.
----- 10 Salvage can be obtained with two hits of a Hammer or one hit of a Sledgehammer. Approx. 5 seconds, either way.
--- Two Components can be obtained with one hit of a Sledgehammer. Normal hammers do not work; You must wait a few days in game for player to collect the necessary materials to "discover" Sledgehammers. The only other way to get Components is through a Component Mine. Assuming you find one that's not being hogged by other players (and this is a genuine struggle), you can get nine Components every 30 seconds. 30 every 30 seconds if you have Petrol to fuel the mine with, which, again, is hard to get sometimes. All of this to say that getting 20 Components takes about 30 seconds, either way.

One Assembly Material IV takes One Processed Construction Material and 66 Litres of Heavy Oil. You need 25 in total.
--- (Look above for how you get one Processed Construction Material)
--- To get 90 Litres of Heavy Oil, you need to go to an oil field, build the appropriate buildings (with upgrades), then refine 150 litres of oil to 90 litres of heavy oil. That process takes 2 minutes and 40 seconds, not to mention the resources needed to power the buildings.

Wondering how long that all takes? For the 25 Assembly Materials IV, it takes 45 minutes from one of these facility buildings, assuming you already have the Processed Construction Materials. Those 115 Processed Construction Materials (90 + 25) take 1 hour and 15 minutes. You can do these two things in parallel if you have the buildings, of course, but it takes time to make those buildings. So, we will call it at about 2 hours to make a single vehicle that helps make one aspect of gathering resources slightly faster.

I ask you, reader, genuinely, do you think that this entire process is respectful of people's time? I don't. I would change my tone completely if the process were more engaging for the player to partake in. Some mini-games would go MILES and turn this review from an essay length negative triad to me just saying "haha hit metal make gun".

"Join a Regiment" (this game's version of a Clan) - Fine. That might work for some people. Clans often times ask their members for a certain number of items to be produced at a factory or for them to gather a certain amount of material before you go off and do what you want to. That's not why I play a game. I play a game to hop in and have fun. I'd rather just play Overwatch 2, and I hate that dumpster fire, but at least it respects my time.

As of right now, i really cant find myself giving this game a good review. It might be best to view this review as a neutral one, perhaps trending towards negative right now. 

Why? I've clearly got a fair few hours in this game so surely it cant be that bad

Well, its not, its actually quite enjoyable at times. Working together with other people to accomplish a victory be it with lumbering armour, large cannons or just well coordinated infantry , is a neat experience.  You can interact with some swell folks and the game has a truly passionate community.

[b]So why do i say neutral trending towards negative?[/b]

The community combined with the current issues (perhaps they'll be fixed soon, but this review is for the now). 

[b]I'll start with the issues. [/b] Server connections in this game can be *really* iffy and due to how this game works, that can have a MASSIVE impact on the war (if you cant connect to a server reliably, you can't exactly contest the region). 

Part of the issues with this game are the developers, as unfortunate and wrong it feels to say that. They're clearly passionate about the game and put out some truly incredible content, but they seem to focus almost too much on new content, flashy tanks and large vehicles. They put out updates about 4-5 times per year  and  i shit you not this is pretty much the only time they balance anything outside of [b]exceptional[/b] circumstances. This means that if they add a new piece of content that throws the game balance completely out of wack, it is not unreasonable to expect it to take half a year or more for them to rectify the issue. (examples include the Warden heavy field cannon and Colonial superheavy anti-tank gun). The balance changes made also tend to be very large and almost like a sledgehammer being used to adjust a delicate piece of equipment. (the community probably doesnt help here to be honest, both sides fight like lunatics to prove that they are actually victims of poor balance and the developers should buff them and/or nerf the other side)  


Another part is the developers being silent, Granted i admit that i wouldnt want to interact with the games community either (see below), but they seem to be almost allergic to any sort of communication.  In response to the above mentioned server issues the response was "yeah we know and we'll fix it next update probably" [paraphrased] . This is incredibly rare. Normally they say NOTHING at all in regards to anything, which also feeds into the next issue:

[h3]The community[/h3]
There are so many great people who  are truly delightful to interact with, but there is also what seems to be a not-insignificant amount of quite loud and toxic people. Exploits are common in this game due to the above mentioned dev-silence and a fair few of the people outside the game itself (eg: on the reddit, discord etc.) are just unpleasant to talk to. 

The community has also been largely left to moderate itself and the end result is just....disappointing. People will actively ignore people exploiting or otherwise partaking in shitty behaviour for the simple fact that they are on the same team. That same person might then turn around and demand a permanent ban for someone doing similar shitty behaviours on the opposite side. 

A good idea, executed relatively well and clearly worked on by a passionate developer team,  marred by the developers refusal to even state what is considered an exploit, and by a playerbase left too long to its own devices that at this point seems to only care about winning an imaginary war (winning wars does nothing but let one side say they've won X wars btw.)  by any means necessary.

War 110.

It gets mass reported to the bugs channel and the devs respond with.

So I have clocked almost 100 hours in this game over the past week and I have had a lot of fun and I think I will keep playing it for some time. If I could give the game a neutral rating I would have done so, but for reasons that I will get into I chose to give a negative rating over a positive one.

Like I said the game is actually fun, but as you get more and more into it, it's flaws start to become more and more obvious.

First off, there are cheaters in the game and there is no anti-cheat system in place outside of a reporting system. Reporting systems can be abused and I have heard other people claim, that the large clans are mass reporting people they don't like or agree with. I have no personal experience with this so I can't say if it is true or not, but most games that has clans and a reporting system seem to have this problem, so I guess it is reasonable to assume that the rumors are true.

There are cheaters that use auto-aim bots and hacks that increase their health, viewing distance, build speed, run speed and much more. I have my self seen many people flying above the ground while using a set of binoculars to scout. If you are far above the ground you can see more. There are so many ways to cheat this game, just go and make a quick search and see for yourself, what kinds of hacking software you can get for this game. You will see what I mean.

Another way of cheating is to buy a second copy of the game and make an alt account. This account is meant to be set to the opposing teams faction, so that you can move in their territory freely while sabotaging as much as possible. These people destroy vehicles and supplies, they basically grief the other players.

I have had a lot of connection issues. This is not a problem for me in any other game.

There are at certain times at the day a lot of queue time. When crossing from one border to another you are essentially going from one server to another. These servers are called regions. Each region has a max population and when that has been reached you must wait until someone leaves the region before you can enter. At peak times that wait time can be up to 20-30 minutes EVERY time you need to go into that region, which makes it unreasonable to run supplies to those regions.

I have clipped through the ground multiple time while trying climb a trench.

Often times when climbing rocks, you will find invisible walls that will glitch out you player character making him make a sort of weird dance. If he does that while the enemy is near you, you will die because you can't move or shoot. This has happened to me many times.

I don't know what the solution to the cheating problem is. I don't think it is a development issue. It is a player issue. However, the clipping, the queue times and the weird dancing glitch that happens when you climb rocks I feel like are issues that the developers should have fixed before a 1.0 release.

These are just some of my thoughts about the game. The game really is a lot of fun, but I am left with a bitter taste only because it could be so much better.

Makes you feel like something bigger than yourself, especially in the 1500v1500 or 2000v2000 (i forgot) war, you can log on day after day and the war will have gone on without you, immersing you further, plus the map is huge to explore, and there are SOOOOO many different ways to play the game and contribute to either team. For Callahan!

Foxhole is an amazing product and with the number of hours I have put into the game and the hours I have enjoyed I should really be putting a positive review. I have almost 8k hours in the game even though the majority of that is idle time and I will admit I have definitely got my moneys worth out of this game.

However, over the past two years the developers have shifted in a direction that doesn't respect the players time.

And the best way for me to demonstrate this is to walk through a very common process that is required which is refueling salvage mines.


[h1]Before the release of Foxhole 1.0 this is generally what the process was like:[/h1]

[list]
[*] Go to a garage. Build a fuel truck using basic materials.
[*] Drive over to a refinery, access the refinery from the front and pull diesel.
[*] Drive over to a salvage mine, lock the truck, Hit the refuel button on the salvage mine.
[*] If an empty fuel truck was already sitting at the salvage mine when you arrived. Drive it back. If not, you can go back to home region and spawn somewhere else.
[/list]

[h1]After the release of Foxhole 1.0 this is generally what the process is like:[/h1]

[list]
[*] Go to garage. Build a flatbed using components. Unlike basic materials. Components are harder to acquire.
[*] Drive over to the construction yard and build a fuel container with basic materials.
[*] Package the fuel container, get into the crane and pick up and place the container onto your flatbed.
[*] You now can drive to two different places for fuel:
	[*] A. Drive over to the refinery. Get into the crane and pick up and place the fuel container onto the loading dock. Pull diesel.
	[*]  B. Drive over to an oil facility. Find the mobile crane or structure crane. (if the facility doesn't have either of these you need to build one at a nearby town hall or relic). If they have a crane pick up and place your fuel container next to the small train rail. Use the small train car to pull petrol into the liquid transfer rail car and then transfer that fuel from the liquid transfer rail car to the fuel container. If they don't have this setup, place the fuel container onto the liquid transfer station (if they have one) and pull fuel (which takes about 10x longer then the first process I explained).
[*] Alright, were almost there, just hang in there. Now get back into the crane, repackage the fuel container and put it back on your flatbed.
[*] Drive over to a salvage mine. 
[*] See if the salvage mine has a nearby mobile crane or structure crane. (if the salvage mine doesn't have either of these you need to build one at a nearby town hall or relic).
[*] Get into the crane. Pick up your fuel container. Place it next to the salvage mine. Get out of the crane. Unpackage the fuel container. Hit the refuel button on the salvage mine.
[*] Drive your flatbed back to nearby storage/seaport and put it into your reserve. That thing cost components and you will want to save it.
[/list]

Notice how the process went from 4 steps to 10 steps and if you need to build cranes you might as well take those 10 steps and make it 12-14 steps.


This is the problem with Foxhole. You can take what I described above and apply it to other areas of the game where the developers took something that was simple and straightforward and added layers of complexity and time consuming steps.

[h1] Please Give This One A Go [h1]
I honestly wasn't sure if this game would be right for me, I saw the tiktoks and other creators praising this game and showing off unreal battles but I was just not sure I would get into it. I say that only because I thought it would be difficult to insert myself with such a niche community and that I would end up only playing solo. I was wrong.

The foxhole community showed me the ropes with anything I wanted to do or learn about, they answered all my questions about the game without hesitation and random players would stop to ask if I needed help when I clearly did not know what I was doing.

On paper this game ticked all the boxes for me: large scale map, multiple battlefronts, multiple branches of combat, REAL LOGISTICS, communication and coordination like I haven't seen before and lastly a unique art style and set piece.

In my time playing I have almost exclusively played logistics, as it makes you feel important, that you're contributing to the war machine and without players like you the war is lost. I loved thinking about how the bullets, weapons, bandages, artillery pieces and materials that I ship to the front via truck or boat will eventually be used by another player to help win the engagement. That is a level of immersion I haven't felt. Seeing players roleplay basebuilders, factory workers and seamen makes me really happy because it shows the games unique roles are all being filled by someone.

There are several roles I have yet to play that I'm excited to jump into like being a crewman on a battleship or tank, joining a massive assault on a town, mass producing bigger equipment and building my own base. This is the ultimate sandbox that offers a playstyle for anyone interested in the genre. Please give it a chance, have some fun, this is a breath of fres air.

[h2]TLDR: [/h2]



1) MMO + CoH2 + Factorio. 

2) Main goal is to win war on the global map. One war usually lasts 30-40~ real days. 

3) [u] [b] Heavily socially driven[/b]  [/u] . Not for solo players, but you can try. Better play with allies.

4) Full war production cycle: from mining raw resources that eventually turn into ammo / clothes / tanks / battleships / nukes.

5) The larger and more experienced group of people (=guild/clan) you have, the more you can influence the events on the fronline. The same applies to production facilities - —Åhinese players do not sleep, they have night shifts at the factories in Foxhole.

6) [i]Not for all :-) [/i]

Foxhole offers a unique way of playing simulated war games in a MMO fashion. Most war games only lets you experience the forefront battle and nothing behind the scenes as your always just play as the soldier with their gun shooting enemies until one side has more points than the other then restart and go again. With these games there is no constant struggle for dwindling of supply's and equipment while trying to push the forefront on scarce resources. 

Well Foxhole has another thing coming. In Foxhole your whole team of 100's of players will have to work together to supply your team with resources then build, buildings, warships, trains, tanks, weapons, first aid etc, with those collected resources. Then the other side of the team has to push the enemy back with that built equipment. Truly every roll in Foxhole is really important and no one is left out. Another thing I enjoy about this game is that the world is your oyster and you get to design and build defences like trenches, and bunkers like the pillbox bunker and a lot more. 

Honestly I can fall in love with this game... although there one issue that i want to bring to the table.
That is: You can not not remove your allies buildings: In Foxhole there will definitely be moments where you will run into ally constructions and say to yourself "w*f is this s#*t" because the buildings that are placed by your team are placed in such a horrible manner that you cant even squeeze you player model through it. Then the worst part is, is that you want to remove it and revamp it, yknow make it look better, make it function better. But no, no such thing as removing buildings in foxhole, you cant even remove it with explosives because then the game will ban you from using weapons for a short moment for 'friendly fire'???
I get it, its to reduce trolling and griefing but then what about the players who really want to make good logistics and defences. I just hope the devs will come up with something. 

I like to play foxhole with logistics with me building tanks and shipping them on a train to the front line... idk that s#*t just cool to me but fr i cant even support my team like that because there are so many ridiculous team buildings in the way.

But other than that i give it a 6/10 just because i cant really achieve what i want to do but still fun non the less and I think you will enjoy this game too.

[h1]Foxhole - A Tactical Warfare Odyssey Review (7 Hours Played)[/h1]

[h2][b]Review:[/b][/h2]

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚òÜ

Foxhole, with 7 hours of intense gameplay under my belt, is a tactical warfare odyssey that demands strategy, coordination, and unwavering determination. This persistent world war experience offers a unique take on multiplayer warfare.

[h2][b]Pros:[/b][/h2]

[h3][b]Persistent World:[/b][/h3] The game's persistent, player-driven world sets it apart. Battles have real consequences, and the evolving map reflects the outcome of each engagement.

[h3][b]Teamwork and Coordination:[/b][/h3] Foxhole thrives on teamwork. Coordinating with fellow soldiers to achieve objectives is not just rewarding but essential for success.

[h3][b]Player-Crafted Economy:[/b][/h3] The player-driven economy adds depth. From manufacturing weapons to delivering supplies, every role contributes to the war effort.

[h3][b]Strategy and Tactics:[/b][/h3] The game encourages strategic thinking. Planning and executing successful offensives or holding crucial defensive lines are immensely satisfying.

[h3][b]Community and Communication:[/b][/h3] The Foxhole community is dedicated, and communication within the game is vital. It fosters a sense of camaraderie among players.

[h2][b]Cons:[/b][/h2]

[h3][b]Steep Learning Curve:[/b][/h3] Foxhole is not for the faint of heart. Newcomers may find it challenging to grasp the complexities of war and logistics.

[h3][b]Time-Intensive:[/b][/h3] The game's persistent nature means that significant time investments are often required to make a substantial impact on the war effort.

[h3][b]Occasional Server Issues:[/b][/h3] Some server instability issues can disrupt gameplay, although they're typically addressed promptly.

[h2][b]Verdict:[/b][/h2]

With 7 hours played, Foxhole proves itself as a unique and demanding multiplayer warfare experience. Its persistent world, heavy emphasis on teamwork, and player-driven economy make it a standout title in the genre. While the learning curve can be steep and the commitment substantial, the rewards of meaningful battles and a dedicated player community are well worth it.

[h2][b]Recommended for those seeking a hardcore multiplayer war game, fans of strategy and coordination, and players looking for an immersive and persistent online world![/b][/h2] ü™ñüåçüõ†Ô∏è

EDIT: I won't be changing my review now that the game has been released in 1.0. Despite the addition of some new content, the core design and technical issues remain. The tutorial remains unfinished, and many of the mechanics are not explained in game and probably will never be.

TL;DR Foxhole is a very unique game, with some innovative ideas for an MMO. Unfortunately, the execution leaves much to be desired, specifically when it comes to game design, technical issues, and community management/moderation. Therefore, I can't recommend the game in its current state as a whole to the gaming community in general, although some gamers may wish to try it just to experience the unique, albeit flawed, experience the game has to offer.

Foxhole has been my love hate relationship for years. I was originally attracted by the promise of a large open world team game with strategic aspects. As a fan of RTS games, I knew I was most interested in the logisitics side of gameplay. Making strategic decisions about which supplies to make, where to send them, etc. can be extremely fun.

The problem is, the majority of the gameplay is NOT spent devising strategies and making moment-to-moment tactical choices. Rather, at least on the logistics side, 95% of your time will be spent in the most utterly uninspired, grindy gameplay to ever be included in a videogame.

For example, gathering resources, which is the baseline activity needed to create everything else in the game, consists of driving (very slowly) to an in game location, then holding down the mouse button to gather resources until your inventory is full, then driving back, rinse, repeat.

It is incredibly tedious, it does not offer any interesting challenge beyond a sheer test of patience, and it is so boring that virtually everyone who does this part of the game has to have something else - a YouTube video, or a podcast - going just to keep them going insane from boredom. When when of the core mechanics of your game is so boring that people can't even engage with it without distracting themselves with something else, you have a pretty serious game design issue.

For me personally, the grind is the most egregious issue in Foxhole; it permeates everything, and it is obviously a very intentional design choice by the devs, but I personally think it's a pretty bad design choice. Not only does it not respect the players' time, but it increasingly requires so much grind that many tools and mechanics are effectively out of reach for solo players. So the game has become dominated by clans, and while that's not necessarily the worst thing in the world, if you are a casual player like me that doesn't like taking orders in a videogame, you are going to find it difficult to experience everything this game has to offer.

There are two other major issues besides the glaring flaws of game design itself. The first is bugs. Although the game is reasonably stable, there are still many bugs left to iron out. And because the game is so time-demanding, and punishing, even an infrequent bug can make the game borderline unplayable. A common example is for a player to spend a lot of time grinding resources, turning them into supplies for the frontline, loading up a supply truck, only to encounter a bug when trying to cross a bridge, or move from one server to another, that causes them to lose said truck. Boom, hours of work just disappeared thanks to a bug. You just wasted precious moments of your life grinding without even getting to enjoy the fruits of your labor. When the game wastes your time so blatantly like that, it's hard to stay invested.

The final big issue is a lack of moderation. Although moderation is not totally absent in the game, there are no dedicated moderators. And the grindy nature of the game makes it ripe for griefing. If you're playing a match of COD, and a teammate kills you a few times, it's nbd, you can just kick them from the server and that's that. But if a griefer in Foxhole takes all your stuff and dumps it in the river, that's hours of work that you will never get back. This leaves an extremely sour taste in the mouths of players, and it's arguably the number one reason for recent dissatisfaction with the game.

Having said all that, you may be wondering, if the game is so bad, why did I put in 1,000+ hours? There are two answers to that. First, the game is so slow paced and grindy that even just giving it a chance means playing it much longer than other games. This is not a game that lends itself to casual 30-60 min play sessions. Logistics in particular demands pretty huge investments of time. So I have more hours on this game than on other games that I have enjoyed considerably on the whole - because those games don't waste my time and allow me to get what I want out of the game much more quickly.

But more fundamentally, there is a strong dichotomy in Foxhole that is the root of my love-hate relationship with it. There is no denying that the game is innovative. There are very few games it can be compared to, and I might go so far as to say Siege Camp (the devs) have almost created an entire new genre of game. Parts of that experience - delivering supplies to the right base at the critical moment to help the defenders hold of a wave of tanks, or coordinating a large armor assault across a whole region - offer a totally unique experience. And when everything is going right, it can be almost magical. Unfortunately, these magical moments are buried beneath an absolute mountain of grind and downright terrible design choices.

If the unique aspects of Foxhole so intrigue you that you must try it, and there's no other games that can sustain your interest right now, give it a shot. In some ways it is worth experiencing the very innovative ideas that the game is presenting. But be aware that in terms of execution, this is a pretty "bad" game. The mechanics are unpolished, and the visual design is adequate but uninspiring. The devs are not super competent, nor super professional, and they don't communicate well with the community. They refuse to add microtransactions to the game, and while many may see this as a plus, I believe that for an online game it makes it harder to sustain and improve the experience in the long run, since you don't have ongoing revenue to support the game. For all of these reason, I can't recommend the game in its current state to most gamers.

Killing the game.  Rumor is they got rid of or are getting rid of the Charlie shard.  What this means is that any possibility of learning the game, playing how you want, etc., are dead for new players.  A few super clans will dominate the Alpha shard and anyone refusing to play how they want will get regulated to collecting a few resources, or if they are lucky participating in some front line combat (at someone else's direction of course).

Pros - game is fun once you begin understanding how things work
Cons - big clans run the show, going to one server shard (which means even more lag), and the community is one of the most toxic you'll ever meet.  

Buy or not?  Well, depends on if you are willing to be someone else logi slave for hours so they can have a little fun, or if you're a good soldier, maybe you'll be lucky enough for a clan to hand you a semi auto rifle and a few grenades.  Too bad too, this game has so much potential.  Like every MMO, the producers are looked down on by the combat guys and just expected to toil away for hours so that a combat guy can lose a resource intensive piece within minutes sometimes.  

Not worth it IMO.

As it stands I would be hesitate to get this game. There are constant server issues which greatly impact gameplay and the developers of the game have not communicated or shown any efforts to fix or address said issue.

Huge immersive game that anyone can get into. Literally everything is made by a player. Wonderful experience.

Edit 1/19/2024:

I cannot further endorse this game. The issues Siege Camp either do not give a shit about or just cannot figure out how to fix are killing any hopes and dreams of wanting to play this game ever again. The main issue is their servers. When scheduled resets happen (every morning around 9AM CST) it pauses action and is SUPPOSED to freeze all players in place and then restore your position with all of your gear, vehicles, etc. just as it had been left then begin again after a timer to allow all players to return to the game. 

However, this does not happen. One side or the other will get "connection errors" and not be allowed back into the region's server essentially allowing the other faction to push, destroy defenses, wrench and steal vehicles, etc. UNCONTESTED. In the middle of a huge push where you're about to take ground and a reset happens? Welp you better hope you dont get the connection error or guess what? All your progress is gone.

With this, I will be changing my review from positive to NOT recommended. I suggest either getting this game on sale or catching a free weekend or some shit because spending money on this will let you have only so much fun until their terrible servers eventually screw you and your entire team.

The state of this game from where it came from is just atrocious....so many dumb bugs, exploits, and just lack of care from the developers. I know that last one is going to not make people happy but its the truth. The developers have no sense of what balance is or how it works. Instead of gradually increasing or decreasing the percentage of something I feel they say "Hold my maple leaf and watch this!" and slap a 15-25% change in it making it absolutely busted in either direction. The infantry combat is so stale and so terrible that its actually more enraging to do than logistics! Get shadowdanced (for newer players looking into the game the individual basically spams WASD and somehow gets 100% accurate rifle fire while doing it also making it near impossible to hit them back.....makes no sense but whatever) wait 40 seconds (seriously who ever came up with this idea obviously doesn't play the game at all) to spawn and then immediately die to artillery and get the spawn time increased to 1 minute! That's basically punishing you for basically playing the DANG game! Also talking about being punished to play the game wait until the servers go down and you potentially lose equipment and momentum and not to mention if the servers don't crash the region becomes so laggy that doing anything meaningful is pointless. The community is a weird one in regards to either being super toxic or kinda cool...there never seems to be an in-between. There is so much that I can rant about but the biggest one and a call out is to the devs....Siegecamp....QUIT.....slapping.....dumb.....balance......increments......and change your servers! Your game needs a basically Operation Health (don't follow exactly in Ubisofts steps) before you do anything else with it! If something gets done ill be more than happy to change this review but until then it stays as is.

I was between a positive and a negative review on this game but ultimately decided on a positive review. There are some positives and some negatives to this game. A positive is from what I have seen the community is very helpful in teaching new players how to play and most everyone on this game is pretty chill. The negative however is that if you play solo you can get very bored very fast. This game is really built on community and proximity communication. There's nothing wrong with that and the game itself is pretty unique with unique features that is a big positive. The issue I have with it though is that the aiming system is frankly just frustrating and makes the game not very fun to play if you play by yourself or get separated from your squad/regiment. I personally would really just like to see the aim steady much quicker than it currently does and just give players like one more hits worth of health. Randomized aim is frankly just pretty tilting and takes a lot of fun out of the game. If you're just looking to chill with your friends or find a good regiment there's still fun to be had, the game would just be much more fun with more of a skill aspect than relying on rng. I also think the negative reviews I've seen make a lot of sense. If you're a solo player and don't try to actively get involved with other people and tasks/strategies you will not have fun on this game. This is a game you are definitely going to want to communicate with other players in some way and probably will have more fun with if you look to join and communicate with a regiment on discord.

All in all it's a decent game for the comms and unique features/wars but you might have a hard time wanting to stay on it all day due to the low skill rng fights. Especially if you are playing by yourself and either don't have friends playing or don't look to make friends on the game.

It's a semi-positive review because I have a lot of complaints.


Logistics gameplay feels like a second job, even more so ever since facilities were added. Gathering basic resources (collecting scraps from scrap fields) is a point-and-click adventure. Takes too much time and work to build enough materials to fuel a frontline. No wonder half the bases are devoid of resources. Oh, wait, regiments hoarding resources is a second reason. Speaking of which:

Much of the content is only attainable by the monopolizing regiments who usually may not share their toys with outsiders. Why? They fear it'll be wasted by the "simple minded randoms". They hoard anything from mass-produced tanks down to simple Basic Materials. Therefore, the rest of the world is reliant on their local regiment feeling particularly charitable.

Big moderation issues regarding false report spams and alt accounts. Be careful who you cross, or you might get banned for doing nothing wrong. Don't expect the devs to help you about it.

Personally, I can acknowledge this is a really cool game. The premise is unique, the scale of what is happening is staggering, and the degree of coordination is impressive. 

That being said, at no point during this game was I engaged with the game mechanically. Playing it never felt fun. I sat under artillery for a hour straight, firing thousands of rounds at wave after wave of infantry. It was cool knowing every shell and round flying through the air was made by people and I found the [i]situation[/i] to be interesting and memorable. However, I did not find the gameplay of fighting fun, I was never immersed. I have some minor complaints about some design choices, for example the tanks feel more like RC cars than a Tank. Though those are minor.

Overall, this is a good game but if you are expecting to really get engaged and immersed in the fighting, it may fall short. Hell let loose and planetside were my gateway drugs to this game and if youre coming from a similar background, be a bit more cautious than I was.

Long, Massive, persistent warfare where everything is player made. Every bullet, gun, uniform. I love the idea of the game. When I got a PC in 2018 I was interested in foxhole but a friend said "you got to watch out for early access games" so I slept on it for a while. after a bit, I would see reviews saying the Foxhole community is extremely toxic. since playing I have to say I have NOT had that experience. Most players were more than willing to explain things to me and teach me about the mechanics. Sure every once in a while you run into an asshole but no more than literally any other game. 

I would recommend if you're new going straight to the frontline and getting some blood on you're hands. I mainly wanted to do logi runs and resource gathering but It's a good idea to just fight in a contested area to get use to the feel of the game and see how fun the game can be.

Also very excited for Siege Camp's next game which is pretty much foxhole in a medieval setting.

I liked that there is no K/D ratio. You don't know how many kills you did or how many times you died unless you count manually. This forces players to play be more team oriented rather than showing off their individual skills.

Game has many issues but it is still possible to escape into it.

The main negative about this game is that many times you might find yourself in a situation when after playing for like 6 hours straight in an active combat, you will get a feeling of not achieving absolutely anything useful towards your faction eventual win.

For example, you might die to static AI defences or spammed tanks bunch of times, you might even kill a few dozen of enemy infantry in the trenches. But after 6 hours frontline won't move a bunch. Enemy Static defences are still there on the high-ground. Nothing changed. So you feel that you, yourself accomplished absolutely nothing.

You might think, OK, in this case I will go build a tank destroyer or some big mortar to counter enemies. But guess what? Even if spend tons of hours crafting this things, bring them to front and shoot a bunch of times, enemies will just instantly repair the damage, and you still accomplished nothing.

In a typical FPS match you at least have your K/D ratio.

So, if you are a solo player like me, you myself, you must be aware of this side of the game.

Edit: However, even as a solo player it is possible for you to create entire industrial complex Factorio-style and manufacture trains and heavy tanks for others to use. The manufacturing system is kind of non-trivial, so if it's your cup of tea, then go ahead, fellow solo wolfs!

Foxhole is an incredibly unique game and if you are interested in playing as a soldier in a large virtual war there is basically no other game like it. I think anyone that's interested in this type of game should at least try foxhole. However the devs definitely design the game with the rule of cool. A lot of things are implemented because of how cool they sound, but often without too much thought into how they affect game play. This leads to lots of imbalances in all sorts of areas. It has also caused the game to become grindier over time. You don't necessarily need to grind yourself, but someone on your team has to do all the annoying grindy bits and if not enough people are willing to do it then its very hard to win. This grind is usually what burns people out on the game.

I've enjoyed foxhole off and on for 5 years as casual frontline infantry.  I cannot speak on backline factory logi play.  I coordinate with others nearby me, there are occasions I get invited to crew for armor, arty. or naval.  I do not play the backline or logi, I dont vibe with that bunch very well.  There is a lot of frustration in their ranks and they tend to take it out on each other.  

They occasionally throw shade at frontline players for not trying hard enough to "win the war" also but they are easily ignored.  There's 2 types in foxhole- casuals and tryhards.   I prefer the company of casuals is why I've been able to enjoy foxhole over 5 years.  The tryhards seem to be angry with each other much.  The frontline is mostly cooperation when someone rallies troops to a common goal.  There is a lot of humor on frontline comms.


Tho frontline can be played casual and doesnt always require a clan, things are better in clans this is a clan based game, but for frontline infantry clans are not a must if you enjoy moment to moment combat, open mic comedic larping, foxhole is a very satisfying war sim.  

There are annoying players and know it alls but over all infantry is open mic at a comedy club that I come back for and hear the multi national accents of other infantry nearby.  I'm very satisfied with the current population which in the past I was disappointed by low population but its been fine as of late.  

This isnt a shooter where you come in with FPS skills to play as lonewolf slayer tho that is possible with a lot of experience but it takes time to develop instincts and understand range and aiming system.  Its not an easy aiming system compared to FPS but if you are burnt out on FPS you might enjoy foxhole's combat.

If your a lil doomer baby who cries that every online game is toxic (which is somewhat true) or you refuse to network with other players and demand everything be developed for solo you wont like foxhole.

If you are a vet at war games and you dont let some occasional player static make you sad then you might like foxhole.

Not worth the otherwise IMMENSE time needed to overcome the massive learning curve; if you don't have a job, don't have work to do IRL, don't have a car, don't have a need to make money, or any of the above, then you can actually learn. For everyone else, though, it's virtually impossible to overcome it without ridiculously massive investment for what - losing a stupid war? 

Don't forget - the community's not too fun, either. Teamkilling and trolls are common, and stealing vehicles is pretty common too. Want to get a tank to the front? Good luck! It's gonna be stolen if you leave it unlocked thinking others will 'help', it will disappear if you log off for a moment and leave it thinking it'll be fine, and then it'll just get turned to dust by the enemy anyways since they always seem to be better off. Good luck.

Oh, and here is another thing. So - the war is usually fought with second rate or third rate units and tanks. Not top tier artillery or tanks or vehicles, not top tier machinery or anything - those are stored up in caches and hoards on either team, held in by people who grind hours and hours... just to look at the thing. They spend hours and hours just to be able to say 'I made it' without actually realizing the whole point of the game - to use it. It's sad. 

I'm not gonna lie - mechanics wise, gameplay wise (occassionally) and resource management wise - it's honestly impressive. But it's like using a Rolls Royce to haul cow shit. The community is downright awful, they don't care for their team, and these so-called Regiments and Clans - well, they see their fellow Wardens as the same as an enemy Colonial, and vice versa. You want this game? Fine. But be warned, your nice game is gonna be rolled in the cow shit like no tomorrow. It's not worth the heartbreak. This game is the League of Legends of strategy and military gameplay.

click lock is a windows feature that you can use to help gather scrap without giving yourself an RSI. scrapping shouldn't be this bad: it feels like a placeholder system implemented years ago, and the devs have sunk into such a pit of mediocrity that while it was once slated be replaced with gameplay, they've since just said "fuck it" and consider the system done now.
