i've updated this review to confirm that the game is getting worse instead of better. it's been a couple of years and they've made a couple of updates, so i popped back into a war because i hate myself. they've convoluted systems that were already atrocious, i've experienced more gamebreaking bugs and crashes this year than the last time i played, server stability is remarkably worse, and the game balance is, to my fury, also worse.

back when i used to be among the screeching choir of players begging for game balance, the devs said "we can't make reasonable decisions because we're still _gathering data_." ladies and gentlemen, it is with disgust that i inform you that the devs are still _gathering data_. it's been years and all they've accomplished is muddying the waters with more stupid items and vehicles that no one asked for. they've hammered idiotic bandaid fix on top of bandaid fix for literal years now: it shouldn't be a surprise that their product is actual trash.

So don't get me wrong this game is super confusing and a little overwhelming at first. You don't really know what to do or where to go but once you in like 30-40 min and you start to get it, it's insane. Literally do whatever you want. If you're a fast paced action player.. spawn to a forward base and just shoot bad guys. BUT it's so much more than that nearly every aspect of a war is simulated in this game. ITS CRAZY! You can harvest materials on the backline and craft gear, vehicles, meds, ammo, etc. Or you can go to a dock make a ship and cruise around with 20+ people with a person manning every important part of the ship and unleash hell on other boats or the shoreline warfront. One of the craziest things I witnessed personally is when my side, the Wardens, spent weeks researching and building this games version of a tactical nuke and took an entire city off the map.. Which was 100% player built by the way, It's insane.

This game has a good mix of stuff to do for every player type. If you want front line combat, base building, or running a factory to produce war materials. All of this kept me busy for 1,200 of game play. 

However, you will find the base building to be unsatisfactory. Because you can build the best, and most indestructible base possible, and nobody will help you supply it. Worst of all, the infantry only care about "pushing". Noobs are constantly crossing bridges and taking territory they have no hope of holding. They can't be content to hold out, slaughtering enemies outside your fortified gates, and stock up. Nope, they gotta load up with gear, run past all your defenses, then die like idiots in wide open ground. Repeat that, until your base is drained of supplies. So, ultimately, the 20-30hrs it took you to build that base was totally pointless.

The facilities are also disappointing because of maintenance cost. When you first plop down a factory, you might be the only one in the area, so it's cheap to run. But, as soon as you get 2 or 3 neighbors, the cost to run the factory goes up by a factor of 3-4x. As a solo player, that cost will crush you. Because you'll spend a good 2-3hrs of your day just on maintaining the factory. It's fun for two days, but then it feels like a job. Even in a regiment, the workload is not easier. Now, instead of running logistics to support yourself, you're supporting X players in the regiment who don't want to supply anything.

Being a front line soldier is fun, for a while. But unless you are in a regiment, you rarely get to play with cool toys. Mostly, that's because this stuff has to be made by players, which takes factories, and bases to defend the factories (see above). Without access to cool stuff, you just take your chances with whatever someone has already stocked at your spawn point. You'll run to the front, die, and repeat. Maybe your push will be successful this time. But, the next time you log in, all those gains are gone, because nobody built a base to defend what you took.

My last game, Liberation Point was completely neutral and undefended for more than a real day. All defense has decayed away. Nobody bothered to take the point, rebuild the town base. Could've been done by a single guy in a jeep, with some bmats for the construction vehicle that was right outside the building. Instead, they spent all day fighting over the wooden bridge into Abandoned Ward.

Even though this is a negative review, I still recommend the game. You also will probably spend 1,000 hours figuring out why you're never going to play again.

A friend of mine said it best:
There is nothing like this game. It's like a ww1-2 mmo where everything is up to you. 
You can do almost anything you want to do, and never have to do what you don't. 
Do you want to build? Never fight, rarely if -ever- see an enemy combatant? You can do that. 
Do you want to farm supplies, fill up a truck full of life saving ammo, shirts(respawns) or building materials. Bring that truck to the front and save a Forward base from being over run? You can do that. 
Want to drive a tank in a tank line with five or more other tanks, pushing into an enemy tank line? You can do that. 
Have a bunch of buddies who play? Want to do navy stuff? Build a Battle ship, and you and upwards of twenty other players sail that MF into an enemy harbor and absolutely level a city? You can do that. 

This game is what you make it, and I honestly believe it's going to erupt. 
I've personally gotten 8 of my friends into this game, and only one has said it wasn't for them. 
When writing this I haven't even had the game a month, and it's the best $30 I've spent on a game in recent memory. 

Does it have it's own issues? Yes, every game does. But I have yet to run into anything game breaking, or immersion ruining. 

This game is 100% worth it. 
Buy it.

This is one of my favorite games ever and I had to quit because the in game chats were so mentally taxing.

Update: Somebody in the games Discord recommended I switch the the Colonial faction so I have it a try.  Making this change, paired with not keeping general chat active, and occasionally turning mic chat off when I'm not in a good mood. On top of this, I play on the Charlie shard (which is primarily intended for new players) and this is possibly the choice that has made the most difference above all. These changes have made this game comfortable again, and for anyone with a similar temperament, I recommend doing some of the things I mentioned.

I can't blame the developers for player behavior, and if you're still reading this review, consider this a recommendation in limbo. The game that the developers have made and intend to provide is great, all obnoxious interactions aside.

The idea of being a simple soldier and nothing more may seem bad at first, but then, when you start playing, you find that this concept really chills out the game. It's harder to sweat in this game, not only because it offers an alternative casual style gameplay, but because dying is just normal in this game. It's not punished, not even by other players, it's just seen as an aspect of the game. It's this view on dying that also makes the community very friendly and helpful. They view new players not as a burden on their team, but an individual to shape and mold into the perfect killing machine. The game also provides plenty of replayability as every time you fall asleep, you will find that your team has lost significant ground and now you're fighting in a cold tundra where the chances you'll get shot is less than the chances you'll freeze to death.

I've been a solo through most of my play time and its now next to impossible to do anything without a large regiment. this problem has slowly been getting worse with each successive war and updates. the latest update (the naval warefare update) proves this really well. if you want to join naval ops you'd better be in a huge regiment because it would take a group of 10 people to even support the base needed to produce materials for the ships, much less build them. this update was aim solely at large regiments, and only reinforced the need for large regiments. the days of being a solo are all but gone. I've put almost 1200 hours into the game and it just depresses me when i load it up because i know no matter how good of a soldier, engineer, etc i am. i will never make a difference on the battlefield because getting even small tanks is a struggle, much less anything that will actually impact the state of the front. unless the regiments want to take land, its almost always a stalemate that goes nowhere. dont get me wrong, i love this game to death and have enjoyed many years of play, but the way the devs are taking the game really punishes solos or small groups of friends.

A very thorough game surrounding teamwork at its core! This is an incredible game that brings together WW2-style themes and places it front-and-center as the MAIN focus: drive the enemy back and control their territory! This is accomplished through deep teamwork, synergy, and cohesion from logistics teams gathering raw materials, processing, and making weapons, ammo, fuel, and everything that ultimately 'fuels' the front line! I'm excited to see just how deep the teamwork goes! 

This game has a bit of EVERYTHING and ALL is equally important to the progress of your faction.  For all those people that like RTS-style games (ie: Company of Heroes), this game adds WAY more depth and complexity to every part of the game! From every gun to every round that's fired, every vehicle driven and the fuel that makes it GO, every tank, even the RESPAWN's of players to a base is supplied and fueled by other players. There isn't anything I've seen yet that isn't player made, supplied, and maintained. It is the WAR EFFORT from each player that fuels each battle and that truly helps maintain pressure on your opponent. Every person has purpose and helps make this game happen! It is TRULY a great accomplishment for the devs, their vision, and what makes this game tick! Yes, there is a learning curve. Yes, there's more to do than you have time for. However, your entire faction is counting on you to play your part! Learn to play your role. Grow to be great at it and teach it to others! HOLD THE LINE! There is a great community out there that wants to see you succeed. Spend some time in training and learn how ALL THE PIECES FIT TOGETHER. Watch a few videos. Then GET OUT THERE and help your team! :D

I have always enjoyed playing supportive roles like MEDIC, ENGINEER, etc. This is a game that RELIES on those roles in an amazing way and truly makes a difference! 

Get this game, if you haven't already, and BE... ALL THAT YOU CAN BE!

Foxhole is a top-down MMO shooter set in a persistent world war 1-2 era fictional universe. The Wardens (blue men) fight the Colonials (green men) over a map spanning the country of Caoiva (the Warden homeland). The game has a lot to offer, player logistics, frontline death, artillery, tank gameplay, trains. There's a lot of fun to be had and overall the game's improving slowly. There are still issues like the general community paranoia over alting and other foul play, the devs are slow to address issues and thanks to the length of some wars (longest war so far was 42 days) along with the dev's quarterly update cycle means you can be forced to deal with one state of the game for a while. The tutorial is bad, ask in world chat for help if you need it, if you want to do logi just find a logi buddy. Facility gameplay will take all of your free time, don't do it alone. I love this game and the devs do sometimes listen but they still have a long way to go, also if they stopped adding tank variants every single update they might actually have time to work on the important things.

Review Jan. 2024

I can finally positively recommend Foxhole. While it still has some bugs, it seems like the developers are finally taking on more player feedback and actually making positive steps. Facilities still suck, and there needs to be an alternative to them rather than hoping another regiment in game will help you. But at least they're not absolute cancer to build and maintain anymore so long as you don't make your facility too massive.

Cheaters and alts still exist, but they don't seem to be quite as bad as they used to be even during the Naval Warfare update war of late 2023. If the reporting function doesn't work quick enough, if at all, at least the community seems to step up more to make those people's game experience go downhill. That's just how it has to be it seems. Chinese and Russian players by and large will still spend more time harassing their own team than fighting the enemy though. Exceptions exist, but still more progress needs to be made there.

Big ups to the devs for finally banning certain toxic streamers who were contributing nothing positive to the game or community by bullying other players and even encouraging cheating. Thank you!

For new players, please please PLEASE ask other players in game for help if you don't know what you're doing, especially when doing backline logistics, facilities, or trying to prepare a tank. People will help you, and happily! You just need to be willing to listen.


Old review c. May 2023
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

Despite the changes and attempts to fix the game with update 52, the game is still broken and spirit crushing to play. Alts and griefers will just find new ways to ruin the game and logistics is still a week long grind just to get anything above basic stuff. All the fun stuff is locked behind the 1.0 facilities still, which requires about 10 dedicated players to keep running, and finding any clans with a public or shared facility is a nightmare sometimes. Chinese and Russian players especially seem to spend more time killing their own team than the enemy.

The efforts by the developers have been too little too late, and it seems the game is dying. They seem to have moved on to working on Anvil Empires, which I expect to be plagued with many of the same problems as Foxhole. I've lost hope that this game can be fixed without going back to pre-1.0 and removing facilities, and I'll be avoiding anything made by Siege Camp at this point.

Old review c. Feb. 2023:
d0g sh1t game

In all seriousness, since the 1.0 Inferno release this game has become a second full-time job just to maintain your facilities and bases, depriving many players from being able to enjoy other aspects of the game. Sooner or later, you WILL get burned out from playing this. The main developers in Siege Camp have themselves admitted that they don't/barely play their own game because "It takes too much time."

Speaking of the developers, they do not listen to the community at all. Rather than fixing what already exists, they just keep pumping out new content in hopes of bringing in new players temporarily instead of assisting the existing player base. Very little is done about cheating/alting in game, with the common punishment for such things being no more than a 3 day ban, despite one act of cheating/alting could undo WEEKS of time and efforts from 20+ people. It's been getting so bad that since war 100, it's safer to shoot low rank teammates with Russian or Chinese script names and apologise later rather than wait until they do anything.

Because of the above, the game community has become incredibly toxic and territorial, as opposed to the more cooperative atmosphere of pre-1.0. It also doesn't help that a number of higher-profile Twitch streamers for the game not only encourage such toxicity, they engage in it themselves unashamedly. 

Faction balance is otherwise fine in my opinion. It is the game mechanics and development team that needs a huge shakeup. Until something major happens, the only thing saving this game for me is the amazing bunch of people I play it with. I wear my regiment tag with pride.

Siege Camp, if you ever read this. Stop adding crap until the game is fixed. Either fix the game yourselves, or bring in people who can.

This game is stressful, with no guarantee of either a short-term or long-term payoff.

From my personal experience, the praises about this game are true: there are complex mechanics, requiring players to consider supplies to wage war as well as the limitations (and any gameplay-enabled advantages) on waging war.  For example, just about any type of supply has to be manufactured, and that would mean harvesting raw resources to be eventually converted into supplies. For another example, there are border bases that can be claimed at the edges of enemy territories, if only to surmount the problem of getting supplies into those territories and forming a beachhead in the first place.

Unfortunately, a steep learning curve mixed with lousy quality of life designs means that the inexperience of players, players' lack of ability to learn, players' short attention spans and language barriers, can adversely affect any chance of deriving any satisfaction from this game.

For an example of inexperience players inconveniencing everyone else, an unwitting player can build a structure in a location that should be clear, such as the front of a resource mine. (The area in front of a resource mine has context-sensitive coding that allows players to place resource containers for easy retrieval of resources.)

For an example of players' lack of ability to learn, there are players who repeatedly send supplies to the frontmost and newest forward base - which also happens to be the most vulnerable to being overrun - regardless of how many supplies that it already has.

For an example of players' short attention spans, there are players who just leave vehicles around, as soon as something else catches their attention and they leave to redeploy elsewhere. ("Redeployment" in this game is a simple matter of despawning the player character and respawning it elsewhere.) These vehicles inconvenience other drivers at least, and at worst, they can be stolen by enemies that have sneaked past the frontlines.

For an example of language barriers, there are many people from different countries who are players on the same side; do not expect them to understand each other when they should for the sake of tactical coordination. This could be surmounted with skill built from experience, but until then, the barrier is an obstacle to instruct and teach each other.

Having said all that, there is now the matter of long-term gameplay in this game; the default game mode is "Conquest", a war that spans across multiple territories. Strategic decisions are necessary for either side to make any gains; these decisions won't come if players play alone and/or are incapable of strategic thinking.

For example, it can be very frustrating to watch another team fail to follow up on their otherwise successful thrust, e.g. failing to build a new base on top of an enemy base that has been cleared, even after its surrounding area has been secured.

If you have read up to here, chances are, you have read other reviews too. Some of these might mention the "toxicity" of the community of players in this game. This is unfortunately quite true, and it stems from all of the above.

Expect Western players to have a poor opinion of Eastern ones, and vice versa. Expect players to bring nationality bias into the game, and steal from other players of the same side to give to other players of the same side who happen to be of the same nationality. Expect experienced but bitterly burned-out players to treat new players poorly (e.g. suspecting them of being "alts", i.e. double agents currently playing with different accounts to sabotage the side that they are currently on).

In summary, if you are looking for a game that you can play with other people or against other people, this isn't it - unless you are somehow addicted to stress.

[h1] Imagine Running with Rifles, but as a cooperative MMO. [/h1]
No money, just a common pool of resources, and a big scary bad guy. The game has two major factions: The Wardens, and the Colonials. Each faction has it's own tech tree that is unlocked slowly as the war progresses, with different battle tactics that their commanders can call upon. This makes the game feel very immersive, since you really feel like the enemy is another country entirely. Foxhole takes place in a "World War" style universe, primarily influenced by the second world war.

[h2] Every player is just another soldier[/h2]
There's many ways to contribute to the war effort. You could grab a rifle and go shoot bad guys, or get in a tank with some friends, and shoot bad guys with a bigger gun. But the main pull of Foxhole is it's comprehensive logistics system. Every time you spawn, you use 1 Soldier Supply, and you'll probably grab a rifle, 2 magazines, and maybe bandages or grenades. All of those things need to be made and shipped to the front by other players, and that's just the absolute basics. Players also need to ship building supplies, maintenance supplies, artillery shells, even tanks and other armored vehicles. One of the most overlooked roles, however, is the role of the engineer. These guys are the guys digging trenches (PLEASE do not ONLY dig trenches at first, trenches by themselves are only any good in very specific situations), building bunkers, and even giant fortresses. Just grab some bmats, a hammer, a shovel, and ask where you're needed. 9 times out of 10, you'll find someone engineering.

TLDR: If you want to feel like a cog in a machine, this is THE GAME for you.

It's... it's like an RTS but mass multiplayer. It's both high stress and low stress, theres room to solo or room to squad up. This game has a space for many different kinds of players and it's a wonderful wonderful game. Truly something special!

We're a team.

As much as I'm enjoying it, the developer really needs to work on quality of life for this game in basically every aspect.

The issues below are not ordered in order of importance, but they together drag the game down.

Despite the flaws below, there's no game that is quite like this. I just wish the devs would really focus on QOL so I can say the game is great and unique rather than good and unique.

Also, not sure if the devs should be making Anvil, the game like Foxhole but medieval.

[h1]Issue #1 - alting[/h1]
Alting is leaking information or griefing using an account on the other team.

Basically everyone and their cat has now been accused of alrting (myself included - on Reddit!) and while I think some of it may be overblown on both sides right now, it is happening. I don't know what kind of consequences the alting accounts face, but there are some things I feel that some things could've been prevented in a different way. Usually they drive vehicles into water.

For instance, there was an incident where a base got destroyed much more easily because someone added another piece to a bunker, creating a glaring weakness in the defences. This could've been fixed if there was a claim system in the game where alliances or regiments can lay claim to a certain area (and then have the community minus the claimants vote yes/no) after which that alliance is the holder of that area and no one else can build in it unless structures nearby are getting actively destroyed.

I've also found tanks parked in suspicious places.

[b]War 102 update[/b]
During the defence of The Baths, Drowned Vale, I had eyes on 6 griefers/alters + several other being reported in other areas.

[h1]Issue #2 - UI readability and mechanics[/h1]

The UI in this game needs so much work, a lot of this affects new players in particular.

Map - close to the edges of each hex on the map there's two different zones where placing buildings is increasingly costly and makes them decay. It would've been nice if the default map showed this. This can be fixed with a mod. New players also need to take time to recognise mountains on the map. [strike]You also can't see certain important player-made structures such as vehicle assembly stations or field modification stations.[/strike] This is now fixed.

Colours - it would be nice if you could make all enemies on the map appear as red regardless of side. I'm not colour blind, but when you're zoomed out it can be actually a bit tricky to discern blue mixed with other colours from green mixed with other colours. This can also be fixed with a mod, but should really be a game option.

Information - it would be nice if the menus specified limitations. For instance, you can build construction vehicles and cranes using hammers (amongst a host of other things). What the UI doesn't mention is that this has to be done near certain kind of bases or landing ships.
It would be nice if tanks showed in their inventory what kind of ammo it takes (you can see it by getting into the gunner seat).

Inventories - it is difficult to read bunker inventories on the map because things are not colour coded and do not have text. Answering questions like "does this bunker have bandages?" takes more than a couple of seconds because everything is monocolour. There are mods that help this issue.

Gear confusion - unless you run around these things all the time, knowing which upgrade a vehicle assembly station has is difficult. There's five different kinds of assembly materials in the game, all with almost the same icon except for the type determining bit in the upper left corner of each. These could've been more easily distinguished if the UI had some colour or texture difference. Other names would've nice too such as "oiled assembly materials" or "hardened assembly materials".
It would be nice if the ammo type was listed on the icon of weapons - this isn't a problem with your side's gear, but what about looting enemy gear mid combat?

[h1]Issue #3 - bugs, glitches, and other annoying things[/h1]

There's a character recovery mechanic in the game (for when you crash/get disconnected), but you flip a coin about whether or not it works every single time. It feels terrible when you spend a long time getting somewhere only to disconnect and not recover when crossing a hex border.

Sometimes vehicles you grab from your private stockpile stop being possible to put back into said stockpile for no apparent reason.

There are places where you can walk straight through a mountain.

Climbing is a mess because it relies on the geometry rather than developer-defined areas where you can vault. This makes it incredibly inconsistent where you can sometimes get up rocks, sometimes not and the remnants of destroyed bunkers are sometimes impossible to climb out of despite being literally 40 cm high.

I've dismounted an AT gun and that has launched it forward (into enemy AT).

Just being near a moving tank will often kill you even if you'd be realistically bumped by it rather than crushed. Other times, vehicles (in particular half-tracks) can dance on top of infantry not killing them.

You can't cancel using a wrench.

You can't claim border bases unless you have no claimed areas in the hex. This leads to both sides purposefully not capturing areas to prevent border bases being available.

Friendly fire mechanics are not great. Say you steal an enemy vehicle and you try to get away, during the escape someone gets a sticky on you and you're now moving at 0.1 m/s through enemy territory, unable to go up hills. You can no longer reliably destroy that vehicle even if you had the means to do so because if you do too much damage to it, you might get flagged for team damage and get locked out from using weapons for 20 minutes.

As a partisan, the damage you do indirectly by dropping (recently stolen) enemy vehicles in front of enemy garrisons or into water is not counted nor are the resources you destroy counted. This makes gaining commends to give others as a partisan difficult.

[strike]You can't see who the last person (if friendly) to touch a vehicle was.[/strike] As of war 102, you can now see who touched it, but not which side that person is on. You can still effectively check that by trying to squad lock the vehicle (which will not work if an enemy took it) 

Sometimes squad locks on vehicles expire even while you're in the vehicle, meaning that when you get out you may have a situation where you both can't get in, nor use a wrench to unlock the vehicle, but the enemy can. [strike]Additionally, even if you're in the squad that has access to a given vehicle through a squad lock, it must be your currently active squad for the vehicle to be accessible.[/strike] This is fixed, but you can sometimes end up locked out by making a vehicle public while locked even if it is your lock.

I've been booted out of the game several times and completely unable to return to my position. Usually that should be possible. This is often an issue when Valve does maintenance on their servers.

Honestly, just give us a health bar in vehicles already with the thresholds for being damaged etc. marked. Some tanks can be repaired from inside and as long as the repairing person has materials, they can tell the rest of the crew the damage state, run out and I don't think you can anymore.

Also, why can 12.7 mm damage some buildings, but not 20 mm shots (that can actually destroy tanks)?

This game desperately needs an in-game view of resources and their sources as well as vehicles and how to make them.

[h1]You seem to be enjoying this game though[/h1]

Yes. Which is why I really, really want these things fixed. I'll be happy if I don't see a single piece of new content for a very long time if they just polish up the game and fix the above issues.

---- Initial Review ----
Save your $30 dollars. Although I enjoyed it for what playtime I have logged, I cannot in good conscience, recommend another person to pay for this game. Game turns into wartime logistics simulator where if you expected moving from trenches to trenches fighting infantryman, you'll quickly find yourself in a frontline where you have no supplies and you also don't have hope of seeing your supplies re-stocked because it's all done by players.

Tutorial is dilapidated and does not sufficiently teach you even if you played tutorial. Poor design disguised as "we want to have players discover" philosophy.

Clans from each faction rule over all the other players who just want to have fun.
Don't buy this game if you're a real American.

It's a confusing game, you don't know if you hit someone. 
Okay, let's roll with it. It's hardcore, I get it. But it's too confusing, like for example - 

- You have levels, but the game doesn't even teach you how you progress them. So I wasn't able to figure it out at all.
- Shooting is wonky, as you get a line of sight, but even when you're prone, it's hard to aim and get shots where you want, as a line of sight becomes red in every possible way. (I did basic training, where it explained how to shoot, move, etc. but it's still hard and needs a lot of practice I guess)
- Squads didn't even work for me, as I joined the most populated war area at that time, there were only two squads open with 4 people and nobody even spoke there or gave any commands. As all other squads were locked I could not join them at all. So I was roaming confused as to what to do. Was running in covers and to sounds of action, where I didn't even understand what to do or where to shoot, or run. You have only a compass on you, without any indicators of where to run or what to do. The big map was also confusing af.

I did watch a basic tutorial on this game which was on the main menu of the game. It helped a bit before I started to play. This game needs a lot of practice and has a learning curve, it is hard for newcomers. And I just didn't feel like digging all the tutorials for this game, to just learn and understand what to do there. Maybe for someone this game is exactly what he looked on to. But that's not me.

In my, own individual, opinion, this game is overpriced even for sale, where you can find more interesting multiplayer games for less than 17 euros, what I paid for.

The game sucks. Even more, the game is not like on YouTube. Even worse, this game is no Planetside. It is far, far from it.

I've done everything from fighting to construction and logistics. It is not fun.

Firstly, the controls suck. They made looking on the 2d plane occluded by 3d objects, making it a pain to target an enemy on the other side of a tree or rock and requiring crazy mouse movements to do so. You also don't see into buildings in the only plane that matters to you, which is the one on your elevation, unless you are a foot's way from a wall. Even then, you might just have to enter the building to actually see inside of it, but good luck with that. You're probably going to end up dead by enemy gunfire from people that can see and shoot you, but you can't see and shoot them.

You want to autorun?
Use an external program.
Build anything?
Use autoclicker lest you wring out your mouse.

UI Response to the events also sucks. If you get damaged, there is no indicator that you have been damaged unless you take a very close look at your character in a lit area, and even then it's hard to tell. Status effects don't tell you what to do, so have fun figuring that out on your own. You could try to ask in chat or vc, but you may or may not get an answer unless you find someone nice.

There ain't a good way to do logistics, much less even move around. Players are limited to existing in hexes instead of a better seamless transition between space because the game is not designed to properly handle players transitioning between areas in such a way, even going out of the way to prevent to many players of one side existing on the same hex.

On that point, everything is already priced in by already existing guilds. You're definitely not going to set up a factory somewhere since you won't get any space, and you're definitely not going to gather any meaningful resources to affect the war. God forbid someone claims an unused clan technical lest the grudge reports be loosed and you get suspended for a while. If you're not banned from the game from your teammates, you'll probably make a small base that's well defended by AIs. The only issue lies within a large enemy clan simply waltzing in with 80+ mammons (high explosive grenades) and twenty guys to trip up the AI and blow up your base immediately. It doesn't matter how many guns you have if they are unable to fire as the AI cycles through targets to kill, but ends up hurting none.

On that point, constructions. This also sucks. Because the terrain changes when trenches and bunkers are built, the system isn't tolerant enough and you have to 'blueprint' the entire base to make sure it can fit. The algorithm behind it is too rigid to be used without quite a lot of finagling. Additionally, you cannot delete or modify the tops of bunkers once built. You have to destroy them with mammons, and that'll end up with your weapons being locked. Any time you cycle through build tools, you'll also be kicked out of the build menu.

This also reminds me of the inability to choose what goes in your primary or secondary slot. Shovels and hammers take up the same slot, the primary one, as well as any form of weapon. If you want to dig a trench, you'll have to make do with a crappy sidearm. Any good weapon, such as submachine guns or rifles, will always take up the first slot. And you have to keep in mind, the one who shoots first wins in these engagements. You simply cannot compete a rifle with a sidearm.

This reminds me of another gripe, the lack of an explanation on anything. You'll get a tutorial on how to move and shoot, and that's it. Go talk to others to learn anything else. That'd be a good idea, if the other players even knew the ins and outs of the game. As I've heard from other players, most of the data known about the game, such as construction, is data-mined because zero information is provided about the stats of buildings. You'd think having a low structural integrity would make a bunker easier to destroy, but it fact it only makes the bunker only a little harder to destroy with each piece you talk on. This kind of game design is counter-intuitive and needs to be explained by the developers, not data-mined by the players.

The game is not even optimized, causing many lost frames and freezes when using binoculars and when environmental effects like rain come into play. Keep in mind, I'm on a Nvidia 1660 Ti GTX and this should not be happening. I develop on UE5 with this machine doing crazy things and I rarely lose frames in this manner. This of course, is only a small point and I digress.

Steam would not refund me for playing this game for 30 hours, which is barely any time spent in this game. If you do not fall in love with this game immediately, do not spend a single moment of your time more, lest you waste 30 dollars and 30 hours like I have.

Overall, the game is a great, unique experience. It strikes a harmonious chord between overly realistic simulation and action-oriented combat. There is really something for everybody in Foxhole, as everything that is used to fight has to be made by the players, and the roles you take are really up to your imagination.

There are flaws with the game, but the developers do spend a lot of time seeking resolutions to these problems. However, there are two issues which just seem to be amounting and would have to take some drastic changes in course to resolve.

The first is the widening seesaw of balance the game sees as larger, more exciting content gets added to the game. This results in victory streaks that last up to a half of a year (yes you heard me right). One of the largest regiments even had to swap sides to throw it off with intentions to prevent nerfs. While victory streaks have existed in Foxhole for a long time, the duration of the wars has only increased consistently as the map expands with newer content.

The second is the direction that content is heading; the recent major Naval Warfare update mainly featured large ships that only the largest of regiments could make and field, leaving a very disappointing update for the vast bulk of the player base. Going from just gunboats for years to reworked gunboats alongside destroyers, submarines, and battleships is sort of like if only tankettes/scout tanks existed for years in the game and then suddenly battletanks and supertanks were added, without ever seeing any medium or heavy tanks added, except to an even greater scale. I find this to be a major misstep in the development process and think it has a lot more to do with marketing than anything else, as less than two months in the average player count is already down to a third of what it was earlier when the major update hit, showing that retention is lacking because the content is just not for the players.

Foxhole encompasses everything you want out of a war game, and strikes a nice ‚Äãbalance between an easy to start but hard to master playstyle. This top down war ‚Äãgame put‚Äôs players on the same giant server, where each side battles it out to gain ‚Äãterritory and ultimately win the war. The main selling point of this game however is the ‚Äãsense of scale and purpose achieved within the game.

Foxhole‚Äôs design philosophy is to create a large map with a grid system, and instances ‚Äãare created for individual grids which contain every player nearby. This allows the ‚Äãentire player base to feel a sense of comradery as they are all fighting the same war, ‚Äãwhile the actual game itself is able to save a lot of processing power due to this ‚Äãsystem.

The gameplay of Foxhole is so much more than your regular Battlefield or Call of Duty ‚Äãgame however. Combat aside the addition of a company based system allows players ‚Äãto create large groups on third party sites like discord, and coordinate large ‚Äãoperations together. The fully imagined logistics mechanic within the game provides ‚Äãdifferent play styles to just being on the front line, as every weapon, vehicle, bullet is ‚Äãcreated and transported to the battlefield by players. The sense of depth they have ‚Äãachieved through this system makes for a large scale strategy that is unmatched in the ‚Äãspace, as the biggest reason for losing territory is it‚Äôs neglect for logistics.

The combat however is the area which needs some work. The top down aim system ‚Äãcould do with more fine tuning, as often you will find yourself aiming at nothing or ‚Äãfiring in completely different directions to intended despite how long you gave the ‚Äãweapon to aim accurately. Despite this, there is such a unique form of enjoyment that ‚Äãyou get by pushing a bridge or objective for hours on end, and the proximity chat ‚Äãallows you to develop temporary friendships with players that have a common goal. ‚ÄãJokes and strategies can be shared across the mic, and teamwork can be achieved to ‚Äãsuch a higher level once people have heard the voice of their fellow players, and don‚Äôt ‚Äãsee them as just a pixel on the screen. One slight disadvantage worth mentioning is ‚Äãthat the community has created a merit based system, which blocks new players ‚Äãbehind a 100 hour wall before they are given access to some of the late game content. ‚ÄãWhile there are tanks and artillery in the game, aswell as sniper rifles etc; they are ‚Äãoften allocated by more experienced players to the most deserving on the team, ‚Äãrestricting newcomers to a basic rifleman. This experience can ultimately disway many ‚Äãplayers from sticking around for more than one battle (which tend to last around a ‚Äãmonth) as it often leads to constant corpse runs back to the front line after a gas ‚Äãgrenade or a machine gun caught you off-guard in an uncounterable way.

Foxhole is definitely a must-play for diehard fans of war games, and offers many new ‚Äãsystems to the table which feel fresh within the genre, but it‚Äôs the moment to moment ‚Äãgameplay which will keep this game as a neesh community of experienced players, ‚Äãand only those who want to really dig deep into it will ever experience everything it ‚Äãhas to offer.

This game has a broken queuing system. The game gives you priority to return to a front-line hex if you leave it for whatever reason but sometimes it just doesn't work, you lose your priority, and when you try to queue again you get bumped down by anybody that tries to queue ahead of you. Sometimes you need to cross the border to get supplies that logi can't bring in due to the queue, and this is super frustrating when it happens to you.

This is much more fun than I've expected. I've participated in a fight which lasted for about 10hrs and it will remain in my memory forever:
Spawned on some border region which was actively contested. 
Mostly trench warfare: we sit in a trench, enemies sit in a trench. 
Collecting ammunition/weapons/first aid from fallen soldiers to preserve supplies. 
Enemy tanks came. 
Forced us to back down from our positions. 
Reported tank sighting and prayed that they will bring some AT to us. 
Crew of 3 tanks came to our aid. Got an MG position in one of them.
Tanks formed a line and we charged enemy positions with ~50 people + tanks. 
Managed to get upper hand and drive them up to their fort. 
Somebody constructed an encampment in the middle of the field. 
Supplies needed. 
Found a truck, loaded it with scrap, went to factory. 
Brought back supplies. 
While I was away someone brought heavy artillery gun and started shelling their position. Victory was close, or so it seemed. 
They brought 5+ tanks from their side. AT ammo low. 
They brought more artillery. 
We lost our camp. 
Got locked in our base. 
Enemy artillery shelling. 
Base got on fire. 
Everyone runs around with buckets. 
Managed to put out fire. 
Shelling continues. 
Everyone knows it's over. 
Evacuating the most precious things. 
Our artillery is being packed on a trucks under fire. 
Managed to save it. Fort collapses. 
PTSD unlocked.

So I had built a small facility to make tankets and armor cars witch took forever to get set up with coal,scrap,rations to keep it from falling apart. Its not Rust not all for your self but it how some people play it an i ruins the experiences that game set forth of large scale team for for the greater good of your side. 

  All in all it a good game with lot of potential but with a few toxic player it make the game hard to enjoy.

[b]Foxhole is a very unique game that has a ton of persisting flaws that unfortunately makes it very, very hard to recommend.[/b]

The game is a mechanical mess, balanced terribly with minimal playtesting (this isn't pre-alpha anymore ffs) and is only held together by the incredibly dedicated playerbase who invest all their time and energy into keeping this persistant war going. 

Without the playerbase, this game would literally not work and from my perspective the dev team are not doing enough to make them keep playing (QoL is the most requested thing by far). Siege Camp loves to drop more content for the game, but below the surface all it does is to increase the amount of investment the average player has to put into to gain access to it. Burnout players are unfortunately the norm because this game is grindy as hell, and that's by design.

This game features only a barebone tutorial and there's no dedicated test enviroment apart from a very short time period when a new major patch is implemented, which only purpose is to iron out the biggest bugs and the most controversal of balance changes. The rest will just go live and the entire war becomes basically a testing ground with the playerbase as playtesters. The latest Update pretty much was so bad they had to implement an emergency patch it right after the first update war ended. That's how little confidence they got in their game, and they make the players work through that.

Mechanically, this game is janky and unforgiving.
Building is time-intensive, unintuitive and a big investment with little return.
Double that for facility buildings, which are a very controversal addition that would blow the scope of this review.
Maintainance mechanics which are poorly explained and commucated.
Couple that with the most barebones of commucation tools and you got a toxic cocktail going that causes a majority to fail and quit the game.

Speaking of lacking communicational tools, Siege camps offloads that onto the playerbase too which resulted in each faction having several hubs on 3rd party apps such as discord. Which is frankly ridiculous as we're expected to communicate in-game too as people have to claim territory for building. All of this results in unneeded toxic conflicts (especially at the start of a war) but the dev team has put exactly ZERO effort at improving this for crying out loud.

The dev's focus on adding more content rather than fixing this game underlying problems hasn't shifted in the 2 years I've played this game. The game was never even once in a polished state, It's unacceptable at the point of this review as it's been over a year since this game went out of early access. 

If you're only going for casual infantry/tank gameplay and join a clan to leech for their resources, you'll likely have a good time with Foxhole. If you intend to spend any more time/effort into foxhole to go deeper into the mechanics... 

...stay the hell away from this game, for your own sake.

Foxhole transforms players into vital cogs in the machinery of war, placing them in the trenches rather than commanding from afar. With a staggering variety of roles, from front-line combat to logistical support, each hour brings new challenges and rewards, keeping the experience perpetually fresh.

The game fosters meaningful conversations and genuine connections among players, sparking discussions, plans, and debates in the pursuit of victory. It transcends being just a game; Foxhole becomes a platform for team building and strategic collaboration beyond the digital realm.

The persistent world map adds consequence to decisions, with wars unfolding over days or months, impacting the battlefield. Engaging in all facets of warfare with real players makes every moment matter. Despite occasional balance hiccups and technical challenges, the developers' commitment to improvement shines through constant updates. Foxhole isn't merely a game; it's an odyssey where friendships are forged, tactics are honed, and each invested hour feels like a step toward victory in the ever-changing theater of war. Highly recommended for those seeking not just a game, but an immersive team-building experience.

I love crafting and this game has great depth here. Not just a large variety of things to make, but all of the logistics needed to get your goods to the front lines. First game I have played where crafters or "logi" feels critical to the success of failure of players you are supporting with it.

I found an unlocked truck and went to a scrap yard to break down old vehicles and such for scrap. I loaded the truck and drove down a long dreary road sharing an occasional mutual honk with passing trucks. I eventual find a giant town completely taken over and fortified as a military base. I blocked a road, taking it all in when a man started shouting out me. He seemed to be shouting at everyone, directing them to drop off mats here or there and to grab a gun before heading North. With my truck unloaded into the common storage of materials for someone else to do something with, I was suddenly on foot with a rifle and a band of soldiers heading directly towards the front lines, glory and a certain death.

This game is great if you plan to play along with friends or get along with randos.

Definitely not the type of game you will be playing solo in terms of getting your own gear, vehicle or base. This game will require you to use and share resources with the people in your team. Sure you can build your own base, vehicle and gear, but its going to require you quite a bit of time to do that since the game is meant to be multiplayer and not solo. 

If you prefer to just grab a gun and go, then this game is still a good option as you can just grab an equipment someone else made on the frontlines bases and just go to town. I do have to say that if you want to focus more on driving the fun armored vehicles or artillery pieces, then you might need to ask around, find a abandoned one, steal from the enemy, or try build one yourself as these assets are valuable to the war and can easily change tides if played right.

Overall I say its a good game, with a decent community. Definitely try it out if you want to actually play with people (Not just see people). If you prefer the same type of game but for solo play, then you can take a look at Running with Rifles as that game has a pretty similar gameplay to this one.

Some of the most fun ive ever had playing an MP game. People are friendly, helpful and generally in it for a laugh. The game is complex, challenging and strategic. Charlie shard is a blast, if you're in two minds about this game, i highly recommend it and once you're hooked you cant put it down.

Foxhole takes the concept of a massive multiplayer shooter/war game and fleshes out the full scale of war by adding in the logistics of actually supporting a war effort of its size. Raw materials are harvested to create manufactured goods which include the weapons you fight with, the vehicles you drive, the support buildings and infrastructure across the whole campaign map. This gives the game so many different play styles whether you're looking to jump straight into the front lines as a grunt, supporting soldiers on the ground in tanks and other armored vehicles or being one of the logistics men who put in the massive amount of work it takes to keep weaponry, vehicles and supplies going to the front lines. These are just some of the various aspects of gameplay that Foxhole has as I'm just barely scraping the surface. Foxhole has everything I want to see within the genre but I can't recommend that people should buy the game due to the community.

The in game experience is unfortunately failed by how the community chooses to act and play the game. While there are plenty of great clans and solo players that help make the experience positive, all you have to do when you launch in to your first war to see the problem is look at the global chat feed. It's nothing but and endless stream of toxic s**t about why certain people think teams are losing, alt accusations, players stealing resources etc. When you pick your side in the war (Wardens or Colonials) you will be locked into that faction for the remainder of the war after a period of time in game. It prevents players from simply abandoning ship mid war to "win" but also traps players on teams where certain clans will steal public resources and guard them for their own operations, certain players will simply just sabotage the team's operations because they want to troll or potentially are "alting" where they'll play as one faction to sabotage it to help friend's or clanmate's. While I really love what this game is on paper I'm harshly reminded what the actual experience is whenever I get the itch to reinstall and play. In the end Foxhole is a great game thats sabotaged by it's own players in the pursuit of victory in game.

Foxhole, a barely playable game:

- climbing anything is unresponsive and buggy
- spotting height differences/ climbing spots on rocks is near impossible
- top down view angles can completely block vision on things such as enemy players/vehicles/defenses EVEN WHEN YOU HAVE FULL LINE OF SIGHT
- aiming system is wonky AF especially when you have to aim up or down, basically hope the game gives you a good angle
- aiming when fighting with bare hands is ridiculously tedious even when you are literally touching the enemy THEY REALLY SHOULD MAKE IT CONNECT BETTER WITH ENEMY TARGET OR MAKE IT MUCH MORE RESPONSIBLE OVER ALL (you do get animation locked for about a second when punching)
- IF you can land a hit with your bare hands it does a MASSIVE 50% damage on an enemy player MEANWHILE I CAN NOT EVEN ATTACK WITH A BLUNT OBJECT LIKE A SHOVEL, PLEASE DEVMAN IF YOU MAKE FISTS SO STRONG, WHY NOT MAKE ME HIT AN ENEMY WITH A SHOVEL EVEN IF IT DOES SAME DAMAGE!!!! THIS WOULD BE AN INSANE IMPROVEMENT FOR ANY ONE DIGGING TRENCHES
- since the naval update there is a new sound bug that affects 100% of the in game audio, making it unbearable to listen to and which forces you to restart the game to fix (a bit rare)
- since the naval update there is also another new audio bug where you lose all you audio from the game after entering a new region (happens almost every time i play, making the game experience super ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•)
- squad/regiment voice chat is even more unreliable than previous mentioned audio issue, making it totally useless.
- MG sound bug that melts your ear drums when a tripod MG gets destroyed while shooting
- anything mounted on a tripod will float in mid air if the structure it's placed on gets destroyed (really silly, can't imagine it's intended to work like that
- excessive team killing, happens often
- abusing alt accounts, for spying and sabotage
- lots of team griefing, it's quite easy to do
- (false) mass reporting, often by clans
- disagreements are often settled with guns, not with words, civil war is not uncommon
- poorly designed reporting system (innocents get punished/ true toxic players, team killers and alts get away)
- frequent theft of friendly vehicles
- squad locking anything just makes it worse for team mates while not being useful to the person who locked it in terms of securing the vehicle.
- you can't even lock bicycles
- some one locked a boat that's (only slightly) in the water? well good luck getting that unlocked again! YOU CAN NOT CROUCH IN OR NEAR WATER, YOU CAN NOT CLIMB ON TOP OF SMALL BOATS (EVENT THOUGH YOU SHOULD BE ABLE TO DO THIS, I DON'T SEE WHY NOT) AND YOU ALSO CAN'T USE ANY TOOLS OR WEAPONS WHILE SITTING IN A BOAT (EVENT THOUGH YOU SHOULD BE ABLE TO DO THIS, I DON'T SEE WHY NOT) LET ALONE IF THE BOAT IS MORE THAN JUST SLIGHTLY IN THE WATER
- when parking a gunboat next to a locked ironship, you can get locked out of selecting the driver seat of the gunboat and instead can only select the ironship if you end up in the wrong position.
- lots of toxicity, saltiness and white knight behavior from a large portion of the player base.
- the deployment map is not good at showing where people are needed on the front, especially confusing for new players
- map colors don't make sense half of the time, can't tell what you look at on map
- want to navigate the map while driving any vehicle that is faster than a snail? good luck! the mini map sucks and even the main map is not that much more better
- for some reason the nearly indestructible enemy maintenance hatches show up as defensive structures on map for no good reason, they actually have their own icon but only for your own faction, is this a mistake in coding !?!?
- so many chokepoints on the map that barely move that it becomes stale and boring quite fast, only a few fronts available with more move options
- map design on a macro perspective is quite bad, once one side makes an initial breach breach past one of the main choke points it's a downwards spiral for the opposing side. IT SHOULD BE THE OPPOSITE
- AI defense systems are in the top 5 of questionable design choices in this game since they favor the side which already has higher player numbers, adding even more to early game defeatism on the losing team. should it not help defend at lower player pop?
- in theory a faction can always make an epic comeback after an initial setback, but defeatism prevents this most of the time, people rather quit after losing ground
- want to build anything larger than a coffin? good luck competing for building space!
- you want to build anything on a front-line? good luck finding a spot where backpacks are not blocking your building space
- don't know which RPG ammo goes with which RPG launcher? well, good luck figuring that one out
- having two systems that do the same thing but differently is just poor design. YES I'm talking about barbed wire and how its fu*n STOOPID how you can remove some of the barbed wire with a wrench BUT NOT IF IT's PLACED ON A TRENCH FOR NO FU*N REASON BECAUSE OF COURSE ITS LOGICAL THAT NOW I NEED TO USE BMATS INSTEAD EVEN THOUGH THE COST AND FUNCTION OF THE WIRE ON THE TRENCHES ARE IDENTICAL TO THOSE THAT YOU CAN PLACE ON THE GROUND
- trying to place 2 types of walls/barriers like barbed wire or sand bags next to each other? don't bother trying the auto snap function is horrendous and greatly limits your placement options.
- the idea of having weather systems (snow/rain etc) is cool, especially when it affects the game play, BUT WHY IS IT COMPLETELY RANDOM AND NOT A PROPER SEASON SYSTEM which would be infinitely better
- although I do think the muddy feet penalty from rainy weather is actually quite a good idea, meanwhile it's actually ridiculously easy to warm when it snow's, to the point that if you are aware of the mechanics it won't really affect you as infantry even without a winter uniform (you can simply get warm from sitting in a trench, pillbox, vehicle (yes even riding bicycles get you warmed up!) or any building structure, even if it's shot to pieces and has massive gaping holes in it.)
- did some clan claim an entire oilfield and locked down the facility on top of it? too bad, guess they are the oil mafia now
- if you think claiming oil fields is bad, what about squads claiming front line bunkers and than logging out without releasing them to the public making it impossible to properly maintain.

- occasionally clipping in pre-existing objects in the world like that time I sapwned into a table, went back to home region, deploy again aaaaaand stuck in the same spot again!
- also climbing over or jumping on objects in the world you can get stuck especially if there is buildings around pre-existing objects but also possible when climbing on rocks.
- unstuck tool? useless, going back to home region is faster/less effort most of the time, which also sucks sometimes since you have limited deploy's per time unit.
- typing in chat during your respawn time out is buggy, you will get randomly cut from typing in chat for no good reason
- You can also randomly get cut from typing at a map post
- don't even bother to read chat, all people type there is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and ****

- build able signs are occasionally useful to display messages, but lets be real 9/10 times they are made to advertise some clanman Discord server, which sucks since they still cost Bmats

One of the aboslute best war sim games out there. 

The community is super serious about gameplay and rights and wrongs. Which can be both good and bad for your playing experience. 

There are people dedicated to teach newbies on the basics and get them up to speed. I had one, Beef. Taught me logi, basic building and mechanics. Later people will tell you what kind of battleplans work and do not work, how the enemie tends to work in different fronts etc. 
People can also tend to get agitated, like when you build somewhere a clan has built something already and they don't like it. You will get yelled at. It's best to apologies and move on. 

The game features player built towns and frontlines, every weapon you hear, tank you see, hole in the ground etc is made by players. 

In short, for 25‚Ç¨ you will definetly get your moneys worth, bring you mic, bring your roleplaying self, and bring a hot cup of tea and join the frontlines.

Foxhole is amazing game where you can spend hundreds and hundreds of hours and keep enjoying playing the game, you cannot win the war yourself, you need to cooperate, groups, regiments etc. but as one you can do your part really well, you cannot turn the tide of the war, but battle yes, one granade killing whole squad going to capture your spawn base, one logistics run saving the front for hours to come, one good medic keeping the frontline alive himself, until others arrive, etc. etc. If you want to buy Foxhole 100% wait for sale, you can refound in 2hours of playing, i suggest watching this YT channel: https://www.youtube.com/@FreerkHoltes and if you would still have questions, you can go on Foxhole Official Discord - http://discord.gg/foxhole , Steam dis. - http://steamcommunity.com/app/505460/discussions/ , or in worse on Foxhole Official Reddit - https://www.reddit.com/r/foxholegame there are people to help you, each Faction have it's own unofficial discord server, for Colonilas - Sigil: discord.gg/colonialsigil for Wardens WUH: https://discord.gg/e2gM4MF - (Warden Unity Hub) , i suggest for newbies to join clan, if they want to be part of large operations, or want to enjoy some artillery gameplay, same with ships etc, witch is something you cannot do alone, or build... 

I'm myself main medic, i can tech you basics or advanced stuff, discord: vedagi , i'm behind uncompleted "Medical Guide" project, and [work in progress] "Medical Library" project, as medic you will save a lot of lifes, medics tend to be helpful and friendly all time, being medic become at this point more like job to me, i'm not the best, but to be honest one of the top i would say, not just because of my experience, but also thanks to having a lot of time to play, there are medical regiments, DM if you want to join some, i'm probably the only person who knows most of medical clans in game.

In general, Foxhole is amazing game, and you'll cry one day when you'll think of the people and friends you met, and never seen again, the great times when you know people from enemy team, the great stories what you'll made, and one day, you ask yourself, why did i stay?

10/10 Imperial Guard Simulator

The great thing about this game is that there are so many different rolls to fill:

You want to gather and craft? GREAT, every bullet fired is made by a player!
You want to run and gun? GREAT, we need someone to fire those bullets we made!
Your soul yearns for the road? GREAT, we need those bullets moved from the factories to the battlefield!
You want to be a pirate? GREAT! Take to the sea and disrupt enemy logistics!

Operate a tank, fire artillery, infiltrate enemy lines to disrupt logistics, build fortifications, build production facilities, so many things to do!

You a homebody? You can stay in one Hex the whole war if you want to. Or you can go out and see the 64 square kilometers of battlefield that is divided into 37 hexagonal map regions/servers that you can freely travel between (barring any queues due to server population)

You can play this game as a solo just helping out where ever you can. You can form or join a Regiment to organize and build larger operations. There are tiny Regiments and mega Regiments, hardcore, casual, and larp. Your regiment can join a coalition to organize global offensives and operations.

This game is epic!

Life of a foxhole player, spawn in a random front, get blown by arty 40 times, get pushed, start panicking, it's too late, get blown up again, base dies, rinse and repeat until the same happens to the opponents.

Foxhole is an amazing game.



If you want to end up with severe paranoia, trust-issues and PTSD that is.
Foxhole is ruined by both its community and its devs, I'll be giving you some examples:



-Firstly, you'll love this game if you have a year of time to spend on it, however if you always have limited time, don't even bother playing it.

-In Foxhole, if you are a Colonial or a Warden, your enemies aren't the other team, but actually your own team. Piss off some hardcore no-life player? He'll wrench your truck full of RMATS and BMATS then throw it in the river then kill you, you took a single stack of RMATS to go build a tankette but a dude was gonna take said stack to build a jeep for no reason? He's gonna follow you in a truck yelling the hard-R at you for 2 hours, waste your tankette's fuel and ammo then drive it to the other team's frontline and blow it up.


-In Foxhole, teamwork is a neccesary element to any war, sometimes it needs to be coordinated, so clans have been created, and this led to almost every big clan being full of power-hungry no life hardcore basement dwellers that if you even DARE to piss of once, they'll cry to their clan and tell them to mass report you and you'll be banned within an hour. When oil was added in-game, big clans at the start of the war imediately did a bee-line for the oil fields then killed anyone who even DARED to try to take a single jerrycan leading small clans and regular players with no way to fuel their vehicles, this led to literal civil wars in between big clans controlling all the oil fields for their own stuff and killing anyone approaching the fields, small clans leading attacks and sabotages on the big clans oil wells and regular players just trying to win the war.

- The devs are very respectful to critisisim, if you even dare to leave a constructive and backed up negative review, the chances of you being shadow banned from the game and discord are close to 100%, they also listen a lot to their community, main example is the famous L.O.G.I strike, basically, logistics player were complaining to the devs that logistics was tidious, boring, unrewarding and riddled in bugs, they made a letter to the devs and gave them a deadline to either respond or fix the issues. They, of course, never fullfilled the deadline and this led to logi players going on strike for the next war, guess what the devs did? They removed half of the refineries and emptied world storages instead of listening to their community in order to punish EVERYONE leaving both teams needing to swap out their frontline duties for logistic ones, I guess I don't need to mention the fact they are ready to ban a new player with 3 hours of playtime if a high clan member asks them to, but if said clan member sabotages their own team or even hack, you can be sure nothing will be done against them.

- Foxhole has the amazing ability of sapping your morale away faster than spending 5 minutes on Twitter. Picture this, you've been supplying a frontline bunker base with shirts and BMATS and other resources for 3 hours, you help build defenses, barbed wire, mines, AI bunkers and so on, you team up with other logi players and build a battle tank, you take it to the frontline go fight with it and your teamates and capture a town so quickly the enemies don't have the time to take their vehicles with them and end up abandoning them, after a hard day of work, you decide to log-off and go to sleep, when you wake up you hop on the game only to see your team has lost both the town, the battle tank, the vehicles, the bunker base and the seaport, all of that within 6 hours. How? Simple, a Warden logged on with his Colonial account when most players were sleeping, took the vehicles you captured and brought them back to his team, dismantled a part of your trench so he could sneak his Warden account in and burn it down and did the same to the Town Hall and gave the areas with no defenses to his team, worst thing? This happens ALLLLL the time and the devs REFUSE to do anything against it, they refuse to take any action despite the community literally begging them to do anything. This caused a majority of players literally ending up with depressed or with no morale because anything they worked hard for could be rendered meaningless and useless within 2 minutes by some basement dweller.

- The moderation in Foxhole uses a bot, logical, most games now use bots to moderate right? Well, Foxhole's bot does it differently, does it base itself on the evidence, on who is getting reported or on your actions? No. It bases itself on how many people report you, you decide to report a hacker once? He'll never be banned since its not enough, however if a clan decides to report you 254 times for bullcrap reasons? Expect to be banned in the following hour because logic is that "If there's a lot of reports coming from lots of players on the same clan on a single person it HAS to be real" But it doesn't stop here, the Foxhole devs in order to stop people yelling slurs in the chat have introduced a "Communication Rating" system, basically the Reddit upvote/downvote system but the devs have somehow made it WORSE. Upvoting someone gives you no rewards whatsoever, downvoting someone however screws them over as if their Communication Rating becomes "Bad". They'll simply and casually be PERMANENTLY MUTED FROM GENERAL, REGION AND LOGISTICS CHAT leaving you with only Local chat access, now it might not seem like a big problem until you realise something. In order to get your Communication Rating up, you need to be upvoted, but the thing is, you CANNOT upvote messages in Local chat effectively leaving you muted from the general chats for the rest of the war and since downvoting messages for no reason don't give you consequences, you can effectively shadow mute anyone from communicating in a game where teamwork and communication are key.


Overall, I wouldn't recommend Foxhole at all, the game's slowly dying with dwindelling player numbers because the devs just refuse to listen to their community, useless update adding more and more useless vehicles and mechanics (who thought decay would be a good idea? And who seriously uses the ambulance?), the community is a toxic mess full of power-tripping clans, alts and hackers that get no punishements whatsoever, the game can go from the most fun experience you've ever had until, Uh oh, a bunker base needs shirts and BMATS, time to drop down your rifle in a war game and go scrap for 5 hours straight while being constantly griefed by big clans, only for your progress be meaningless because some guy with an alt account waltzed past all your defenses and burnt down your storage and up with severe paranoia resulting in you shooting anyone next to your storage because they seems suspicious and end up shooting a clan member that then tells his entire clan to mass report you only for you to end up being banned.

This game has potential to be so fun. Whether you are running around trenches, hunting for weapons and ammo, or grouping with 7 people to rush an enemy structure so you can all throw 4 HE nades inside, or if you are relaxing whilst driving around delivering supplies to the front, it has potential to be fun.

But the devs just cant quite grasp it. Yes, the balance is fucked and warden is objectively better tech wise. But you can overcome wardens having better tech, and we were. But suddenly every colonial in Clahstra gets kicked, all their AI gets disabled, and wardens are just able to undo hours of progress with no effort. They were on their heels, losing ground, and they were saved not by their ingenuity, not by some amazing call or plan, but by the devs. Dozens of people quit the game on the spot, many claiming they didnt plan to return because it simply ruins the fun and feeling like you have an impact when the devs allow this. 

2 hours post the event, and no dev has responded, not comments from any staff on the official discord or in game. I have lost many times in this game, and all of those sucked. But this was not losing, this was getting cheated. No fault of our own saw us lose hours of progress and resources. Until the devs are able to respond to this situation, i cannot find the motivation to continue, or recommend this game.

This game is an absolute piece of shit.
We're destroying the Town hall in Clahstra.  Devs kick 90% of collies out, despawn 90% of colllie vehicles.  Hex goes from bombs and shots going off in deafening fashion to complete silence.  Wardens keep their 50 player pop vs now 7-8 people.  AI is gone on all 5 bunker bases instantly and we can't even activate AI on a single bunker. Wardens proceed to PvE everything. If you're going to kick everyone out, make sure you kick everyone out of both sides, noobs.

Game has a lot of issues.

Some things I'd like to see fixed...

1. Can't stand up once you start cocking a grenade (I've seen tons of people blow themselves up because of this), HUGE delay for crouch after throwing one as well.

2. Both your team and the enemies buildings under construction are blue, it's literally impossible to tell whose is who. Which can be hugely important. Also the flags over the buildings are very hard to discern, I think wardens look yellow and blue and collies are pure yellow? I'm not even sure, they don't look distinctive at all in my opinion.

3. Everything surrounding building, maintaining and upgrading trenches is bad. It's very difficult to build them or connect them. You can't shoot through the rope as they are being built. You need building materials to fill them in or remove sandbags / barbed wire upgrades (I think it's dumb you use a wrench to remove barbed wire as well, they should just make wire cutters).

4. It's extremely difficult to climb in and out of trenches as well, you spam spacebar in every direction and it frequently takes 5 secs or more, which is certain death when your trying to run from a grenade.

5. I think it's dumb you can't right click to assemble and equip items from your bunker base. 

6. The logistics system is bad too, it's really annoying. There should just be a separate tab at the bunker base where players can request items from the logistics people. Right now it's just a million people making posts on the map begging for basic items. I would build them myself but after nearly 170 hours of play I still have no idea how to do that. The tutorials are horrible. So many new players don't even know how to use to a bandage, much less use construction vehicles, or build a tank. I think the only realistic way to learn how to play this game is join a clan. There aren't even good youtube tutorials. 

7. I think it's dumb that you win the war and like nothing even happens. Some guy in France probably knows but I still have no idea despiste winning two wars. I went to sleep after playing for a long time and next time I log in it's just like ok wars over. I don't think it even says who won, you just infer it was your team. There should be fireworks in the spawning area and a parade or a video cut scene or SOMETHING. It's really a bummer, I don't know if you can even check your stats or anything. It would be cool if it told you how many kills / deaths you had, trenches / items built, literally something to reward players for such a huge time commitment.

8. The game is heavily dominated by armored vehicles because there is absolutely no way for infantry to get past the endless number of automatic gun turrets that instantly target and kill you. Really dumb, you log in at the start of a new war and there is basically no point in even playing until tanks or artillery are unlocked. Mammons have ridiculously short range, it's basically 100% suicide if you try to use them to destroy a vehicle or a automatic machine gun, they even insta kill you if you are standing in a trench.

9. Another thing that's very bad is the aiming system, I was shocked when an enemy was 4 ft away from me and I spray fired 30 bullets with a sub machine gun only to have all of them miss? Ridiculous. Or how you pull out you pistol to finish an enemy lying still on the ground 2 ft away and to have 4 shots miss? You have to stand there and aim for like 2 seconds to shot them. It's really a bad system. Also your frequently shooting at people and it you gives you the red line that means you can't hit them, and surprise you can! People somehow turn immortal when they lay down as well, the whole system is pretty bad.

10. Lots of toxic players, people saying all kinds of slurs and teammates screaming into their mics. If a teammate kills you on purpose you can't report them while your dead, you can't commend people either (The commendation system is really bad, you can alt + right click to mute / report / commend people but I'd wager roughly 85% of players don't know that). People can kill you and instantly close their game to avoid all punishments. There should be an immediate pop that asks if you want to report them - and if there's excessive team killing other players should be able to watch clip of the incident while there dead to ask if it looked intentional and give them a 90 min ban for first offense and escalate if they keep it up. Right now there basically no moderation at all. 

11. It is STILL very easy to get stuck on mountains and raise trenches, you can type !unstuck to get out of it BUT not if there's enemies near??? Surprise, there is! Like literally every time, BECAUSE WE ARE FIGHTING A WAR. Most people don't know that, how would they, even if you do know that it takes two minutes??? that's 4 deaths? wtf. I've seen people begging teammates to kill them because they can't get unstuck - just really bad.And it's on super common terrain that's copy and pasted like a million times, how is this not fixed?

Great fun, great moments, great community! Taking part in massive firefights for several hours over small stretches of land, knowing you are only a small part of a much larger machine, is when the game truly comes alive.Quite a unique experience among other games and definitely worth a try :)
