This game adopts a World War II setting with Allied (Colonial) and Axis (Warden) factions. The Warden leader, Callahan, is portrayed as Hitler. However, a notable drawback of the game is the apparent bias towards the Axis faction by the developers. They seem determined to disrupt the server whenever the Colonial side advances into Warden territory. The game's imbalance is evident in the equipment provided to the Colonial faction, favoring the Axis team and resulting in their consistent victories. You can google the win-loss ratio between the two teams. If you're interested in role-playing as a Nazi, this game might appeal to you; otherwise, it's not recommended. There are other games available that offer a more ethical experience.

I don't normally leave reviews. I have way more hours(800+) invested in this game than I'd like to admit, it is that good. While it isn't perfect, this might be one of the best games I've ever played in the MMO genre. I would not classify this as a twitchy game at all so if you are older, like RTS games, like MMO games and used to play shooters you might like this.  It is unique and has endless hours of gameplay to offer.

[h3][u]Pros:[/u][/h3]
[list]
[*] MMO with an ending, each war ends and then restarts. Yes, there are game loops in this game the require a grind  but only if you want there to be. I find myself grinding 1 war to get resources for something fun and powerful, like a battletank and then the next war, more casually playing. These options help prevent burnout.
[*] Great co-op play with friends. It is a full pvp game. 
[*] Death, destruction, absolute chaos. Big battles are intense. Honestly, I've had more fun losing in a last stand than winning a lot of the time.
[*] Attention to detail/realism. For example, to fire artillery, you need a trigger man, a guy who loads the shells manually and a spotter who provides coordinates to fire at. You also have to make the artillery piece and shells, then transport them to the front.
[*] Sandbox/player made elements. The logistics/economy/factory side of this game is amazing. It is complicated and has a learning curve but it's actually kind of fun. I normally find that type of activity to be tedious(it still can be at times) but Foxhole does make this interesting.
[*] Tanks are awesome.
[*] Naval update was a game changer, excellent new content there.
[*] Allows for different play styles. You can be casual and have fun at the front or deep dive into the extreme resource gather, building and facilities end of the game.
[*]  Community - there's some cool people who play and that will help you out if you ask.
[/list]

[h3][u]Cons:[/u][/h3]
[list]
[*] Learning curve. It isn't easy to figure out at first. There's a training area that was okay when I first started but not great. It is a true sandbox and you have to figure things out as you go. It can be overwhelming and it took me months to figure out the way things work. I feel like I'm just now getting to the point where I'm comprehending all the elements of the game(end to end) and their importance. Go to the front early and fight, that will get you hooked imo.  
[*]  Time investment - you can play casually but if you are like me, you might find that hard to do. There's always stuff to be done which is bad and good.
[*] Connectivity issues and bugs sometimes. Not terrible or game ruining, but not extremely polished.
[*] Can be a little too much sandbox at times. It gets frustrating when people take your important stuff from your facilities without asking. There could be some improvements to the game mechanics around that in my opinion.
[*]Community - for every 5-10 good people, there's a few that are just toxic or annoying for no reason. Can be brutal. 
[*] Larpers - Way more than you would expect but maybe I'm just not into that.
[/list]

After finishing my first war, I can confidently say that I am indeed forever troubled by the horror's of war. In all seriousness, this game is really fun and has insane replayability. The experiences you make when you boot up the game will be completely different every time, and they are just as fun as the last. There's so many different ways you could play too. You could be an infantryman, you could be a medic, an artillery crew member, a tanker, you could even be running logistics to supply the front lines, there's no wrong way to play the game. I could go on, and on, and on, and on about this game and everything in it, but I wont, instead I implore you to buy the game and see it for yourself. Foxhole is worth your time, money and and sanity.

Update on 11/30/23
It's been a few months since my last review update, and you might be wondering what's new. The developers have implemented some changes and are committed to introducing Quality of Life (QoL) improvements that will enhance the game. Based on this latest update, I now recommend giving this game a try.

"Foxhole" stands out as a gem in the realm of cooperative war games, offering a truly immersive experience that hinges on community and communication. The game's shining attribute is its player-driven warfare, where every soldier, builder, and logistician is an actual player contributing to a persistent war effort. This setup fosters an incredible sense of camaraderie and teamwork, as success in "Foxhole" heavily relies on effective communication and strategic collaboration. The sense of achievement you get from coordinated efforts with fellow players is unparalleled.

The game's community is one of its strongest assets. Players are generally welcoming and eager to work together, which is vital in a game where coordination is key. New players can expect to find guidance and support from more experienced soldiers, creating an inclusive and engaging environment.

However, "Foxhole" is not without its challenges. Factionalism is prominent, with extreme loyalty to one‚Äôs faction sometimes leading to a divisive atmosphere. This can occasionally detract from the overall experience, particularly for new players navigating these complex social dynamics.

Additionally, some of the developers' game design choices have been met with mixed reactions. Certain updates and changes have sparked debate within the community about the game‚Äôs direction. While these choices show the developers' commitment to evolving the game, they can sometimes feel misaligned with player expectations.

In conclusion, "Foxhole" offers a unique and compelling experience for those who thrive on teamwork and strategy. While it has areas that could be improved, particularly in terms of factionalism and certain game design decisions, the game remains a standout choice for players seeking a deep, cooperative military strategy game.

When I first played back in War 93, I spent hours just driving trucks and barges. Didn't hear a shot fired the whole time. I drove bmats to Buckler Sound when the siege broke. I brought wrenches to the Battle of Ulster Falls during the dismantling of the Fuhrerbunker. I hauled artillery up the hills in Reaching Trails to destroy Fort Mousetrap. I delivered shells to the recently-liberated Blemish to help destroy what can only be described as an obscenely large fortress to the south. I was present for every major engagement in what was by all accounts a historic war in the role of logistics grunt and it was some of the most fun I've ever had in a multiplayer game. 

This game is a highly effective autism diagnosis tool, and continues to improve as an experience over time. Cross-faction voice chat makes it easier to discuss things like the fates of prisoners, whose jingoistic nationalism for a fictional country is the strongest, the physical and personal characteristics of someone's mother, etc.  8/10, balance issues are commonplace between patches but aren't as bad as people make them out to be. Game has an adequate number of boats at present with more on the way.

Developers are obsessed with making players waste time with stupid facilities that add nothing to gameplay and get old after 15 minutes.

Devs are stuck chasing "their vision" no matter how un-fun and grindy that makes the game. 
They're fixated on some immersive war simulator that doesn't value players' time and discourages teamwork whenever possible. 

If you're not part of a regiment, good luck getting fucking anything done. If you are, enjoy having everything you make get stolen by dudes who don't want to work for it. 

Enjoy having devs sit idly and refuse to ban griefers and known alt accounts. Send video evidence of alt accounts only to see them log in the next day after a 24 hour ban. 

===========

Spring/Summer 2023 Patch:
Yep, Devs are just adding useless fluff crap features instead of fixing existing content.
They haven't iterated meaningfully on facilities and logistics in 9+ months, but not a single crippling issue with the game has been addressed.  

Game is on life support with individual team members just adding whatever feature catches their eye, rather than getting together and making meaningful changes to core gameplay loops.  

It's easy to see most of their motivation left and went to work on Anvil.

===========

Fall 2023 Patch (Naval):

They added crappy boats that don't fit into the flow of the game, take massive resource investments, and had to give them their own hexes to make them relevant. 

The least fun and interesting update they've ever pushed. Buggy boats and more grind.

Again ZERO quality-of-life. They added MORE grind and MORE tedium while ignoring glaring issues with the game's core gameplay loops.

They just announced their next set of patches and "QoL" that includes minor UI fixes, but again, for the 500th time, does absolutely nothing to address the game's overwhelming hunger for your time and utter disrespect for the effort you invest into it. 

The devs continue just adding whatever flashy crap their ADHD-addled minds latch onto this month.

Foxhole delivers a unique and engrossing wartime experience. The persistent, player-driven world creates a sense of ongoing conflict that is both thrilling and unpredictable. The collaboration required for logistics, resource gathering, and frontline battles fosters a true sense of camaraderie. Foxhole's top-down perspective and emphasis on strategy make every action feel like a crucial part of a larger war effort. The evolving front lines and player-driven economy add layers of depth rarely seen in online multiplayer games. Foxhole is a captivating blend of strategy and action for those seeking a truly dynamic war environment.

I don't even know were to begin, for starters it is one of the best war games I have ever played. Most other people have probably already talked about the mechanics in the game so I'm gonna go over some other points/suggestions for new players:

1: Play on Charlie shard (shards are servers). Able shard is full of toxic tryhards and really not worth playing on (and this is coming from somebody who has roughly 50ish hours on this game)
2: Build trenches, but build them well. Research IRL trench formations and try to copy that, alot of IRL tactics/defenses actually translate well over to Foxhole
3: When fighting tanks, aim for fuel tanks, turret and tracks. Taking out the tracks makes them nearly immobile, damaging fuel tanks means that the tank looses alot of fuel and taking out the turret disables the turret from rotating. 

And the final tip (or rather an answer to a question most newbies ask): Which Faction to pick?

First off, lets start with the Wardens. The Wardens (Or the Caiovish), culturally, are based on the Celtics while most of their equipment is inspired by the French (with a little german inspiration sprinkled in). In terms of lore they are fairly conservative and value individuals, often making statues of great leaders/people in their society. They were once a massive empire that is now in decline, and while they weren't an empire in name, they were a trading nation and there is evidence to suggest that they held a monopoly on trade in the region. 

Second, the Colonials (or Mesean Republic). The Colonials aren't actually one peoples, but rather a collection of smaller cultures, the main one being the Meseans (Italian) with smaller countries in it such as the Velinians (Greek), Kraunians (French) and Estrellans (Spanish). The Colonials use a variety of equipment, guns from Estrella, tanks from Kraunia, ships from Veli and general gear/equipment from Mesea. In terms of lore, not much is known about them with people either calling the Republic a Democratic Liberator or a Tyrannical Oppressor, all that is 100% confirmed is that they are a highly militaristic state, with a collectivist mindset and little care about individuals unless they made a great contribution to the Republic.

In terms of gameplay, both factions are somewhat identical though the Colonials have better Infantry weapons while the Wardens have better tanks

Let me start off by saying I really like this game and enjoy the loop. From logi, to tanking, to clearing the trenches. I just have to warn you now, The community is rabid. Alt accounts, a practice where a player will purchase an alternate account with the express purpose of joining the enemy side to sabotage key facilities and provide intel they would otherwise never gain access too, are out of control. You cant trust any new players because they might just be there to ruin you're game time. This creates a cycle where new players come in and get burnt our by the community for making new player mistakes since the older players have to keep this practice in the back of their minds when ever they try to help. Too many have been burned and lost a base SOLELY because of alt accounts . The regiments would usually love to help new players, but there is a genuinely high risk of that account being an alt. It ruins the game and the devs have NO idea how to actually fix it. Also the balancing is a complete joke, the game BARELY respects your time, and the devs will NOT hard cap faction sizes. This means that the current overpowered faction will ALWAYS have more players. And from everything I have heard in game, the devs are OK with this and actually give unfair balances to one side depending on who they want to win. In other words, YOUR ACTIONS MEAN NOTHING. I will keep playing this game because there is nothing else like it, but only because there is nothing else like it. The second that changes, I'm gone.

This game is good, but need so many features. First of all logistics can be problem. Lets say I work hard, but cannot see the result of my productions in frontline (maybe give assist or points). So I joined for the latest war, played entirely too much and absolutely won't be recommending this game to anyone I know or anyone else unless I really really don't like them. Overall the game is super unique and actually very engaging. I did a mix of activities some front line combat, solo ran a small public facility for vehicle upgrades in a convenient location that actually made me some good friends in game, and did back line to mid/front line logistics. Enjoyed all of it. So why the not recommend?

The community. Before buying I was told on reddit that the community there was way more toxic than in game....that was nothing short of a lie. This game is a huge playground for toxicity and griefing. Most of the "toxicity" I saw on reddit appears to be valid criticism of the game. In game is soooo much nastier. From world chat that is constantly on about who is at fault for losing and nonstop whining about losing, to fights over who stole what (especially trains), whose resources are whose, and top it off with folks intentionally sabotaging your own side. Because everything is player made and some items are difficult if not outright impossible to secure from your own team griefers can and do wonder the map to find high value assets and destroy them. My own facility had people on multiple occasions just come through and throw manufactured materials on the ground to rot, disconnect power to structures, and unlock and move vehicles out into the road to block pathways into and out of a nearby town.  This happened right before a big attack on the region which of course suggests it could be alting (a nasty practice of having an account on the other team and using it to sabotage stuff for an advantage) but could just be vindictive idiots. Sure, I've met some good peoples and helped some folks about but I've also been team killed for trying to set up a public crane at a public mine by a clan that set up their facility on top of it and received obscenity laced tirades because I was parked "wrong" at a refinery because someone else was parked wrong when I got there so I made do. Dude was truly unhinged because it took him 5 extra seconds to access the building...

Finally. Because there was a new update released the devs opened a new server to accommodate the influx of players, new or returning. Pretty standard stuff for an mmo right?  Well expect in this case the devs play the game and want to protect there "pure" vision of the gaming experience from anyone new that might disrupt that. So they put up big warnings about ques on the Alpha server, which is their own private playground and shunt any and all new players to Charlie. The whole community on Alpha treats Charlie like a joke. They call it a meme server and call for it to be shut down after the current war. You as a new player are literally seen as a lessor by the player base here and shoveled off to a lessor version of the game. Is it a scam? I wouldn't go as far as that but i would call it a cash grab. There is no subscription and no cash shop so the devs have to make money somehow. To do that they put out a new expansion, run a sale or something to bring in new players, give them an experience that is good enough to keep them around until they can't refund the game then have the community and gameplay drive away 99% of them so they don't have to open another server and can keep the purity of the one true war.

I think I'll stop there. I could touch on other issues like the attempt at asymmetric balancing, server issues, or how mind numbing some of the logistics loop is but I'm sure others have and will cover that.

Before i start. I like to adress that this game is really really fun to play for a long period of time. But after getting some sessions. you slowly going to see the same patern in the game mechanics and you have to use the experiences you get from previous wars and put them in good use in the next up coming battles. that being said let be point out the Pros and the Cons of the game.

PROS

- It's a very simple looking game, but with a huge in-dept cooperation mechanic. (Simple put. It's like an ARMA game.) 
- Very huge maps with it's own uniqe feature in maps. (one map has a Swamp, the other are islands and some have huge options in flanking.)

- Interesting way of telling how old Warfare during WorldWar was carried out. (from Logistics to Frontlines. Every department has to help each other out in order to achieve victory.)

- Price. For what is delivers it is worth it for just 20$ as a just gonna help a team out in the weekends or just every day. (and with the SteamSales the prices are even more worth while!)

CONS

- Huge flaws in teamwork can quickly be a bad game expierence. (players that start from the beginning instantly go to the Frontlines without proper training on what to do and will get very frustrated when the enemies can overwelm them in better logistics arms.)

- Un-even maps, can make some area's of the map unfair. (even tho the Devs wanted this way, i do see that some of those maps form a huge issue in order to make an orginized assault possible)

- Cheating. (Yes... even in this game cheating happends, and while the Devs are aware of this, they have not found a perfect
solution to find and stop the hacking toolkit. They are thinking about an Anti-cheat system in the near future.) 

- The Disconnect between Logistics and Frontline. (Logistics are the foundation of the war. They deliver Weapons, Vehicles, Building Materials and more to the frontlines. most of the time a lot of newcomers will ignore this and go straight to the front. and that leaves more empty hands in order to get supplies to the Front.) 


Well then. I hope if someone is reading this. it will give them a better understanding of the sistuation of the game and if it is worth you're try. My personal opion is. Yes. In the in between moments i had a lot of fun with playing with Random players that just charge towards the enemy while also falling off a cliff and instantly explodes on impact.... The front line battle aspect is pretty realistic. Apart from that, the logistics field is also very much in depth. It may tempt you to grind resources and manufacture supplies for the front line, and you may do it on a small scale. There's no use in trying to mass produce or try and build combat vehicles unless you have a big squad. Most materials (like coal ) need time for refining even after mining them. Be careful to set resources to private if you intend on using them later. To properly mine or gather basic resources, you'll need big vehicles (flatbeds), not the puny R1 Hauler type which you will have used a lot and then realise what a waste of time that was. You'll make the big trucks, only to be stolen after you logout. So, unless you've got a big squad, just have some fun in the front line or do small scale logi related grind and deliver it to the front lines. It's immensely satisfying. Then, you might ask, if I've gotta play in the front line, why should I do it in a silly top down manner where there are plenty of realistic front line experiences like Squad? Well, it's a different experience. And the front line is just chaos (unless you've got a good command), with you trying to aim and shoot, only to realise that a teammate has come in your "line of fire" and that you've shot them accidentally.

That said, if you have a squad, then there are a lot of things that you'll be able to build and supply. The manufacturing process is unbelievably in depth, realistic and complicated too. There are trains (both small gauge supply and normal gauge ones with cannons fitted) which I feel is a pretty cool thing.

In short, unless you join a clan or have a lot of friends playing this game, you'll just feel exhausted after putting in a lot of effort.

Just treat this game as a way to pass time. Do some small scale logi, deliver it to the front lines, get commends, try to take out some enemies. Don't just stick to logi or fighting, experience it all. 

Update : The servers, being based in EU, are pretty laggy and it isn't a fun experience for a player from Asia. I get disconnected 20 times a day, that too at crucial junctures. Most of the times, it says, "connection refused". I've never had such a consistent problem even in other MMOs with EU only servers. Lost a lot of resources because of sudden dcs.

Final Update: The game has become unplayable because of too much alt activity. Players from the opposite faction just come during low pop. and dump vehicles into the sea, steal material and ammo from facilities, etc. Basically, whichever faction has more alts is bound to win. Not gonna play unless the devs decide to do something about it. Countless tanks and other vital machinery are being dumped into the sea / destroyed by alt. accounts. Fking with regimental facilities on a daily basis is a whole another chapter.

I've played quite a bit of foxhole. 

Don't be fooled by any cool posts or videos you'll see of this game. That kind of interesting, video worthy stuff almost never happens. 

You can join a regiment sure, but nothing will happen. Most of the time even concentrated team efforts are just like solo ones. Either way you'll just end up ramming your head into a wall and the wall wins 95% of the time. 

And the other 5% where you beat the wall? Nothing. Most of that time, the enemy comes by when you're not around and undoes everything. None of it mattered. 

Unless you are willing to sink huge chunks of your limited time on earth into this game, and then also manage to team up with the right people by chance

You will never do anything of note. 

Tank crew or ship crew? Forget it. Everything but the smallest boats and tanks is ridiculously expensive and takes many real hours of waiting and grinding to get. The only people that can ever afford to do that are the large regiments who will rarely use their toys anyway because they're so expensive that they can't afford to lose them. 

Not to mention, a lot of interesting vehicles or resources are blocked behind facilities. Which suck.

There are facilities that offer public resources out and are willing to help you with what you want. Can you find them though? There's literally no way to know if a facility is public, what it does, or who runs it unless you happen to walk into it and find someone in there. Most of the time, their someone in a regiment who treats all randoms with suspicion and will try their best to get you out of there. 

The communication tools are maybe one step above barebones. You have map posts which easily disappear or a world chat that offers nothing of value 99% of the time. That's it.  

The core gameplay is terrible, and is missing so many quality of life features that the community has been asking for for years. 

The worst part of it all is the developers. These are some of the most out of touch, slow paced, and uncommunicative developers for any game I have ever seen.  Developer interaction with the community is almost zero. Developers listening to feedback from veteran players who've played the game for years? Also zero.

They come out of complete silence after several months, announce some content that they've put a miniscule amount of thought into, then go back to ignoring everyone and every thing. The content is admittedly impressive and looks shiny and interesting when they reveal it. But in practice ends up being locked away from the vast majority of people and is often even grindier than the last peace of poorly thought out content they made. They will add more and more content that is completely unfun, poorly thought out, and broken instead of trying to polish what there is. 

You will get no quality of life features, the enjoyment of this game is all down to the players and how willing they are to deal with your early game questions. The tutorial of the game is downright awful, and hasn't been touched in the slightest in years. It's literally missing content from several major updates. 

I desperately want to like foxhole, hence my playtime, but the game is missing so many tools, so much polish, and so many little fixes or tweaks that it just feels terrible to play. 

Please do not buy this game. The developers have only made it worse overtime and refuse to listen, interact, or even acknowledge the complaints that much of the community has.

Post full release edit: Even more amazing than I could have ever dreamed. A massive world with an active war happening that alters the landscape. You will drive miles of road passing grass by. You will run hundreds of yards charging to your death on a front line bullets whizzing past. You will fire thousands of rounds from rifles machine guns and machines of war. You will catch a non-zero amount of artillery shells on your head. You will smash a hammer into a blue outline more times than you ever expected to. And most importantly, you will find yourself having fun even as you witness the scorched earth your artillery fire left behind. even as you wake in the morning to find your stockpiles destroyed. Even as you carry your friends screaming for a medic. There is no other game quite like this. A great war simulator.

Gigantic battles are awesome. This game fits many genre's: Builder, Craft system, combat, logistic/driving, strategy, RTS, open world, sandbox. All the things. I really enjoy the chill builder vibe when you are constructing stuff behind the front line, then changing it up and running into the heat of battle just a km away. There are many many items all with their own uses/ purposes. Everything is player built, giving a purpose to people that just want to craft bunkers and foxholes. Ammo, weapons, medical and all building resources are created by players who farm resources in each zone. Those resources and equipment are moved across the world by players driving trucks, trains and ships. 

This game has some bugs but in the 70 hours i have played they are few and far between. My main issue is with the aiming system which is a bit finicky. I'd like to see improvements in the organization of squads and regiments, with ways to issue orders from high command to individual units. I also think underground bunkers and tunnels could be a cool addition. Maybe we'll see those kinds of updates eventually. 

Overall this a very entertaining game with lots of room for meta and replay ability. 9 out of 10.

I say good
Every few weeks it cycles and resets the persistent map when one side wins though, and late-stage war seems like an impossible tank slog. One thing I don't like: all the man-portable AT involves either the RNG-based Armor Penetration Chance system or the RNG-based getting close enough system. And none of the successful hits can involve instant tank crippling to the point that you're safe from the return fire.

90% of the game systems are intuitive but extremely arcanely built and unexplained. Tutorial Island doesn't let you play with all the parts of the game, nor does it leave you tanks and boats to learn how those work (the thing killing you most often while learning the game) I believe it's possible to assemble them on Tutorial Island but you would have to craft it manually. You know, the thing where immense legions of Chinese and Russian gamers have literal human 24:00:00 days of crafting queue time to get the resources for. 

Fast tracked education tidbits for new players:
There is PvE in the form of bunkers built by other players that auto-shoot you if they're within range of an upgraded enemy spawn base, and you can shoot them with a lot of bullets to suppress them
All weapons have damage spread (for some reason) so if you died in one shot there was an element of dice
BB is short for bunker base, which you must manually set your spawn at when you get to. It's the FOB of this game, since the actual FOB structure is a direct downgrade to the bunker base.
Run directly at the nearest player with a rank next to their name and ask questions with your mic to learn everything. They will see you have no rank next to your name and immediately know how to help you - which could mean pointing you at the higher ranked guy.
The fandom wiki (unsurprisingly) is full of holes, but helps you learn old game systems like what it takes to make a jeep. Spoiler alert it's 200 components.
Set your mic input volume to 50% and go up or down from there depending on what people around you say about it.

Unfortunately logi is not very fun.

The way you do logi is bonking salvage nodes and filling up material containers or trucks. But that process takes a long while each trip and it's very mindnumbingly monotonous. I tend to do solo logi, which I focus on stocking up the local refinery with bmats and emats..

Don't get me started on fuel trucks. You can only pull 3 cans max at a time and a singular fuel truck can fit 200 bloody cans. Game's been out since 2017 but there still isn't a button to auto fill instead of wasting my time having to shift click every 10 seconds or so. (Do correct me if the pull time is wrong)

Some will say "why don't you make your own fuel then to pull out faster?".
Problem is refineries tend to accumulate fuel cans that number in the thousands. Seeing over 6k cans in refinery isn't rare and no one is going to bother pulling it due to having to pull it all yourself without respite. That isn't gameplay that's wasting someone's time.

As far as I've seen they want to make logi more clan reliant. Have people scroop for salvage, have some others ship them or truck them to refineries. Other people use the products from the refinery in factories and then move the complete product over to their clan stockpile or to a frontline BB.

Problem is that really screws over people doing solo logi. Even with a flatbed it can only carry 5k salvage which isn't much in the grand scheme of things. You have to go back and forth every single time and you only make about 2.5k bmats per trip. Not all that much considering that thousands can get used up on frontlines on an hourly basis or so. It also doesn't help that the distance between refineries and factories are soo bloody unnecessarily long. Sometimes you have to go to a whole different hex on the map just to get your salvage to a refinery.

Best town I ever did solo logi in was Ogmaran (Before the devs fucked it over so hard that only the seaport or a garage or was it a different thing?). 

I liked Ogmaran because it had a high number of resource nodes in 1 hex, it always had a nice ratio of salvage:components fields.
It had 1 refinery, 2 factories, 1 mass production factory, a garage and a thing where you built those immovable machine guns/AT guns unless you had a crane.

Even though trucking stuff from the nearby fields to the refinery took a bit longer that I would have liked, I still enjoyed it as I didn't have to through very awkward routes to get there. 

Ogmaran was easy to deal with for solo logi and was also the first logi town I was in when I first started playing, now it is a husk of what it once was unfortunately.

Now yes, I can just ignore logi entirely and focus on the fighting aspect. But that's like ignoring an entirely crucial mechanic in a game. Without logi, people would have to walk all the way to the frontline armed with  only pistols.

(What else would you be interested in having a tad more elaboration in if I might be able to help)



14/2/2023
In the last part of my review I rambled on about something that was not important in the review. I am also redoing this as certain things have changed.

So I still do not recommend this game unless you feel joy from not feeling like anything is an achievement. There are "alts" which are people that join team to sabotage it to help the other, it's like if teamkilling had no repercussions on the perpetrator. However these alts can destroy hours upon hours of work with next to no consequences for their actions AND THEY KNOW IT. There is zero moderation at all in this game.

 Even if someone were mass reported for an allegation with video proof, nothing is done to ban them permanently. They just get maybe a week ban at most and then they can just get back right to destroying people's hard work. Sometimes they're not even doing it to help the other side, they just like seeing people' reactions and they know nothing permanent will be dealt unto them. This problem is rather far more worse than a blatant hacker as I don't even know of any alts that have been banned permanently.

The utter lack of moderation has caused a noticeable number of the community to be very paranoid about alts. Some fears were founded, but most of the time it just ended up being a newbie being accused of just having no clue what to do and not do. A worser case of this is a streamer that accused a new player whose only sin was trying to build a Bunker Base (think of a base with defenses or small drop off points) and not knowing how to do it because the in-game tutorial is shit and you only figure out from another player telling you about it, you can search for the video if you want but I won't link it because no need for more fuel to the fire.

Facilities, my my.
The devs really would like you to believe that Foxhole is definitely a 1.0 full release game (no bug guaranteed), yet still multiple glitches persist and balancing choices that seem to entirely ignore any of the feedback from the community. They used to do QnA sessions with questions from the community, now they don't anymore and are already making a new game. 

So to actually talk about facilities, they are painful and I have never felt like it was an achievement or it was satisfying to "engage" with. Trying to deal with the bullshittery of the devs telling us to use facilities but putting heavy maintenance costs on them if you think of building anything bigger to build trains and the like while having defences because "too much strain on servers". Why add facilities to the game if you are going to limit us because the game can't handle it? 

The introduction of facilities also marks the dreaded vehicle variants. If you look at the vehicle roster of Foxhole, you'll see quite a decent amount of vehicle types. However they have locked all but the "base" vehicles from being built in the vehicle garage. Now these variants require a facility vehicle pad in that's also upgraded with the right upgrade to built the variant you want. However, there is no easy way to tell where the right vehicle pad exists if you are a person going solo (with other random/friends in a tank). So you have to ask in game chat if there is a vehicle pad available for X vehicle, in-game map is useless in conveying any useful information of that type.

Another thing, facilities really kill off randoms joining together to supply things. Logistics is of great importance in Foxhole, and a decent chunk of it is just random players sending supplies to whatever front need it. With facilities though, there is no way for randoms  to be able to help with running other players facilties on and off short of joining the group that owns the facility. In-game coordination tools are horrid, even the devs tell us to use Discord for better communication. I don't mean joining squads in Foxhole, I mean one-off communications with people you probably aren't going to see again coordinating just for the 1-4 hours you happen to play together with that isn't being right next to eachother.

The in-game "tutorial" is still a joke, if I didn't get abducted by a random dude on spawn island wrangling up newbies to teach, I would have refunded the game before it even hit an hour of playtime.

The game has so much potential being a one of a kind where you won't get large clans being the strongest by virtue of hoarding shit since time began. Sure there are still clans that hoard supplies en masse, but it ain't like EVE where you gotta play for 2 years before you can join an existing group. And with the end of a war comes with the GREAT RESET, where the technology tree randomizes and resets captured territory reverting to starting war state and we get to do it all over again.



TLDR; Devs don't even communicate at all with the community nor even tell us why they don't communicate anymore while implementing balance changes no one asked for certain things.

10/10 would have truck ran over again.

This game at a base level is pick side, don't die, be racist to other guys, don't die, shoot gun, don't die, make shirts, don't die, walk to frontline, don't die.

There is a lot more to this game however. You have logistics which can be different. You could either collect scrap to make items, you can run supplies to backline bases to keep them from decaying, or you could run supplies to the frontline to keep everyone stocked and able to keep pushing forward.

If you want to frontline you can either use basic gun and shoot the other people, you could be a medic running around healing your team and reviving fallen soldier, you could man a tank or artillery and start shelling the enemies making their defence harder, you could grab a hammer, shovel and some building materials and help make the frontline base stronger to repel attacks.

If none of that sounds interesting you could go into the enemies backline with some others and sabotage their supply lines, destroy their supply hubs to reduce their production, or try to steal some enemy tanks and cause some havoc before you get taken out.

There is probably more to do but that is all I have done and enjoyed. 

And yes, some reviews say the community and devs aren't the best. But from my entire time playing I haven't experience anything like that yet. Most people in the community are just having a good time trying to win a virtual war over the course of days, weeks or even months.

So with a bit of more time and a tad bit of On off playing with this I have found the wonders of Logistics that joy of watching that thing you worked to build get blown up and the joy of Yeeting Arti shells at other peoples bunkers and that anyone who throws a Gas Grenades really should be charged with war crimes,

it does take a bit to get used to thing and learning how and what can take some time but can be worth it,

i would recommend you find people and if you have a Mic start talking they will help you,

Still i vote to shotgun everyone with Gas Grenades outright, something something check list,

Foxhole is a rough jewel, a unique and interesting game concept with complex mechanics where a player will find they can do nearly everything in this sandbox military game. From logistics to combat, stopping by to transport and build defensive structures to support your faction assets, you can find a lot of different kind of gameplay.

In this game a player is but one cog in the great war machine, for better, or worse.

And after having played for few years, in the current state I can only say it is for worse.
The game albeit interesting in its asymmetric warfare system, suffer great imbalance from one update to another, for one faction to another. It has always been the case so far, but it became an even worse issue when the content added brought so much length to each war and grindiness in the game.

It sorely lacks quality of life tools, and when the grind is so bad, - even worse since the addition in 1.0, the game become painful. Player base tire and population vary so much in a single war due to burnouts that it worsens the imbalance. 
Hours and hours of work can literally burn in mere minutes, you won't even get the rewarding feeling that "it held well even it fell" because... well no one was there to defend, and the IA defences can't do much against PVE. There is nothing rewarding in that.

Developer do not moderate (or there is so very few things done that it make no difference). There is no anti cheat, no actions against abuse. There is no proper voice moderation nor text chat regulation. Nothing against bots, nor against alting, and griefing is only punished by "player justice", whether it is justified or not.

I sincerelly hope that the game evolve in a better direction and that I can change this review to something more positive.

EDIT Some  issues were adressed, some fix were found. We're not there yet but hope it's going in the right direction.
The concept is cool, but the combat is dreadful. I rather play a 1st person shooter.

I've only played in one war, so my review is purely based on a fresh persons view on the game.  The game overall I think has a lot of potential and can be a very fun game at times, the sandbox aspect of the game and thousands of players working together to fight/build/run logistics to the frontline is such a great concept to the game.  However there are some major flaws that cause the game to have issues:

1- Clans and groups taking control of major resources and hoarding them, or preventing people from using them for other uses causes major issues and limits other players to enjoy the game.  This issue actually occurred to me my first week of playing, as I was looking to get some components and after harvesting a good number I had also gotten some broken ones, so I went to the groups facility (Who even put a sign saying will trade broken for fixed comps) and did the math and took them from the PUBLIC facility.  As I was leaving I was then shot by the group accusing me of stealing.

2 -  Server issues caused quite a number of big issues during the war, causing rollbacks to happen in which concrete bases (which are the toughest available) were reset after being destroyed multiple times for Wardens.  Not only that, the Colonials had an issue with their login servers to where they could not get into the game, and losing a zone because the Wardens could join in and push through without any issues.

This may be pure speculation, but based off the things that have happened this war, I can only help get the feeling that there is some biased hotfixes and rollbacks that only seem to favor one side.  The wardens had multiple tanks stolen recently after a server crash, and immediately the developers rolled back the server, restricted Colonials to get in the server around that area, and moved the tanks back towards the Wardens.  After that a hotfix was made to restrict tanks being taken after a server crash.  However as I previously stated the entire Colonial army could not login to a zone to try and push back an assault, but nothing was rolled back in that instance.

Will I still play this game?  Of course.  Even with the issues that have came up, I still managed to have a fun time doing it all from frontline combat, to logistics, to just harvesting resources.
This is the perfect hybrid of Factorio, Euro Truck Simulator and Hell Let Loose.

EDIT: OK after trolling grown american men to tears, i will say that this has gone from a 1/10 to a 3/10.

It's an MMO and can be a time suck like any other MMO. There's a lot of different facets to this game. As a solo individual you have the opportunity to fight on the front lines all the way to mining the materials used to support those on the front. Grab a truck and move much needed supplies to where they're needed. 

The game is definitely best experienced with a group. This gives the support needed to run larger production facilities and coordinate larger combat operations with larger equipment.

It can be enjoyed as a solo player and while playing in a group. There's a ton to learn though, so don't get overwhelmed in the start. In the least, grab a bolt action rifle, 2 magazines of ammo, and find a trench at the front.

The report system is abused to the point where it's not even a helpful implementation to the game at all.

Here's a personal example:
I'm running logi and dropping off some supplies at a dockyard with my tanker ship. Clan comes up to me and starts cussing at me to move my ship because I'm blocking the deployment area. Instead of waiting for the few minutes it takes for me to submit all of my supplies and leave, they shoot at my tanker and then mass report me, which results in me getting banned in seconds.

The worst part is that there isn't even any kind of support for this widespread issue (just look at most of the negative reviews, it's almost the same story every single time). When I tried to inquire about it on the Discord, I was just straight up banned for no reason. What kind of moderation team enforces rule breaking?

The game in itself is fun, but the community is absolutely awful, especially the large clans who will just claim everything as theirs and just steal it from you.

Getting banned isn't even the worst part; the game displays your infractions publicly, which leads to getting mass reported for "alting" and getting another ban.

In summary, unless you're cannon fodder for the larger clans you're going to end up getting ostracized from the community with no way to defend yourself from frequent bans and harassment.

Ok, so this is my first ever review, I'm not the best at writing so bear with me.

Foxhole is a supremely unique game, allowing you to contribute to multiple wars in the game. Every person you see running around is a player and they all have their jobs and things they need to do. I highly recommend that you work together with other players by joining one of the many clans within the game or get some friends to join you. There's so much you can do in this game. Whether it's getting materials to make supplies for the frontlines, or be at the frontlines in combat with the enemy, or healing the wounded and getting them back in combat. Foxhole's greatest feat is allowing you to choose what role you want. You're not forced into any role you don't want to be apart of.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]Foxhole gives their players a choice of what they want to do and how they contribute to the war, which is more than most games give, especially how many roles you can play as in Foxhole.

[*]Foxhole gives you a choice of what faction you like to join and every faction has different weapons as well as vehicles you can choose from. 

[*]Any amount of cooperation with other players can change the tied of the battlefield. If you enjoy playing with other players and teamwork you would enjoy this.

[*]Foxhole's price is perfect for early access and for what it gives you. I never had any issues with the price, at least to me anyway.

[*]If you like lore, Foxhole has a massive amount of unexplored lore that the devs placed in wanting players to find. They also have a wiki talking about the lore and factions about Foxhole. So if you like having a background story during the wars this is also a fun thing they have.

[*]One last pro is the community is awesome, there's so much that the community does and makes up, yes it's a bit toxic here and there but in the end, the community is pretty cool and the devs are giving out some awesome upcoming updates.
[/list]
[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]Foxhole is a game that requires a massive amount of cooperation. I know I said this is a pro but to people who like to work alone this is a massive con. You can't do much on your own. All you can do on your own is send supplies to the front and just be 1 guy on the front but you'll end up dying more than anything.

[*]Foxhole is still in early access so there's still a bunch of bugs here and there, but I wouldn't let it ruin your experience being in a war-torn world.

[*]In Foxhole, there are sometimes massive queues in certain regions, so much that sometimes you'll be waiting for 10-15 minutes to get into it, there are ways around it but still a massive issue if Foxhole continues to grow. Queues happen when there are more members of a faction than the enemy side. It happens due to the server size as well. Only handing a certain amount of players.

[*]Another con to Foxhole is how you rank up, there's a commends system. So basically with what you do and how you do in the war, some other players will commend you which you need a certain amount to get a rank up. This is a very long process, so if people play this casually don't expect to get ranked up fast with this system. Some people will even ignore you if your rank is too small. When I was a Corporal in-game I was telling a 2ndLt and some other people that we were getting flanked but they refused to listen to me due to my low rank and they ended up getting flanked and killed by the enemy. Some people can be ignorant when it comes to those things.
[/list]

[b]Overall[/b], Foxhole is a fantastic game that gives you so many possibilities and roles you can be, especially with every new update the devs do that makes Foxhole so much more interesting. With the cooperation of other players, you can do anything to change the tide of the war. I highly recommend you try this game and if you don't like it you can always refund, but give it a chance, also try joining one of the many clans to get the full war experience Foxhole can truly be.

[b]Edit/Note[/b], New things are being added every season, so there's so much to look forward to in Foxhole. Best of all, the Community recommends things and the devs listen. - Edit Naval Update was added and brought me back to it a bit, Always loved Naval combat and beach landing in Foxhole, now even more it's possible to hit your targets by using battleships. Highly recommended

In Foxhole, there are many occupations you can pick. Be it a logistical driver in the back lines making guns and artillery shells or a medic trying to heal the wounded of the front line; each has its costs and its benefits. This game is relatively easy to get into, as it is often or not obvious where the front line is, thanks to the in-game map. Just spawn, press E, grab a gun, two mags, and a bandage, and you are off to the races. However, if you are not a fan of being a common (often disposable) grunt, you may not like frontline combat. 

Some of the good factors I found while playing in the last three wars.

1: Every day is an adventure. You will most likely do something new and meet new people every time you log on and go to a front.

2: The audio design is very good. Despite the camera being the way it is, guns feel unique and memorable. 

3: Plenty of jobs that you can pick from and get good at

4:  A job for anyone, and often any mood. If you want to fight in the frontline, go for it. Do you want to build Verdun? Go for it. Do you want to be a tanker? Go for it.

5: The lore (despite being a mess at times) is very cool, and you can find yourself immersed by your sides traditions. Like the Wardens (Also known as blueberries) often say, "Praise Calahan." 

There is plenty more probably that I can't think of right now.

Some negatives about the game:

1: The map is constant. There is little to no change to it, and eventually, you will see it all. Of course, there are unique landmarks and towns, but eventually, you will probably see it all, and I have not seen much change.

2: The war is constant, which means you build a base that needs defenders due to a lack of AI defence. And players don't spawn at your base to help you; chances are the nighttime players (Often Asain and European) will steamroll the base.  This also connects to my next point.

3:  Player count for each side can quickly become unequal and can stay like that, which means that you are often outproduced, out teched, and outnumbered in these situations because the other team simply has the manpower to do things. It can be rather demoralizing.

Apart from all this, I would rebuy it and recommend it to just about anyone. ( Updated ) (EDIT FOR 2023 game reward)

Amazing war simulation from sky view, it is very innovative, how you control and see everything around you, still works well. Also you don't need to grind for levels or loot for items to feel you can fight, you can just grab a weapon from the storage, and you can hop into the fight on the front line.
You feel there is not enough weapons or bandages on the front? You can make everything by yourself starting from the basic material you can collect on the field, then you can bring it by truck to the factory, where you can make weapons or other things from it. Then you can bring these to the frontline to help your soldiers!
You have much freedom, what roles you want to play in this game, be friendly and try to learn from the experienced players. Feel free to ask for help in chat and join teams to make the war effort greater, but you can always make difference alone, even if you don't feel so your help matter, however sometimes the weapons and aid you bring to the frontline bunker can arrive at crucial point of the fight on the part of the front! So every soldier can make a difference in this big battle!

i love the concept of this game but unfortunately Siege camp is not capable of providing this games true potential. the game suffers from problems with balancing that can cause bias to one side then over correct to the other. the devs are silent most of the time and it gets frustrating when a major issue is revealed and there is no mention from them. the game deserves a better engine and server to alleviate issues regarding region queues. i want to play on a front line and find that every frontline region has a 10 man queue it really discourages me to play sometimes. i dont believe the Alt problem to be as large as what others claim and i feel the community unintentionally chases off new players because they accuse them of being alts. there is little to no moderation in game and cheaters i feel are a larger problem than alts. another unfortunate fact is the only community where the devs dont have a say in whats posted is the steam reviews as they delete and ban people that point out issues claiming its "witch hunting" when sometimes someone who is actually witch hunting gets off no problem because they are a popular streamer. there are some serious QOL issues that are present but they are the result of building on old foundations. what the devs really need to do is tear down the logistics and building systems and rebuild them from scratch. the 1.0 update was riddled with issues and oversights and then when they tried to fix some balance issues they made the almost everything they added in useless. its an absolute shame the only other game that is like this is WW2 online but that is extremely out dated when you look at it and is also subscription based. 

TLDR i love the game but issues due to devs have made the game not fun.

UPDATE: dev communication is better now but still needs improvement and they still suffer from "pre nerfing" new things that they fear will be too good to the point they become unusable at launch like the submarine

Too slowly the devs will adapt to the playerbase while still ignoring several bugs.

6/14/2022: New review, but still the same old. If I thought the game was buggy before, it is a lot worse now. Lag is crazy from squads lists, to massive bunker bases, to just poor optimization of certain functions in the game. The land is still littered with rocks that you can't climb, blackholes from trenches, or trying to climb out of trenches being buggy unless you find the "sweetspot". QoL is awful for players unless you just pop in for an hour to play infantry on a frontline IF you can get through the queues. The devs have done a great job with such a small group to add so much to a game like this, but it feels like they are trying to rush to 1.0 and just leaving so many things broken to fix later if they do. Many things have been broken since I first played. It's just scummy in my eyes to ignore so many bugs and continually creating new bugs with new things being added and expecting the playerbase to just truck through it. This game solely relies on the player base to even function in the first place, and its the reason many players quit or take month long breaks from the game. I'll end off with saying at the current state I would rather play a different game to waste hours of my day and time to lose to alts or a volatile front in 30 minutes or go back to previous versions of this game.

11/20/2023: The game is still exactly in the same state it was over a year ago. Sure flashy new updates come and bring in a influx of new players who leave after a few wars and the population is back to the same usual number and devs do nothing for the ones that commit their time to the game. The newest naval update was a great concept and long awaited, but this update war has by far been THE worst war i've been involved in. the home region of all places being unable to get to from the world conquest, several regions crashing consistently, the ships introduced acting like floating fridges on water with how bad the handling is unless you use blueprint turn, creating a terrible asymmetric gunboat, and the drama from their flawed input of the next logi grind of rare metals. I come back every few wars and check in to see if they ever fix the things that are broken, but never do. The community is even more toxic than before from reddit to discord to in-game to faction specific streamers. The developers used to have very consistent updates letting the community know what was going on and created fun events to break up the monotonous of the wars. Dead Harvest and relic wars were great. The devs say they dont want any monetization in-game, but focus more on flashy new toys and a new art for foxhole store page to bring in new players, but wont improve the QOL in the game.

Overall, the point of my original review still stands: The dev communication, while better, still struggles in ways from lack of a dedicated CM. Decisions seem impulsive and whimsical.

The game struggles with server issues due to population in any major update, bringing to question whether the devs can actually pay for the servers or deliver a game that is capable of living up to the Vision‚Ñ¢ or the supposed max player count. When there is an issue, the servers frequently fail to enter their recovery mode correctly, leading to unfair outcomes. And then if the devs intervene, because they have no clear or stated policy, that likewise ends up looking unfair.

Notable balance issues can go unaddressed for long periods of time as the devs insist on keeping balance tied to milestones in a roadmap rather than using incremental balancing common to modern PvP games (keeping in mind the average war length these days is well over a month). This, in combination with the questionable communication, leads to periods in the game where one faction or the other perceives the game/devs as biased.

The lack of good CM also means that the community is still one of the most hyperpartisan battlegrounds you'll encounter outside of American Twitter.

Oh, and a good chunk of the game is still a Sisyphean chore.

Don't let the negative reviews get to you. This game is an addicting time machine. The combat is really fun, logistics is relaxing, facilities, and so much more! 

Steep learning curve and barely any tutorial. Just explore the starting island, look at your keybind settings to see which keys do what, and when you feel like you got the hang of the firing range and the driving range, deploy into an active front line and try your best!

There are many players who will take the time to help you and answer any questions you have. Community is a strong component in this game. Everyone is constantly relying on voice chat to coordinate on the battlefield, which always leads to entertaining and spontaneous banter. 

If you give Foxhole the time and attention it deserves, you will find it is a fantastic MMO and well worth picking up.

Foxhole. This game is good in concept. Bad in execution. Let me start with your time.

So, I just had a blast, I was in a tank, killing the enemy, running around killing partisans, ran out of fuel, got some more, killed more partisans, enemy was attacking and pushing beyond the bridge, I swung around with my buddy and we murdered them all and got our allies back up onto the bridge before they could counter us with AT. Waited a while for some enemy to show up, then found some and attacked them, then went back to waiting. Eventually we REALLY ran out of fuel and had to head home. 

I wanted to keep the tank. 

I'm in a clan so I went to a storage depot to return the tank and keep it for later. This is where the problems began. 

I went to the nearest storage depot a sector away, ok, and tried inputting my tank to save it for later. It tells me I need to repair the armour. Ok fine. The nearest garage is 2 Sectors away.  Full server changing map sectors. Ok fine.. I'll drive there. I found some fuel along the way. So I drive, and drive, and finally get to the garage. Then the garage tells me, I need 100 bmats to repair the armour. ....Okay Fine... Where are bmats? Scrounge around for these damn bmats and finally repair the tank, refuel and then take it to the nearest storage depot. 3 sectors away from where I want the tank to be when I play again tomorrow. 


This, why do I have to go through all of this just to keep the tank? There are plenty of other situations where it's annoying and tedious on purpose and it doesn't have to be. Sure I get 100 bmats to repair ok. But why aren't there more garages, refineries, etc? It's just wasting my god damned time.

Foxhole is a social game for Germans men. ( I have yet to encounter a single person of the opposite sex )
To have fun: Have a microphone, join the game, join a regiment, join their communication platform (usually just discord server), see what operations they run, and attend.
Don't know how something works? 
Don't do the (in-game) tutorial, literally ask ANYONE in voice chat (preferably) , or text chat for a tutorial and they will probably give help you in the nicest way possible.
An important thing to remember is that you are a cog in a the machine. You alone will probably not make much of a difference. But as a collective you will.

That said I don't recommend it because the developers put too man menial tasks with timers in the game, for example;
Want to refuel a fuel container? You'll be wasting 2 minutes of your life clicking a icon. That sounds menial but these interactions add up to be a colossal waste of time... waiting.
The loading, of retrieval of items discourages trolls from taking every thing from a base and dumping it into the ocean.
However, it also means that you'll be doing a lot of waiting. If I were immortal I would not mind, but my time in this body of flesh and bone is limited. And not valued enough by the developers that I can recommend the game.

I first got this game because it seem to have a lot of gameplay aspects that I liked, and that were pretty unique. I liked the gritty feeling to it, the unique perspective and system of shooting, and the idea that is was a constant, live world war with players all around the world. Plus, the game had pretty good specs and ran mostly fine. The graphics are really good and I like the art style.

For those not interested in reading my entire thesis, here are the bullet points for why I wouldn't recommend this games:
[list]
[*] Foxhole is highly social. You will not get the most out of it without a mic and discord server with friends or a 'regiment'. Most vehicles require multiple people cooperating and communicating in order to use them. This isn't why I'm not recommending the game, I'm just putting this here to warn others like myself who thought they can play this solo/casually.
[*] Total lack of QoL features. Doing even the simplest things in the game requires an excessive micromanagement, mouse clicking and keyboard pressing. 
[*] Time is wasted liberally in this game. Logistics is a constant, tedious grind, all so OTHER players can have fun. Lack of QoL features also wastes time. If you have a job or an actual life, then forget about it, because playing this game is basically a second job.
[*] The game makes you feel guilty for playing it. Since every weapon, magazine, tank etc is made and delivered to bases by players, wasting these materials is bad. Knowing how awful logistics is, you basically avoid using anything more advanced than a rifle in fear of losing that weapon and thus wasting another player's time.
[*] Occasionally the playerbase is toxic and takes the game far more seriously than they should.
[*] The game has a research system. When a war starts, 90% of the equipment in the game will be flat out unavailable anyway, regardless of whether you have the materials to produce them. You have to rely on logistics players to deliver aluminum to engineering facilities to advance the research for your faction. This takes IRL days, so you're stuck with your basic rifle anyway.
[/list]
Below I'll expand on this points in more detail.

As I said, the game is highly social. If you don't have a mic and were thinking of playing Foxhole casually/solo, say after work at the end of the day, then this isn't a game for you at all. This is a hardcore game and will take hours of your times just to do very little in the grand scheme of things, and to get the most out of it, a mic is the minimum requirement. I'd also recommend joining a regiment. Most of the game will simply not be workable otherwise.

That was a bit of a bummer, since I don't have a mic and don't intend on getting one, but what really killed my joy for the game is the total lack of QoL features, and the fact that the developers seem focused on expanding the boring aspects of game as much as possible while minimising the fun parts.

In any other game, when you spawn in, you automatically have the weapons and kit you need. In this game, you have to spawn in a rear base, travel for five minutes (usually on foot) to a forward base (closer to actual combat), manually set your respawn so that in the VERY likely scenario that you die in combat, you won't respawn again in the rear base. Then you have to manually go into the base's inventory/stockpile and equip a rifle and some magazines. You almost always equip just basic stuff, because people die so often in this game that if you want to use anything more complex, you have to be 100% sure you can use it effectively, otherwise when you die that weapon is likely lost. That's IF you equip anything, btw, because people die so often that it's often encouraged to just navigate your way to the active warzone and loot the gun and the appropriate magazines from the bodies littering the ground (while dodging bullets). I'm not going to lie, that part is actually kind of fun, but sometimes you just want to get into the game and shoot stuff without all that time wasting time scavenging off bodies.

You COULD grab the SMGs/RPGs/Tanks/etc if you want, but unless you're very experienced, you're probably just going to waste it by dying immediately. Thus, the game makes you feel guilty for doing basically anything fun or unique in the game, because all the equipment/resources are extract/refined/manufactured/delivered by players. That's ignoring the fact that often groups of players will claim ownership over resources/equipment, so that you can't use them even if they're publicly available. If you try to, you'll be team killed.

Plus, the inventory and equipping system is janky. Say you have already set your spawn in a forward base and you've just been killed. When you respawn you have nothing but a pistol, so you have to manually access the base's inventory, grab a rifle and magazines (which isn't instant btw, it takes "assembly time"). Then you have to close the base's stockpile, open your inventory, transfer the rifle from your backpack to your hands, close your inventory, press 1 to equip the rifle, then press R to load it. You have to do this every single time you die (which is a lot). I just wish a rifle and 1 magazine/clip were part of the "soldier supplies" to begin with, and that when I transfer a weapon to my hands from my backpack, the game automatically equips it instead of forcing me to press 1 every time. If you swap a rifle for an SMG, the game automatically unequips you, instead of just keeping you holding whatever is in your main weapon slot. It's janky, unintuitive, tedious, time-wasting and unnecessary.

Another thing, because of the social and hardcore aspect of the game, it tends to attract sweats, tryhards and buzzkills. They take the game far more seriously than it deserves, and so they ruin it for everyone else trying to have fun.

Another thing that I briefly touched on before is that this game will waste hours of your time. Grinding for logistics, delivering supplies to the front, equipping basic weapons to go fight, just to die and wait some more to respawn. This is how logistics goes: once you have made or requisitioned a truck, fuelled it, driven to a scrap yard, bashed the scrap, filled your truck with scrap, drove to a refinery, refined the scrap into usable materials, delivered the materials to a factory, manufactured guns/ammo/whatever, then congratulations! You can now spend the next 30 minutes driving back to the forward base, loading several servers in the process along the way (since the map is so huge that each region is a separate server, so to travel between regions requires loading time), just to deliver a dozen rifles and a handful of bandages that they needed an hour ago, and which someone else has probably done already. That's if there aren't enemy "partisans" (i.e. enemy players in friendly territory) that don't kill you during your journey, thus undoing about an hour of two of progress.

This game is TEDIOUS. Torturously boring. Logistics is so convoluted and dull, that half the game is unplayable except if you're playing a podcast or youtube video in the background, while playing truck driving simulator to the front. It sounds cool and unique on paper, but actually playing it is frighteningly dull. All for what? So you can support OTHER people's fun? To deliver a tiny amount of supplies that probably won't make a difference, since every war lasts about a month?

The game is awesome. If you like building games, crafting games, etc. boom you have such a cool game that gives you meaning to your work. You are helping a war effort that literally makes your team win or lose. 

You prefer a standard shoot em up game? boom! This game has you covered, it's literally the point of being in battles. So two different games blend beautifully together with a theme that makes sense.

Neat game, but the time investment is way too much for someone playing by themselves. You need a group of about 5 players regularly playing to really enjoy much of the game. Building and gathering is extremely time intensive and all of the work that can go into a base of 50 hours building and mantaining can go up in flames very quickly if you don't log in regularly. 

So if you bypass base building and upgrading vehicles you got the combat, which is decent. The combat is a bit simple but due to the sheer amount of equipment from field guns, tanks, and small arms equipment smg, rifles, grenades, and flamethrowers etc you get alot of tactical options. With all those tactical options though, you again need a group to work with, that or rely on the many many random people out doing their own things.

 So you may log into fight a bit and have a very boring stalemate of people running around willy nilly dying one by one with no aim, or you log in seizing ground inch by inch through well coordinated pushes, or better yet blitz the land with a group of people that synergize well and use the gear for awesome combined arms. There is alot going on in this game thanks to all the equipment being player made, but this also hampers the game because you just can't do much without a large group or extremely dedicated small group.

I can't recommend a game like this just due to it being too  unreliable in delivering a fun experience, I don't want to my fun to be completely dependent on many random people and can't force my friends to play a game. Still cool game when all the cogs are running.

P.S sorry to all those I convinced trying this game out
This has become a part time job

To my complaint to the game moderator on team-killing and false-reporting that resulted in my ban from the game, the game moderator's reply in essence was: the appropriate course of action is to hope that other players will join you in vote-kicking the offenders. No apology or direct action taken. I have not touched this game since then. There are friendly and toxic players, but here the toxicity stands out not because of the players but because the developers are the enabler of the toxicity.

There is a legal duty for shop owners to protect their customers. This duty is based on the concept of premises liability, which states that property owners have a responsibility to keep their premises safe for their customers. This means that shop owners must take reasonable steps to prevent injuries to customers on their property. The protection extends to harassment from fellow customers. 

The same legal duty is expected of the owner of this game. While the customers are on the game‚Äôs premises, i.e. the game server space, the customers are expected to be protected by the owner of the game. Unfortunately the owner of the game has failed to take reasonable steps to protect its customers from harassment by other customers while on its premises. Since the owner is a Canadian, all we need is a Canadian customer who was harassed by other customers to file a lawsuit. If the lawsuit succeeds, a class action lawsuit can follow. It would be a public service.
