ABSOLUTE CHEATER RIDDEN GAME!!!  RAMPANT HACKING AND EXPLOITING, DEVS NEVER ADDRESS ALTING ISSUES AND NEVER FIX BUGS.  THEY WILL NEVER EVER BAN HACKERS BUT WILL BAN LOYAL PLAYERS WHO SPEAK POORLY OF THERE GAME.  NO MODERATION AT ALL.  NO COMUNICATION FROM THE DEVS ABOUT BUG FIXES, BUG FIXES NEVER HAPPEN.  ONLY FOCUS IS ON SHINY NEW VEHICLES AND MORE CONTENT THAT ADDS NO REAL VALUE OTHER THAN MORE BUSY WORK FOR THE PLAYERS.   DEVS DO ABSOLUTELY NOTHING TO FIX THERE GAME BUT CONTINUOUSLY ADD MORE UNPLAYABLE END GAME GARBAGE THAT DOESNT WORK HALF THE TIME AND THAT NO ONE CAN EVEN BUILD BECAUSE OF HOW EXPENSIVE AND TIME CONSUMING IT IS. 

JUST TODAY GOT NIGHT FIRE SHOT AND SHOT FROM AN INVISIBLE PERSON WHICH IS NEW. 

Getting Night Fired is basically shot at threw the fog of war where someone shouldnt be able to see you yet because your not in range but they can see further at night using hacks.
Alting is where they make a 2nd account and play on the other faction and just use a radio to sit and get infinite intel about everything.  Then they call out all this info to there regiments and even in world chat to the whole faction.  

Speed Hacking is where they can up there characters move speed
There is also aim hacks ppl have used before
There is hacks that allow your tanks to shoot faster basically increasing the speed of the reload timer.
All of these cheats have been documented by streams through clips and videos.  The people in these clips still play the game. 

I saw discord message leaks of people admitting to hacking and cheating then i literally saw the people from those messages in game the very next day still playing.  I saw someone who stream sniped Summit when he played using alted info to guide summit around defenses.  Without Summit knowing this obviously.  Person still plays the game.  Then a year later he was still playing.  This same person then went to someones twitch chat who was griefing the colonials vehicles by throwing them into the water and they told them where to go to grief and who to grief and encouraged them to do this.  That person still plays the game.  All these instances where there is hard evidence of people hacking, cheating, exploiting and alting. 
 These people STILL DONT GET BANNED.  

It doesnt matter how much evidence you have it will not change anything.
Constantly getting stuck in terrain, constant lag due to poor optimization,  No balance whatsover,  Dev's will roll back servers for one faction.  The Cheating/Alting/Hacking has been happening for years constantly with no mention to stop or try to prevent it.  No ban waves,  And even when people do get banned they make another alt instantly for 3 dollars and continue to cheat and hack.  There main will never get banned.  Players are expected to moderate the game yet can abuse this by mass reporting and banning innocent players.  Everything is Clunky and unoptimized.  Lag in regions that have a lot of bases/concrete.  Combat is just bad, prone = invulnerable, trenches = invulnerable.  People Glitching into mountains to be invulnerable.  Can't climb out of dead concrete bases.  You will lag backwards 5 seconds and get hit by a bullet even know your behind cover,  You will get stuck in literally anything and everything.  You can get stuck under a trench in water and drown.  half the time you cannot climb outta trenches in general.  


Rain encumbrance is a dog water mechanic but supposed to be colonial advantage.  Oil coats do nothing. Tiny row boat being able to block a massive barge or large boat.  character not being able to swim more than 5 feet without drowning.  Bridge battles... being absolutely the worst part of any front.  Border Bases being horribly designed and never mentioned for years and years.  Border bases giving free mats because why?  I mean there's so much wrong with this game you literally couldnt fit it into 1 single post.  The only Thing that makes up for a lot of these flaws is the fact that there's no other game with the depth of logi.  But most of Logi is just plain and simple busy work that is mindless and boring.  Something to do while watching TV or listening to music,  Why play something just to be doing something else while playing.  Most ppl will say doing logi is like a second job because its something that has to be done but no one really wants to do it.  It's interesting to provide stuff for the war effort but not to swing a hammer for 8 hours straight at nodes.  These devs have had so many opportunities to turn this into a successful game but they squandor it adding more busy work for the players and providing no new player experience or retention while also letting the cheaters ruin everything.  

Then going a step further and actively helping one faction during the war.  The Bias is obvious and has been for a very long time but the real problem is they  let hackers and alts run rampant with no repercussions forever without care.  People who are holding out hope just don't, they will never change because they have had a million opportunities to do so and never have.  They will continue to add more unusable garbage and will not fix or moderate there game.  I come back every now and then to see how the moderation has changed.  I literally get night fired cheated on 4-5 times in my first session back every time as well as seeing speed hacking first day back playing almost every single time i pick the game back up.  It's almost always the same clans and players who just openly exploit/alt/hack every day all day.  They do it because they know they will never get banned.

I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME!  

And if you do play don't expect any cheaters to be banned, expect to face hackers and alts on a regular basis.  If you can look past that then you can have some fun occasionally.  It's to bad devs continue to disappoint and drive players away.

edit 8/12/17

  This game has grown on me more. I have discovered there are solo options , and I have really enjoyed this game so far. Since I have purchased this , I have not played anything else. Very fun and very addicting especially if you commit yourself to 1 war (server) till the finish.

  I was playing the colonials . Built a tank , supplied it , linked up with another tank , recruited a squad of 12 or so infantry , planned an assault over a bridge to take a fortified position. We took the flag , and using the resources the enemy kindly left us there , managed to win the war 2 days later.

This is like many games rolled in to one-- it can be either an intense team battle, or a chill logistics simulator, or a combination of both.  I find it relaxing to chill down with Truck Simulator sometimes, and Foxhole can be the same way.  Except that when you haul a load of goods in Truck Simulator from Flagstaff to Las Vegas, there's no real point to it.  But in Foxhole, you know you're bringing things to the front lines that they need.

Every shell, vehicle, gun, trench, barbed wire, uniform is made by people and brought to the front lines by people.  A lot of interesting game mechanics are at play here.  For example to shoot artillery, you need a couple of people operating the gun to move it, someone outside of the gun with binoculars to see where the enemy is and direct the shots, and someone to load the gun.  You can sort of get away with doing it with 2-3 people instead of 4, and with multiple guns, you might be able to change the balance of who loads things for truly optimal efficiency.

It's also like factory and truck simulator game, in the back lines, as well as trains and freighters in the water.  And it's also possible to infiltrate enemy lines and mess with their logistics.  There are trucks, trains, factories, flatbeds, cranes.

One thing that surprised me is that things like boats, tanks, and planes are far more accessible to a new player than I expected.  The challenge is learning and figuring out how to do it, which is fun in itself.  For example, you might think as I did that something like building a tank is only for people who assemble in a large team and work on it for a long time.  But in truth, you can build a low-end tank yourself in, say, 1 hour.  But for me it took me days of learning and experimentation to figure out how to do that.  The trick is don't try to gather the materials by hand; start by building something else that makes it easier to do the next step.  Similar to how in Ark Survival Evolved building a stone house is a big ordeal, but if you get yourself a wood gatherer and a stone gatherer first it's not such a big deal.

Another thing that really struck me as unusual was the community.  Driving a truck around the back lines, whenever we'd accidentally crash into each other due to high traffic, people would say "oops, sorry" via voice, which is always active by default.  Once when I was in the training ground shooting artillery, there was another guy learning there, and after we missed a shot, he said "Hold on a sec. I need to do some math."  These are not typical gamers.

Rank and promotions are solely a function of how many people click to give you a commendation. Each person is limited to commending someone else a certain number of times per day.  It felt really great to figure out how to do medical and spend some time out there keeping our people going and discovering I'd been promoted at the end of that session.
War. War changes. - Bethesda, maybe.

A unique game, offers a mix of many different things. If anyone's old enough to have played an old f2p game on the "Sony Online" platform called Infantry - the "core" gameplay is similar - You are part of a (very) big faction, fighting over a persistant map. A lot of different equipment can be used, next to a very large selection of vehicles. On top of that, a very complex and complete building and logistics system fuels the whole thing - base building, resource extraction and conversion, actual supply chains complete with transport by land and sea, trucks trains and boats... It's very similar to EVE Online in that aspect too. 
You can play solo or in a clan, both are viable however if you want to really experience the deeper aspects of the game (serious base building, tank warfare, artilery missions or the brand new naval combat) you really should get in a nice clan because these types of resources are not available unless you build them yourself - which you can't do all alone ;)
Free expansions usually add a lot of new features...

Next to the whole gameplay aspect of the game, there's the community - It's also similar to EVE Online, with a lot of "on the spectrum" and general "internet idioicy" all over the place. Imagine vanilla WoW Barrens chat, but multiplied by a ton. Basically if you've grown up with the 90s internet you'll be right at home. If you are a delicate Gen Z flower you'll get instantly offended and go cry to the sky in outrage.

So yeah, definatelly a recommended game! :)

Foxhole is a good game and is worth the price, but it lacks enough components for a solo player or even small groups. 

SOLO:
You are essentially forced to work in a regiment (a clan) to get cool equipment. While it is possible to build stuff as a solo player it will require a chunk of your time. Cooperating is sometimes easy, other times it is difficult as regiments claim 'their stuff' in the form of resource nodes.

GROUP:
The developers have created the logistic and base system to supposedly make the game better, however, in reality it necessitates large clans. The limited number of nodes, combined with the labor required to maintain bases at said nodes, creates a system where large clans dominate: while smaller ones die due to not having the 'fun stuff'.

The developers have ignored players and continue to extend the length of wars and the labor required to develop equipment.

This game is amazing but not for everyone and I can't stress this enough.

THIS IS A HIGH STAKES MULTIPLAYER GAME!

I will try and use this review to drive a point trough that many people might not immediately get when approaching the game for the first time. People discover this game and become enamored by the concept of a massive player driven MMO war, that's what happened the moment I discovered it and I had a blast playing it ever since. BUT! I repeat myself.

THIS IS A HIGH STAKES MULTIPLAYER GAME! 

At first glance this might seem absurd right? This is the game where you play as a single soldier in a massive war, a cog in the machine, your actions are mostly minimal and irrelevant in the grand scheme of things. How could this possibly be a high stakes game? All of those statements are true, however the counterpoint lies in the fact that we are all fighting in a SINGLE month long war, and people REALLY want to win. The stakes become even higher when you consider people are spending hours every day building, gathering resources, planning, training, recruitnig, studying just to get that W. 

This game is not like a single 25 minute match on your average MP game, people really get passionate about their faction and winning the war. This passion is, in my opinion, one of the most amazing and unique aspects of the game, It is the main driver behind the comradery and dedication you will often find on the battlefield. This passion brings out the magic moments of cooperation where hundreds of players organically acomplish something amazing like an epic last stand, an overwhelming offensive or even building a megabase.

But on the flipside, everyone expects you to be a team player. And being a good team player might not seem exactly obvious when you are starting the game. The vast majority of the community is super receptive of new players and someone will almost allways help if you are struggling with any aspect of the game, just ask around in voice or text chat. Does this mean your actions as a single new player actually have a significant impact on the front or even the greater war itself? 

NO!
(99% of the time at least, there are some things you can do that can really screw everyone up, but don't think too hard about that. Just don't build any bridges by yourself and you will be fine.)

Your negative actions or missplays won't cause everyone to lose, but people may call you out on it. Not because you are going to tank the war by yourself, but because you might not know what you are doing. Not knowing obviously does not make you a bad team player. The problem arises when you don't know what you are doing and you don't care. In this case you are not being a team player, and people care about that, players are passionate and they won't be receptive of new players wasting public resources selfishly.

Now, a few ways not to be a bad team player when starting out:
-Be humble and always assume you are ignorant! If you are not sure how something works ask first before wasting public resources !
-If you want to learn a new weapon ask how to use it, don't waste all the public special weapons by dying while brute forcing your learning!
-If you want to drive a tank just ask for a tank crew, don't just drive one by yourself!
-If you want to build a base ask if you are in a good spot!
-Never build bridges without massive infantry and vehicle support behind you.

Fundamentally you will have to understand this is not a game about YOU, In Foxhole we all win together, all the thousands of players on the same faction. This goes for new and old players even some elitist player clans. If you become humble and understand that we are all in this war together, you will experience the joy of being a good team player in an amazing community.

One of those games where the more you play, the worse it seems. Spent 2 weeks making a facility with my buddies, hanging out having a blast. only to have it leveled by a larger regiment. Turns out you can flag buildings for disruptive placement. And if enough people do that. (say a bunch of people working together in a regiment) They can blow it up without it being considered friendly fire. So basically anyone who has more people or is more organized, can just wipe out whoever they want. Team game my ass.

A game that is truly innovative, breaks the mould in a variety of ways; the freedom of player decision is truly amazing and makes for some highly engaging gameplay, from designing/building bases and then defending them from incoming attack to conspiring with other teammates to assault or invade key strategic areas, at the very least pushing your teams front line forward and at most making for truly captivating as your team wrestles with the enemy for tactical advantage in a region, player made clans help to coordinate efforts between clan members and ultimately help the entire team, having to supply forward bases and constant repairing of buildings under fire is a small price to pay for such a great experience. 

Shooting and driving mechanics can be a bit jank at times, but that is a negligible issue for what this game brings to the table. 

The problem lies with the total player control and clans being as big as they are, if you plan to be part of a clan then i assume you'd have little to no issues. However from my experience being a solo player, trying to stay committed to the front or even having fun can be strained when interacting with some clan members. The total power given to players means that some members of clans will act insanely pretentious, and will at best disregard other players thoughts/ideas outright, and at worst you will be tk'd if you are seen to be interfering with their work, even if that isn't the case. From my experience they're no point trying to reason with these individuals as they will simply argue against/disregard your point. 

TL;DR if you're a solo, be prepared to be overworked and underappreciated, while higher ranking, less competent players experience the opposite, just like the real military!

It is very fun.
You can switch your play style however you like.

You wanna have more chill gameplay? Do backline logistics - mine resources, build facilities with your friends, produce everything from bullets and weapons to tank.
You wanna have a bit more thrill? Do frontline logistic - haul produced goods from the backline to the frontline, look which regions is running low on what, check for partisans on your route and weigh your option between the faster or the more secure routes and get celebrated as you bring in the much needed ammo, medical suplies and materials to fix tanks and buildings.
You wanna have action and kill wardens... I mean enemies? Go to the frontlines, fight in the trenches, kill enemy tanks, or man your own tank with friends or random players.
You wanna have even more thrill? Be a partisan - sneak into enemy territory, disrupt their logistics, destroy equipment before it even reaches the frontline, destroy whole production facilities or just sabotage them sneakily and have the enemy look for hours why their production isn't running, because you destroyed one of their power lines.

Now you are wondering: "That sounds like a fun game for everyone - solo players, coop with friends, coop with strangers. Why the negative review?"
Well, let me tell you about alts and cheaters.

First the obvious - there are cheaters out there, which simply circumvent mechanics like limited sight at night, which conveniently lag every time you shoot at them or which are able to fly over or run through structures.
And then there are alts - players who have a second account on the enemy side and use it to grief, spy, give equipment to their side, screw with your fabrication, block logistics by putting stuff in the way or disable your massive defences by parking trucks in front of your automatic guns.

Let me paint a scenario:
You have built a small facility with your friends, gathered resources over multiple days, traded with other groups to finally build a big battle tank. What could go wrong?

Alts taking your resources along every step of the way and just load it into a truck and driving it into a river or into the frontlines.
You would have been okay if the occasional player uses your buildings to refines their resources or even take a bit for their own needs, but now you have to make private stockpiles, lock everything away and start guarding and shooting at your own ppl, because they could be griefers, but often you just kill a curious new player who was exploring.

You dealt with griefers, so what else can hinder you building the beauty of a battle tank and having fun with your friends killing some wardens... I mean enemies?

Well, innocent looking player from your faction with binoculars look at your facility and stalk out where you store your resources, where your important production buildings are, act as if they are newbies and look exactly at how much stuff you have in your stockpiles.
And a few minutes later a single partisan or a group of them sneak along the borders a few hexes into the backlines and make a bee line to your stockpile, destroy it and leave.

So now you build start building defences - place pill boxes that shoot at enemies, build trenches and bunkers, haul tons of resources just for building them and pay their upkeep and shoo away and shoot at every player that comes even near your facility.

Just so you can be finally save and have you facility survive just the last few hours until the battle tank rolls from your assembly pad.. and finally you are done. You see the majestic curves, the smell of fresh oil - there it is. Now you just need to call your friends back from mining resources, put ammo and fuel into it and drive it to the front.

As you do suddenly you notice a hauler parked right in front of your defence. You wrench it open to check which newbie parked it in the most inconvenient place ever and drive it a bit further down the road. But as you enter the truck you hear explosions coming from your facility, you run back and you see a single partisan, which ignored all the overfilled stockpiles and important production buildings and went straight to where your tank was waiting for it's first action since its birth.
And you only see a smoking husk, which just despawns as you arrive. The partisan is quickly dealt with and you can still hear their spiteful laughter as you think about how you have to tell your friends that your weekend of driving you snazzy new battle tank was ruined by a single person with 2 accounts.

Your friends and you are now close to rage-quitting the game, but you decide to give it another try, you schedule your vacation time, use another week to gather the resources and are organising guard shifts among yourselves and finally you are sitting sleep deprived, but happy on your way to the front in your new battle tank "Betty II".
You dodge the conveniently abandoned cars on the road, the 3 ambushes which totally random pop up exactly where you are driving, despite you first driving on smaller not often used roads and then even completely off-road over the ripening fields of corn, seeing the raging farmer in front of your inner eye.

You arrive at the front, talk to other tank crews, are celebrated as the reinforcements everyone was waiting for, form a tank line, barely survives the enemy infantry concentrating their hail of AT-RPGs and anti tank grenades on you and there it is. The sound every tank driver dreads... the ringing of the bell of a bicycle and just as you are pulling back to fix the holes in your formerly pristine battle tank, they park behind you and for some reason a single bike is even sturdier than a reinforced wall... No screaming and cursing at the lowly Private on his bike helps, the enemy pushes forward despite it being dusk and you, your friends and Betty II the battle tank explode, sucking in their last bit of fresh air - ultimately killed by a bicycle.

So now you find yourself typing an angry report of this player and his bike. Looking if you have any message about the reports of the previous 10 accounts of alts over the last 2 weeks. Looking through the forums to see dozens if not hundreds of stories similar to your own. And you decide enough is enough. You edit your previous positive steam review from an enthusiastic report about the helpful community and the many-faceted gameplay options to a report of your heart-crushing futile fight against players, who don't play by the rules and devs who don't seem to care, because every alt is just another sold copy of their game... and you leave defeated looking for a game without pvp, because human scum always find a way to kill the fun for everyone.

Overall: 4/10
I really wish I could give this game a good review, but it just drains me to play. The actual fighting as well as building (to an extent) is really interesting. However, logistics is utter bullsh*t (steam wants me to censor it), and that's what really topples the game over. Without logistics, there is *nothing*. No guns, no ammo, no vehicles, no structures. And there is so rarely anything other than basic rifles and rifle ammo, *maybe* some anti-tank, that there's nothing to do other than blindly run at the enemy with a gun. This is not good tactics. If you want something more, if you want to help actually *win* a battle, you most likely need to do the logistics all by yourself. For the most basic supplies like rifles, rifle ammo, and respawns, this means:
1. Find a salvage truck (harder than it sounds)
2. Search on the map for a salvage yard that isn't empty (harder than it sounds)
3. Drive to the salvage yard (several minutes)
4. Sit around in the scrap yard holding down left click to gather salvage (tens of minutes)
5. Move over to the salvage truck and put the salvage away
6. Repeat from 4 until the truck is full
7. Drive the truck to the refinery (several minutes) and submit the salvage for refining
8. If you need more materials, repeat from 2
9. Put away your salvage truck in a storage depot (several minutes)
10. Wait for your materials to be refined (can take hours)
11. Find a supply truck (harder than it sounds)
12. Drive to the refinery and take the materials out (several minutes)
13. Drive to the factory and put the materials in (probably several seconds but could be minutes)
14. Wait for the supplies to be made (several minutes), take them out when they're done
15. Repeat from 12 if you need more
16. Drive to the front. (several minutes) Repeat from 1 if you are ambushed by partisans.
17. Unload the supplies, drive the truck back to a storage depot to put it away. (several minutes)
This is the most basic list of instructions I could think of for making basic supplies. All of these minutes add up to a huge amount of time. Trying to make anything else is even more complicated and tedious, *especially* if it has to be made in a facility rather than a public factory. Facilities are player-made factories that require constant and heavy logistical upkeep. Most of them are private, so you can't really use them. Worst of all is that they're nearly impossible to find on the map, and there is no indication of whether they're public or private. 
It seems like some people like the routine of logistics, but I find it to be an anti-fun mechanic at the backbone of an otherwise very good game.

The sheer size and logistic to run a war. Every single bullet and materials has to be crafted by someone, then delivered by someone. It's huge but every little supply run or man in the trench can win a town.

I wish to be clear, this is a "War Game" in a very literal sense. Fighting on the front lines is something to can do, but only because of the hundred or more people behind the lines doing Logistics. Everything from the guns you use, to the bullets you fire, the radios, the grenades, the tanks, the fuel. EVERYTHING is made by players for the most part. If you go into this thinking that the game is only fighting in trenches, I don't think you will enjoy this.

If you go into this thinking of going into Logistics (the crafting of everything that goes to the front), you will find a sometimes frustratingly in-depth system of resource management, material collection, and base construction system that can have you grow into force to be reckoned with simply with how much you provide the military-industrial complex of your chosen side. 

Regardless of what you choose, this game is infinitely more fun with friends, both for the social aspect, as well as the fact that if you leave your builds for too long without resupplying, they will start to break down (This takes 24-48hrs after resources run out, depending on the structure).

Foxhole is a game that checks all the boxes I could want from a game, from back-line logistics to front-line fighting. I am one to prefer the routine of back-line logistics, going through the motions of mining resources that are needed and turning them into supplies, weapons or vehicles that are needed throughout various stages of the war. My greatest sense of pride is seeing the crates I made from the factories being shipped out by truck, train or ship.

I have experienced front-line fighting in my first hundred hours or so, half of that on foot and the other half as armor crew before being recruited by an armor regiment (clan) and introduced into facilities to make some of the facility-locked tanks and upgrades for vehicles/tanks. I fell in love with the ability to build your own facility and produce all sorts of items needed for other facilities, and it does get complex at times with facilities and it is rather easy to get lost into it.

This game is heavily based on finding a group of players to work together towards goals for the war, finding a Regiment in this game goes a long way in helping you understand the game and have the manpower needed to help you in various tasks, whether logistics or front-line operations. Seems to be the most difficult part is finding group of players to work towards certain goals, not too hard to get into the big regiments that are around but I prefer to avoid the bigger regiments as I personally steer clear of the bigger clans and prefer to keep to a smaller regiment size as it's easier to manage and a little less chaotic. I highly recommend newer players to join the bigger regiments just to help get a feel for how the game play is as they'll have more clear cut goals and more people to interact with during their ops to understand how operations run for the most part.

For logistics, spawn in the back line and ask in the regional/logi/world chat about needing help understanding logistics and someone will be more than happy to help. I always do my best to help players that ask questions to help them understand what is going on, when I first started playing and I opened the map I was completely overwhelmed and had no idea what to do or where to go. Always ask questions! 

Now on to the bad of the game.. This game if you "enjoy" logistics is super grindy, you can spend all day working on a facility and getting resources needed for the facility just for you to log back in the next day and it all be gone due to the power running, other players taking all they can get to reduce their own grind or partisans coming along and blowing it all up while you are asleep. In this game it feels like you are punished more for actively wanting to do logistics and especially so if you want to run a facility. You have to keep in mind decay, in which your facility (depending on the quality of supply is) can decay completely in 24 hours, so you are forced to log in everyday and grind for X amount of hours to ensure your maintenance supplies are where they need to be for X amount of hours you will be away. 

There is toxicity present in the game, but I tend to avoid it. Not as bad as League of Legends but it can get toxic or crazy in world chat sometimes, but there is an option to minimize the chat so it's out of sight and out of mind. As long as you find the right people in the game, and avoid the crazies you can have a fantastic time in Foxhole!

I joined a regiment: Jager on charlie shard as the colonials. War 107. We held the Flair.

It was enjoyable! We held the flair, contributed to the war effort, there was a sense of progress, of accomplishment.

8 gunboats leveled a weeks work in less than an hour. And the wardens landed like never before.

Flair stood.

Through blood and pain and in the rubble of our lives, hope endured. Flair was not lost to us. I was enjoying losing, /knowing/ we could perservere.

Flair stood

For what must have been 18 hours we held off the wardens in the rubble of our homme.

Flair stood

But we had to sleep eventually. I was one of the last to log off, secure in the knowledge the randoms who had held the Flair under my direction would hold it stil. That in the morning we could rebuild. That the Flair Stood.

The Flair Fell.

In the wee hours of the night, the wardens erased all that hope without us being able to give even a word of resistance. All that meaning, all that hope, all that righteous fury, gone in the wink of an eye.

I'm not sure I want to return to the game, though I probably will. I doubt I'll enjoy it as much.

Flair stands within me, but I am unsure if I stand anymore.

As well stated by Freerk, this cooperative game is great not because any particular phase of it is great (although the economic balance is really, pretty good to great) but because each phase of the game is good to very good, and other than the occasional glitch, not much is really bad - it is in fact that the game HAS all these aspects together and the sum of the parts is far superior.  Worth a look if you don't mind top down FPS gaming (which I would say generally I do not like, but like I said, the other things just compel me to play) 

Only Full MP, and only one instance where there may be thousands of people playing over the course of an hour or two.   Cooperative play is rewarded and uncooperative play is  generally frowned upon.  Sure, there are knuckle heads (I don't know of a single game community that doesn't have some) but they are far fewer in number here, are certainly NOT encouraged as they are by some game designs, and the general populace of the playership does not support idiot behavior very well.   Worth a look at a lets play.  If you watch a stream, try to watch one with multiple people on it.  Watch for more than a few minutes, or you find yourself wanting to find more vids, you know what you need to do!  :)

I've played the game for about 10 days. First thing - the community there is AMAZING. People are genuinely nice, responsive, explain the game, it's easy to form groups and have some nice team play. Team play is actually everything in this game, you cannot do shit without other players. It's complex and demanding and there is no good entry point, you will learn the hard way. It's not immediately pleasant, and you have to invest tens of hours to develop skills and understanding. In this sense it is a truly great game.

But, having said all that, it is hard to enjoy it. If you want to do anything it just takes a lot of time. The game loop for catching a gun and running towards an enemy is good for a couple of sessions, but then it becomes boring. Most of the time you spend running, choosing equipment, waiting to spawn. If you want to take part in the logistics operations, then you will be driving from one side of the map to another. The game looks good, people are nice, you feel like you are taking part in an important and large operation, and you want to contribute, but then you realise it takes good 30 minutes to build a truck, then to process scrap material, bring it to a factory, make some guns and then another 15 minutes to deliver it to a front line. And this is only for the most basic items. Anything more complicated is like playing Factorio. It is not fun if you don't want to dedicate some serious time into it, and coordinate what you do with others. It's a big game, and a big world, it takes a lot of effort to build a tank or anything bigger. Building trenches and other structures is incredibly boring - you essentially have to hold a mouse button pressed down for 2-3 minutes to create anything, and that's the time you cannot spend on doing anything else. I'd say it would be a little bit more enjoyable if you could just press a button and leave for the necessary time for your soldier to finish the job. It is simply boring. It does get better when there is a team with you, that cuts the time down, but still it is brutally slow. The game is highly addictive, but after spending 40 hours playing I really feel I am wasting my life not even clicking, but holding two buttons - one on the mouse, and one on the "w" key to move forward. I do feel like joining again and going to that stupid bridge in the east of Endless Shores, but I feel it is pure waste of life. Because of that I don't feel like playing anymore.  

Another aspect is that the game is not new, and you will play with a mixture of total newbies and veterans, and there is a palpable tension between the two groups of players. Again, people are super nice, but I understand they want to play their complicated operations, they put tens of hours to prepare a naval attack, and suddenly a new player comes along and wants to build something that goes against the big savvy group's plan and it's just not entirely pleasant. It is also hard to join as a casual player if people are really treating the game with dedication, like a serious sport competition. 

I don't regret buying the game, but after playing for 40 hours I don't want to play it anymore.

Fun game, but it's plagued by toxic players. Have you ever tried establishing a base away from the frontline to support your team through crafting? Well, it's not that simple. Unfortunately, toxic players seem to be everywhere, and it's a daily struggle to protect your resources from would-be thieves.

Whenever my friends and I attempted to build our own facilities, gather resources, and contribute to the region by constructing infrastructures for everyone, we encountered this kind of behavior. And if they aren't stealing from you, they might resort to griefing your base.

You might wonder if there's a way to report these disruptive players. The truth is, there is a reporting system in place, but it only works if you can gather enough reports. This means that if a large group decides that you're an inconvenience, perhaps because your base is in a location they desire (a true story I've experienced), they could falsely report you, resulting in an automatic ban.

It's quite unfortunate because the game itself is enjoyable and has the potential for even more fun. However, the situation has worsened as the developers seem unwilling to address these issues. I understand the challenges they face, but they need to make significant improvements to tackle these problems effectively.

Want to set up a base with friends? Sounds fun right? Good luck, for a couple of reasons.

1. Everything you make can and probably will get stolen. Nothing is protected. You can lock your vehicles, but people will break into them and steal them. You can squad lock your facilities, but that doesn't even seem to work. If you're in a squad with friends, as I am, you're going to constantly have to deal with over-selective or under-selective rights. You can't lock a structure your squad-mate built, only they can, and it may not even work. You can't unlock a vehicle that your squad-mate locked personally, unless you break into it like a common thief, a process that takes shockingly little time. I spent hours grinding out base supplies just two nights ago, and when I get on the next day, we're missing most of our supplies, which took hours to grind, and I catch someone leaving with hours more and spend half an hour in a stand-off with the guy (go find a better way to live your life, [DOE] Beetle) as he tries to gaslight me into thinking the base actually belongs to his friend. People will even steal stuff that's easier to make than it is to steal, like our liquid container. And if you finally make something nice, after days of hard work, like a Taurine Rigger, it'll get yoinked the first night you sign off, with NO WAY to find out where it went or who stole it. Was it partisans? Friendlies? The same person who robbed us yesterday or someone new?

2. If you don't play for a few days, the whole thing will deteriorate into nothingness. We have to move 8 truckloads of scrap every single real life day if we want our mid-sized (6 factory buildings, 2 power plants, a resource transfer station, and a small assembly station) base to endure. That's a chore that will take probably 2 hours, every single day,depending on how available the local scrap yards and mines are, just to keep what we've already spent hours building.

This game is undoubtedly great for some things, but if you want a casual game to play with friends, to build a base and support the war effort, then find something else. I want to love this game so much, but when you can have no true security (I'd even be happy with just an unbreakable 5-day squad lock that can only be used within friendly territory on vehicles built by squad members. We need some sort of protection that can't be broken in less than a minute by partisans, trolls, or thieves) and when you need to grind hours just to maintain what little you've built. The decay is too aggressive for small groups to be able to do anything effectively. It needs to be halved, or quartered, or more, and the supply consumption modifier needs to not be so aggressive.

I don't remember when I picked up Foxhole or why I did. But I cannot thank my past self more for the purchase. Foxhole has been a thrilling adventure every time I play and the combat is nothing less than exciting. If you are considering picking up the game I recommend doing so. 

Being in a world where every building, rifle, and vehicle are created by players is something I have never gotten to experience before. And yes it is just that! Every single tool you see in the game and many of the buildings were created by players and you will often see players utilizing factories and scrap yards if you are in the production zones. But it doesn't stop there. You will also find a variety of players creating fortifications on the front lines! 

But if you choose to be just a soldier which is what I have spent a majority of my time doing then you will fit right at home in the trenches holding off one of the two factions of the game the Colonials and the Wardens. Something I will say about this game is that you are not usually going to be a war hero. This game isn't about that. You are a part of the wider whole and a member of a large and diverse team. Rarely does going at it alone do anything more than get yourself killed. But that doesn't mean you can't try it out as a partisan and disrupting enemy supply lines. 

With all that being said the truth of Foxhole is that our achievements and victories are part of a larger war. We may have felt that we won an adrenaline fueled battle the likes of which could never be topped only to remember that the enemy has another base over the next hill. But that is the beauty of Foxhole. No two fights are the same and the experiences you have over VOIP are game changing. 

This review was rather lackluster but truly this is a great game that has constant updates. I recommend you look into it. And should you decide to join the Wardens I hope to see you on the front lines or perhaps alongside me in the mighty fleet.

I've been enjoying Foxhole from the sidelines for a while. Seeing Rubixraptor, Moidawg, Isawabear and the documentary of the 19th conflict had me hooked already. Now that I'm able to play I can say that the expectations are exceeded and I already had high hopes.

Sure, there are a few issues with the game. Some battles and fights can be boring, especially when low on supplies but that's more on the logistics of the game instead and how spread out they can be during war times.

All in all I'm having a blast. Sometimes it can be mentally exhausting and but I think I messed up my sleep cycle playing this none stop.

It's just the fact that it's all organic and human. Every bullet made, every shell shot, every trench built. It gives off this vibe of a living, breathing world at constant, intense war. The community as well is a major pro as well. The lore and jokes and immersion from the playerbase who have been fighting on both sides for years really makes things more fun. Hell even the memers that just crack jokes and are there to have a good time killing Wardens/Collies are appreciated.

All in all I'm having a good time playing this. Glory to Callahan.

I want to like it but the combat is unsatisfying and the rest of the game is just tedious for the sake of being tedious. I mean really, it takes me ~1 min to pull out a single item sometimes and that process needs to be repeated every death. It can take up to an hour just to load ammo especially if you have a vehicle which is no fun at all. A good game if you have no job and no life and want to waste your time, can keep you occupied all day just moving things from one place to the next because it takes at least 5 min to fill your inventory. And by that I mean when you grab something from a friendly base it starts a timer which is anywhere from 30 sec to what seems like 5 min, for each individual item... I imagine it's some half-assed way of controlling griefing but a game like this is a disaster without human mods. Not to mention the weird attempt at a top down view where you can only see like 10 ft in any direction even in a vehicle making collisions comically common as well as teamkilling on the road (very fun).
2/10 wish I could both refund and get my time back.
Devs if you make the view distance for trucks and frieghters much greater that would make this game much better.

Never went to the main front-lines. But I can provide a POV of what it feels like to be on the flank of the enemy at the very far side of the map. Less chaotic, less resource to deploy to destroy pill boxes, and more concern for enemy if they start getting numbers. Its a push and pulled back situation most of the times. Medics are rare. But if you're the type to enjoy at least least chaotic battles, you should definitely come. Worth my money too.

Another opinion. It's up to you if want to take this, especially for people who are always/mostly busy, those who wants to play casually or play only an hour. 
1. If you intend to buy this game and play for an hour, expect to stay in one position. Let's say you intend to push the bridge with your teammates, in an hour, the result you can achieve there is by killing 2-4 Warde- I mean, enemies. You can expect to shoot down 2-4 enemies. And mostly at those times you'd be sitting to cover for your team to prevent them from pushing and taking over your spawn base. You'd be dying and dying over just to realize you have to take this game slowly. 
2. You can get kills under an hour, and sit there doing nothing since you realize you can't push because of automatic pill boxes. 
3. You can't get as much result as you expect it to be. Take this game like real war strategy in real-life. It WILL take you almost a day to even get a proper support from the Logistics Guys and some other Squads who handle artillery or armored vehicles(Shout out to these guys!). In short, you can't expect to push through territory and take the land in a day, it will probably take a week or more. 

My conclusion as someone who played the game in 4 hours total and a newbie, it's peaceful and good for casuals. But for people who only have an hour or two free time, you can't expect the game to be fast paced. This is extremely slow-paced! if you get interrupted because your mother told you to do chores, it's fine. You don't get punished in this game but you just spawn back at your town base or bunker and ruins the immersion. Overall, it's a good game and good community that helps out!

Ladies and gentlemen, gather 'round, because we're about to dive into the mad world of "Foxhole," a game that proves war can be funny if you squint your eyes and look at it from the right angle.

Foxhole is the place where your strategic genius meets your complete lack of map-reading skills. It's where your grand battle plans can crumble with the subtlety of a Jenga tower in an earthquake. But, you know what? It's all part of the charm!

The "No Idea What I'm Doing" Award: If you've ever found yourself frantically building sandbags in the middle of a forest, convinced it's the perfect tactical move, then congratulations, you're a Foxhole player. "Foxhole: Where Shovels Solve Everything!"

The "Art of Ambush" Medal: Foxhole is where every bush becomes a potential assassin. I mean, who knew that shrubbery could be so dangerous? It's all fun and games until the bushes start shooting back. "Foxhole: Where Foliage Is Your Frenemy!"

The "Logi Life Crisis" Trophy: Logistics in Foxhole is like playing a game of "Human Tetris" with crates and trucks. You'll learn to appreciate the thrill of a well-organized supply run, but also the agony of getting stuck in a traffic jam with 20 tons of ammunition. "Foxhole: Truck Simulator on Steroids!"

The "Epic Vehicle Stunt Show" Plaque: Foxhole is where you can see armored vehicles attempt the craziest stunts, like backflips off bridges or interpretive dance on minefields. "Foxhole: Where Tanks Have Better Moves Than You!"

The "Friendly Fire Fiasco" Ribbon: Nothing beats that moment when you toss a grenade with the grace of an Olympic athlete, only to realize it's headed for your teammates. "Foxhole: Because Who Needs Enemies Anyway?"

The "Guerilla Marketing" Accolade: In Foxhole, you'll find yourself manning radio towers like it's a nightclub DJ booth, broadcasting propaganda and misinformation to confuse the enemy. "Foxhole: Where Wars Are Won with Propaganda and Dubstep!"

The "Invisible Sniper" Pennant: Sometimes, you'll be 100% convinced that there's an invisible enemy sniper hiding in the bushes just to mess with your sanity. "Foxhole: Where Camouflage Meets Mind Games!"

The "Sudden Rain of Death" Commendation: You're casually walking down the road, singing a war tune, and suddenly, an artillery shell lands on your head. Surprise!

Vehicles should be able to be clan locked, so randoms can‚Äôt unlock and steal them. Production facilities should be able to be reserved for longer, and accessible to a regiment, than just a squad. And public raw resource sites shouldn‚Äôt be able to be hogged by anyone.

Foxhole is strangely engaging. At first look it is not much and it might even feel strange. But ones you start to realize the complexity of the whole war effort and every little thing that goes into it it is truly amazing. No other game can capture the feeling quite like foxhole. And just holding the position until your friends arrive can feel like a major victory. I find myself following the progression of the war i'm engaged in from time to time just to see what the situation is. People are nice and helpful and the community seems to be a fun one. I have not met any toxicity yet.

A brilliant game, definitely overrated. 

Since I am a slow learner, I was hesitant at first because of reviews talking about how clans mass-report to get people banned. I took the chance anyways, and do not regret it. So far, I have seen two cases of clans calling to mass-report a single player, and even though it was for a good reason both times, the players were not banned and I saw them both the next day(s). FYI: There are different types of reports. For instance, build-griefing reports result in their build ability being temporarily disabled, and excessive friendly fire will eventually result in a weapons lock. 

The gameplay itself is big enough to make my current 60 hours of gameplay still classify me as a noob.  The last games I got so addicted to was Factorio and Sea of Thieves, and this games has parts from both, so my personal life is officially screwed at this point.

Despite being 5 years old (with a 1.0 release only this month), the game's community is growing.

There are only 3 servers for the game, regardless of the country you live in, so you play with people from all over the world.  I really enjoy this aspect ever since I logged in at 5am central time and experienced a squad of Russians breaking into enemy lines and pushing their borders back.  This is a game of war, and it does not stop. Even server patches are rolled out per map region.

The game is not without its issues, but none of them come close to making the game frustrating to play.

Fun game, but be ready to find friends or clans. A lot of content requires ton of resources and custom facilities (player-built logistical structures for advanced in-game stuff) buildings which need to be done and maintained (regularly or else structures will decay with time) to produce everything else that isn't done just in "normal" logistical structures. (world structures that are avaiable to everyone and don't require any processing on custom facilities)

You've probably heard it a lot already but this isn't your classic MMO or war game as everything here is done by players - defences, weapons, ammo, fuel, resources, tanks, ships etc. which sounds super interesting but also means you can't just have it all and to get it you'll need to grind and often wait hours to get some more advanced stuff like basic tanks (dont forget about fuel and ammo for it) as most players and clans value them and wont gift it away even though you are on the same team.

You still can enjoy game solo even somewhat casually being at fronline as infantry guy roleplaying a bit and having your PTSD from constant shelling and mg fire or play with "classic" tanks (tanks/armored vehicles that aren't a special gimmicky variants that can be done in facilities) if you grind resources and find some random players (or friends) to man it. 
But if you want to experience all content (advanced tank combat, artillery operations, rocket artillery operations, naval combat with large battleships (since naval warfare update)) then you'll need to join clans or bring friends that are gonna be as dedicated because otherwise its very hard to do alone.

tl;dr This game is heavily clan based and teamwork is what its buit on and what makes it so fun. You can play game solo but you won't be able to experience all content without communications.

This game is great. The players are super chill and supportive.

Because the game features hundreds of players fighting in a war all at once, something as little as driving a truck to deliver supplies feels fun.

The report system is abused to the point where it's not even a helpful implementation to the game at all.

Here's a personal example:
I'm running logi and dropping off some supplies at a dockyard with my tanker ship. Clan comes up to me and starts cussing at me to move my ship because I'm blocking the deployment area. Instead of waiting for the few minutes it takes for me to submit all of my supplies and leave, they shoot at my tanker and then mass report me, which results in me getting banned in seconds. 

The worst part is that there isn't even any kind of support for this widespread issue (just look at most of the negative reviews, it's almost the same story every single time). When I tried to inquire about it on the Discord, I was just straight up banned for no reason. What kind of moderation team enforces rule breaking?

The game in itself is fun, but the community is absolutely awful, especially the large clans who will just claim everything as theirs and just steal it from you.

Getting banned isn't even the worst part; the game displays your infractions publicly, which leads to getting mass reported for "alting" and getting another ban. 

In summary, unless you're cannon fodder for the larger clans you're going to end up getting ostracized from the community with no way to defend yourself from frequent bans and harassment.

Recommended if you have like 15 friends to play with otherwise don't bother. The devs HATE solo players and enlisting and playing with decent sized clans is like experiencing office politics dialed up to 11. Used to be way better before facilities solos in like 45min could get a tank running. Also love that "We want this content to be accessible to all player types" Nonsense during their naval reveal stream meanwhile 80% of content requires facilities which requires you to play this game like a second job if your solo.

best war simulator ever

POSTED: July 27, 2017
This game takes the cake. It is very entertaining and the endless war/game concept is spot on. The game has plenty of active players, so its easy to interact with a community of soldiers. Games are full. Worth every single penny. And then some.

EDIT: October 29, 2023
This game still continues to blow me away on a regular basis. The updates that the Devs push out are incredible. Just when you think they cant top it, they top it. At the time of this review, they have just pushed a Naval Warfare update out, and I'm speechless. This game has become so full of content, its becoming overwhelming. You can dig into whatever you want as a new player because the game has it to some extent. Trains, yep. Ships, yep. Tank warfare, you bet. Trench warfare, yes. 

I keep telling myself, we will NEVER see biplanes because of the way the game is built with top down camera mechanics, but at this point... nothing would surprise me from this Dev.

Would love to recommend this game to other but as it is now i cant do that.

Main reasons for that is the community and unwillingness of the devs to see whats is happening. The basic explanation of this is the game is designed for the team in a two sided war to work, gather, research and produce together for the war effort. Which on paper sounds like a good idea but its far from that. What ive seen in game is people on your side will turn on each other to steal and murder anyone for what they want. Got a good amount of resources, be prepared for someone to steal them. Have a nice tank, watch as someone on your side breaks the lock and steals it. Want to stop them, be prepared to be banned for team killing to stop the theft.

Basically the devs think the community works together and leave everything up to the "community" to behave and not basically raid their own allies. But that dosent happen, as you cant lock or store anything at your player built base that someone cant just come and take. And it dosent help many people have "Alt" accounts on the opposite team, and will eaither spy, steal, or scout for the other side.

In my 24 hours in game ive been killed by more allies then hostiles.This was becasue me and my friends where trying to build a base and get a long range artillery site setup. But a large logistics group wanted our resources. So the stole, attacked up, and destroyed parts of our base constantly. But you cant shoot back, because if you do and happen to kill one of them, their whole group reports you for team killing to have you banned just so they can steal your stuff. The Game really dosent let you and your friends have anything private owned, and what little it does is very small and even then easily stolen from.

This is the kinda toxicity and clan bullying, control that is ruining the game. Basically its either fall in line, bend over, and let them have their way with you, or be banned.

With only being able to report 3 people a day it nearly impossible to stop the greifers, especially since it take multiple reports on the same person to get anything done, and those that just want to steal and break what you have. And lets not mention the large 'Clans" of player who abuse the report system to get people they don't like banned.

Maybe in the future this game will get better but as of now i would stay away from it.

Well you can make those with basic mats right? There's not a single bmat anywhere either. Well you can scrap and refine that into bmats right? Yes if only scrap fields weren't completely empty. Well you can go to the field further away? No, because it's winter weather in the game and my character will freeze and die halfway to the scrap field.

GET TO THE LINE
You can play on the front line fighting or working logistics to support the war - very cool game.

First off, I want to say I played 125 hours within the past two weeks.  Clearly I enjoyed the game and what it had to offer.  There's a lot of variety of different things of what you can do.  Fight in the front lines?  You got it.  Want to help do supply chain logistics, you have that too.  Want to go behind enemy lines and disrupt their logistics, there's that too.

The game has sucked me in with the continual purpose of contributing in the war effort, constantly doing my best to supply the front with the ever so needed armaments or trying to do a large push to destroy a relic base for zone dominance.  

But at the end of the day, I definitely cannot recommend this game to others.  The amount of toxicity I have received from others really left a sour taste in my mouth.  Don't get me wrong, there were so many pleasant experiences I've had with other players.  So many players were accommodating towards me, teaching me on certain operations or asking me how I like the game and what not.  Teammates have come to my rescue in defending my base against partisans in numerous occasions, rallying against the forces of the other team.  Neighbors constantly asking me what I've been up to, sharing resources and vehicles, and just being that friendly accommodating neighbor everyone wants in their lives.  I once joined a group of players in vehicular warfare and the driver was guiding me on what to do.  He was extremely accommodating when I made a mistake (I shot a AT bunker as a tank), and said it's OK, it's a learning experience.

But despite all of these positive experiences from players, I've had way too many toxic players.  As a solo player, you get bullied from groups of players truly taking advantage of you.  You cannot go to certain sections of the map as clans will kick you out.  Certain resources are under lockdown as they are 'owned' from the other clans.  I've built bases/facilities for the purpose of having a public facility yet all of my vehicles and resources get taken out of my bases before I can get them running.  I would have to travel 2 hexes to gather resources and would have to sit in my own base to wait for them to process in fear of my own teammates in raiding me.  Teammates would wrench my own vehicle to in order to steal resources from my truck while I am in the middle of gathering resources.

What really made me leave this game, was when a player constantly followed me while cussing at me, just for the point of griefing me.  Just for context, I primarily played this game in logistics and I primarily gathered resources where no players usually went to (places where resources were constantly out of gas and were often capped out, so I assumed the zone had a lack of players maintaining that resource node).  In this instance, while driving towards a refinery, this player was driving in the middle of the road and we ran into each other.  I get it, cars will always run into each other, even if both players happen to drive on the right side of the road, it just happens.  You both back up, make space, and move on.  In this case, I backed up while this player started yelling at me while driving forward.  His teammate/squad then decided to come behind my vehicle and block me while this player continued to yell at me.  His teammate gets out with a wrench wanting to unlock my car, and I'm thinking wow, this is not fun at all.  Eventually as I leave, to continue to gather resources,  this player continues to follow me, blocking me off the road all the while yelling and making fun of me.  I just want to play the game.  He eventually was able to unlock my car and decided to sit in the passenger seat, so now I'm left with him wherever I go.  Fine, you win, I quit, you must be happy now.

If this is the experience I get while I play this game, I decided I'm over it.  I also do want to note that all of these players that have been toxic have always been a high rank.  If I'm constantly running into higher ranks that are toxic already, then I'm going to keep running into them if I were to keep playing this game.  You feel useless, discouraged, and inferior against a larger group of players that bully you.  I definitely do not want to put these experiences that I've had with any of my other friends.  
 
TLDR: The toxic negative experiences you get aren't from the other team, it's from your own teammates.

A small town with a steel gate and near impenetrable walls, hundreds of sandbags and foxholes set up around the front entrance, several hundred Wardens and Colonials firing endless clouds of lead towards each other, howitizers, tanks, gas, high explosives, troop carriers and trucks transporting waves of Warden troops from the nearby FOB, immeasurable casualties, piles of the bodies of fallen men from both sides, machine gun fire, the agonized cries of wounded soldiers as combat medics rushed to treat them, it seemed like the battle would last for days on end. But we knew they had nowhere to go, no vehicles to escape with, no supply lines, and a dwindling army of troops. They would be forced to surrender soon. And as suddenly as it began, the battle ended. The Colonials of the area had surrendered, and we cheered our hard fought victory.

=> Please read! After playing about 200 more hours, I have gathered some more thoughts that I'd like to share. I still wouldn't recommend the game, even despite the exciting new things happening with the naval update.

Some people may be wondering why I am not recommending this game to others, given that I have played it for over 100 hours. There are many, many things to love about Foxhole. Its gameplay is unlike anything I've ever played. Foxhole is a massive war simulator inspired by WWI and II in which every building, every structure, every vehicle, every gun, every bullet is player-made. Gather raw resources, refine them into usable materials and use them to craft supplies to sustain the war effort. Whether you play frontline or backline, combat or logistics, Foxhole is a collaborative game at heart, and you won't go far if you play all alone. The satisfaction you get from seeing a project come together thanks to the efforts of a whole team of people is incredible. But those moments are merely the silver lining of a game experience which, often, is otherwise tedious and frustrating. As it is, I simply cannot recommend Foxhole. Here are some reasons why:

1. Programming and game design issues. There is no proper tutorial. The existing tutorial only goes over the bare minimum of the commands and doesn't actually tell you how to play the game. There should be at least some semblance of a tutorial for logistics: they make up a significant portion of the game, and yet you cannot grasp logistics-related gameplay mechanics unless you pour over the wiki for hours or you know someone who's already been playing Foxhole for a while and can show you.

Also, the game physics are really rough and unrefined. There are numerous issues regarding hitboxes, people clipping into buildings and getting stuck, etc. Instead of fixing these issues, the developers... gave players access to an unstuck command, presumably because they'd rather work on more game content. Those issues would be understandable coming from an early-access game, and Foxhole was early-access for a very long time. But now the game is at update 1.53, and is supposedly officially released at this point. These problems are simply not acceptable coming from a supposedly finished game.
 
=> Edit: after some more game experience, I've come to realize that hitbox and skin problems, while real and annoying, are marginal in comparison of another issue which has existed for a long time and is getting more and more pressing with the naval update: the game is held back by its hardware. Due to server limitation, the world is not continuous; rather it is divided in regions colloquially known as hexes, and hexes only allow up to 100 players of each faction to join, creating issues with queues and wait times, especially for frontline regions. And the game is going to have to dedicate yet more of those already sparse resources into handling water physics and boat physics. And the boats are big. The developers need to make it a priority to upgrade the game's servers. I dream of the day when we might see a truly open-world Caoiva...

2. The relationship between the community and the development team. The developers are... uncommunicative, which is an issue for a game like Foxhole which depends upon a relatively small, but dedicated community of fans. I remember when the community was awaiting update 52. The game had numerous issues which made it frustrating to play. Among chief complaints were: lack of balance between the two opposing game factions (I'll get back to that one later on); slow rates for building structures; a confusing map, with many people feeling the need to use mods to make the map more readable (that is still a problem to an extent); a confusing rail switch system for trains; and a poorly-implemented new system for logistics and production revolving around facilities, which was hard to use, time-consuming, resource-hungry and desperately needed to be streamlined. The developers left the community plunged into a radio silence for months regarding this much-awaited update, which was supposed to bring many quality-of-life improvements that the game very badly needed. Eventually, frustration, resentment, anger and apathy grew and festered in the community, with "devman doesn't care" and "devman bad" sentiments being pretty widespread at that time (the latter one remains a frequent occurrence to this day).

Another issue concerns moderation. Foxhole being an MMO, it needs moderation. The moderators are... none other than the developers themselves, which in my experience only breeds suspicion of devman bias (whether real or perceived) and resentment towards the developer team. Even worse, suspicions of devman bias extend beyond the moderation aspect into the very way the game is built, with many players firmly believing that the game unfairly advantages the Colonial faction against the Warden faction. One of my friends, who played both factions, once expressed it like this: "Playing Warden is playing Foxhole on hard mode." I only play Warden, so I cannot personally assess whether this sentiment is true, but in my opinion it is too frequently expressed to ignore.

3. The behavior of the community itself. Foxhole is not spared from the toxicity issues that pretty much every online multiplayer game has to deal with. Foxhole's player base is pretty international, with not only British and American players, but also Eastern European and East Asian people, as well as a decently-sized French community. However, the game is mostly in English and the majority of the community remains English speakers. The language barrier leads English-speaking players to frequently antagonize players who are Chinese or Russian, and French players frequently complain about unnecessarily rude and sometimes xenophobic comments from English and American players.

Faction loyalism is also a major issue, with players getting too caught up in the fantasy the game sells and unnecessarily antagonizing players from the enemy faction simply for being from the enemy faction. Petty infighting about whether Colonials or Wardens are better is pretty frequent, and can sometimes morph into something deeply inappropriate, such as some players claiming that the Colonials represent the Allied forces of WWII and the Wardens represent Nazi Germany, due to a misunderstanding of the loose historical references within the game and despite developers clearly stating that the in-game factions have nothing to do with any real-life armed forces, whether historical or current.

This petty infighting even exist within factions. As Foxhole is a team game at heart, it is possible to create regiments within a faction, colloquially known as "clans", to better facilitate player coordination. Clans frequently fight each other and it is not uncommon for small "civil wars" to break out over the course of a war, despite there being restrictions placed on friendly fire (mostly in the form of restrictions, kicks and bans at the discretion of the moderators). This is not helped by the fact that the raw resources in this game are very competitive: almost all of these civil wars break out over a conflict for the securing of resources. On top of that, while some clans dedicate a significant amount of time each war to building public facilities for all to use, others hoard resources and supplies, making it harder for everyone else to play. All of these problems create antagonism between clans and between clan members and non-clan members, with "clanman bad" being another fairly common sentiment.

TL;DR: the game has major programming and design issues despite having been officially released for months; the developers are uncommunicative and appear to be favoring one faction over the other; the community struggles with toxicity despite a few silver linings when playing the game with friends.

A game with so much potential, that I have had many excellent experiences on, being murdered by it's very creators. A mother, smothering their own child believing that they are saving it. As the new Naval update is about to be release, I prepare myself for arguably what will be my last war on Foxhole, and what I believe is about to be the death of the game. A game, where content, and new experiences should be celebrated, and I find myself dreading it.

The Devs, who previously I would have supported in taking time to make good development choices, have shown themselves to be almost wholly blind, and lacking in any thought when it comes to choices they make. Asymmetrical balance so bad, that guns/vehicles WITHIN a faction are made completely redundant by virtue of other weapons in the faction (ignoring progression); not to mention that some weapons are just simply pointless to make. Not to mention the bugs that have been present for years still go unfixed.

Do not waste your money on this game, this development team, or this company. You're money is better spent on Overwatch 2 in comparison.

To any Devs reading this I have the following comment to make.
It speaks volumes to create a game that you don't even want to play; that forces the dedicated players into horrible game play loops for the 'greater good' of a fictional group. It tells a terrible story, that the community on your own game commonly states 'dev man bad' because there is no other explanation for why mechanics are the way they are. You've successfully managed to take a genera leading game, and have failed on game play loops already proven to succeed. Your 'vision' is so blind, that I now question if you ever had eyes in the first place. In a weird twist of irony, I can only truly congratulate you on one thing. You've made a game, that is as hopeless in real life, as is the situation in the world of the game. 

Here is a summary of game play loops/mechanics.
[u]New player experience[/u]
A) You found a vet who happily teaches you the game. Victory!
B) You were unable to find a vet that teaches you the game, and combat + Logi is forever a mystery.
C) You ran into one of the toxic clans, and looked at someone the wrong way, promptly being accused of being an Alt and banned.

[u]Communication/clans[/u]
Operations used to exist, allowing for randoms to group together effectively to do things. Still waiting for this to come back.
Squad/regiment system is easily the worst system that I've ever seen. Foxhole clans exist on discord, not foxhole. 
Voice comes will randomly disconnect, and you will need to restart the game to fix it. Pray no-one kills your sleeping body so you can return to the same spot.

[u]Infantry[/u]
80% I shoot more bullets than you/luckier than you, 20% game knowledge/position/skill
If someone is spamming grenades, then they win.
Infantry AT is actually pretty nice to use.
The only sniper in existence isn't the sniper (worst weapon in the game). It's the anti-tank rifle. 

[u]Vehicles[/u]
I heard you like line battles? 
I heard you love RNG even more than infantry
I heard you love several hours of logi, 20-30mins of arming the tank/yourself, only to be killed in 5mins because of a bush 94.5mm AT gun.
If you can really good at tanks and have a well coordinated crew, they can be really fun.

[u]Artillery[/u]
Arguably the only balanced area of the game. Good sounds on the guns too.
Rocket arty is extremely fun to fire, but generally worthless.

[u]Making defences[/u]
2-3 people with autoclickers + 1 person designing the place + 2-3hours = bunker base.
You will have no defences at your base (unless its literally the front) for 1-2 RL days, during which point its very vulnerable to attacks. 
You will pay your several hours of logi game play each day to keep it alive, otherwise it will decay.
Also pray that someone doesn't come and destroy your plan because it isn't "meta"

[u]Logi[/u]
Do you like no QoL? How about your QoL being removed?
Do you like taking 30mins to make basic materials for basic guns?
Do you like artificial timers and autoclickers? 
Do you like taking 20-30mins to drive to the front?
Then logi is for you!
Also, There is also a 50% chance, you'll meet people who exist to deny your ability to do anything for fear of wasting 'their' resources. There is also a 50% chance you'll find the most amazing and helpful people in the game.
Note: Devs have never actually played logi, and it shows. Seriously devs, you actually just need to play logi on both teams for a way as normal players, and you'll understand 99% of the problems of the game.

[u]Facilities[/u]
So, foxhole is literally the ideal place for some Factorio/Satisfactory game play. Shame this is the Foxhole devs version. This is not a factory game, this is a Idle phone game with a side of logi.
For the uneducated out there (including the devs), complexity is a GOOD thing, and should REWARD players that engage with it successfully. Instead, foxhole punishes the entire community to access what should have otherwise been basics.
Could have had actual tank factories with actual ability to produce variants.
Also, you will pay your 1-2h of forced labour every day to keep your small factory alive.

[u]Partisan[/u]
Good game play loop (for those who like this sort of thing). It's been made more difficult to do, but still doable. Also, the asymmetry of the two stealth buffing uniforms, could have been made really interesting, but was deployed terribly, rendering the benefit of using one of the uniforms redundant.

My overall feeling on the game now is that if you're willing to grind in Foxhole like I did clearing out scrap and sulfur mines, doing logi, even building stuff occasionally, you can play any other grindy game that exists right now and have more fun the whole way through that other game.

You won't be yelled at in a game that requires mandatory Loudness Normalization via WIndows, you won't be harassed, you won't have your vehicles stolen or your character griefed because a clan claimed a public resource as its own and don't want you on "their land". You won't even need to join a clan to enjoy anything in that other game most likely. In Foxhole you are essentially required to be in a clan or you're locked out of most of the game's content.
