EDIT: Ignore what I said below; this is a GREAT game. The rifles are the ones with the aiming problems, but once your side unlocks SMGs and assault rifles, it gets a lot better.

ORIGINAL REVIEW
This game has an amazing concept and SHOULD be really fun but the basic gunplay is completely non-functional.

Your gun can only aim accurately if you're hiding behind cover, so combat out in an open field is essentially impossible unless you know how to zip around and abuse the 1 second window where the game doesn't apply the aim debuff.

If the only way for your gun to actually shoot where you're aiming is to abuse actual glitches, there's something wrong with your game.

Thankfully, Siegecamp's next game, Anvil Empires, has a mechanic to prevent this. Plus, it's melee combat anyways so aiming won't be an issue.

Highly recommend you get this game. It's a great game that i keep coming back to time and time again. Either playing it casually or intensely a few weeks at a time then not for a few months. Each time i come back to it, i fall in love with it all over again. 

Since i got this game, nearly 3 years ago, it has dramatically improved in play ability and there is so much more content. Given i was happy with the original level of content at the time of purchase, this is easily the best value PC game i have ever purchased. 

Biggest Positive: There are so many different ways to play this game - builder, logiman (driving trucks, trains and ships), manufacturer, tanker, artillery man, guerrilla fighters (Partisans), infantry man, scout, miner ... 

Biggest Negative: As with all MMOs, there are a few toxic players who will cheat with alt accounts to get intel or act as a fifth column but that in a way makes it more realistic (Spies and Saboteurs) but frustrating. However, in all my hours of playing I have only come across this on a few occasions.

I like the game mechanics for the most part. My main issues with the game are instability/game-wide lag spikes resulting in getting kicked mid-action and the often incredibly punishing death timers. Devs are active but prefer working on their vision for the game before fixing core problems. The community is generally great but is marred by occasional groups who get way too invested and resort to cheating. Generally, I'd say get it if you're not stressed by random disconnects and have friends you can play with, otherwise hold off or wait for a good sale. 6/10

This is a extremely good game for a couple of reasons, one of the main reasons for this game being this good is that you are not a super soldier that can kill everything in one hit you are a regular foot soldier which dies to a single bullet  the logi in this game it's a god send it could at times feel like a job but it's perfect and it will sometimes take awhile for a vehicle like a tank or a armored car to get to the front making it feel actually like a real war.

If your looking for a game where you can go from driving a truck of supplies one moment, to joining a charge into fortified enemy defenses the next, only to turn around and hunt down sneaky enemy sabateurs near your teams factories... then look no further. The battles i have been part of have made for some of the most intnse, yet fun and memorable gaming moments I have ever experienced.
One of the best games ever made, in my opinion. It's like Sims + Battlefield + MMORPG and immensely satisfying to play. Even digging trenches is a blast.

Honestly, I forgot just how fantastic this game is. I bought and played it for under twenty hours before forgetting the game existed. I remember having good fun, and I always wanted to get back into it but never found the time. 

I play solo, which can be a bit of a frustrating experience. But soloing as a medic and doing the best you can to make sure your teammates don't have to respawn (and spend the required respawn resources) is honestly very rewarding. Yelling "it's okay, I got you" as someone is RP screaming down the mic while you're patching them up and saving their life leaves a feeling that can't be described. 

As of writing this, War 107 has ended in a Warden victory. I was lucky enough to have logged in today. But for my faction to have also won makes me want to fight in the next war even harder. Sitting in a trench, gunning down Collies as they try to push our position and praying to whomever that you don't get shredded by an artillery strike is a hell of an experience. And it's only made sweeter by the victory screen.

If you're debating whether to get this because you have no one to play it with - don't. Trust me, you'll feel a sense of belonging just from fighting alongside countless fellow soldiers. And you'll find a play-style you like.

As a completely new player this game has been incredibly fun for me. I haven't been berated by the community for walking around aimlessly at times. I've actually had a few nice interactions so far even when im doing something unorthodox. I've mostly been fighting on the front-lines and have yet to dip my toes in any of the more technical aspects of the war. But the combat is rather fun and tricky to learn. Once i got the hang of it ive been enjoying even more than i already was. I think the main fear of getting into this game is the community and to be honest its scarier then it looks but i can assure you there are way more nice and engaging comrades then there are bad ones. 

I also think that if you find games where you're doing a lot of hard work and getting little in return to be not as fun then this might not be a game for you. Attacks and killing other players can be rewarding in itself but if you're expecting to hop on a push the front line even further then you're going to find yourself mentally exhausted because more often then not you will be fighting in the same spot for hours or even days. The other day i was fighting in one area and decided to get off and take a break. When i returned we were still in the same spot doing almost the same thing. Fighting in the same trench as before. But it does feel nice when you get back on and you see that the area that you fought for hours and days for was finally captured.

Imagine, if you would, a very funny top-down War MMO with logistics, factories, all that jazz. Very fun game on paper.

But then, you realize that games like this are a  prime breeding ground for terminally online losers who require the validation of others in the form of clans. Simply put, piss off a collection of these losers and you're banned from the game, essentially. The moderation in this game is the form of mass voting people off, and the devs picking up the pieces in the forms of tickets submitted to their help desk. A clan can ban you for a few days, and your only recourse will be an unban that will occur in 1-3 business days. 

However, this process has improved greatly as of late. Serial mass-false-reports tend to be banned more often now (See the case of "BadManLarry" in the Foxhole community), but there is still much room for improvement. New players tend to be targeted the most by clans because they are suspected of being alt accounts, and older players who tend to piss off clan men get mass reported the same as well. I would recommend this game under 2 conditions:

1. You're willing to join a clan, willing to be bossed around, and willing to be a punching bag for certain people who haven't found a way to manage their anger issues, and take it out on newer clan members. (Of course, you'll have clan guys who say "We aren't like other clans!!! we're different!!!!" but as someone who's spent hundreds of hours trying out various clans, they tend to be all the same.)

2. You're willing to deal with the fact that you may or may not eventually piss off a certain clan member, who will then go to his discord or squad chat with 10-20+ people to have you banned off the game, forcing you to make a ban appeal and wait a certain amount of time before you can return.

Otherwise, the community makes what could be a really fun game, an absolute cesspool.

If you're looking for a review on this DLC you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

This is a very difficult game to review.  On the one hand, you get a lot of value per dollar.  The developers are continuously developing the game and never charging for expansions, dlc, micro-transactions etc.  If you enjoy the idea of a persistent war that continues to develop while you are offline, this will certainly be an interesting game for you.  I highly doubt you will regret spending $30 on the game.

On the other hand...it is difficult for me to "recommend" this game based on the grindy, addictive nature and the generally toxic community.  People love to hate players in the "enemy" faction and it gets pretty bad.  It's just a game, but not everyone thinks that way.  Many people joke that Foxhole is a social experiment.

The balance is a very contentious issue as the asymmetry in this game is more extreme than any other game I've ever played.  Any frustration is exacerbated since you have to pick a faction for the duration of the war which can last months in the real world.

Just be careful to enjoy the game in moderation, and work as a team player rather than as a solo.

That's just my personal experience though.

Until they fix this ill be leaving this negative review here.

Edit from negative to positive review.

Something ive learned since last I played, Joining a clan is probably the best thing you can do as a new player. it both gives you the opportunity to learn the game, but if you need help with small things like knowing the difference between tanks, Knowing what gear to take  etc. can be really helpful.

Join the Foxhole Discord and find a clan for you preferred side and enjoy your time.

Stay well and truly clear if you're mostly a solo or small group player. The game and its devs have long since abandoned making this game fun for those demographics.
The latest update for naval only doubles down on this.

In inferno, once easily accessible vehicle variants and more where all shoveled into the terrible Facility system. Facilities serve the purpose of making what was once a relatively simple logistics process into literal nightmares of tedium and constant upkeep. Only large clans have enough manpower to reasonably run facilities by splitting the maintenance tedium among members and building out large enough facilities to make the higher end vehicles. This has largely resulted in large clans hoarding resources and keeping everything locked to themselves, and really why wouldn't they. There do exist some that do what they can to share access, but that is essentially a bandaid to the hurdles the devs intentionally put between the average player and their ability to access those things.

For the naval update the devs have decided this was all a great idea and have doubled down. All the new toys are still facility only. All the new ships and spgs have exorbitant costs and construction times. Even the basic trailers are facility made only. And to add insult to injury, the new towing mechanic screws over field gun arty with nonsense undeploying and redeploying to change the aim, and the towing isn't even fast enough to be considered useful anyway. Yup, even a basic function like towing was made to be so hopelessly inept at doing something basic like pulling a gun to the front without needing a flatbed, it is instead an entirely useless mechanic.

The average small time player is no longer part of the dev's vision for this game. So save your money and go else where, it simply isn't worth your time.

Oh Foxhole...why are you, a game of my childhood dreams, giving me such a love-hate relationship vibe?

Before you buy foxhole, please let me offer you my experience with this game.  First, I love this game!  It has all the elements of a dream game that I wanted since my childhood.  A world to build anything and everything.  A place where you can part of a truly huge war driven completely by players.  And a healthy community to have fun.  

But!  I have to be real with myself and those looking to buy this game.  While fun, this game requires TIME and "not so fun" teamwork.  Time because this game needs a few hours per play session to feel meaningful.  Teamwork because anything meaningful (assault, logistics, building, and operations) require a group of your friends/teammates.  Perhaps this is not really a negative as much as the nature of this type of gaming.  However, for those of us that are fairly busy, unless you have a tight group of friends to play, this game may not be for you. 

Overall, I love this game and I recommend playing this beautiful war game.  Just understand you will need to reserve some time and cooperate with others to truly make it an enjoyable experience.

This game is something special; there is nothing else like it out there. However, over the last couple of years the developers have been growing more and more out of touch with their playerbase. They regularly add content and make changes to achieve their "vision," but this vision only makes sense if you don't actually play the game. They have no idea what the players want or what the game needs in order to be a fun experience that respects your time.

The fact that there have been multiple "logi strikes" says it all. The majority of the playbase only logs in to check out the new update and then leaves again. The devs are unwilling to compromise, unwilling to listen to feedback, and are destroying this amazing game that I loved.

Foxhole can seem really daunting at times because you're kind of just dropped into the action with only a little bit of a tutorial which doesn't explain much other than the basic controls. This is the kind of game where you kind of have to figure things out as you go and listen to what other players tell you when it comes to doing certain roles. This game isn't going to be everyone's cup of tea. Logistics can be tedious and combat can be as well. 

However, with all that being said, this is honestly one of the best games I've ever played, period. There really isn't any other game that quite captures the vibe that is Foxhole's mix of quiet, back line logistics and deafening, sprawling front line battles with dozens of players. Being there for a major battle at the end of a war where both sides are throwing everything they have against each other are some of the most cinematic experiences I've seen in a game before. Whether you want to dives into the complex depths of logistics or you just want to be a guy with a rifle in a trench, there is something here for you. If it's a game that you think you'd find interesting it's one that I highly recommend looking into.

I've been playing this game on and off since its original free version years ago and there honestly isn't any game that comes close to what Foxhole has, though a few have gotten close. While not perfect at times, the game manages to capture large-scale combined arms warfare in fantastic fashion. Now while you can't turn the tide of battle on your own, Foxhole still manages to make you feel like almost every person plays a small role in a battle's outcome, all while taking place in large-scale wars that can last several weeks in real-time. Though as i've said before, it isn't perfect.

While you don't have to spend every second on the frontline, working logistics can be fun at times, provided you can feel comfortable spending hours building a tank, along with fuel and ammo for it, only for said tank to be destroyed in a matter of minutes because a few random people wanted to use it......at night....... with low visibility........outnumbered by other enemy tanks (totally didn't happen to me a few years ago i swear). With that being said, the game can be a lot of fun, provided you don't take things too seriously and if you can bring a friend or two, even better.
A great game to play with friends!

You play as one soldier attached to one of two optional factions. The Wardens or the Colonials. In its current state this game is asymmetrical, which is the "vision" of the developers. It requires both sides to be even in population and skill for the game to achieve initial balance. Currently one side or the other gets massive population and that determines not only victory but the pacing. The team with less population (and coordination) cannot support the intricate ecosystem of logistics, infantry, artillery, vehicle production, facility building, facility upkeep, base building, base upkeep and manning of said vehicles. Alongside some interesting balancing issues where one side has a clear advantage on late game. There is so much potential. At this time if you still decide to purchase this unique title, play on the Warden faction you will get a more traditional "fun" video game experience where the expected outcome is to experience a winning experience. But be prepared to wade through significantly toxic people on both sides. Especially the usernames...it's funny they will censor the world chat but people can be called C*** Monster and it won't be censored. Aside from this I will say there is no game like this. The developers are sitting on something with so much potential...but in it's current iteration there will be high turn-over of players, but those that are loyal to the play style, are loyal to a fault, (present company included) and the community is currently burned out at times, toxic at times or the few making the most out it and hoping for more updates to come. Best of luck and please for the love of all things war if you play the game do not build a trench right in front of a base.

The issues with switching have largely been addressed, and the gameplay has been MASSIVELY overhauled since this initial review. I am happy that this was a momentary sadness and not a consistent issue for the game.

[h1] A unique game where you're able to play as a cog in a war machine. [/h1]

I think this game is an amazing gem. It's a world of constant war where basically all of the in-game situations are for players to create.

[h2] In terms of gameplay and fun, it really depends on how you play.  [/h2]

[h3] Playing solo - is mediocre. [/h3]

As mentioned earlier - you're just a cog, a game is balanced in a way that only by a collective effort of a lot of people major changes to the frontline are achievable. If you're looking for MVP SOLO 360 NONSCOPE CLUTCH - there are games that fulfill this need way better. The most fun solo experience is when you're able to communicate with other random players and team up to achieve something. Or just admire the beauty of horror that is happening around you - the situations this game generates are fantastic, you will constantly hear a soldier in a side tranch calling for a medic, an officer yelling at you to push a fortified MG encampment, constant artillery shells taking lives of your fellow soldiers - and much much more, you can find examples of such situations in a lot of different reviews here.

There is also a solo logi experience that basically comes down to driving your truck from salvage fields to a refinery to the factory to the frontline while listening to a podcast or watching a video on a second screen and trying to understand what kind of supplies people actually need at the moment based on map intel. It may be fun if you enjoy the feeling that you actually help your fellow men and the guns you brought may be used to eliminate enemy soldiers, or medical supplies may save many lives.

[h3] Small group - fun. [/h3]

With a small group of 3-5, you are open to much more content such as armored warfare, artillery, infantry squad, sabotage group, gunboat crew, simple base building, and more, but not everything. The game really opens up a lot and you can start to feel your impact but it's still not much. You won't be able to comfortably sustain industrial facilities or large bases with such a small group unless you're investing way too much time in the game, and without those, you won't have easy access to high-end armored vehicles. It's not too limiting but you will feel it anyway once you stumble upon an enemy battle tank or a super tank.

[h3] Being a part of a regiment - fun? [/h3]

This is a way a big part of long-lasting community plays. It's basically a big group of people that are well-organized, with usually their own industrial facilities, consisting of smaller groups that specialize in different types of activities (like armored warfare, artillery, and infantry) and they plan out big operations. They have the most impact on the frontline and wars in general. Being part of such communities comes with the burden of social responsibility, since operations are executed in specific time and you have to participate in those to be noticed. I'm not up to those kinds of responsibilities since I have at least some kind of social life, so there's not much I can tell about that experience.

[h2] Community [/h2]

For some reason, a lot of people say that the community in Foxhole is toxic. I assume those people are new to the internet in general. Of course, there is some level of shit-talk present, but from solo and small group experience, the community is one of the best in video games. Tons of cases where random people came up to help, explained some complicated game mechanics, risked their lives to save me and get to the medic. There was even a case where our group tank was stuck in trenches and another fellow tank took all of the enemy shells while a squad of infantry tried to dig us out of it, we made it out thanks to their help. ZERO, I would like to repeat ZERO cases of intentional griefing or ruining behavior spotted. It might be luck but considering more than 100h of gameplay it is safe to assume that those cases are really rare. Maybe people are talking about regiment communities, but as already mentioned I wasn't able to be part of those.

Overall - I recommend this game since it's a truly unique experience and devs deserve the support.

[h1] Nothing matches the pure brutality of Foxhole. [/h1] 

Watching someone being incinerated in front of you, watching a tank's ammunition cook off, charging toward an enemy position with gas grenade in hand, suppressing pillboxes, all of these experiences are some you'll never forget. If that isn't your thing, try the back line. Ferrying goods to and fro, running risky supply missions, and assisting a greater cause, these are memories you won't forget either. Foxhole is well balanced, a masterclass in video game economies and most importantly, feels real. The scale of the war is unfathomable. Even as you sleep, individual players are coming together for a common goal; and it's not just a few of them. There are thousands of players active at any time. Foxhole is easily one of the most immersive games I've had the chance to play. I highly recommend.

[h1]Title: A Remarkable Sandbox War Experience[/h1]

[h2]Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ[/h2]

Foxhole is an exceptional and immersive sandbox war game that stands out in the crowded gaming landscape. It offers a unique and captivating blend of strategy, cooperation, and persistent warfare that sets it apart from traditional shooters and strategy games.

At its core, Foxhole is all about player-driven conflict. You're not just a soldier; you're a cog in a massive, persistent war machine. The game's open world is a constantly evolving battlefield, shaped entirely by the actions and decisions of the player community. It's this player agency that makes Foxhole a standout experience.

One of the game's most remarkable aspects is the sense of teamwork and cooperation it fosters. You'll find yourself working alongside fellow soldiers to build fortifications, transport supplies, and launch offensives. The need for communication and coordination is paramount, creating a strong sense of camaraderie among players.

The game's strategic depth is another standout feature. Battles aren't won solely by twitch reflexes; they require careful planning and execution. You'll be tasked with managing logistics, coordinating with your team, and adapting to the ebb and flow of the war. The feeling of accomplishment when a well-executed plan succeeds is truly gratifying.

Visually, Foxhole might not compete with high-budget AAA titles, but its simplicity allows for a smooth and engaging experience, even on less powerful hardware. The graphics serve their purpose well, immersing you in the game's war-torn world.

One of the few drawbacks is the game's steep learning curve. Newcomers might find themselves overwhelmed initially, but the supportive community and in-game tutorials help ease the learning process.

In summary, Foxhole is a gem in the world of multiplayer war games. Its player-driven warfare, emphasis on cooperation, and strategic depth create a uniquely immersive experience. If you're a fan of games that emphasize teamwork, strategy, and the thrill of large-scale warfare, Foxhole is a must-play title that offers an exhilarating and ever-evolving battlefield to explore.

The region queue system is still broken.

This game was supposed to be a replacement to a very old game i played that's still around I used to play some time ago. The premise was WW2 massively multiplayer on essentially ONE server. You can go infantry, tanks, planes or navy, it was quite a surreal feel to join a battle with over 100 other guys.

That being said this is close to that feeling. The game is top down which feels weird, and the shooting is hard to master. When i joined you couldn't even see beyond your firing arc. Despite  how jarring it felt it was so interesting that the game was so full of life. A sign from some random guy begging not to steal, people mining endlessly for hours etc. The immersion is a great aspect of the game you feel like your apart of a bigger machine. You fight in different climates and different places that become notable once you play long enough. You can even tell your own war stories because the chaos of the battlefield is always so interesting. I spent little time on the battlefield because aiming is so bad, bullets tend to drift etc it just doesn't feel good unless your in a group, which leads me into the main negative.

If for whatever reason you play solo, it will suck. Anything interesting requires a team or group. Which isn't bad its just how trash the already formed groups are. If you don't have irl friends who are into this kinda game good luck getting into a tank etc. I spent a lot of time as logistics. Working the mines, producing supplies, moving supplies etc. Eventually it became  pointless? Atleast that's how it felt. Why am i spending ours helping to create stuff i won't ever use? The game i initially referenced allowed you to go up in rank based on kill count and held capture points etc. There was a sense of achievement, in foxhole you basically get some guy giving you a thumbs up if you deliver stuff. Plus it was easy to take part in the bigger more complex equipment in the other game. You don't NEED to be in a clan. In foxhole you NEED to be in a clan to accomplish anything worthwhile that is.

 Not being able to participate in fun stuff and constantly having to act as fodder for the war machine aswell as mindlessly and endlessly farming supplies to feel some sort accomplishment that you are affecting the war etc. It really becomes less and less fun. This game just isn't for solo players, those without a friend group, or those who don't want to intimately interact in groups with people online. Its subjective, but i wouldn't reccommend it.

Foxhole is truly an amazing concept. An MMO set during a "modern day" war is something that I've always wanted, and the amount of dedication and drive the playerbase has is amazing. The world and story feels alive and I really enjoy the world which Siege Camp has created. 

The sheer amount of independence and choice the player has is what makes this game truly special. Wanna go be a grunt, stuck in a trench, warding off an offensive? You can do that. Or perhaps you want to join a tank division and push back waves of infantry. Maybe frontline fighting isn't for you, and instead you would rather man large storm cannons in the backlines. Or, you could participate in a large naval landing resembling D-Day. Maybe fighting in general just isn't your thing, and you'd rather go and manufacture everything needed for a war effort. It's totally up to you how you play the game.

The videos of this game that you will find make it seem really fun, with big teamwork action and an expansive choice of gameplay.
- You can either fight on the frontline with a plethora of weapons that requires teamwork to achieve good results with.
- Or you can go to the backline to make the factories and equipment that the frontliners will need to push the line.
- Or you can build large bunkers to secure terrain against enemy invasion.
- You will need to organise with hundreds of players to achieve shared goals.
- The two available factions have different playstyles that you will need to adapt to.

The game's concept is amazing. The execution however...

- Game balance has been terrible since the introduction of asymmetry. It is probably worse now than it was during early access. These problems are easily fixable, but for some reason they remain unfixed. [b]One faction has a definite upper hand over the other faction balance wise, which leads to a pop imbalance (who wants to play on the always losing team?) and bigger queues.[/b]
- Factories are unintuitive. Logi is unintuitive. You spend a lot of time asking questions because the interface does a terrible job telling you what the gameplay loop actually is. [b]You spend a lot of time grinding just to work around the game's clunky mechanics.[/b] You will have a hard time learning anything here unless you join a clan or you are lucky enough to come across an individual that is up for spending hours with you telling you how the system works.
- Good bunkers require the use of game bugs to build. The bunker meta is something that only the vets understand. [b]Bad balance in terms of anti-structure weaponry means people who build bunkers can lose a week's worth of work in 1 hour or less.[/b]
- Ingame organisation is awful. If you want to organise anything, it will be all done on discord. The game's squad system and map marks alone are wholly inadequate to deal with the task of organising offensives involving hundreds of people, and yet that's all you have to access. Casuals just do whatever on the front, only clans ever actually properly push something nowadays. This is not "skill issue", it is simply because [b]organising for people who do not live on discord is terrible, and at worst impossible when the ingame VC system goes down.[/b]

You can have fun in this game. But on balance you will spend more time being frustrated with the myriad of issues that it has, than having fun. The more you play, the more you will notice the glaring issues in the execution of its design. The more you will become annoyed about the thousands of issues that would take a tiny amount of time to fix that the devs never seem to fix.

You might think "haha look, another guy who has played 2k+ hours leaving a negative review". Yes I play this game even now. [b]Would I recommend it to others in its current state? Absolutely not.[/b] Save yourself, don't get involved, don't chug on the hopium/copium that the devs will fix the game. Just wait and see from a distance. I still hope that it will become competitive again, but in its current state it is not. If the devs do manage to fix it in the next few months, I will change this review.

Update 05/10/2023: No colonial sub. Nuff said lmao

I love the game, but I hate that the devs are not willing to do something about the problem of people creating a secondary steam account, joining the enemy faction and griefing the enemy faction.

And if a dev answers: I know that you hand-out temporary bans of like a few days, but I don't count that as "doing something" because you don't escalate the bans and the alts don't care. They just log into yet another alternate account and keep doing it.
Permaban these griefers after handing out some temp-bans.
Or hand out at least longer temp bans.
And hand out hardware ID bans against these players, so they're banned, temporarily or permanently, on their main account too.

Or, since you're so unbothered by the alting problem, make it an official game mechanic, where you steal the uniforms of enemy soldiers, that you have to repair in the backline, so you can go and do spy shit with some repurcussions (like AI doesn't detect you but there is a chance that they discover you're a fraud).

Do at least something!
"Report them and we ban them for a day" doesn't cut it and doesn't warrant all the extra work.
Imagine: The alts ruin our fun and then you expect us to go all the extra mile to catch it on video, catch their Steam-Profile ID, upload it on YouTube (in areas with slow internet that can take ages) and report it to you via your website and we don't even get a reply if an action has been taken against that player and his main account or not.

I repeat: I love the game itself but as long as the devs don't take decisive action against the alting problem, my review stays negative, stay away from the game, don't give these devs money, don't give them money for their upcoming game called "Anvil".

In the case that the devs do decide to take decisive action, I'm willing to change my review.

PS: So for Update 52 they announced a huge bunch of QoL And Moderation/Anti-Griefing Updates, which is good, BUT they didn't adress the core issue yet, that alts get banned way too short-spanned with like only 1-3 days bans and get no perma bans.

If I could give a neutral review, I'd do it, but I can't, so for now I leave it as a negative review.

Since they added more logs now to track down alts and want to improve their moderation of the game, maybe they will do something in the desired direction with Update 53.

So TL;DR, they're on a good way, but not there yet.

[h1]LONG:[/h1] 

The aiming system sucks. Im perfectly capable of putting my mouse cursor on the enemy and clicking, but even on enemies who are standing out in the open the game decides i didnt click hard enough or something and refuses to lock on, instead sending the bullet way over his head or straight into the dirt 5 feet away from me. There is also not alot of visual or audio feedback for when you shoot someone or get shot. No hitsound, no screen effect, you have to squint your eyes and look for the subtle blood splatters and wait for either you or the enemy to fall over dead.

Navigating the environment can be difficult for stupid reasons. Ive fallen through the floor multiple times, cliff edges sometimes push you out into the open to get shot, sometimes when walking ill get caught on the weird geometry and get stuck until i either get pushed out or die. The climbing system is broken too; sometimes i can climb shoulder-high objects easily, other times i have to shuffle in place and hold the spacebar for several seconds before the game allows me to climb over the shin-high plank of wood blocking my path. 

The social and strategic aspects are really fun though. A single soldier can easily make a difference even in a 50v50 with the right strategy, and there are quite a few playstyles for infantry to keep the game fresh. The community is about what youd expect for a world war style military simulator but it was suprisingly friendly, I havent heard a single racial slur or homophobic rant over voice or text chat. Which is EXEEDINGLY rare for a game like this.

UNRELATED: Once i got caught in the open reloading; an enemy ran up to me and tried to shoot me at point blank range, moving around between each shot. He missed 5 times in a row and said "What the fuck!!", as if he somehow wasnt expecting this, like the game wasnt working properly. This epic meta strategy he probably learned about on reddit or youtube had failed him, something about it was so demotivating i logged off for the night. I genuinely felt bad for him, he had given in to the meta, he was no longer a gamer but a collection of strategies carefully crafted by nerds who are allergic to fun and whimsy.

(building glitches such as curved bases and so on). I tried as a solo player for a bit, and with a small squad of friends, personally didn't find it very engaging.

Tutorials and training are poorly done, making it pretty unfriendly to people who aren't familiar with these types of games. - It gives you a vague grasp of the basics, for a game that has a huge amount of complication, I would've expected at least a better beginners' guide.

The camera is disorienting and makes it hard to fight in rapidly changing situations from a top-down perspective. - It's hard to view what's ahead more than 50 metres unless you're aiming down iron sights, making it hard to plan routes ahead. - I'm used to Total War top-down cameras and fast-paced action, but this took it to ridiculous levels when needing to push through multiple houses and alleys.

Terrain climbing on natural objects is janky and glitchy, moreso on rocky terrain.

Stepping into ankle-deep shallow water somehow turns you into the slowest man alive, and you put away your weapon, despite still being able to use it if you re-equip it, it makes it feel almost like a bug when it happens?

The few gunfights I had were fun when they were fixed positions or slow pushes, but the above just made the game unappealing.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Negative Review Saved Below for Posterity made at 764.2 hours. Thank you to the person who gave me an award for it, I still retain a negative-ish opinion about the devs' PR skills.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I bought Foxhole in early-access, about 2 months prior to the Entrenched Update and I absolutely love this game. I have by far the most hours on this game compared to any other I own and frankly it shows. 

Foxhole is a game that is incredibly addictive, you can easily go from one position to another in a very fluid manner, with each position incredibly fleshed out and exciting. I'll include an example from earlier in this war:

I, a medic, near the Iris (east side of the map) needed medical supplies and looking on the map found some in a bunker about 500 meters away, running there I found the medical supplies I needed to heal people and found a truck with fuel. As no-one claimed the truck, I thought it would be better to run logi (logistics) to the frontline bunker, so people won't have to run to the backlines to get medical gear like I did. Upon leaving to get medical gear from a logi port, I passed a decayed base (keeping that in mind) I delivered the supplies and returned to the decayed base to repair it. 

In the span of about 50 minutes, I went from medic, to logiman, to engineer and each felt like I would have a clear definable method of aiding the team and my allies. Now some of this is due to my short attention span, but on a good front you can have hours of fun just playing one role. (Infantry, tanker, medic, support). 

Even the scrapping and material making can be fun in small doses, put on some music and drown your eyes with scrooping, or run materials from the far backlines to the midlines. It's incredibly fun.

Additionally, the community is one of the most engaging and welcoming to new players that I have ever seen(for the most part, more on that below). My first 300 hours was all done without the aid or membership of a regiment, and I remember those days fondly. Community engagement can lead to all sorts of fun just with people being themselves, or playing characters on a battlefield. 


So why the "No" Vote?

The stereotypical cry for attention. Simply put, as I engage in higher levels of Foxhole discourse I have noticed the developers have ways to just not care about listening to their audience in ways that make us feel heard. I have two examples of this. 

First is the LOGI Union. A group of international players who worked to form a real-life union for an online game. It sounds crazy, but it happened (and is still happening). It was big news in the community, lovers, haters, and the in-between all talked about the Logi Union; it was even covered by a couple Games News Channels. The following update, there were some marginal changes to logistics mechanics, but there was no official acknowledgement from the developers. It was as if they were some big company trying to strike-break a union by offering cookies and crumbs to get them to stop. Despite not fully committing to the Union myself, it was an obvious sign that things would continue in that manner. 

Second, is the problem with alts and cheaters. To preface this, I will say for a long-time I have resisted this complaint, a lot of people use "alt" as an insult to to derogate the other people or regiments in the game and can be highly divisive within the community. "Alt" stands for a person who creates another account in Foxhole to join the other team than their main account to purposely sabotage logistics, vehicles, bases, and intelligence (planned operations that sort of thing). However, this war I have seen first-hand multiple people who gas out entire townhalls full of people, or drive cranes with emplacements into rivers, try to steal tanks from others, and generally be a nuisance. 

This has always been a problem, however never at a level that has committed vast grievances across the whole community. In the end, oftentimes alts do the work of partisans, and those who are more obvious are caught (but never banned), but the real problem is the damage it causes to the community. Take a quick scan of other negative comments, many come from new players who got "caught" as an alt and were quickly mass reported. Alts know what to do, they are veterans who go in with a specific task and leave before they can be caught. A new player makes a mistake and they are lynched for it. Because these days more people are quicker to judge, mistakes have been made that led to waste of resources and we are more suspicious as a whole and I hate that. 
The other day, people were talking in region-chat about a suspected alt, I thought they were just being babies about a new player. 5 minutes later in the height of an artillery barrage, he gassed out the townhall, we survived, but it makes me weary to trust new players. And I went through that experience as a new player.

Siege Camp and the development team of Foxhole hurt me. They insult the players' intelligences and they roll out updates without a word of acknowledgement. I will continue to play, but I do not recommend new players to until this review becomes positive.

If there was an option to leave a mixed review, I certainly would. Foxhole is one of those rare gems that I've been seeking for many years and yet I cannot help but find myself rather... disappointed in several regards. My review will detail what I love, and utterly despise about this enjoyable, but headache inducing game, and why I give it a tentative thumbs up. 


[h1]What I love:[/h1]
[b]Teamwork the good:[/b]
The game glorifies teamwork. Teamwork is literally the name of the game and without it nothing would get done. Half the time, everything runs smoothly. Logistics is on point, delivering ammo, B-mats, weapons, uniforms, medical supplies, explosives, ect to the active frontlines where they're sorely needed. Players are working together to fortify a heavily contested location; building up intricate bunker and trench lines that are nigh impossible to crack without a heavy armor spearhead and countless artillery bombardments, coordinating combined arms of artillery, tanks, light scout vehicles and infantry into a beautiful blend of overwhelming firepower and morale crushing speed. Medics are playing their roles well keeping the frontline alive and active with their invaluable work, ensuring each squad is back up to full fighting strength without too much downtime. Often going out of their way to pull victory from the jaws of defeat with well timed and well coordinated triage efforts. Teamwork makes the entire game run, and without teamwork Foxhole just wouldn't be possible. By that point alone it's the main selling point that hooked me without question. 


[b]The Community the good:[/b]
Regardless what side of the coin you fall into; Colonials, Wardens, it doesn't much matter. Foxhole offers you a rich and diverse group of players who can move whole armies, shatter impregnable fortresses, craft endless tides of weapons and vehicles for war, aiding and guiding newer players on how to play well, while providing an experience unlike anything I've seen in an MMO before. I've met many a wonderful player who has made the game all that more engaging and wonderful, forging strong bonds of friendship that last even to this day for me. Foxhole has time and time again shown it's an incredible game with everything I could ask for. It's like a blend of RTS and third person shooters, and I adore it beyond words. As cliche as it sounds, when you're hunkered down in a foxhole with three other players with artillery shells exploding all around you, you feel a kinship with those players. Especially when someone breaks out into a shanty while explosions tear the land asunder with everyone else joining in.


[b]The Wars the good:[/b]
Foxhole lives up to the promise in crafting an all encompassing war that spans days, weeks, months at a timeWars that can swing from one side having the initiative and advantage, to it all being lost by one massive breakthrough by the other team. The high stakes of every engagement, the thrill of being part in some grand operation to push the enemy out of territory you need, and the white knuckle firefights where one mistake could cost you hours of progress. It what really helps the game shine, and makes it feel like the most authentic large scale persistent war I've had the pleasure of playing in. 


[h1]What I hate:[/h1]
[b]Teamwork the bad:[/b]
While teamwork is the name of the game... you're not always going to find it in Foxhole. Logistics ignores priority zones in favor of hording resources for specific clan bases, which can lead to massive swathes of territory being lost, and the war tipping firmly into the favor of the enemy. Players run around like chickens without heads grabbing as much ammo and material as possible only to die by throwing themselves haphazardly into the enemy lines losing both shirts and vital resources. Or just as often kamikaze a vehicle into the enemy base in some vain effort to feel like the main character of the game. Medics are screamed at for not running out into the line of fire to save some fool who chose to run headlong into the enemy machine guns or just as often not doing their jobs and healing those who are dying. And the absolute nightmare that is haphazardly constructed bases that are more of a detriment to the builders than to the enemy. Teamwork is the all important thing that makes Foxhole run smoothly, and unfortunately it's a mixed bag which result you'll get. Half the time it's a deeply engaging and breath taking example of what the players can accomplish by working together, and other times it's an utter cesspool of stupidity that there is no real escape from. 


[b]The Community the bad:[/b]
This is where the majority of my criticism lays. In this large scale persistent war you will find the absolute worst aspects of humanity on full display. Granted, my complaints are not focused upon the majority of the community, but the deafening minority who unleash slur after slur at each other for no other reason than to get a rise out of the other. Attacking people based upon the faction they choose to play. Sending death threats and calls to 'remove themselves from living' for daring to play a faction other than their own, harassing and degrading new players for simply trying to learn the game or just outright shooting them repeatedly for the laughs, and countless other examples. The game is supposed to glorify players bonding and playing together for a shared goal, and yet a vocal minority ruins the fun for the rest of the players by being xenophbic asshats who deify their precious faction to an unhealthy degree. 


[b]The Wars the bad:[/b]
In a game about persistent war, there are going to be agonizingly long stretches where you find yourself with nothing to really do. You missed the massive breakthrough into enemy territory and there's no trucks around to give you a lift? Better start running and hope you don't run into partisans. Get killed without setting your spawn point at the Battle Bunker? Best hope you don't get left behind when the frontline charges forward. The wars can be a great deal of fun when you get to take part in the actual fighting, but just as often you can get left behind without warning, or get drafted into resource consolidation by some higher ranking player who can and will kill you for disobeying them. Or just as often staring out across no-man's-land for hours on end waiting for the enemy to attack or your own team to attack. Or, worst of all, being on the receiving end of a total rout. Being steamrolled day in day out with no real way of fighting back, it becomes discouraging, and frankly not much fun. I could go on much more about it all, but I think my point is fairly clear.


[b]Conclusion: [/b]
At the end of the day I give the game a solid 3 out of 5. Foxhole has it's goods, it's bads, and it's ugly. In short, you should at least give the game a try and see if it's up your alley, though I highly suggest getting it while it's on sale. The game may not be for you, but there's no real harm in giving it a try as long as you keep in mind that like any game there will be toxic assholes, and frustrating lapses in action. I have much more to say about the game, but this review is already long enough as it is, and in the end only you can formulate your own opinion on this rough but undeniably gorgeous gem. A tentative thumbs up.

If you are looking for a shooter where you can get a pentakill after 5 seconds you spawned in, this game is not for you. If you really want a WWII shooter experience without feeling like the main character and unfair death is the norm, this game is for you.

First off, your actions have to be slow and deliberate in order play well. You can't just rush into the front lines. I can not tell you how many times in my first few hours in the game how I took a bunch of gear just to go and die because I thought the trenches were just aesthetic. Only poke your head out for short periods of time. Stabilize your gun before you fire. Wait until night to rush across the battlefield. Even tanks can get demolished by going a bit too far into enemy territory.

If you want a more chill experience, you don't have to be in the front lines. The equipment in a base is constructed and transported by far more people in the back lines than in the front. If you just want to collect coal for 8 hours strait while listening to music, you can do that.

The world makes you feel so inconsequential in the whole scheme of things. Even if you are in a tank or manning artillery or get behind enemy lines with a bayonet, your actions can not hope to change the tide of war. A few feet of ground can be an entire region lost tomorrow. Even if you do win, a new war will just start up anew again. If you feel like you let your faction down, just know it's not your fault.

Anyways, Foxhole is fun even when you get pounded by infinite artillery/tanks, the game can be very intense or not if you so feel like it, and the Wardens can eat my Colonial ass.

This game is like none other that I've played.  I had a hell of a time trying to explain this game to my friend, so instead I simply linked him this, and we watched it together.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5U03hTMAmtI

I have yet to run into a bug, which is great for an early access game.  On top of that, when I started off, I had no real clue what I was doing, and while I was trying to get situated, a random sergeant recruited me to help him with logistics, gather scrap and turning it into materials to be used in various factories.

We ran materials to the front, from city to city, delivered loads of shirts (respawn material), rifles, ammo, and grenades, and had great fun for hours.  We lost track of each other when a city fell we were in, and I died before making it back to his truck.  After respawning, I began to dedicate myself to taking back that city, at first simply working with a few others to halt the enemies advance from that one along the back roads to our HQ.  I found my original Sergeant again during a push, and using smoke to disrupt lines of sight, and HE grenades to blow emplacements, 20 or so of us fought for each yard, and eventually each foot on the way back to our lost city's center.

Before I quit for the day, that city was ours once more, and a new front had begun to develop.

All in all, a completely different experience from any other I've had in over 30 years of gaming, from PacMan to now.

Foxhole is not in a good place right now.

1) Wars last too long.
As of writing, war 100 is wrapping up with a length of roughly 55 days, making it the longest war by a wide margin. The previous record was from War 95 taking 42 days, which was so long it was referred to as the "forever war" at the time. The next in line where 36 days and 35 days respectively. In my opinion, wars should never take more than 30 days, as any longer just causes immense amounts of burnout on both sides.

2) Logi and Facilities suck. 
The logi system, which has always sucked, was meant to be fixed by facilities. However, they do nothing to address the array of problems that logi has, and instead introduced a whole slew of new problems.
- They require massive amounts of materials to construct.
- They requires massive amounts of upkeep just to be maintained.
- Automation is practically non-existent, meaning everything needs to be done through manual labour.
- The massive amounts of hours that need to go into running a facility makes it impossible for solo logi and small clans to achieve, as well as still being a massive burden to all but the biggest clans.
- They are really hard to defend, requiring either a massive base to be constructed and maintained, or hoping no partisan comes near your facility.
- They get significantly more complex if you want to build the late game stuff, exacerbating the previous issues.
- All of this is extremely tedious and unfun.
- The best items are locked behind facilities, meaning those who don't want to deal with this are screwed.
The fact that the dev team saw the massive outcry from the L.O.G.I Union, and decided that this was an acceptable solution is a very sad joke.

3) Complete lack of moderation.
This isn't a situation of the devs not moderating enough, but rather the devs refusing to moderate at all. They promote a system of self moderation by the community as a way of not having to pay for moderators themselves, with has just left alts and toxic players getting off with almost anything scot-free. This then leads to a situation where systems like the report player button cannot be significantly changed despite how easily abuseable they are by clans because its the only form of moderation that is available. Better a broken tool than none at all.

4) Complete lack of developer communication. 
A signature move of siege camp is a refusal to properly engage with the community. They can have a literal strike by a large section of the community and they won't even give a "we are working on it", let alone seriously engage with the issues presented. The only time they will communicate is when they push a massive update, before going back into hibernation for half a year. Its a big game, they can afford to hire a community manager.

If you haven't touched this game before, you may think its weird I'm writing this after getting 700+ hours out of it, with many other reviews coming from other players with hundreds or thousands of hours, but that's because the more you play this game, the more you are exposed to the deep seeded problems imbedded in this game. Out of all the games I've played, this is the only one where it feels like its actively getting worse with no real hope of change without a significant shakeup at siege camp, which seems improbable at best. I feel powerless to meaningfully change the game in a positive direction, or to address the array of problems not outlined in this post, so the only real thing I can do is post this, and hope the devs take note.

Foxhole is one of my favorite games of all time.

It has some issues that need to be addressed (I won‚Äôt go too much into it, but you can look it up, but little stuff like watchtower shielding, and bunker-bending), and it can be difficult at times (especially if you try to do things solo) but man, this game has some special stuff to it that no other game can offer.

Logistics is a game of its own and can be a lot of fun (although time-consuming) and super satisfying actually seeing things you produced yourself causing destruction on a front line. There is a lot of complexity and levels to it, all the way from the person mining scrap up to the truck driver, or ship captain delivering it.

There are so many special moments you can get in Foxhole you can't get with other games, like being the driver of a truck full of much needed supplies, and sliding through enemy artillery fire to deliver in the knick of time, or my personal favorite: the incredible rush you get from taking down enemy armor as an infantry with nothing but some flasks, your instincts, and adrenaline.

Another thing I love about this game is how global it is, If you play a lot you will end up in squads and regiments with people from all around the world, fighting together for one cause. I have learned so many little facts about other people's cultures, just from shooting the shit in a trench or talking while we wait for daybreak in a tank.

Couple all of that with a community so passionate it borderlines mental illness and you have magic.

Also, a small side note: the ambient sound is so good. It‚Äôs such an eerie feeling when the sun goes down and before all you could hear was gunfire and explosions, and you find it replaced with frogs, birds chirping, and the wind. Really sets the mood.

Persistent faction warfare, logistics, engineering, trench digging and resource management across dynamic territories. 

Foxhole is for the most part - the military sandbox MMO I'd always dreamed of that the gaming industry had lacked the tech or interest to achieve. Foxhole excitingly achieves this military simulation with an isometric view somewhat limiting your range of vision. This surprisingly creates quite a fun immersive experience, as you begin to notice how insignificant your combat efforts are compared to the larger war machine. Or vice versa, as hero soldiers, covert partisans & tireless engineers change the tide.

Been a persistent faction war demands persistent players and balance on what a single player can achieve. If communication here is not your type of game you may find yourself extremely limited in what you can do. Grab a rifle, a couple of clips & repeat on the front-line. As much as I love the concept of what Foxhole is, as well as what it allows players to achieve, the last few wars in Foxhole have demonstrated to me that Siege Camp is not going to adequately enforce or moderate the game. War 106 has largely been an "Exploit War' where regiments and people from both sides of the game have elected to exploit things in order to achieve victory, and worse, defend their cheating as legitimate. The community has gotten overly toxic and while I am the last person to ever condemn or point blame at the developers, the lack of communication and moderation from Siege Camp is deafening. The only thing they've done is acknowledge that they're aware of the issues, but refuse to take action on video evidence of people blatantly exploiting unintended mechanics.

I love Foxhole, I truly do. I wanted to commit a large portion of my content creation towards the game, and I've brought a number of people into it; However, I will likely now largely warn my community and to any considering Foxhole to avoid it until Siege Camp elects to moderate their game more closely and strictly by banning those leveraging exploits, as well as actually communicating more with their community on their plans, calling things out for being exploits, and making it clear that the developers will take definitive action against those exploiting the game. Until Foxhole does this, I have no interest in the game moving forward and I anticipate that the player numbers will spike briefly for the upcoming naval update, and then once again plummet.

For the time being, I advise that you avoid Foxhole. You will end up committing a large amount of time towards a game that has been largely abandoned in terms of developer silence and its lack of moderation.

Foxhole is truly a gem of a game, albeit for the right player. Take everything below with a grain of salt, and consider this is all told from the perspective of a Medic main.

[h3] Pros / What I like [/h3]
What I love about it the most is that you are a very small cog in a large machine, and you'd better get used to the thought when playing! No one player can have an astronomical impact on the front as far as gameplay goes. No one player is going to kill you and all the other friends around you, blow up a tank, and then run laughing back to their lines. Yes, you might get outskilled on occasion, and feel frustrated, but in the long run it is hardly influential to the outcome of the war or even the stretch of front you're playing on. This aspect, apart from allowing even a complete newbie to have fun, encourages cooperation among players (you won't see any squad of 4 people hopelessly destroying your team like you see in Battlefield). Everything  turns out better when you work together with your fellow soldiers!

Another thing I enjoy about the game is that it has one of the best blends of realism and goofiness. It is realistic where it should be, as a wanna-be milsim game, and goofy where it would be too annoying to be realistic. The mechanics are generally fun, the art is lovely, the gameplay simple to grasp. The map is nicely constructed to allow strategical positioning and building, while retaining a cozy feeling whenever you drive around the many different and unique places. Not to mention there's also a little bit of a backstory to it and easter eggs scattered around for players to find.

Continuing the list of aspects I like, I have to mention the fact that winning doesn't matter in this game. Yes, the plot consists of an all out war between Colonials and Wardens. It is a nice morale boost and source of pride for a faction to win a war, maintain a long winstreak, or win significant wars when the playerbase soars and tactics and determination of both factions are put to the test. But does winning matter down to the individual soldier? You can still have fun regardless. You can still crack jokes with your friend while under artillery barrage. You can still catch an enemy tank offguard and destroy it. You can still conduct an operation with your clanmates and push the enemy back. Rude as it sounds as a premise for a game, most of the *fun* in foxhole is derived from the amount of misery you can provoke to the enemy. The more painful you make it for them to take territory, consolidate already occupied one, bring resources and even walk to the front [i]*cough cough artillery barrage cough*[/i], the more fun it is for you. That is, until you're at the receiving end of the same treatment :D


To summarize, why is Foxhole fun? It's a persistent all out war in which cooperation rather than individual skill is the key to victory - which I believe should be the goal of every multiplayer game that pitches one team against another, but none that I played have managed to do so in such an organic way. Not to mention the fun community, the jokes, the roleplay, and the dude blasting Fortunate Son in local voice chat.


[h3] What you might not like [/h3]
Now, let's see what aspects might not appeal to people.

For starters, while I said the mechanics are pretty simple, it will take you a while to get your head around them. The game has a tutorial area in the home region - it's okay for a new player I guess, but somewhat inconvenient since you need to read signs and what not. It's much to learn, but I have always found veteran players willing to teach me in a very friendly manner, and it's way more engaging. I still haven't learned how to build bunkers efficiently after 2k hours, but I know many people who do and whom I could ask for help when needed. 

Another fundamental yet debated topic is Logistics - basically, everything that goes on so that rifles, ammo, vehicles and everything else gets to the front to be used. It's a time consuming process, involving quite a few hours of work depending on what you want to build and ship to the front. Harvesting resources, refining them, turning them into gear and transporting are all simple mechanics, but you need to do them over and over again if you want a healthy stock of supplies to support a front with.

We should also talk about facilities. They are relatively new to the game and are an entire new level of logistics gameplay. In short, they are a pretty long production chain of resources: you build buildings that produce a type of resource using already available materials. Then that resource is used for a new building, producing the next level resource. At the same time, all these resources can be used to upgrade vehicles and make new toys of war. The problem is, it's hard, if not impossible, to do this solo. While regular logistics are ok for a solo player, facilities are usually maintained by clans, where all members pitch in a little and hence the workload is lessened on everybody. Some people / regiments take to maintaining public facilities which you, as a solo player, can use for upgrades freely / for a resource fee. All in all it's not that bad, but doing a solo facility is like getting a job so, for your own good, please don't.

Some people accuse the community of being toxic - in any community you have some bad apples. What bad apples can you expect in Foxhole? People who think their in-game rank gives them authority. People who try hard and start blaming newbies when things go wrong (i.e. their tank gets destroyed and they blame the nearby privates and corporals for not being able to kill harassing infantry). People who gatekeep new players from organized activities - this happens more rarely but as a new player you might see a big clan (lots of people with the same tag before their name) doing something organized. It looks fun, you wanna help or join in, then they start yelling at you to not do something / not mess with their stuff and all that. Sounds bad, it is to an extent, but most often however, it's just too difficult to integrate a new player into an ongoing operation involving tanks, artillery etc. Too many mechanics to explain on the go, and this equipment is quite expensive. Once you get to know logistics better you'll find out why operation leaders are not too keen on letting new players join in in the middle of an ongoing effort (I have been guilty of this myself a couple times). 

Another often toxic interaction is new players building and veteran players telling them to stop doing so. This occasionally devolves into shooting, and yeah, not very fun for a new player. I like to refer to building as a 'delicate art', which myself I don't know how to practice, so building badly can be advantageous for the enemy, and hard for friendly builders to fix after. If caught in such a situation, use the opportunity to ask what you're doing wrong - there has to be an explanation, a reason, preferably a logical one. Try to work out the conflict, instead of escalating.


Many other reviews claim that you need a large group of friends or a regiment in order to have fun. I disagree. I started as a solo medic, had loads of fun at the front on my own / occasionally cooperating with other medics in the same area. I did join a medic regiment and, in time, ended up commanding it, but I integrated so well with the community that I can find another regiment doing an operation at almost any time of day, and they'd be more than glad to have me swing by. You can do the same even by staying solo. Most regiments have auxiliary roles for people who are not members but often play alongside them.


I hope I managed to give you as good of an unbiased opinion on Foxhole. In over 2000 hours I think I can say I've had more than just fun, and I sincerely wish I knew about this game sooner!

Foxhole, an innovative top to bottom militaristic sandbox game, along with massive multiplayer and an online persistent war. In this review, I will be going over what Foxhole is, what it has to offer, and identify it's strengths and weaknesses in it's current state which at the time this review was written, the version is 0.4 Alpha, the Amphibious Warfare Update.
Let's get started shall we?


[h1]Important information on Foxhole[/h1]

Now granted, you must know this going in, there is a HUGE learning curve here in Foxhole, and if you don't devote some time to reading the tutorials, checking out official videos on how to play, or communicating with your team, you are going to most likely [b]hate[/b] your first experience.

You will spawn in at your army's main headquarters, you will have a hammer and a pistol with a single magazine. You can gether scrap and hundreds of other materials in your backpack, but be careful as your bag gets heavy upon gathering materials, carry too much and you will become encumbered.
 Your objective, win the war. To win, you must capture all towns and your enemies' main headquarters, pretty simple. Upon spawning in, you can do one of two things, you can fight on the front lines, or you can take part in logistics operations. Rifles and other weapons do not grow on trees in Foxhole; they must be created through scrap, components and other various recources from the field of operation, and creating and manufacturing these weapons is quite a process.
One final thing, Foxhole is not a game that can be won by yourself. If you are not coordinating with your teammates through your microphone or text, then you're not going to be assisting your team very much by wasting recources trying to kill the enemy yourself, you will easily get killed all alone. Instead, look for some teammates to tag along with, fortunately the Foxhole community is full of very good and passionate players... mostly. The player's rank is displayed in parentheses to the left of their Steam username. Corporals and Sergeants are the most common and have a good amout of experience on what to do in a squad, don't be shy to talk with your teammates; communication is key.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]


Very fluid gameplay. It's a top to bottom shooter, taking aim will represent a line displaying the exact direction where you are aiming your weapon. There are many many different weapons in the game from rifles (which is the most common), SMGs, Carbines, Mortars, Assault rifles, Machine guns - you name it. Pro tip: you are harder to hit at a range when you are crouching or proning. Your visibility is greatly reduced at night, so you must stayon your toes when partolling at after dusk. I get this eerie feeling when slowly advancing to the enemy town with my squad, the thought strikes you - "Are we walking into an ambush?" "Is there an enemy foxhole just up ahead?" Combat can get tense.
Even though there are only 7 maps, each of these maps are enourmous, and the average war can take hours and hours to end; I've never participated in a war from start to finish in a single sitting.


[h1]Story of Foxhole[/h1]


There is not much known about the lore of Foxhole, however there are a couple of known facts and notes found by players during the weekly wars that give an idea of what the lore is about.

Foxhole has two fictional factions, the Wardens and the Colonials, fighting a 100-year war in a fictional world (It's locations and setting do not have any correlation with the real world). The makeup of the two factions geographically are unknown, but they do not represent the historical Allies and Axis, even though many players including myself enjoy to depict the Colonials as U.S. Forces and the Wardens as the Axis Forces.


[h1]Issues with Foxhole[/h1]

My largest gripe with Foxhole is how boring and tedious this game can be while running logistics operations, everybody who joins a war wants to grab a gun and fight, who wants to swing a hammer for an hour? And the thing is, logistics is arguably the most important role to play in this game. As I said before, weapons and ammo don't grow on trees. And many players take all these weapons and equipment for granted. Look at it this way: That Assault rifle that guy took and lost.. had taken 3 hours to produce. And yes, it can take 3 or more hours to create an assault rifle, because only logistics can muster the technology upgrades to produce said weapon, [b]which takes a long time.[/b] Logistics needs to be less of a hassle, or simply add a mode where you can respawn with more weapons and medical supplies. I get that Foxhole is supposed to simulate real war in a way, but it would be nice to see some changes.
Another issue is the reprimandation system griefers can use on any player at will as they please. If you are reprimanded, you lose an hours worth of experience points from playing the game; this happened to one of my friends, he was just about to hit the Sergeant rank and suddenly, he was ranomly reprimanded by some troll. The reprimandation system needs tweaking.
The next thing is when an army starts losing the war, the players on that team begin to lose the will to fight and proceed to drop from the server, this leads to the opposing army crushing their enemy beneath their treads as the game drops to 60 VS 20.

Last thing I could say that would improve Foxhole, I believe more Players vs Ememies content is needed, it would help ease more players into the action, and it would be nice to just sit back and have a good time with your friends.


[h1]Summary[/h1]


Overall, Foxhole is very innovative and fresh, of course, this is in 0.4 Alpha at the time this review was written, so there are many spaces for improvement.
Foxhole earns my recommendation for it's diverse gameplay, and the memorable moments I had with my squad on the battlefield. I got my $20 dollars worth from Foxhole. I am currently taking a break from Foxhole for now, once I return, I am hoping Clapfoot will add or improve some of the features I have listed above. If you have any friends that are considering Foxhole, it may be worth giving it a shot.


The final rating for Foxhole is a difficult one since this is an Early Access Game. But for me, the final rating for Foxhole stands at a 6/10. I hope to see a lot more from this game in the future.

This is my first review of an Early Access Game, This is Commander Stealth and I will see you all on the next review.


Over and out. ~Stealth

Edit: I'm revising this review as Foxhole has dramatically changed since this was originally written. Cheaters have overtaken this game and developers have done little to nothing to stop this from happening. Looking back at it now, I've been too nice on this game. Corner-screening always wins, the community is toxic as frack, the population is low and there is no PVE. Not Recommended. Unfortunately I cannot change my recommendation on the review as it will erase this review's ratings, and I will not do that.

after 5,000 hours on this game.... i can tell you there's a lot to learn, but ultimately, it's not worth the effort; game is badly broken in many aspects, and community competition is just about abusing the bugs.  you will lose weeks of work in 30 seconds for no reason other than bugs being abused.  devs dont care, they are happy to sell new copies of the game after banning the offenders.

it is also made for about 5k-8k people per team, but only pulls about 2k per team, and of those, only about 100 will play the game properly.  the rest just regard it as an arcade shooter.  it's really a great shame, because it could be a great milsim game.  instead, it's just a broken grind-fest.

play it if you dont care about having a proper competitive game - but if that's the case, there are much better games anyway.

this is a game that future devs should  copy, but fix, and i look forward to when one does.

There's so much to say in a review for this game because it absolutely has it's ups and downs. If you want to ask about concerns you have with buying the game, feel free to comment or private message me. As someone who's been around in this game and following development off and on since 2017 (first released in early access on Steam), and someone who works in game development, I feel like I have can explain peoples issues with the game and the counterpoints often brought up as well as how the game has progressed over many years. 

Overall, I'd definitely recommend it with the caveat that it's not like any other game out there and it's certainly not for everyone. It's a very complex game with many in depth features so expect a learning curve. There's absolutely flaws in the game but in my opinion, it's completely worth it. Especially with how much love the developers put into the game. They're not always right with what they want to do, and they certainly don't communicate as much as they should, but they're clearly VERY passionate about this game and they continue to show it so long as you take off your jaded sunglasses.
