Edited review: Very niche game, but a well executed one. Plenty of 'space' to fill a role of your choosing, be it infantry, tanking, logistics, construction, etc. Can be played solo or with friends as you please with ease.

Foxhole has completely captivated me with its unique blend of strategy and teamwork. From the moment I stepped into the expansive battlefield, I was immersed in a world of constant collaboration, evolving frontlines, and the thrill of cooperative warfare.

The player-driven world of Foxhole is unlike anything I've experienced before. The seamless integration of logistics, combat, and resource management creates a dynamic and immersive environment. The feeling of being a part of a living, breathing war effort is simply unmatched.

The strategic depth of the game is truly remarkable. Coordinating with fellow soldiers, planning attacks, and strategizing to hold key positions keeps me engaged and invested in the outcome of each battle. The camaraderie that emerges from working together to achieve a common goal is incredibly rewarding.

The persistent world adds a layer of realism that few games achieve. The consequences of our actions have a direct impact on the ever-changing frontlines, creating a sense of agency that drives the gameplay forward.

The game's art style is charming and fits the wartime theme perfectly. The sounds of gunfire, explosions, and the hum of machinery all contribute to the immersive atmosphere of war-torn landscapes.

What sets Foxhole apart is the strong sense of community. Whether I'm fighting alongside familiar faces or making new allies, the cooperative nature of the game fosters friendships and memorable moments that stay with me long after I've logged off.

This game is a gem. Is a unique war MMO.

It suffers from a lot of issues, specially developer communication with the community and cycles of balance issues that generally get fixed in months that are exacerbated by the very embroiled in the game.

If you
-Like massive Multiplayer Games
-Like Wars with tactical and strategic decisions that matter
-Like games that gives you different things to do besides combat including building, supplying or just even participating in the community outside the game
-And have no life

I will recommend this game.

If you don't like
-Very intensive communities related to balance posts
-Games that take time and effort to complete tasks
-Uncommunicative devs
-Factionalism or discussions about the game that makes it looks like a cheap reddit political debate

Then I wouldn't recommend it.
Have fun.

At first I thought it was great. Like a tower defense except my enemies were real people. Putting down barb wire and defenses then watching the enemy struggle into them while my allies picked them off was great. Then it all started to fall apart. 

Whether or not you or your team gets to use certain weapons or tactics is entirely dependent on the clans that run that part of the world. In the current war there are parts of the world my team cannot go because the enemy Storm Cannons (Most powerful artillery in the game, extremely effective) will obliterate us if we try. If we are in range of those guns, they are firing. And they won't stop firing until all of us are dead. 

Meanwhile take a trip to our side of the map? There are SC's one river away from our enemy that just sit dormant because the can that runs them wants to do something else. And because clans can LOCK these weapons, NO ONE gets to use them. SC's will sit fully charged, with 100+ rounds sitting next to it and remain completely unused. When you challenge the clans about this they say you're a noob and need to shut up. You can point out that our enemy isn't letting these extremely powerful weapons just sit there but it doesn't matter they run the world so no one gets to challenge them. 

This goes for a lot of things like logistics, supply, who gets tanks, who gets any kind of support at all. Clans will come in destroy everything you made remake it the way they want it and then leave again and refuse to support you with materials to upkeep. And on top of ALL of this the game has 0 stat tracking. Which means you have no earthly idea if you're making a difference. You can place down 1000 land mines and kill 1000 people or, you could kill no one. You have no way of telling whether or not your contributions made a difference which makes the 3-5 minute slog back to the front lines feel absolutely pointless when you get run over by a friendly car and have to re-equip and walk all over again. Uncertain of if your efforts make a difference. 

It was fantastic for the first few hours. Now I regret getting it, and every time I try to get into it I just find more glaring holes in the formula that make me feel exhausted. If the major clans don't immediately agree with you, you might as well not be playing because you won't be getting any help. Entire sections of the map fall because clans hoard their wealth weapons and resources.

Bought the game yesterday, and have already spent almost 12 hours with it, even without playing with friends. Everyone I've met have been incredibly friendly and a ton of fun to play with. There's so much depth to a lot of the systems in the game, but despite of that, I haven't found the learning curve to be bad at all. The tutorial pretty much gave me everything I needed. The addition of proximity voice chat is also amazing, and while it can be hard to determine which direction a sound is coming from, it allows for hours of fun, talking to both my own team, and the enemy. I've only really played as a medic, but I plan on trying out all of the other roles over the course of the coming wars.

When i was originally looking at THIS exact page, wondering if i should buy this game, i ran into a lot of the reviews complaining about large clans, and their overwhelming power over their own faction. Often people would talk about their bad experiences with a clan that dosent like them, mass reporting them, and them getting banned.

Before i say anything about anything...I would like to say that i have mainly only played casually and alone. That dose not mean i havent interacted with other players and the community as a whole! I have been a part of many small scale operations formed by smaller groups of people or even larger clans. But i am not directly a member of a clan/group, big or small. Now that we have clearly established my position in the player base, lets get into what MY experiences have told ME, about the community, and game as a whole.

I have fought in two wars (at the time of writing), War 105, and 106. In 105 i was a warden, in 106 i am a colonial. I have not gotten into any brawls/fights/arguments/"just a bit of banter"s or general disagreements with other players. Specifically in war 106, in which i started properly interacting with other players. During war 105 i was a lot less experienced and naturally intimidated by the idea of simply joining a tank crew for example. So i have more experience interacting with colonial players than wardens. I cant yet properly say if wardens are any better/worse than collies, but at the very least i can confidently say collies have been VERY noob friendly so far! Now these are only my experiences, which dont speak for everybody, but i personally think that at the current stage of the game (at least if you go collie) you most likely wont have to go through any...Bullying, insulting, mass reports, team kills to players or structures, or any kind of toxicity. But dont think you can get away with doing something legitimately dumb! You will be scolded, but not ruthlessly shitted on.

TLDR: i dont know about wardens, but collies are pretty friendly. Worth the price.

Edit 2: I am seeing progress being made and I like it. But, I am still waiting to see if it's a one off update, or the devs are finally going to address the ages old issues consistently.

While a lot of issues are still not addressed, we might see them fixed in the future. I think the cross-faction vc warrants the change of review to Positive. Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ (5/5)

I've been a part of the gaming community for years, but Foxhole truly stands out as an incredible gem in the vast sea of titles. From the moment I joined the frontlines, I was hooked by the immersive and dynamic world this game offers.

Foxhole's approach to large-scale warfare is nothing short of genius. The persistent war, where players collectively shape the outcome, creates an unparalleled sense of camaraderie and accomplishment. Teaming up with fellow soldiers, whether it's in the heat of battle or during resource gathering, feels like participating in a real, living war effort.

The game's focus on teamwork and strategy is both refreshing and deeply engaging. Communication is key, and I've made friends and memories that will stick with me for a lifetime. Whether you're scouting the enemy's lines, coordinating assaults, or playing a supporting role, every action contributes to the bigger picture.

One aspect I truly appreciate is how Foxhole promotes creativity. The freedom to construct structures, establish supply lines, and shape the battlefield according to our strategy adds a layer of depth that few games achieve. It's incredibly satisfying to see your plans come to fruition, and the feeling of turning the tide of battle through sheer coordination and ingenuity is second to none.

Graphically, Foxhole might not be on par with the AAA giants, but it's still visually appealing in its own right. The gritty, war-torn landscapes and the attention to detail in both character models and vehicles contribute to the game's immersive atmosphere.

Foxhole's developers deserve major kudos for their dedication to improving the game. Regular updates, responsive community engagement, and a clear passion for their creation are evident in every aspect. The game's learning curve might be a bit steep, but the supportive community and the feeling of accomplishment as you become a skilled soldier are absolutely worth the effort.

In conclusion, Foxhole is a shining example of what multiplayer sandbox warfare games can achieve. It's not just a game; it's an experience that keeps me coming back for more, eager to be part of something much larger than myself. If you're looking for a game that rewards strategy, teamwork, and creativity, look no further than Foxhole. This war simulation masterpiece has earned its place as one of my all-time favorites!

A massive multiplayer top down war strategy game that allows multiple play styles from the shooter to the builder.

A interactive war zone that is mined, defended and attacked by player design. The logistics/builder types build tranches and bunkers as well as backline industry to support the frontline efforts.

While it has a learning curve once the basics are learnt the rest is on the job training. Headset and microphone is a must for a more coherent play.

Just out of early development with continued developer support and plans to improve.

Highly recommend for multiple play styles it covers.

I want to like the game, but I just can't recommend it.  There are massive gameplay balance issues.  If one side starts to get just a bit of momentum, the whole war is over.

There are also lots of other frustrations; visibility is terrible, you feel like you're fighting wearing a scuba mask, the 3D is sketchy, someone in a trench is more protected than someone in a building looking down on them, and basic logistics is tedious by design.

They have the purchase money, not save them on server costs and go away.

Original review. 
Had a little bit of fun but overall felt like the game is too much of a chore. 

You wanna run logistics to win the war? In order to get resources, you have to farm mats for them and this is really boring with no personal satisfaction whatsoever. You just hold down M1 button to farm or go drive around the map going to auto-miners. 

Maybe you'd like to be a driver? But your vehicle gets disabled after a few bullets and your supply may end up going into enemy hands after that. Worst still, griefers will come and steal your vehicle full of supplies meant for your home base and rid of your inventory or drive it down to the enemy camp for them to steal. Many times, these griefers are from your own team.

Good luck getting people to vote-kick the griefers if you're a nobody. Much less luck if you are without a clan and don't have any group pull. If you're not in a clan, you belong to a group of nobodies and bad eggs from big clans/groups have pretty much their way to either bully you in game by screaming vulgarities or treating you poorly. 

Maybe you want to be a builder? It might be fun to build walls and establish defences around your base wont it? Yes it would, BUT in game all you really do is laydown a blue print and hold your M1 button between 50-100 times and painfully construct your walls or foxholes with a hammer. Repeat that 3-4 more times to upgrade their tier. 

Developers need to sieve out these poor game design choices and make them more engaging and worthwhile for all parties. Ass of now, being a builder/logistics/farmer/driver is really too much of a chore.

I honestly believe the potential for the most fun and strategy in this game belongs to being in the frontline. You get to scream at logistics for resources, you can plan your attack and flanking options, you even get to go for missions to steal enemy tanks and whatnot. That is what makes a fun game, not pressing M1 button for hours simply to get resources.

Do yourself a favor and join the frontline. Forget about being a logistics, especially so if you're alone or without friends or a clan. Griefers will ruin your gameplay and you'll have no place to address your grievances because you're a nobody. As of now, I wouldn't recommend this game till devs make the game better for all parties involved, and make this less of a chore when it's supposed to be a game.

Disclaimer: If you're really interested in the game and need a review to help you decide, you're at the right place, but if you don't like reading consider the other reviews.

If you read much of the recent reviews, you'd probably get the gist of the situation right now. Always starts of as the game being a great concept with different working parts to such a player-driven system, from different levels of logistics all the way to the many frontline roles you can fill in, before it devolves into criticism concerning in-game and community moderation, toxic factionalism, QoL issues and more.

My intention for this review is to leave an unbiased review (i.e. leaving out equipment asymmetry)so that those who are looking to buy this game know what they're buying for. It also stands as a message for the developers that, despite all of the major updates they have done and all of the shiny new toys we have, much of the game mechanics remains unchanged and ill-suited to the current state of the game.

There are two main criticisms that people might want to consider:

1. In-game Moderation
     Because persistence plays a major part in Foxhole's gameplay loop, it's to no one's surprise that having a good anti-cheat system, or even just an active moderation team would stop a lot of the cases you usually don't hear on these reviews. 

Cheaters and alt accounts aren't as prevalent as people think, however because of the game's small playerbase and poor tutorial system, they can seem more prevalent than they are and new players can be accused of "alt behavior" for something they didn't know was an unspoken rule of the community. There is also the case of toxic behavior and factionalism, however much of it can be attributed to the lack of in-game response that riles people up and causes paranoia.


2. Poor QoL
     Like I said, the game is very player-driven and people can choose what they want to do, however, unless you are taught that there are actual needs to the war you most likely wouldn't know that the non-combat (logistics, building, etc.) gameplay loop takes a lot more time and effort out of the lives of people than it should. 

The map isn't properly adjusted for the new logistics systems in place, base building and facility management is more of a second job to many at this point than it is an "engaging part of the game" and causes burnout, there is little in the way of a proper tutorial for new players, and so many smaller issues that have caused minor uproars all the way to an actual, organized strike because of these issues. 

Many will mention that the developers are out of touch and do not know what actually happens in-game, and this is mostly true. While I understand the limitations of their QoL updates because of how the game engine was built or because of time restrictions, I have NEVER seen "good enough" community engagement even in the form of a simple Q&A outside of devbranch (which has a completely different atmosphere than actual wars).


TL;DR, the game is good on paper, ignore much of the toxic factionalism and focus on playing the game itself and it's actually not that bad of an experience. Many core mechanics and the gameplay loop needs to change to accommodate its current state, more QoL needs to be addressed, and there needs to be more active moderation in both in-game and the community. 

Don't get me wrong, this game has had some great wars and I and many of my friends have had great experiences over the years, however, that doesn't change the regular gameplay loop that we are forced to endure. There are certain roles that only some people are willing to fulfill, and only so much you can do, and that's okay and kind of the idea of a persistent war game, but that doesn't excuse the shortcomings in other areas that could elevate people's experience. I love this game, the 1k hours of gameplay would tell you enough, but I would not recommend it to anyone in its current state.

Edit: Okay, things have changed a bit. In-game moderation is still player-dependent but we have been equipped with tools and lines of communication that so far have been effective. Even better QOL as well as mechanics overhaul and additions that have made the game more playable. 

 While I wouldn't recommend it entirely I believe that it's still a relatively enjoyable experience as long as you don't delve too deep into the community.

Foxhole is both a fascinating and frustrating MMO. One the one hand, a massive player-driven war economy that produces and harvests all material used in the war to come. Also, a player-base  large enough to sustain the game while also being small enough to be friendly and non-toxic. 

On the other hand, the game can often feel like it swallows you up in the larger war. Players without vehicles are often given few, if any, anti-vehicle options that don't involve suicidal rushes or ambushes. Tank battles are often decided by who has more material and patience rather than skill or coordination. Infantry pushes are often stopped by AI with perfect aim, which is often far more punishing than it needs to be. Maps can also feel incredibly bland after a while, with fights either taking place in either an open field, a small city, a bridge, or a narrow mountain pass. A final criticism is that you cannot manually aim up and down, which often leads to fighting your own cursor to get a decent shot.

Foxhole is one of those games that it is a hobby unto itself. If you've ever gotten into table-top wargames before, this is worth a try for sure. It's also way cheaper and labor intensive than table-top wargames. The best part is because of the MMO aspect you can play as much or as little as you want, but every soldier in the field helps.

PROS:
+ Early Access game that is very well done.
+ Always something to do. Always something going on.
+ Playable as social and solo players.

CONS:
- Tutorials only teach you the basics and there is a LOT to learn in the game. (I recommend watching some videos on what you want to do in the game.)
- You'll need mods if you're not great with color. (RIP allied soldiers I blew away before colors registered)
- A lot of the biggest features requires coordination across multiple players, so without a clan or a dedicated group you likely will miss out on a lot of late game stuff.
Good game, but need to improve a few things to make it more reasonable as well as to develop the community. Have fun !!

If you can live with all of that this game worth its money and you'll probably have a blast. If not you better wait for devman to fix the game's issues or hope that Anvil will be better (hahahahahahaha :') )

Too in-dept into resources and economic for me.

At first I thought the game would be focusing on the frontline aspect with a little side of logistic.

Like tanks, cars, boat, etc etc would be spawned and ready to use as long as you feed it with resources.  And to get resources you just to go resource drop off station, carry it to frontlines, and it will be turned into spawn points for cars and guns and ammo and such.

But nope, you got to collect specific resources (this is where I draw my line) and turned them into different crafting materials, then you got to go to car factory, choose blueprint you want, and start building it.

When you craft guns and ammo and medical supplies and stuff, you can't even use it outright. You got to put them in crate and have tracks ship them to frontline base where god knows who can issue them to soldiers.

(you can't crate/uncrate them as you wish, btw. You got to specify it when you make a batch of it, which is the most BS part, think if you try to put something in crate IRL and you magically can't because you're not doing it when you manufacture it.)

Also vehicles uses fuel, which you got to craft.

A great game which has so many different aspects to it. Logistics, maintenance, building, facilities, farming materials, performing and responding to partisan work. That's not even taking into consideration all the different things to do on the front line which include fighting, medics, scout, mortar, artillery and repairing defenses! You may also partake in the vehicles which is another aspect altogether, including jeeps, ambulance, armoured cars and everyones favourite, tanks.

This game is really a one of a kind at this time. It has team kills, awesome!! You can hear the enemy yell at you, awesome!! It is sort of like actually being in some kind of war, in a sense. You are free to do pretty much whatever you want, awesome!!! There are no leveling up, no super powers, no BS. Many types of held weapons, mounted weapons, and vehicles. Machine guns, RPG's, mortars, you name it. One of my favorite things to do is grab an anti-tank rifle and go punching holes on the front lines. If you are looking for a super hero action packed game, this ain't for you. If you are looking for a more realistic simulation war game, this might be for you. I like it, and I'm getting others to join so we have a squad. 

You could be sitting in a pill box for hours waiting for the enemy to show up. You could be in the trenches on the front lines, popping heads. You could be manning the turret on a tank, or using the machine gun to mow down the advancing enemy. Maybe you are not enough grunt to murder digital soldiers. You can always mine and manufacture weapons and vehicles and other supplies for the war effort. Maybe your thing is to hunt down enemy snipers and then run up to watch them die in bloody gory  agony. You can do that in this game.  

The only thing it is missing is the corner hut brothels and the bars. Add that in and they would have a really fine simulator, lol.

One of the most fun experiences you can have in gaming. The bold idea of hosting so many players on a single server cooperating together makes for a unique experience and truly immerses you in a realistic war simulation.

The majority of the community is welcoming and being a team player is what the game is all about, which makes it so rewarding when an operation succeeds. The key is to keep a balanced playtime as the game can get addictive and grindy easily only if you make it so. More players greatly ease those problems but unfortunately the game wasn't designed to handle so many players concurrently due to technical limitations and you often get into situations of waiting into queues. However their new game Anvil Empires supposedly solves these problems using a new from the ground up engine and its medieval setting is so very promising. Huge potential for a perfect game there if done correctly, do check it out.

Edit: However, infatry movement and combat in general is enough to stop you from playing. Running full speed, stopping and aiming perfectly as well as accelerating with zero inertia equals to shooting teleporting targets and makes for an FPS experience. Especially when these people run head on towards AI dodging everything and proceed to destroy the defences you built for so many hours. Please fix this finally....

You might spend 8 hours building a bunker base that is your contribution to the team, only to have another player destroy it all when you log off because they intend to build something in that same spot at some at some point in the future....Maybe. Incredibly unique game, even as a random player you can achieve a lot of things. Some of my favourite moments include:

-Running out of all anti tank weapons and keeping two enemy tanks from pushing by calling out coordinates for a mortar until more supplies arrived.

I can pretty distinctly remember my first time playing, bought it because i thought "oh this looks fun", joined it first time round, ended up fighting a literal war on two fronts, pushing upto a blown up bridge, having a gunfight for about 10 minutes, occasionally crossing the bridge and occasionally pushing enemies back into the river, all while a south front was also under attack - very nice, ended up being sworn at a lot in french though for some reason (i hijacked a collie jeep and plunged it straight into a river because i forgot their was a big gunfight on that bridge.

A bit later i ended up meeting two other gentlemen, joined up with them in piloting a tank - and heres what i like about foxhole (which is also the thing that foxhole markets itself on) the community. I entirely remember navigating a tank, with police sirens directly playing through my mic while speeding up a main road (this didn't work as someone ran infront of the tank, it didn't end well), assisting a whole bunch of infantry into making a pretty decent push and then immediately being in combat with enemy tanks.

A few days later i came back (now heres the less good bit) - different front of course, thought it'd be the same community overall - it was hectic and extremely chaotic, and ended up in about 3 different shouting matches, once again with french people, very different at certain times, but the community overall is lovely, you meet the odd rough and tumble, but those types exist anyway.

Deciding to come back to the game after a drought lasting a few years now, nostalgia i guess? but yeah, i mean you might enjoy it, probably, maybe, you will end up with a burning hatred of the french if you're anything like me though.

It would be unfair of me to not recommend this game. Although it has many flawed design choices, it is still an experience like none other, for better or for worse. The game sets itself up to fulfill a task that very few games tried to do, and the developers are exhaustively dedicated to improving it, and receiving what equates to pocket change when you compare to the budget of AAA games. I've seen companies and small studios give up sooner to considerably smaller projects. This is a passionate piece of work, and one that has not yet been tainted by corporate greed.

I would be incorrect if I tried to say this is an MMO, as the population is not massive by any means. A consistent few thousand people, but these people are fighting in the same world map for the same war, spread in multiple regions. Every gun, bullet and vehicle is manufactured and mantained by the combined efforts of hundreds of players. And everything must be accounted for and taken to the frontlines with logistical line of supplies. 

The wars are won by the most resilient, but also the most clever, as your team must develop a strategy to bring down the enemy defenses and conquer the map. You will not accomplish this alone, so you should be well aware that this is not a game meant for the solo player. You will be frustrated and disappointed many times if you try to dive into this by yourself. It is possible, but you will miss most of what the game has to offer, as many of the mid to late game tactics and tools are only available to groups that can sustain their HQ of operations and logistic flow. 

The game can be very demanding and time consuming, as you'll have to likely log in every single day even if for a little bit. But if you do it as a group you should be fine. It doesn't try to be realistic in the visual and tactile sense, but this is perhaps the closest a game will ever get to simulate a war. If the concept of  "persistent warfare" vaguely entices your imagination, you should definitely give it a try. You'll either hate it and spend 10 hours in it, or you'll love it and hit 2000 hours without noticing.

Foxhole has been a massive online multiplayer experience I haven't had anywhere else. Being involved in a singular ongoing war brings a unique community experience. With a mixture of frontline combat and logistics, everyone can find their niche on any portion of the map. One second you can be way behind the line crafting materials and transporting goods via truck or train, or you can move yourself to the heat of battle tossing grenades or healing fellow soldiers. The only trouble is finding when you want to step away and when to press onward as unique opportunities present themselves as you help others and they seek your aid. This game has certainly made its way into my top 3.

Played for hours non stop. I've checked the reviews before and people that complain about balancing issues between Wardens and Collies? They aren't lying. I started as warden and everything was fine UNTIL collies get their ISG's (Infantry Support Guns) and their little Tankettes (armored cars). Mind you while they get these 2 great tools, btw their ISG is a 30 mm mortar carrier with quite a decent shot, what we get does jack shit to their early techs. Also wardens are heavily overwhelmed by the sheer numbers of collies atm. Idk what the fuck they are thinking doing it like this, but no until they give wardens some useful early techs I'm not recommending it. You might buy it and join collies of course, since developers seem to LOVE biasing on one faction at the moment. if you're looking to have fun while competing with the other team, FORGET ABOUT IT. It is a one sided war where one side crushes the other and the losing team (wardens in this case) just get frustration instead of fun. I'd like to shake the hands of the individual who dreamt up this composition. Great job ruining a great game and driving long time players from wardens away. Well done.

One of a kind game, truly unique. No other game fills the same niche, which has built a very solid community around it. While there is a heavy us vs. them mentality for the two factions, the people that play can be some of the best people to game with. It can be extremely fun for only certain kinds of people, and can start taking a LOT of your irl time.

With that said, I would not recommend it to regular people I run into because of The V I S I O N ^TM, meaning that the devs take things in wild directions from time to time, with the limited communication they give to the community being true and only somewhat accurate at the same time.

I used to enjoy this game as the playerbase & countless war activities were great fun, and there were a ton neat mechanics for awesome gameplay and environmental cue's showing the game came a long way from what it used to be despite still being VERY grindy & time consuming. Although, since the last few updates devs have promised new features (or returning features originally removed for reworks) and the 1.0 version of the game (despite still having many old flaws players are still complaining about in the official Discord such as bugs and the clear unbalancing between factions) for about a year or so now but have gone almost completely silent. As the playerbase is complaining about lack of communication (& balancing or simple fixes) from the devs, they are simply leaving the game until 1.0 finally arrives while the devs are likely more focused on their new WIP medieval game called "Anvil" currently undergoing beta testing.  For a few of the players sticking around there are "salty vets" that accuse most new players of "alting" (some of which actually are as the devs have to guaranteed method of preventing this) for not knowing an OUTDATED TUTORIAL when you first join the game of which the devs also abandoned, but they'll be sure to update the game with "fixes" the moment a well-known Twitch streamer points something (ignoring their playerbase completely) of which I simply can't support. The devs treat the playerbase more as guinea-pigs than respectable players supporting their game as they control most of what happens at the start of each war such as the map, faction tech trees, possibly the weather also, and implement bizarre in-game stat changes sometimes without any patch notes or answers to player's questions about it. So, if you want a game that you can't really see an outcome and anything you do might get you yelled at or left with more questions or sorrow, this is the game for you (honestly I'd prefer War Thunder for that though).

Update: Tried again recently for a war and with the latest updates post FINALLY getting 1.0 and all the patches after it I gotta say while few parts did get slightly better (e.g. item pull time & another few promises added), the game is in a now limbo-like state which imho I would say is probably worse for one reason: Facilities. This new feature never asked for pretty much locks a lot of the game's content behind a higher grind wall for current, new, solo, and most definitely casual players, pretty much forcing you to join a clan or suffer the grind for the most part while worrying someone might take or ruin your facility throughout the entire time of managing it and gathering the resources for it. What was once (dare I say) a simple grind has been pipe-lined to a longer and more tedious process that forces you to make a facility for most vehicle types (some of them having to wait 1-2 days REAL TIME to complete, and that's AFTER getting all the necessary resources) and even on occasion ammo types with the false promise that it would had made grinding more idle (in other words it's NOWHERE NEAR as satisfying or comparable to Factorio or Satisfactory, especially in terms of throughput). Luckily, although there's still some bad apples in the community, a lot of people make facilities that offer some of the necessary resources publicly (at least on the Colonial side from my experience) to soothe the experience, though there's also opposites that exist with the same notion that they suffer the same grind as you will. The devs said they won't abandon this game's development for ANVIL: Empires, but I would not hold them to it knowing their history of only 1-2 devs on this small team still caring for this game kept alive solely by its 1-2k player community.
Don't buy it.

This game has issues if you no-life and take it super seriously. It's not perfectly balanced and there are a slew of updates that shift things around constantly. 

That said, the game is perfect as an, "I have an hour or two and that's it. I need all of my gaming time to be as fun as humanly possible" title. You can log in at any time and find tons of action. Quick and easy thrill ride whenever you want it. Learning is easy, skill cap is very very high. You will have massive adrenaline rushes and some unforgettable memories the likes of which haven't really been present in gaming for the last 10 years or so. I guess I'm saying you have a legitimate shot at reclaiming some of the joy you used to have when gaming.

TLDR: Pure fun.

After a Year ive come back and many of the issues have been fixed and addressed. No more tech in-fighting and it seems that the Devs are finally listening to what the community has to say. Their are still many issues with this game but it has come leaps and bounds from when i originally made this review. I have changed my review from not recommended to recommended because the Devs have consistently updated their game with good updates, aswell as bug fixes and changes that have been requested by the community. They plan to keep making updates to this game and therefore I think its worth the purchase.

[strike]I LOVE THIS GAME. Needs a Better Player Reporting System. and Vehicles should have similar Variants for each factions. Game also needs a Tutorial for New players. Not always Noob Friendly

Edit: 

This game will never fix the problems it needs to address, The devs have no idea how to fix their game with clear bias towards one side. Ive wanted to hold off changing my review to this game for as long as possible but update after update with the same massive glaring issues that dont get addressed, ive come to realize that Balance being the worst part of the game. The maps favor one side, the vehicles favor one side, the player base favors one side. You can still have a great time in this game and meet some pretty awesome people. After so long the devs dont have any excuse why these bugs that have been in forever dont get fixed. The Devs joke about being called bias towards one side or another claiming to be non-biased but they don't listen to the large number of complaints and feedback about integral parts of their game. They are afraid to equip both factions with the same weapon or type of vehicle because of "asymmetry". They could easily add 2 different types of the same vehicle to both factions that are special to each faction but still have the balance of having both sides having a variant of the same vehicle. MG Jeep, AT Jeep, Standard Jeep, etc.. They also make changes that directly impacts gameplay based on "Lore" aka most Colonial Vehicles are open topped but open top has no advantages at the time of writing this.

Overall: I want to love this game and recommend it, but i cant do that anymore. i tried to play thru the issues but its just stressful and not really fun anymore. I've met some awesome people during my time on Foxhole, the community is Great and very supportive. Its also a very competitive Collies Vs Wardens which i enjoyed, but some people take it way to seriously. This game will always have a place in my Heart, and i truly want this game to excel, but until the Dev's start addressing the bigger issues i have every single time i play i wont play and cant recommend it anymore.[/strike]

The dev team are super talented programmers, but they do not listen to the community response. The game will always be close to my heart, but do not get this game.

This game is unlike any other, for me, there are two points that really makes me love this game:
First, it's essentially an RTS, but with the catch that every single unit is a player, from the normal infantry man and average builder, to the driver, gunner and commander of a tank, the only AI currently existing is that of defences, but even those AIs are quite limited.
Second, ANYTHING that a player interacts with, is built by or repaired by a player, the rifle you wield was made by a player, the ammo you shoot was made by a player, the truck used to bring said items were made by a player, the artillery shell landing on you was made by a player. This system creates an amazing logistical supply chain, that can range from simple to complex, depending purely on how deep you wish to go into this system.
Together with an community that can go from hilariously amazing to hilariously stupid in the split of a second because the one guy that was uniting everyone to a coordinated push got killed by a friendly gas grenade makes this an unforgetable game.

I believe this is the game I spent the most time on.
I made many friends because of it, it gave me much joy, and a lot of stress as well.
There are so many things to do and learn, even with 2k hours I didn't experience all of them.


The game is unique, fascinating and immersive, even with it's isometric camera. A treat for a military game enjoyer.

Until you have to deal with it's bad side...

And for me, these are:

- The game is an unpaid job.

To be really effective, you have to work really, really hard. 

And spend a lot of time and effort on organizing and communicating, since everything is made by players and it is a massive war.

It is just not healthy for the average player. It does not feel like a game, but a job.


- Only large organized clans will experience the game in its entirety.

1.0 changed the game with the "Facilities", those huge Logistics Hubs with pipes, cranes, trains and all.

And that limits solo players and small groups playing with subpar equipment, aka. Base Vehicles. 

Now the good stuff is locked behind these facilities.


- Unbalance causing unfair battles.

"Power creeps" are common because of asymmetrical gameplay, turning the game into faction loyalist ego fights on internet forums and players crying for balance all throughout the war.


- Unfixed bugs and instability.

Some regions are barely playable, the engine itself can't handle too many structures, which is part of the gameplay to defend a territory, some bugs are still being exploited despite players reporting them for a long time.


- Long queues at peak hours. (Not so much as the game declined in player numbers)

Maps have limited player capacity, causing very long waiting times. Some players called the game "Queue Simulator" before quitting for good. The game does not have a system to kick AFK players from active frontlines, which is unacceptable for an MMO.


- Game is infested with "Alts".

Cowardly cheating players that buy secondary accounts on the opposite team to unfairly disrupt and sabotage.

Plus, the devs do not perma-ban these obvious alt accounts. They only get punished with time suspension.


- It has no anti-cheat protection.

Believe it or not.


- Devs silence.

Devs simply ignore the community feedback with long-lasting silence, only appearing at times to announce unwanted new content and not even mentioning fixing it's core issues.


The game is still fun for a new player, the price is really fair, but you might end up not enjoying it anymore because of these reasons.

So war 105 has been my first war. I would classify myself as a Solo 'Casual' player. By that I mean I get on an play as much as I can but I don't intend on joining a large Clan. I just want to jump on a do what little I can to help. Its great, yes the big clans carry out the large scale operations but that doesn't mean individuals don't matter. get stuck in help out, ask questions and people around you will give tips and advice. I have been playing almost exclusively as a medic, harrowing stuff but in certain skirmishes I genuinely feel I have played a big part keeping the front line infantry together.

Ultimately it doesn't matter if you die, but the tension of trying to stay alive during artillery bombardments or the impending doom of enemy tanks approaching is great. Overall its great fun even if you can only play for a hour or so at a time. I have been part of pushes to capture land and felt pure joy in succeeding. And I have fought running withdrawals as our position is overrun and decimated.....still incredibly fun!

After 3k hours, update on review:

Foxhole in general is a great game, you wont find any other even close to it,  which is why I give it a thumbs up (I still enjoy playing it, and still play it as of today).
Its does have its cons and problems tough, and ill mention them here:

1) Problems with voice chat, constant bugs, not being able to hear local vc.
2) Problems with returning to home region, this happens frequently. Having to spend more time that it would be necessary otherwise.
3) Warden arsenal much, much stronger compared to Colonial arsenal:
- Blakerow, Fiddler, Sampo - 3 most overpowered guns as infnatry - they are OP when it comes to shadow dancing, or stopping shadow dancing. Colonials only have the Argenti that is actually decent, especially in terms of shadow dancing gun. Other guns are simply mediocre.
- Fiddler - the most broken infantry gun in the game - it has very steady aim when moving the mouse cursor fast; the recticle shrinks very fast, and stays that way even when moving; the precisions is hilarious, shoots like a laser gun acually; and the distance it can shoot is also crazy far.

- White Ash - AT weapon that is superior to anything that Colonials have in their arsenal - easy to track enemy armour even with splash damage, quite far from the tracks. Its range is crazy, you can throw over obstacles with its long arc and range. Can be used on barges, autoequips so you can throw multiple without going into inventory. Colonial counterpart, which is the ignifist is so much worse - does not autoequip, almost bounces everytime, even 5 times in a row from fresh armour.

- Warden tanks in general are move powerful, whats more, 3 basic variants can be made in a normal garage, without them being locked behind facilities (Outlaw, Silverhand, HTD).
- Warden tanks have so many variants - the Bonelaw and Highwayman - two distinct tanks which collonials do not necessarily have a counterpart.
- The Highwayman one of the best tanks in the game, shreds armour, has high chance to track or turret, again Colonials have no counterpart, not even slightly resembling the attributes of a Highwayman.

I couldnt care much for the game lore in general, but seems like Wardens have a more evolved lore, where more work had gone into it (which again is a sign developers contribute more to Warden faction).

All in all, develpoers cater more to the Warden faction, by making certain things easier to do, and in general a stronger weapon arsenal.

Although the game looked very promising, my first impression is not great. 

The "Tutorial" is absolutely awful. 
You get thrown into a huge camp where you can run for miles to read some signs that tell you how certain things are meant to work. If you cant get them to work with the basic text from the sign (Like vehicle building), then your're fucked because the game is not helping you in any other way. Another thing is that you cant even try some of the equipment (Such as artillery) to their full extent because they require 3 people to operate. Truly brilliant game design smh. 
To call that a tutorial is an insult to games that actually provide useful tutorials.

Then when i was bored after trying a small part of the "tutorial" i went into the actual war, only to find some stupid clan that has locked LITERALLY every vehicle/gun in a huge radius, which basically forces you to walk all the way to the front line (Because despite their frequent drives with trucks from the base to the front, they are completely unwilling to give you a ride and will even drive over you if you don't dodge them) with just a machine gun and some bullets to then just immediately die because you don't understand the game yet and don't know that you can apparently still get headshotted when you crouch in a trench. Because i couldn't use any vehicles, i had to do this every single time until i got annoyed and closed the game. I died like 8 times and got 2 kills, with one being lucky. Not very fun to say the least.

Foxhole is one of the least beginner friendly games i have seen at this point.

Currently deciding if i should refund the game since I'm still under 2 hours or give it another chance.

I did not say anything inflammatory. A moderator said something about trans rights and I said "blocked." Got banned for not wanting to see it. I tried it once and returned it.  The top down myoptic view gives me a headache.  

 I was convinced by a long time game guild member to give it a try again.  So I bought it again.

Well again I say that now I feel like I am hitting my head against the wall playing it.  It takes hours to move products.  The entire game is akin to a bunch of ants moving helter skelter around the map some obviously doing good but the vast majority going around in circles doing little to help the over all war effort.  

All everyone does is run out  as a fighter or drive around blowing your horn as a trucker trying to deliver 20 guns and 100 rounds of ammo.   There are so many abandoned trucks around it seems the war could have been won if just one less truck per minute was produced and one more tank or even bullet.

But then a squad buddy told me the game was a  Real Time Strategy Game and the players were like the little men.  You know that you manipulate in those type of games that say "Yes Sir, Right Away, Sir" when you click on them to do some task like build a  base, a bunker a factory.  

Then suddenly the game became fun.   Sure you can go to the front line and fire you gun with the same top down view.  That gun someone brought you from a factory way back behind lines.  That gun that has bullets because someone drove a truck and gathered raw materials then drove it to a refinery, factory and put it in storage.  Even your ability to spawn some player had to create and move to the front line base you are fighting for and that allows you to spawn and get another hand delivered gun and ammo.  

So if you enjoy being a bit player,  If you enjoy base building if you enjoy strategy then this game is for you.   Maybe you will build the Maginot Line or the Siegfried Line, who knows.  No matter you will make a impact little by little.   I recommend it to you.   

But the truth be known the combat visuals are myopic top down crap with the need for constant camera angle adjustment.  If you get in a crown you cant tell what your character is doing.

It's a fun game, but it's quite grindy at times.  The devs have difficulty balancing asymmetric factions.  Power spikes flip flop back and forth between the factions as the devs buff and nerf things.  The devs are largely absent from the community. They mostly are only concerned with pushing out new content that will sell more copies of the game.  This is both good and bad.

Very good concept currently in a dire situation.
The games feels less & less stable with each passing update
1.0 release was absolutely terrible in terms of added inbalance without feeling any more polished than 0.9 b√™ta was.
Last year of releases are degrading gaming experience and population is dropping massively.
The devs really need to focus on bugfixes, stability improvements and QOL for the playerbase if they want this game to strive.
Dev team communication is abysmal with months of silence between announcing massive additions to the game without ever polishing or refining the existing content.
The rate of imbalance & bug introduction is massively overpowering the rate of bugfixes / QOL improvements
Don't get me wrong, this game concept is unique, fascinating & has a great community, I would love to see the game thrive but the current developpment strategy & trajectory is really getting to be its downfall.

No other game comes even close to what this game does. I wish more MMO's were like this. That said, it has it's fair share of issues.

-You can easily get caught up in Logistics wasting hours upon hours of your time in the blink of an eye.
-It feels like you need to join a Regiment to accomplish anything substantial.
-Your actions will usually not go rewarded, so try and have fun instead of seeking validation.
-The more you play, the more you find out the lengths people go to for a win.

The best advice I can give is to try and find what you enjoy doing, and seek that out.

#NukeJadeCove Again! 
16 Dec steam sales, with more new players than usual due to the awesome 0.20 update featuring Main Battle Tanks and Rockets, I joined Fisherman's Row. As a skirmish map that are not considered to be part of the main combat regions, no veterans are playing in it. I was the only OCDT with another inactive in team chat. So, i took charge after seeing how logi requests get ignored, portbase and its stockpile empty. It triggered me so bad that I HAD to do something about it. What if these new players join the combat regions? How huge will their impact be on them? After hours of screaming at them in team chat, they finally abandoned the Sandbag forts and build real defences. It was an experience being the only one to coordinate such an inexperienced group and I enjoyed it. (330hrs in) 


At 33 hours of play, I can guarantee that what the Hypey steam reviews describe about Foxhole is true. Attack and defence is tense when I do not have a clear idea of the number of enemies and friendlies that are in a firefight which can be solved with watchtowers. With experience and time spent on this game, people recognize you for your efforts and give you a commend, which gives you the required levels and ranks up the military ladder. Higher ranks do not provide any additional perks or stats that skew combat to vets. Although with experience, as a Warrant Officer, I did 1v2 two Lcpls with a pistol once.

I met quite a few very cool and chill people through this game, but honestly I think that says all it needs to about how this game functions: If you have enough people, great, if not, don't even try. Foxhole at the point that it's at just isn't fun anymore, and I'm probably not going to get back on for a long time.

The community in-game is very helpful (Warden side, I don't know about Colonials) - if you are new and need help, ask politely, and you'll get multiple people responding to you.

The game is designed to be group-driven, and as such, you won't have as much enjoyment alone as you would in a team. When you join a frontline, try to see who needs help and tag along. If someone is building, go help with it. If artillery is shelling the enemy, help carrying ammo. Try to change your usual mindset of "how can I win this game" to "how can my side win this game" and you'll have a lot of fun in Foxhole.

As a word of warning, it can be very time-consuming, be careful if you are prone to binge on games.

Top down war simulator.  Players control everything  from resource collection to making materials and weapons to delivering it to the front lines and actually using it.. building up bases. However do not build a base. you will get cucked.

Day 38 of the 87th conflict between the legion and the so called Warden empire... my fellow soldiers are charging the Deadlands, the echo of their hurrahs could be heard throughout the world. It was my first time driving so close to the front. I had just finished my training.

I was driving my truck on a country road to our capital, filled with the "spice" of war, our seaport my was goal. Behind the curtain that is the frontline, I was not prepared for the shock. 
I loaded my spice on an Ironship and set sail while aiming for one of our most vital outposts. Some shot were taken but the fear of loosing everything carried me to the objective. It is upon arrival that I understood, I had yet to see war. 

There was a welcoming party screaming and laughing, how have they longed for the spice. They took me in their group and with their help we organized a convoy. 5 people who were total strangers to each other would protect it with their lives for they knew; their brothers are in the dense bloodstorm and they had been out of spice for days now.

For the safety of the delivery, we cut through fields and forests, then we arrived at the destination against all odds, untouched by bombardements or partisans. We got close to the bunker base and that is when I saw the first shell hit. The land was shaking, dozens of soldiers were running around panicked hoping to dodge the mortal blasts that were making the local landscape a flat no man's land.

2 of the 5 trucks from the convoy actually made it to the bunker, I was in the second. Upon arrival, we did magic. I had never seen so many people unload crates so fast. With our armory full, one of our officer organized a team. At least 15 soldiers regrouped and organized a counter offensive. The way was shown to us by the veterans, we knew where and how to kill their artillery.

We joined in a trench half way to our objective, at the hotspot of our frontline. A whistle started whisthling, Hurrahs were chanted in harmony, without realising, my own battlecry was fueling a rush of sudden adrenaline. Then an officer jumped out the trench and ran, 2 followed and I was immediately behind and we poured between the warden's bullets, some fell, some passed through. All I remember is the fiery explosions and the colors mixing together: blue, green and red were making one.

Original Review:

I have had great moments with this game, but I can't, in good conscience, continue to play it.

The amount of player time that needs to be spent doing the busywork so that people can engage in the main attraction of this game (actually fighting) is absurd. Never before have I seen a community so comfortable with managing burnout or expending hundreds of man-hours to build, maintain and defend structures that may not even last a day. Either I am wasting my own time on this busywork, or forcing someone else to do it by my own refusal (read: desire to have fun).

I'm not saying there isn't fun to be had here. I'm saying that the fun is better had in a game that respects everyone's time.
Foxhole is one of the best games I have every played.  I encourage everyone to at least play within one war from start to finish and ask themselves after if they did not enjoy themselves.

Great game and dev, killed by its community.

Parents: The chat topics and player interactions are definitely adult-themed

I personally find any chat regarding sexual activities of any nature to be inappropriate and uncomfortable.  The chat in this game is 18+.  There are regularly 40+ chat messages in <60 seconds with graphic sexual words (three letters stars with a c).  The developers clearly do not care.  This would be incredibly easy to filter/ban for, but it is obvious the developers do not care.  

In between wars, I observed a role playing between characters that setup a house to engage in graphic sexual activities.  This is a game where a random stranger can walk up and initiate a voice conversation with you, and this chat channel is not well-regulated.  

The sad part of this is that outside of this problem, the voice chat is one of the best parts of this game.

I have heard that clans are really toxic. But i bought this game today and clan people actually seem pretty chill! They welcomed me and gladly taught me how to play! The gameplay is amazing, and the community is great.

Edit:
After hundreds of hours later, i can confidently say that Foxhole is one of my favourite and most beloved games of all time. VERY few games have such a special place in my heart.

Whether you want a chaotic war simulation with lots of action, or a relaxing way to spend your time while listening to a podcast, this game has you covered. It is pretty cool actually, because sometimes in the backlines, you can forget that a brutal war is even going on, it is so dynamic!

The community has some bad apples (like every community on Earth, afterall) but those are vastly outweighed by the solidarity the war encourages. Everyone has a common purpose, to win the war. If players help each other out, they help the war effort. I enjoy logistics, and occasionaly make tanks for people who just want to fight without sinking hours into making their expensive toys. Even if i dont get to see the fights those tanks get into, i know that i have made their crews happy and helped push the enemy back in the process. Cooperation is a win-win situation, and everybody knows it!

If you are willing to sink (a lot of) hours into this experience, i urge you to not be swayed by the reviews mocking the community and the fact that many features seem "locked" behind teamwork. I was almost a victim of such reviews myself. Listening to them would be such a huge and frustrating mistake..

Oh and, go Colonial, FOR THE LEGION!
Game was fun and Asymmetric tech was nice then the factions started losing the uniqueness they had the fun was lost with it too
very fun war

First, I love playing this game with my friends because there's so much opportunity for teamwork. Even better, teamwork contributes to the long-term goal of winning the war! There are so many awesome roles and tools to use that we can switch things up all the time. When my friends aren't able to play, I can team up with almost anyone because 90% of the players are friendly and looking to work together.

I could leave it there and say it's worth a buy, but my personal favorite part about the game is the economy. The idea that every single gun, bullet, grenade, medkit, car, tank, artillery piece, shell, boat, train, building, and more is mind-blowing and adds a [i]weight[/i] to what you use in a fight. The idea that players have to maintain a supply line to keep the war machine going was something I was attracted to. So, I play in this corp of players (shout out FMAT!) that deliver supplies to the front lines so that everyone can keep fighting. The cheers as I deliver ammo to a desperate front keep me invested in their success and I convince myself to stay locked in for hours on end. It's such a unique core game mechanic that I really struggle to find anything similar elsewhere.

I recommend this game to a lot of people, and I'd recommend it to you too.

EDIT: I am currently changing my review to negative due to the poor response from devs to address current issues plaguing the game.  This is not just a holiday thing, it's been a problem for a while.  Alts are rampant during sales and just now both sides are getting griefed to hell from people who buy copies just to troll, there is very little defense against this other than no-lifing and being on 24/7 to watch your shit.

Balance is a nightmare, the most recent update was shoved out the door despite feedback saying it's not ready and to fix balance issues before releasing.

Logistics is a pain and needs to be addressed as well.  I really do enjoy this game for the most part and want it to succeed, but we're running out of options here. Please listen, devs.  Give us a better way to reserve structures so that they can't be griefed and please take a long look at the tech system. I will change this review back to positive if and when these issues are addressed satisfactorily.

DOUBLE EDIT:
After a lengthy logistics strike, and a notable improvement in dev interaction with the community, some changes are finally coming to improve logistics and anti-griefing measures, so I am changing my review back to positive. This game still fucking rules and you should get it.

TRIPLE EDIT:
Things got worse again after 1.0. Devs basically do not listen or communicate AT ALL in a persistent mmo game.  Griefers and alt accounts are rampant, exploits are not punished or fixed, bugs are left in the game for an entire war that are extremely debilitating for one or both sides.  Cheating is increasing because nothing is done about it.  The game itself is cool and a really unique idea but until the devs actually engage, listen, and fix things do NOT buy it.  Don't buy their new game, Anvil, either.

QUADRUPLE EDIT:
Devs have improved significantly in regards to communication and QoL updates. Changing review back to positive. Game good again!

In the current state of the game, it takes way too much time to get any fun out of the game. Devs don't give a shit because they are more concerned with adding fun new toys instead of solving the issues that ruin the game.

Foxhole, oh what a letdown it is. Get ready for a game that leaves you scratching your head in confusion and feeling utterly disappointed. It's a game that promises excitement but delivers frustration instead.

When you step onto the battlefield, things quickly become a big mess. You try to come up with smart plans, but they fall apart faster than a house of cards. It's like trying to solve a puzzle where the pieces never fit together. Who needs strategy anyway when everything just ends up in chaos?

Building bases should be fun, right? Well, not in Foxhole. You spend time and effort constructing impressive structures, only to see them crumble at the slightest touch. It's like building sandcastles at the beach, only to have them washed away by the tide. What's the point of building if everything just falls apart?

And don't even get me started on progression. You work hard, hoping to make progress and get better, but it feels like you're running on a hamster wheel. You go forward a little, only to be pushed back again. It's like trying to climb a mountain that keeps growing taller. No matter how much you try, you never really get anywhere.

Foxhole is a game that leaves you feeling disappointed and confused. It's like a puzzle with missing pieces and a rollercoaster that never goes up. If you're looking for a game that makes sense and gives you a sense of accomplishment, I'd recommend looking elsewhere. Foxhole is just not worth your time.

Youre not allowed to farm materials or hoard them...because its an unfair advantage on those who choose not to. Yet you need a very large number of materials for crafting, building, repairing, upgrades and research. Everytime you die you drop everything you had on you at that location and spawn with pre-set gear at a location. Sometimes you can backtrack and get your things but most of the time youre cut off because of reasons. Dying is extremely easy in this game. Essentially he who shoot first most likely win. Using a small arm to damage the vehicle, truck, in the slightest makes the truck inoperable. You then need materials to repair it before you can interact with it. All this amounts to the need for scavanger famers of mats, which according to the moderators are not allowed. Number of deaths on each side midwar is about 50-100k. Thats 50-100k weapons, first aid kits, ammo etc. Piles up. Standard rifle is 100 basic materials. It then goes up from there..alot of different guns. Lets do math.

You want numbers? Midgame through a war campaign the frontline can consume 122k worth of materials each day to maintain.122.000 materials. One, two, three fronts..yea it matters. How and when to play offensively and defensively matters. If you just run around like Leroy Jenkins..in the long run you will lose the war. Maybe you had fun in the process. 

Ok, so how much is 122.000 materials? Lets talk about basic materials here to make it easier. Every type of material have an exchange rate when refined. Basic material has the 2:1 ratio. Which means, to get the 122.000 refined materials im talking about here you need 244.000 material scraps to refine from. One node area spawn about 30k scraps every 40-60 mins. So if you do nothing but that you can farm, theoretically, 150-250k scraps everyday...depending on how much time you are willing to spend. But but large server and alot of people do this you say.....well.....no. People want to believe mats grows on trees while yelling "Leroy Jenkins". Thats how the devs designed the game. It part of the difficulty level with gameplay. "Scavange as you go". In other words "scavange off those you kill". Problem is they carry guns not materials.

The devs favour one side over the other. They rig the system...sort of.

Once Again, the new powerful Warden vics get nerfed into oblivion (And the Colonial counterparts get a pat on the back and a kiss on the cheek) and the entire game will suffer a playerbase recession, a side product of the new imbalance which takes ahold of the game for the next 3-4 wars until the devs realize their mistake (or do not, and suffer a decently crippled playerbase which actively hates them more afterwards) and proceed to give the two factions new vehicles, which proceed to mend (Or tear further in most cases) cracks in balance, one of the sides proceed to moan (most often Colonials on Reddit), and the process repeats.

I do like the game, but this situation is unsustainable, and often gives both sides a lot of fuel for conflict and division (Not that i do not contribute, but Collies on r/Foxhole usually instigate this behaviour more often than others).

Add to this the relatively recent issue of Facilities (added in update 50 "Inferno" causing mounting stress and increasing costs on the average logistics player. Regiment member or not (Although it has slightly improved with update 52).

When it comes to this game, i am a veteran, and i beg that Siege Camp realizes that adding increasing power creep to the game does not make players want to play it more, because past the cool factor of a gun type being able to one/twoshot most standard vehicles in the game is not fun for people who do not hold such a gun (*cough* 94.5 *cough*).

I will consider changing this review when Siege Camp starts making consistently good changes to the game, and starts listening to all the sides of the playerbase more equally (which is sadly unlikely, as most people would imply), but that is sadly ONLY A CHANCE, NOT A GUARANTEE.

Welcome to Foxhole, the dream game that never was and never will be. As one of my friends put it, ‚ÄúThey try to sell you this idea of a player driven game with all this crazy stuff happening around you, but really it‚Äôs just Euro Truck Simulator and Running With Rifles put together.‚Äù

I could rant for hours about the issues with this game, but I‚Äôd rather focus on just one issue, the main issue and the reason why this game will never improve: the developers don‚Äôt believe in fun. Now what do I mean by that?

Well, first let‚Äôs talk about all the different roles in the game and how the developers are slowly but surely making them awful miserable to play. No, you are not allowed to enjoy the game. You are expected to play the game like it‚Äôs a miserable job that you hate but are incapable of getting away from.

So let‚Äôs say you want to build. Boy doesn‚Äôt that sound cool? You could build anything in the whole wide world. Freedom. Creativity. That sounds like a great time. Well, get rid of those lofty notions. The reality is that you will install an auto clicker and sit your character around for hours holding mouse 1. Gotta shovel out the dirt to make your tier 1 bunker. Then you have to upgrade to tier 2 and then to tier 3, but all this entails is sitting there holding mouse effing 1 for your entire play session. This is your best case scenario mind you. If you happen to mess up part of your building or have to demolish something for other reasons, now you get to track people down and have them flag the buildings in question. Then you all get to take turns getting locked from using weapons for 20 minutes. This is the reality of building in Foxhole. And this is a game you pay money to play.

Okay well maybe I just won‚Äôt build. I‚Äôll do a fun thing. Surely, there are other roles that I will enjoy. I know, let‚Äôs do logistics! Logistics is suffering, and it sure as hell isn‚Äôt fun. The only reason anyone does it is because they want to help their team and win, same as building, but by no means is it enjoyable. Doing logi means driving around endlessly, going to resource fields to turn your auto clicker on while you semi afk, sitting at a comp mine while your autoclicker collects resources for you, waiting on emat or factory queues, and many other boring mindless tasks. For every 10 logi players you ask, 9 of them will tell you they do it to help the faction, not because it‚Äôs enjoyable.

What about facility work? That sounds like the more fun part of logistics. What if you could just play Factorio inside of Foxhole? If only facilities were actually that cool. No, the reality of running a facility in this game is that you have an annoying baby who hates you that you have to babysit all the time. Having a facility means farming multiple fields of scrap a day to upkeep it. And you get to do this every day for the entirety of a war (about 35-40 days long). That‚Äôs just the farm to upkeep it. Additionally, you have to farm to run it and you have to constantly fight off thieves as well.

Fair enough, you think. Logistics is kind of boring sounding anyway. What about combat? That‚Äôs got to be a blast. Let‚Äôs start at the front line infantry. It‚Äôs fun at first, but it truly is draining when you realize that it is an endless back and forth. Any gains you made last session will be undone by the next time you log in. Over time, that realization really does crush any passion you‚Äôll feel for frontlining, but if the combat was fun, it could at least make up for it. The infantry combat is pretty janky and mostly just RNG rolls on top of RNG rolls. That‚Äôs not to say there isn‚Äôt any skill involved, but the way skill factors in is in the most uninteresting and janky kinds of ways. It‚Äôs fun for a moment, but it‚Äôs not enough to actually keep you around for very long.

Well, sure, infantry is just infantry. How about the vehicles? What about the tanks? I will say that the vic combat is pretty fun in this game, or at least it was. This upcoming update will place really low limits on the amount of ammo vics can carry. Limits like 25 shells in a gallant, 20 shells in a FAT, 30 shells in a spatha. These shell numbers won‚Äôt even last you a full day cycle on an active front. This is the developers telling you that they don‚Äôt play the game without saying that they don‚Äôt play the game. Not only do you have less shells, but now they are going to remove the very convenient method of pulling them (more on that later).

These super low shell limits are hell for tank players, but it‚Äôs emblematic of a much bigger issue with the developers. Their answer is always to side on less freedom for players. The best moments in this game are when players get creative, when they pull off unorthodox moves, when they risk it for the biscuit. Sure, running 200 shells in a tank is usually a really bad idea, but sometimes it‚Äôs the best shit you‚Äôve seen all week. The devs try to sell you on a vision of this game being player driven and built on emergent gameplay, yet when anything actually emerges it gets killed off. This upcoming update is even going to prevent people from shooting from on top of catwalks as if that is some kind of issue. The trend is always less freedom for players.

In the last update, the devs wanted to tackle the issue of alting. One such method of alting was having your alt account drive your main account into an enemy base in a friendly vehicle. Because it was a vehicle being driven by a friendly, the AI wouldn‚Äôt shoot it. The smart solution is to make AI shoot at any vehicle with an enemy inside it. Instead, the devs decided to remove the ability to enter a vehicle with an enemy inside it. So, back in the day, if you forgot to lock your tank, an enemy would hop inside and take over a slot. You‚Äôd get punished for it, and it made for some of the funniest clips I‚Äôve ever seen. It was a good part of the gameplay. Now it‚Äôs just gone because the devs can‚Äôt think of any other way to deal with issues other than reducing player freedom.

Another form of emergent gameplay was people realizing that small trains can pull items really fast. You see, if you only have an hour of time for your play session and you wanted to run a tank, you‚Äôd normally spend half your time pulling shells from a base and loading them. It‚Äôs an awful part of the gameplay, but with small trains you could pull faster. This is a feature we‚Äôve had for 10 months now and has become a core part of the gameplay. Sure, it‚Äôs not ‚Äúrealistic‚Äù but so what? It‚Äôs convenient. We don‚Äôt like wasting our time arbitrarily. We want to play the game.

The devs, in their infinite wisdom, have decided this must go. And no, they aren‚Äôt going to remove it and replace it with something that makes more sense. They don‚Äôt care about you and your quality of life. They don‚Äôt care about your time. Your fun is literally not a priority to them. Even though the community is universally and unanimously in support of keeping the baby train, the devs are going to kill it. It‚Äôs such a big middle finger to the entire community. You like this thing that is saving you time and making the game more enjoyable? Too bad. The game is apparently meant to be full of down time, cumbersome, boring, and miserable.

The game is an excellent demonstration of modern massively multiplayer games' capabilities. The game offers opportunities for solo players and regiments alike, from entire, region-spanning operations, to small partisan operations, cutting off much-needed, player-made supplies to open fronts. Even though every way to play the game is so different, it all helps in the end to achieve a goal hundreds of other players are fighting for alongside you. That small partisan operation can deny the enemy spawn crucial spawn tokens, that region-spanning operation can decay defences, and the logi-bros in the backline fuel it all. 

    It goes without saying, however, that certain aspects of the game need to be refined. But, after all, it is what you get for the first game of its kind to delve this deep into the intricacies of war. Games like Planetside 2 offer large, hundred player servers, but dont include structure building or logistics at a level like Foxhole. Some aspects that do need working on, is developer-player communication, tediousy of logistics, and the decay of structures. Recent updates have been fixing some of those issues, however. 

     I am glad to see the developers working on a new game, complete with it's own engine and different systems, to improve or possibly innovate on this genre and game. 

 In short, devman bad, dogshit game.
