One day, I'm gonna write an essay about this game - but for now this'll have to do.

Foxhole is one of the most unique and intriguing games I've ever played. Playing Foxhole is like being part of an ant colony - every player does what they want, but almost every player is working together to achieve the same goals. Down to its core, Foxhole is a cooperative game, and the mechanics work together in a beautiful - if at times flawed - concert to incentivise players to collaborate. You want to command a tank? Well, you better get a crew together - you'll need a driver and a gunner. You'll also need fuel, ammunition and materials to repair the tank when you get hit; you'll need a plan, and infantry support in case the enemy comes running at you with a sticky grenade.

All those things come from other players. And because those things come from players, you end up talking to people, making friends, even if they're buddies you only share a foxhole with for five minutes. Even if your faction is losing, you're having fun because you're talking to people, working with others toward a common goal.

Finding your place in this big world - as a soldier, medic, field engineer, scout, grenadier, gunner, driver, factory worker, artillery loader, quartermaster, whatever - might take some time, but you can try many different roles and have many different experiences. Eventually, you might find yourself leaning into a little light roleplay, too. Once you've identified what you're good at, you'll probably find a sense of identity, and take pride in the work you do.

Personally, I love the quiet (unless you're at a lively battlefront), meditative work of the humble truck driver. I pootle back and forth between the front and backlines, delivering supplies. It's a simple life, but deeply rewarding: because I know that every piece of kit I deliver will end up in the hands of a player.

I love this game, i truly do, but i can't recommend this game in good concience.

Devman: they're so tone deaf towards their comunity. Exposing griefers or alts (people that buy a second copy of the game to grief the other side) gets ignored at best, gets you muted at worst for "witch hunting". It takes them ages to aknowledge balance problems. If they ever do decide to even do something about it its quite often bandaid solutions that don't adres the core of the problem, or just makes the problem worse in a different way. Feedback about new content is completly ignored, leading to situations that the entire playerbase saw comming from miles away and warned about, yet we have to put up with it until the devs open their eyes.

[strike]Another point is in game moderation: it simply does not exist. Its left up to the playerbase to moderate itself. Bans can be handed out this way but are, at most, 3 days long. This is not even a deterrent for bad faith actors.[/strike]

edit: Since writing this initial revieuw the devs have made a good effort to clamp down on bad faith actors.
However, concerns about slow balance patches persist and haev infact, worsend, with the patch notes for update 54, showing a clear lack of udnerstanding from the devs how their game actualy plays in practice.
[b]Biggest example is the 94.5mm shell.[/b] This shell is stupidly overpowerd, the majority of the community agrees. Previously, the Colonials had a defacto monopoly on this shell, later they leveld the playing field by giving the Wardens a vehicle that also uses this shell. In update 54 they will nerf the Warden vehicle while not touching the Colonial one, [b]instead of nerfing the shell itself acros the board.[/b] This will again hand the Colonial side an undisputable late war advantage that the Warden Side will be unable to compete against.
I'm feeling more optimistic as time passes that this game is in good hands. Would strongly encourage new people to try it out, just be ready to learn.

Take Planetside 2 (massive map with tons of players), give it a top/down perspective. Add a boat load of extra mechanics and set it in a world war 2-esque era and that's the game. You level up by people commending you (delivering supplies, reviving them, exceptional team work etc). There is a bit of a learning curve. But its a Planetside 2 scale map where there's always action to be found and 'games/wars' take place over multiple days or even weeks until one side captures enough objectives to win. 

There are no pre-defined class systems. You spawn at a bunker/spawn point and pick the weapons that you want to use, provided someone has been delivering materials/supplies to it. 
Gunplay is not a basic 'aim in direction and shoot'. There's a stability system impacted by your movement speed, posture and left/right movement as well as the gun you are using. 
I'd strongly suggest playing with a mic and maybe finding a group of people to play with because solo it can be very monotonous. It takes more than one soldier to capture a strategic locale after all.

OK 300 hours in here is what I say. If you don't take the opportunity to talk to your fellow soldiers you will be lost for a long time, you will do things that are consider rude or downright team sabotage.  People are generally far more friendly and helpful than most games, so don't be shy. This is because every soldier counts, we don't/shouldn't compete. If you like winning cooperation is key. That said I did find the Wardens far more helpful than the Colonials. Now this might have been because I was still learning with the Colonials, but if I complained about something stolen from me to the Colonials, I generally got told what i did wrong. When I tried the wardens not only did someone tell what I did wrong I often found many people bringing replacements for what was stolen. So there seems to be a difference in etiquette between teams. But ultimately this is not a solo game, reach out make friends and fight as team.

This is one of the best war games out there, in my opinion. It's an entirely community driven game and each war is different because the players make it different. Everything from the fortifications at the front to the weapons we use are player made and player delivered. Some people would say that this is too grindy and to be fair, there is a lot of grinding if you want to make high end stuff like battle tanks. However, almost everything can be made very quickly and without much grinding. If you work with other players, then almost nothing takes much time. And if you don't want to do logistics, there's nothing stopping you from just going to the front and involving yourself as a member of a large operation. 
I recommend using proximity chat as it eases the flow of everything.

Incredibly Unique game with a mostly friendly player base that loves to complain. The best way to play this game is with a group, you will find hundreds of them on the official Foxhole discord, but I have found that the best way to find people to play with is to head to a front line and find a group you like there. Foxhole has the same issues any online game has with toxicity, horrible people, and people who need to touch grass, but If you can look past that, it's really an excellent title. I played around 700 hours in 5 months while in between jobs and I don't regret the time spent, but I would recommend making sure to take a break from the game time to time to avoid burnout. Don't feel like you have to play all the time everyday and certainly do not build any structure that requires maintenance by yourself. I have spent a significant amount of time on both of the teams in game, the wardens and the colonials. Whatever you hear online about the two, just know, they really aren't that different, so just choose whichever side has aesthetics that appeal to you more. 

TLDR: Overall I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a unique experience, but I would also recommend waiting till a sale as this game really does deserve at least 20 hours of playtime before you decide if you like it or not.

Dear Foxhole,

I never thought I could fall in love with a video game, but then I found you. You're not just any game, you're a masterpiece. You bring people together from all over the world to work on an MMO war, and there's nothing more beautiful than that.

From the first time I played you, I knew you were something special. Your immersive gameplay, realistic mechanics, and amazing graphics got me hooked. But it wasn't until I started working with my team in Foxhole that I realized how much more you had to offer.

Together, we fought off enemy attacks, built structures, mined resources, and strategized our next move. It was as if I had known these people my entire life, even though we were all complete strangers.

It's incredible how you brought us all together, regardless of our backgrounds, cultures, or beliefs. We all had one common goal, and that was to win the war. And we did it, thanks to you.

You taught me invaluable lessons about teamwork, communication, and leadership skills. You showed me that anything is possible when people work together towards a common goal.

So, Foxhole, I just want to say thank you. Thank you for bringing people together and creating a sense of community and belonging. Thank you for teaching me important life skills while having fun at the same time. Thank you for being the best video game I have ever played.

With love and gratitude,

A loyal Foxhole player.

Great game, but you have to learn how to have fun in it: its not given to you like in other games. You can play without voice-chat: I did it for over a year. There's a lot to learn, particularly around logistics, tanking, and artillery. The devs are some of the best you could ask for: their commitment to the project is unparalleled. Every time they drop an update, it feels like Christmas. The art style is so internally-consistent it must be feeding a constant stream of dopamine to my brain whenever I play.

Have been playing the game since well before pre-1.0 release (around initial release five years ago). What started out as a game with occasional improvements and a pendulum swing of balance between the power creep of both factions that can typically last upwards of six months, has devolved since it's 1.0 release in 2022.

One of the major complaints players have had for upwards of two years is trolling and people using alt accounts (buying a second account and playing on the opposing faction to benefit the faction their main account is on) to scuff the way battles should naturally happen. The developers have made the least significant steps to combat this, while continuing to add more and more exploitable elements to the game without devoting any real attention to these issues.

The introduction of player-built facilities as part of the 1.0 has also been met with a sour taste, as it removed the ability of solo-players to really contribute to their faction during the war as certain vehicles and weapons are locked into expensive facility metas. It has also weakened the player base as this facility infrastructure was dropped on top of a moderately under-established MMO where building and holding victory points has never been fun, but remains critical. However the need to build facilities to have access to vehicles and weapons has created a defensive imbalance that can dramatically affect wars.

Also, to its very basic interface: Imagine shooting a shot and gambling. No skill or experience is a counter for horrible RNG no matter the weapon being used.

I have updated my review to reflect that the devs did - eventually - address many of the bigger issues in the game re: cheating and alts. It's good - but also frustrating, because many of the changes were pretty simple, but made a big difference.

Facilities/building in general feels better, though I still have facilities and miss pre 1.0 Foxhole. There are still issues re: time commitment - Foxhole is a game you either play casually, or pretty damn hardcore. There isn't much room in the middle anymore, which is a shame because it turns off a lot of newer players.

At the $30 price point there is a lot of fun to have, and the game finally really feels "complete" compared to the disastrous and buggy 1.0 launch in Sept. 2022. Unfortunately I worry these changes came too late as population and interest has waned. Again, still worth the price of entry, especially if you join a regiment and find a good group of people to play with. Just unfortunate the devs didn't implement these changes when the game left early access and had a much larger playerbase.

I'm not one for top down games. However I love how every thing in this has purpose and contribute to the fight.

Pros: Persistent world where the economy is 99% player-created aside from the starting locations of raw resources and logistics towns at the beginning of each war. Anything available for the public remains available for everyone else in the game to use and continue providing and fighting for your team.

Clans (regiments) of all sizes want to carve out their slice of the world to make a difference and help provide for the fight where it's most helpful. And the majority of clan groups are very helpful, willing to teach new players about what to do to accomplish things, and provide direction to understanding the game's fundamentals better.

Devs are semi-hands off with the community in a game where cooperation is near-mandatory, but the player-base came together to build a social construct that works to get people where they want to go to play the parts of the game that's most fun for them. There is 1 official Foxhole discord for the global community to commune, but the rest of the collaboration and decision-making is a 100% player-created and moderated society.

International community of more than a dozen languages yet still this large of a community can overcome language barriers to work together.


Cons: Not 100% of the world is player-created: the raw resources, victory points to capture, and which towns have which logistics buildings are set at the beginning of each war and remain until the end of the war (average about 13-20 days to complete a full war).

Because the world is a persistent state, everything you build and provide is available for everyone else to use, which comes with 2 mechanics: 1) other players are able to interact with, utilize, and take away things that may have made more sense to keep there or use differently. 2) everything that is player-created must be used/maintained or else it will decay and eventually disappear from the world if left inactive long enough.
The 1st point can be circumvented with locking your vehicles and creating private stockpiles, but those need to be continuously maintained to remain locked specifically to you as well (vehicle locks in the world last about 5mins, and each player can make 3 private stockpiles per Storage Depot or Seaport that lasts 50hrs).
The 2nd point can be circumvented by using the vehicles, weapons, etc. before it decays, or by providing Supplies (supps) to prevent structures from decaying.

Because of the ability for players to utilize others' created equipment, some players choose to be toxic and claim public things are theirs and grief/troll to prevent others from playing, or if a clan-sized group bands together to act toxic, they may think their efforts are worth more than non-clan or that others will misuse gear, and they may prevent people they've deemed unfit from playing differently.
Luckily both of these scenarios can be circumvented with the player-reporting system and by not retaliating in a toxic manner; the world is so huge that no single clan, regardless of size, will ever accomplish so much to affect the entire war effort, it still requires a large amount of cooperation to win the war. And if someone does something toxic to slight you, use the F1 screen to find the player and Report them.
Once a Report is filed, devs DO engage, investigate, and issue bans of varying degrees depending on how severe the infraction is.


TLDR; Foxhole is an absolutely massive undertaking of a game requiring a large amount of cooperation between people from all over the world. There's a lot to be done, every little bit helps, and expect the same pros and cons here as will come with interacting with dozens of players on the internet from around the world in any other multiplayer game.
(Also 'U' enables/disables voice chat if you're tired of hearing people talk)

A game not for the faint hearted as the only breaks are between wars. WARS that last without fail for a month on average as players across the irl world clash it out 24/7. Everything in this game is player driven from the spawn shirts to tanks needing to be made in the backlines, then brought up to the front to be used by the war effort. At the front there is numerous activities of building, combat clashes between tanks, infantry and even artillery elements dishing it out. The game world is so grand scale that what happens from one side feels so distant from the other side even if there are major battles sending your faction retreating out of an entire region. 

Keep in mind the game won't save your base, respect your time defending areas or care about your very own soul as it goes on the verge of insanity. Its astonishing and this is a helluva game to get involved into. I wouldn't trade a certain shell shock inducing Saturday operation of War 96 for anything.

I had a lot of fun playing this game for few weeks after buying it but I can't say the same thing now.
The game ITSELF is really good, the idea is brilliant, the execution however...is not so good.

The main issue is that unless you have a LARGE group of friends or you join a clan (which sucks unless your are that type of person to make friends out of everybody) the game is unplayable, everything from logistics to artillery and tanking is impossible without min. 4-5 other players.
The learning curve is stupidly huge, I still have no idea what to do after 50 hours of raw gameplay and hours on youtube.

Bad.
(and logi sucks)

This game is insanely fun, the world chat is full of memelords and the average gamer you meet is eighter a serious sweatlord or a roleplayer. Which makes everything so much fun. You can totally find an epic tank battle going on where the men in the tanks are emotionally shouting at the battlefield in full sweatlord mode given orders to the nearby infantry to charge, while simultaneously some dude in a >bicycle< tries to charge the enemy tankline while playing the soviet anthem and ringing his bike bell.
The big grindy logistical and very strategic gameplay followed by intense combat gameplay(running in between artillery bombs, sneaking into enemy terrain stealing stuff, trying to heal people while being shot from all sides, trying to put out a wildfire spreading in your base) alternated by some of the most ridiculous memes ive ever seen make the game a must play.

Starting off, you have the obvious classes like infantry, tank and artillery, partizan(sneak around kill logistics, steal tanks), (limited naval), builder and logistics and there is alot of subclasses i.e. for infantry you can do shotgun/smg/different rifles/sniper/flamer/anti tank sniper gun/suicide anti tank bomb runner/anti building(grenade/rpg)/medichealer/medicreviver/grenadelauncher/mortar etc etc
and even in the subclasses you can be creative, there is a weight system that makes you choose between carrying more ammo or running faster and you are free to multiclass perhaps you want to take a simple handgun(too keep weight low) add a medic healing kit(not the heavy revive one) and 1 anti tank grenade(because why would a tank expect a medic to suddently suicide run at them? big brain moment)

Besides the obvious classes their are hidden subclasses that are literally made up on the spot, one day ive noticed alot of tank teams are driving back to refuel and restock at a nearby base so i figured i take a small car with a few fuel and materials and drive to our tankline refuelling them by hand so they can fight longer. Which is stupid fun cause fuel is very heavy and sometimes your tankline falls back a little and you just stand there with the fuel while the enemy tanks charge in....haha dont shoot please, im just fuelmen :((
You can also just grab a radio and binoculars and lay in a bush deep in enemy lines, relaying intel to your team about enemy tank movement. Some people have also realised some bases have a long walking time to the front, so they build a bus and spend their days just ferrying other players to the frontline while playing some relaxing music in the bus. No one told them this class exists, but it is useful and they just invented the role out of thin air.
Another one being people that realised there is alot of materials in a place near water but far from the factories so they created a playermade port where they continiously farm materials and deposit them in freighter ships such that freighter specialists can pick up a full ship without having to farm materials while the port staff can just farm away without having to worry about transport. There are so many things you can do/create/organize besides the main classes, its literally insane. And that is just the solomen experience!!! imagine what a complete experienced clan can come up with!!! organizing and coordinating with other clans to plan huge surprise invasions, logistic chains, train networks, you name it.

I've spend my days traveling this open world and seeing what people are doing and what they could use and making up roles on the spot to assist the local needs, super fun and satisfying, everyday is different you start of by delivering a truck of supplies and before you know it some major is randomly shouting in region chat they need someone to deliver a construction vehicle and before you know it you find yourself escorted by a team of high ranked officers in jeeps and what not and you suddenly realize you just joined a small veteran clan operation to build a sneaky base behind enemy lines.
The next day you skip logistics and instead build a small motorboat to scout the enemy beach and halfway on the water you suddently see allied ships pass by with an insane naval fleet carrying tanks, cranes, artillery ships, infantry barges, readying for a huge D-day style invasion, so you end up spending the day joining the invasion grabbing explosives and blowing up enemy buildings.

strategy 10/10
creativity 10/10
variety 10/10
memes 11/10
truck simulator 11/10
ptsd realistic frontline simulator 99/10

The glory days where the actions of rag-tag groups of strangers could turn the tide of a front for longer than a couple of hours are long gone.
Nowadays, you'll be lucky if your efforts (with the help of the ever-present and horridly spoiled clans of course) stick for longer than 2 hours.

Frontline combat usually involves throwing yourself at the wildly convoluted new defense metas that content bloat has spawned over the years. After which, one may want a break from the front and try running logistics only to find a lone hauler was actually owned by a massive faction and then get mass reported to hell and back for touching it.

Doesn't matter anymore though- a new game is being worked on to carry on the sins of its predecessor.

- Major bugs that affect the on going war goes unresolved by devs

- Griefers/Cheaters doing the same stuffs for YEARS with only a slap at the wrist as a punishment
- The server is basically on life support whenever the player counts goes too high
- Queues (I know this is for balancing the forces but sometimes it's frustrating)

Don't get me wrong, I pretty much in love with the game but until the major of the problems are fixed, I cannot recommend it.

Extremely appealing core idea about war game with emphasis on logistics and realistic warfare, and extremely disappointing game design and implementation. All I wanted is to get me a truck, load it with anything useful and embrace my autism for hours driving and delivering stuff to the frontline. Game, instead, wanted me to waste hours searching for guides and learn the whole fucking logistics chain, sOcIaLiZe with squadmates of a squad that I had to find myself on discord, while constantly stressing about underperforming and sabotaging other peoples job (my actual impact on a war was one truck full of bmats destroyed by partisans). You wanted to drive a truck? Fuck you, there won't even be a cruise control after ages of development.

You don't need complex game mechanics including four different items to make it enjoyable to heal other players. You don't need more than one type of fuel to make your trucks and tanks go wroom. You don't need a fucking gun shop with dozens of models of firearms, one type of bolt-action rifle is enough. It's a game, it is supposed to be simple and enjoyable, if I wanted to endure trials of logistic hell I would enlist as Ukrainian volunteer.

Foxhole can be very fun, but also a bit overwhelming for new players. And a massive time sink and grind. It's a bit better if you are in a regiment, but it's still much grinding for supplies and vehicles. The massive battles, with infantry, tanks, and artillery is still great. And big logi ops.

For new players I recommend joining a regiment, as the game is built around teamwork and cooperation. You can still do solo things even if you are in a regiment. But you get access to private stockpiles close to the frontline and helpful people. Most people is friendly in Foxhole, but as we had problem with alts the last war's. People can be a bit suspicious to new players if you doing strange things. Also vehicles (that cost rmats) is expensive, so some people can complain if you do solo runs with it. You can lock your vehicle with 'L'.

The game design is really interesting and lives up to expectations. Having a huge map for an ongoing conflict makes sense for a game like this (until the current battle is finished and the next starts). The hexagonal grids and numpad identifier for subsections are a neat attention to detail. Most other players in the community are also fairly willing to help teach you enough to make a fighting difference. Even if you suck at the game like me, there's still ways you can contribute and kill other enemies, like using the mounted machine gun or lobbing grenades into trenches since neither requires much skill. Patrolling the waters in a gunboat always makes for a good time. Maybe not for the opposition, though.

Everything you do affects every player in your faction. From every equipment you waste to every vehicle you steel/park in a terrible spot and everything you build. This is not an action game like in arcade games. Positioning and having the right equipment at the right moment is more importand than skill. You spend a lot of time just driving/walking from A to B or getting the ressources, waiting in queues or grabing equipment from a building for 5s up to 1min. Teamwork is keypart of the game. So for the full expirience you have to find/work with a group of player wanting to do the same as you. If you play efficiant, there will be times you just do nothing at the frontline too like covering a side or sitting inside a pilebox, waiting for a ideal moment to attack like night or day or a tank to pass by, or covering logi roads against partisan. It's a slow game.

I absolutely love the idea of this game. I love quite a bit in general about this game. However with love, comes hatred. In my 1k+ hours playing this game I've developed some thoughts on it. 
Some Pros:
+The massive battlefields will always have a special place in my heart. From the tidal waves of bodies hurling mammon grenades at structures to the tank lines 20 deep on both sides blowing everything in between to kingdom come. 
+As with any game with clans, you can see a group of individuals truly accomplish the impossible in this game. The well oiled machines of the community have bore fruit on both sides of the battlefield in ever amazing ways.
+The fact I need to put in labor to see my efforts blossom is a reward that not everyone will understand. I personally love the idea of facilities and such that players can create and use. The same goes with the logistics as a whole.
+A fair bit of effort can be seen in certain hexes around the map. That effort should be recognized and applauded.
Some Cons:
-Most if not all hexes have what I refer to as wasted potential. Relic bases with seemingly no strategic point to them that simply serve as another place to capture so the map matches your factions color. They're rarely built up by the players and ultimately just become wasted space. I'm sure the developers will eventually address this issue. Another side of this is poorly designed areas that are vital to each faction. Yet serve as little more than meatgrinders at any given war. Mercy's Wish has to be the greatest example of poor design. The fact that no defenses can be built around the vital storage depot remains a mystery to me.
-Builder and logistics QoL improvements are a requirement at this point. Many players burn out when they take on the role of building a defensive structure that can withstand the onslaught of the enemy faction. A random invisible tree stump can ruin hours of planning as can the sudden inability to build a structure in an area previously able.

Foxhole is a game I dearly love and have invested hundreds of hours in, it's a game that's chaotic and you can invest as much time as you like and with many different ways to find satisfaction. 

However it's also a game that is plagued by a dev team that doesn't communicate enough and doesn't respond to player feedback, they also typically prefer to add new systems to the game as opposed to fixing and improving what's already there which leads to a lot of feature bloat and older systems feeling outdated and punishing. 

Additionally the community of this game has a toxicity issue, it isn't too bad most of the time in game, but lord help you if you ever visit the subreddit, the official discord or happen to cross the wrong group of players. 

As fun as foxhole can be, it's one of those games where you need to take a mental health break from it if you find yourself getting too invested in it.

A 24/7 mmo war between two factions competing for weeks to see who wins. There's two methods of gameplay that being logistics(Logi) and frontline combat. The experience of frontline combat can be very varied and intense with many possible tactics, subterfuge, loadouts, armored war machines, toxic gas, AT rifles or launchers, bayonets, grenade launchers, lmg/hmg, mounted weapons, trenches, and artillery. While logi is totally casual and relaxed as a solo where you may harvest materials to process into finished products that can then be delivered to frontlines to maybe gain commends that'll rank up your character.

  If you're looking for something more serious and organized you could join a squad or regiment/clan that can coordinate to accomplish ambitious goals like organized tank pushes to take a Bunker Base(BB) and territory, fielding several artillery pieces from which they'll rain death on the enemies positions and possibly destroying the enemies BB. If you like being a seriously sweaty gamer that wants to achieve epic things like building tier 3 concrete super BBs with massive storm cannons, participate in tank pushes made up of dozens of tanks, etc. there's a lot of room to be a super sweat. To join a regiment/clan is akin to joining a locked squad; you need to ask for an invite. Some regiments may be massive and run Discord servers where you may need to apply as well as to stay in the loop of the goings on.   

  The only indisputably negative aspect of this game is the lacking tutorials that cover only the basic of basics and everything else needs to be learned by yourself, asking others for help(most people are helpful unless they're arrogant super sweats), or looking up and reading the wiki constantly when you come across new aspects or items of the game.

I have a ton of hours in this game.  I absolutely love the concept, the gameplay, the strategy and the friends I've made playing this game.  It's one of a kind and I truly mean that in the best way possible.

Why is my review negative? Because the devs have signaled that they do not care about the playerbase at all.  Due to how the game works you have to have a high trust in your community to not tamper with equipment produced for the fight or you have to have moderation tools in place to fight against bad actors who are looking to play the game in bad spirit.  Foxhole has neither and its killed my enjoyment of this once great game.

Right now a person can buy a secondary account and log onto the opposite faction and have free reign to do whatever they want.  There's evidence a of accounts with no stats dumping tanks into the ocean to destroy them or dumping supplies from a base out right before an attack or leaving gates open so enemy partisans can have access to a base.

The worst punishment that person will face is a temporary suspension between 3 and 7 days.  That's it.  Hours and hours of work from people playing the game legitimately undone all for that person to only be temporary banned.  These temp bans don't ever escalate to being permanent either.  Users violation logs are visible and multiple accounts exist with 20+ temp suspensions.  It's a complete joke.

The worst part of this though?  The devs haven't said a word on the situation.  They control the official reddit and will ban you from the reddit for calling out alters with clear evidence.  They are quick to ban there but not for their own game.  They absolutely are aware of the concerns and do not give a shit.

My recommendation is to not buy this game ever.  You'll get invested like I did only to be completely let down by a developer team who would rather sweep the issues under the rug than address them head on.

EDIT: They've put in an effort to curb alting

It has slowly become impossible to play as a solo player.

Definitely a game where you should NOT invest your time.

If you're playing casually it's a good time. The combat is passable and the cooperation which the game encourages feel really good when it pays off.

If you stick around and devote your time the shortcomings of the game really start to become unavoidable. The lack of substantial punishment or moderation means that griefing could potentially ruin large amounts of progress made and toxicity can run through the games communication systems, but the main issue is it's development itself. Balance is wack and the new features seem barely tested at all making the players the games Q.A (Quality Assurance[Game Testers]). Finally the core fundamentals of the non combat side of the game are legacy systems with no Q.O.L(Quality Of Life) making it both frustrating and a monotonous grind.

As said at the start foxhole can be enjoyable but only if you take it casually.

TLDR(To Long Didn't Read) do not play this game unless you have cash to spare. Even if you do take it casually unless you 'play'(sell your soul to) games like EVE in which case still don't since it's just worse.

Addendum: Griefing is now more handle able and balance is slightly less wack(for now). Non combat is still up too 2000's level standards 4/10 Help I can't stop playing.

03.07.23 edit: Some of my concerns may be ironed out with the info from the most recent update 52 dev livestream. Will update review after 3-4 weeks of hands-on once game updated.  
04.14.23 edit #2: Still leaving this as a not recommended. The new UI improvements were badly needed, and are appreciated (despite them needing to have been there at 1.0 start). Devs seem content to all-in on facilities being the stop-gap for 70%~ of vehicle content, making what was once in the past a modest trip with mats to the garage or MPF for tanks a multi-stage, dozens hours, uptime-bloated job to get to the same result, without an equivalent exchange in fun. I'm sad I feel this way as you can imagine, given my hours invested, but i'll likely be on hiatus unless they make facilities supplemental (as originally stated) and not a gate.

I've been playing this game for a very long time, first picking it up sometime years ago when devs were still debating whether to include a text chat, boats were in development, and quartermaster was a socially appointed role in charge of delegating where guns, ammo, and resources went. It was a neat game, and I put it down while waiting for more updates.
Sometime in war 83 (each war lasts about a month) I picked the game back up again and all-in'ed on it. 
I marveled at the fact that 99% of everything used in wars were mined up, refined, and produced by players, and that true defensive positions, bunker complexes, were designed, made, and maintained by players. 

I became proficient in and known for building and I took pride in it. The actual building was endless grind and maintenance requiring many players for any kind of efficiency or speed, and garrison supplies, which required raw material and extensive production and delivery time. Yet building was and still is considered one of the most critical aspects of the game, as its the only thing stopping the enemy from rolling over sparsely-automatically-defended AI towns.

Prior to the 1.0 update, despite constant incessant tribalistic bickering between the two factions, Wardens and Colonials, most could reasonably say the game was in a goodish place; everyone can still agree there is nothing like Foxhole.
With the 1.0 update came flame weapons and yet heavier weapons capable of easily reducing dozens of collective hours of building, maintenance, and supply to rubble in less than an hour. Newly constructed bases need at least 24 hours of constant supervision to enable them to automatically defend themselves, or risk two experienced players with flamethrowers burning down a minimum 6 hours of work (not including prep) in less than 10 minutes.
Many variants of tanks and cannon pushguns were locked behind new facility systems requiring their own heavy investment; however, without any additional communication tools informing others what to expect from a facility, what it needs, and what it can produce, there are (still) no reasonable in-game means to coordinate efforts beyond temporary map call-outs and shouting blindly in chat for what you need and what you can give.
Most tank types, including the biggest and most unique, Battletanks and Superheavy Tanks, cannot be stored privately anywhere, meaning unless you take prohibitively annoying steps to secure them, it is plausible for people who have directly invested nothing in their construction to use a simple wrench to take them. 

As someone who has invested and continues to invest so much time in the game, it pains me to say that the game isn't in a healthy place. I do hope the devs at minimum allow facilities to perform a supportive role, such as giving optional enhancements or modifiers to tanks instead of outright restricting their production to them, add an optional "fire resistant" upgrade to bunkers, and add additional in-game communication tools such as a bill-board structure acting like 24 hour map signposts needing refreshed. This game is a truly unique, compelling, cooperative experience dragged down by predatory-mobile-game-levels of grind; it may only require an arguably cheap one-time cost, but it will completely consume your time in mindless tasks to "get to the good parts," and depending on your preferred play-style, unceremoniously take those good parts away anytime.

Foxhole is a good game plagued by absolutely disgusting community and several quite odd design decisions.

It is a game set in an interwar period in an alternate reality. As the technology progresses, so does the war: from trench warfare with bolt action rifles to artillery duels with tanks and automatic weapons. Foxhole has heavy focus on logistics: very few things manifest out of thin air; every gun, magazine, truck, tank and shell is manufactured by players and delivered to the front by players.

Secondary focus is on the teamwork. There isn't a single combat vehicle that can be operated solo; most require crew of two to four people. Same with logistics and construction: it can technically be done solo, but it's much better with a group. Organization is absolutely necessary to do anything beyond 'one guy with a rifle'.

It is a neat concept, similar to what Squad has but on a massive scale. However, there are ugly things under the hood.

Construction gameplay is divided in two parts: 'hold down LMB for hours to build it' and 'feed it supplies daily so it doesn't decay'. Both of these are just time sinks, exacerbated by the paramount importance of construction.

Logistic gameplay is similarly split into three parts: 'hold down LMB for hours to get resources', 'wait for timer on factory orders' and 'press W to deliver it to the front'. There's a bit more variety here than in construction, but in the end of the day you're either waiting on a timer or holding down one button.

Combat is actually really fun; infantry, artillery, naval, armored and guerrilla are all very well done, with asymmetric balance and some depth. You're not Rambo, you're regular guy with a regular gun: you can't mow down hordes of enemies for hours without reloading. Your tank isn't a magic metal box that repairs itself; it runs out of ammo, fuel, requires maintenance after several engagements, etc.

The worst part of the game is the community. While organization is absolutely necessary to run any kind of operation, the best way to enjoy the game is to not engage with community at all. Foxhole is filled with reddit troons, discord pedos and clan leaders on power trip that can and will mass report and tempban you for anything they don't like. If you're seriously considering getting into foxhole, enjoy it with a group of friends - you'll save a lot of brain cells by ignoring everyone in global chat and major discord servers.

Lastly, weird design decisions. 60 second spawn timers, timers to pull equipment, timers to build things, timers to rebuild things,  timers on crafting, border bases, technology mechanics, quirks with shooting into trenches (or up and down in general), weather system - all of this left me wondering why is it done this way and not any other way.

The other example of weird design choices is weather system. Long-requested feature was implemented in the most unfun way possible. 
When it's snowing, you freeze to death and vehicles freeze solid in 5-10 minutes outside. How to unfreeze a vehicle? Build a fire. Terrain not suitable for building? Sucks to be you, this is the only option.
When it's raining, vehicles are unaffected, but infantry rapidly accumulates mud to a ridiculous point: at maximum muddiness you cannot carry a rifle, a clip of ammo and a grenade without being overencumbered.
There are uniforms to help with cold and rain, but by large the only thing weather does is slow everything down.

All in all, Foxhole is a game with a neat concept, held back by bizarre dev ideas and irredeemably woke community that would benefit from arsenic injections.

Update for 1.0: devs tried to address logi grind, but somehow made it worse.
New Facilities seem fun and add some depth to logi gameplay, but in practice it's a case of building $1000 factory to make three $5 trinkets. This update is a massive failure; Siegecamp made one step forward for two steps back.

Update for 1.52: devs tried to address maintenance costs for facilities, but somehow made it worse(starting to see the pattern with the updates?). Now you're punished for someone digging out a massive bunker or building a giant facility 300m away from you. New maintenance system basically incentivizes griefing your neighbours. Beatings will continue until maintenance supply situation improves. On the upside, developers allowed securely storing combat vehicles now and added several other quality of life features. Normally you'd praise update for this, but in this case these features are so long overdue the only praise they deserve is "f*cking finally you slowpokes".

Just starting playing this game and it is really fun! The epic skirmishes immerse you in intense battle as the fight between both sides makes you feel the high stakes of war. The world is massive and evolves as players build and defend bases, set up supply chains, and improve technology. The community is very helpful to new players and everyone works together to build, supply, and fight. There is so much to learn but even as a new player, I felt like a valuable asset to the team by helping dig trenches, build defences, or fight the enemy.  

My first time playing as a Warden, we had just captured a city and were pushing the enemy out so we could build a better defence. We would skirmish with the enemy and push them back into their territory only to have them gain back the land we took. Then we would push them back again, and they would push us back. It was a constant game of tug-o-war, but slowly we were able to push back long enough to build a defensive base. It was a great feeling to have won the battle, and even more gratifying seeing how the team cooperated by building defences, supplying guns-n-ammo to those fighting, and coordinating an attack on the enemy. When I logged in again, it felt like a whole new world as the base was way bigger and we had pushed the enemy out of the region. 

If you like strategy , base building, massive open world , multiplayer , shooter games then I this game is for you!

Foxhole is a game like no other. It has its ups and downs with game balance and the developers building out the game following what is referred to as "the vision" which does not always match up to what the community wants, but generally it offers a pretty rewarding experience for players that enjoy the type of gameplay that Foxhole has to offer. The asymmetrical equipment for each faction makes for interesting engagements, and allows a lot of room for countering enemy attacks and being creative. The game's art style is really cool, and really allows you to be immersed into each faction's lore. Community engagement is a must in this game, and while there are some toxic people like in any other MMO most other players are very friendly and are there to have fun.

There really is a lot that could be said about Foxhole. I would recommend checking out some videos on YouTube before deciding on a purchase. The game is not for everyone, but if you enjoy the type of gameplay that is available there is nothing else like it.

This is probably one of the best games ever made and the potential that it has is amazing. The game features a persistent and fully player driven war being fought between the colonials and the wardens, each with thousands of players fighting for each side in a war spanning a fictional continent. The sheer scope of the game is amazing and every little bit of player contribution helps the war effort, a war that has the possibility of spanning real life months in the name of victory for your chosen faction. If endless possibilities and and intense combat interest you then this  game will be one of the most rewarding investments you can make so hurry up and join the fight.

This is one of the most sophisticated MMORPGs I have ever played. Any player can take on any role, e.g. infantry, logistics driver, medic, tankmen, gunboat driver, artillery gunner, bunker builder. Infantry combat is only a small part of the gameplay for many, but core to the game. Where else can you experience being under artillery fire for 8 hours while you desperately try to hold out for counter artillery? In what other world can you attempt to burn down weeks of another players' work? 

To new player, I would recommend watching YouTube videos or having a friendly player walk you through the basics at the tutorial zone. I also recommend joining the faction and regiment discords to find one of the most collaborative, engaging communities. If you are a builder, enjoy that you built it, but expect that it will go away.

Great Game, Honestly you dont scratch the surface till 500+ hours in when you stops being a frontline grunt and explore the rest of it. Theres so many different things to do to help the war effort to pass time. As a comitted solo play you can do 90% of the stuff the game has to offer, Some things are to great for a single a person to accomplish thoough. IE BT's SHT's and some other of the highest tier equipment. But with a small group of 3-4 committed players anything is acheivable in this game and I think that makes this game what it is. A very under appreciated COOP game.

Amazing concept, great community, great visuals and sound but it seems like the game was designed around having the player do as much tedious tasks as possible. Generally in games i like building, logistics, strategy, etc. All the before mentioned are just a tedious autoclicker simulator in this game which feel like i got a worse second job. There is no automation in the game which is a huge negative for this type of game and there are huge balancing issues between the factions. 
If you join the collies there will be a lot of tryharding but not in the good way as the community refuses to build and use their PVE tools because it's easier to complain about not having the cutler/outlaw/silverhand/chieftain.
If you join the wardens on the other hand there will be a lot "skill issue" where the infantry is slaughtered constantly with no way to retaliate (because the collies PVP is just better in every way), so you are just left with waiting and hoping to reach late game armor tech which will win the game because collies won't have more than 2-3 tanks on a front at a time(again easier to complain about warden armor being op instead of building smelters and bardiches).

I played both factions along 5 wars and I think that the asymmetric balance sucks in PVP and logistic/builder work are just a tedium that should be changed in pretty much all aspects.

Update: Facilities changed nothing in terms of tediousness of the logi/engineering activity. They just made more sinkholes for resources that need to maintained for no reason(because they are utterly useless until mid to late war)
Small gauge railway makes for a slow and underwhelming way to transport resources and is just tedious to drive around manually(unless trains can autopilot to destination they are yet another tedious thing).
Proper trains are locked behind late game tech and non-clan or casual players will never have any reason to use them.
There is still no automation possible (using pipes is 0.5% of the possible automation let's be real).
Building as ever sucks and is composed of autoclicking and with the addition of facilities and rails you just have to autoclick more.

Update: Since the latest update, an attempt was made by the dev to address most of the quality of life issues, with debatable results. Overall the game is improving slowly but surely

Well, where to start, Foxhole is a compelling MMO RTS type shooter, with a MMO system that is driven by a player world. The type of interactions you will face when playing foxhole is unlike any other game, Everything happens on one game but the "World" is divided into hexes that play along towards victory conditions, and ever changing map layouts. It is Still probably one of the MOST intense Factions/VS/Faction game ive played. The mechanics are deep, but you can always choose to do basic things and have a good time.

After more than 3000 hours of play, I have to advise against buying this game. The developers don't think it's necessary to fix the real problems of the game and punish players for misbehavior. Alternate accounts that sabotage the opposing faction are the order of the day and ruin the game for everyone involved. Instead of punishing these players, questionable mechanics are implemented that force players to log into the game almost daily to protect their built structures and buildings from foreign interference, but these mechanics do not provide 100% protection.
Instead of giving the players a pleasant playtime, they are kept in line with unnecessary content updates. Updates that make the game unnecessarily complicated and drag out the process of crafting various items. Things that are not fun but are necessary for the war to progress, take up a large part of the game time and need to be constantly monitored.
The devs stay hidden and don't communicate with the remaining small community. They only speak up again to introduce new unnecessary vehicles or time-consuming mechanics in the next content update.

Edit:
The recent QoL changes have made a difference and made the time spent playing Foxhole much more enjoyable. However, the game is still a hard grind and alting has been made more difficult but not prevented. Some things need some fine tuning but the game is back on track.
is ok

Foxhole is a game of impeccable quality. I have made several good friends playing as the game naturally gears players toward teamwork. For many players during the pandemic and those separated from in person table top gaming communities it is a great alternative. After my first dozen or so hours I was amazed at the value per dollar I had spent. Not only did I feel like I had a great entertainment value on my investment. I felt that it was heavily under-priced for what it is.

Key to the games amazing experience are four key elements. Some of them the development team has continued to improve over the time I have played;
1. Foxholes communications: Communications in Foxhole is easy to understand and to master. This is the first game I purchased a microphone for and it works wonderfully.
2. Fictional Geography: From my first battle at Outwitch Ranch to my fully veteran experience defending the Great Warden Dam the geography of Foxhole is second to non. Each bullet fired, each bandage used on a bleeding comrade, and each bunker built endears players to a location more and more until certain locations become places.
3. Moral: This is the first game I have ever played where battle psychology can be used to devastating affect. A single man with a bayonet can cause a whole trench line to flee in terror.
4. Equalizer: The games lack of achievements and war to war accomplishment inspires players. High school students play next to lawyers. Programmers next to sewage plant workers. It doesn't matter who you are or where you come from. Skill and competence are all players care for. A welcome escape from class structures.

Try Foxhole... Please. You should try at least once. :)

This game shocked me, I tried this game a few months ago and hated it, didn‚Äôt have a clue what I was doing so I got it refunded. 

But OMG, I‚Äôm so glad I gave it another chance, I saw a YouTube video and thought I‚Äôll try again and I‚Äôm so glad I did, the game itself isn‚Äôt the most gorgeous game graphically but it‚Äôs good enough and runs ultra smoothly at 144fps for myself. 

The thing that made me love it is, I met a random guy at a base, who asked me what my plan was as I was just wondering around, and within seconds i was added to his group and we was off on a trip to the front lines. 
Maybe I‚Äôm sad, but hearing grown men and women scream ‚Äúmedic‚Äù with the occasional  group of Russians in a tank singing go past me made me feel amazing, the intensity of the firefights and gun shots and burning through ammo is just amazing, I‚Äôm really not too fussed about the amount of time I would die or get left to bleed out in a trench, to respawn and go back to try and avenge myself was amazing. 

The great fact that everything is built by players is crazy good, I joined maybe near the end of a war or midway through so there‚Äôs lots of tanks and everyone is stacked up, I would love to see what it‚Äôs like at the bare bones of just trench warfare. 

If anyone loves war games and just having a blast with a group of mates BUY this game, holding a town for hours on end is crazy, slightly disappointed when you hold it and log off and then a few hours later your team has lost it to the enemy but that will teach Me. 


I recommend this game and I can‚Äôt wait for the sequel they have planned. Huge fan can‚Äôt wait to play more

Don't let people mislead you here. If you just take it easy and have a good time with some pals you'll find plenty of friendly players who are eager to help or just kinda futz around. There are so many ways to play this game, even just as infantry without a vehicle, with wildly different roles, all of which are useful. Going into it with a positive attitude and understanding this isn't really a gunplay focused shooter game and rather is a cooperation, communication, and tactics based game is important. Sure you might walk outside your base and immediately die to an artillery shell, but war is hell, dude

Highly recommended.

You have two factions (Wardens and Colonials) constantly at war in a fictional WW1-WW2 like setting. Wars have a beginning and end, with victory conditions over a huge single-shard map, and typically last around a month, after which the victors get a commemorative plaque for their win in their home island, listing the top contributors and the map resets.

There are constantly fights over 1 to 3 fronts in the map, and three distinct roles: soldier, builder and logistics. There's gunfights, vehicle combat and naval combat, you can be a footsoldier, a partisan, a medic etc. It is classless which means the player can do whatever they feel like or their faction needs at the moment. There are static buildings and cities, but apart from these the players can build trenches, defenses, bunker bases, FOBs, howis, vehicles, watchtowers etc and fight over them.

Very nice dev team too, watch any of their devstreams to get an idea.

I currently have [strike]239[/strike] 1014 hours played in this game and intend to increase that value. I remember trying out this game [strike]about a year[/strike] [b]years[/b] ago but it was in a completely different state than it is today. My first impression over a year ago was okay, but I could never really find where I needed to go. I felt lost and inefficient.

But now - in its current version, they have vastly improved the UI and feedback of the game. It is clear what the goals are and what is needed. The idea of the war being shared across regions on the same "master server" makes this effort easy to grasp as to where to pick up and go fight. They have a decent training area that covers the basic interactions of the game, the players are awesome to interact with, the fights are intense and there are so many different roles you can get into. 

I have my days where I'm energized by a cup of coffee and I'm ready to rumble in the heat of battle. I can fight at the front lines using a wide variety of tools and weapons and change into any role I need, be it Medic, Rifleman, Grenadier, Sapper, Tank Crewman, scavenger (scoop up weapons/supplies at front line and bring them back), mortar crew...whatever ground troop role you can imagine. 

There are days where I get home from work and I just want to chill and run logistics for the team. I can choose how complex I want to get with my logistic efforts for the war. If I want brainless work, I'll go gather materials and refine them so I can stockpile the main bases in the back. If I want to be a little more involved, I can do that, plus place orders for weapons and tools to stockpile the base. If I want to take it further than that - I can drive my logi truck around the front lines and communicate with the team to find out where shortages are, and create an operation with other people who want to do the same and all of a sudden I'll be involved in a large logistics operation involving multiple people coordinating their efforts to keep the boys at the front pushing. 

Shit, I've been involved in naval operations that raid the shores behind enemy lines and connected back to front line troops to cut off the enemy to win a region back. 

People have the ability to commend based on your actions, which gives a bit of a "feel good" that someone recognizes your efforts. These commendations increase your rank. 

I really enjoy following the war when I'm not playing. I'll spend a night doing logistics or building up defenses for a town we own - then wake up in the morning to login and see if anything made a difference. It feels good to see the front lines held, but you are left to wonder what happened when you lose territory. In any case, I really recommend this game. I've played lots of war games and I'm just surprised I'm into this game since its not a FPS game. 

I feel like this game and its developers are really onto something here and I can't wait to see how they finish this product and what other types of games they might come up with. They design the game in such a way that it feels unique compared to any other game out there, and I like that.

there are a lot of condescending dudes in the big clans who have a very annoying "world of warcraft" type relationship to the game and will take your having a life and wanting to have fun in a video game as either a slight against them personally, or a reason to believe you have an iq of about 50. thankfully, the game is big enough that you can more or less ignore these people and find some fun to be had and some well adjusted people to hang with. I really think going forward the devs should do something about this stuff because there is a really good chance nobody will be playing in 2 years.

I don‚Äôt usually write reviews but for this game I feel like I should. Foxhole as a concept is a fantastic idea for a game that gives you a truly one of a kind gaming experience, unfortunately being a great idea is the only thing that is good about it. Foxhole has been so catastrophically mismanaged by its developers that its own community has actively tried to make the game fail. 

I have played Foxhole in every war from WC71 to WC101 logging over an entire week of playtime during the 1.0 update war, that‚Äôs almost exactly 2 years of consistently playing this game and watching it develop so believe me when I say that this game has seriously gone downhill. The developers of this game have allowed themselves to be stubborn and petty to the point of destroying a revolutionary game.

Here are some reasons that you may want to rethink buying Foxhole 
‚Ä¢Foxhole is filled with long standing bugs, exploits and hacks that the devs have ignored in order to push out bloated content updates.
‚Ä¢The new logistics system in game is overly complex and takes hundreds if not thousands of man hours to maintain a single facility for the duration of the war (usually a month or so). 
‚Ä¢After several years the developers have only recently made changes to reduce the amount of ALT accounts easily destroying/sabotaging your hundreds of hours of work.
‚Ä¢There is an incomprehensive and outdated tutorial that is generally skipped, causing unintentional griefing.

The developers refuse to balance the game. There is a clear faction bias. The last several updates have heavily favored colonials, giving them many cheap yet very powerful weapons and vehicles to add to their already strong arsenal. The new weapons and vehicles have given the colonials a massive advantage over the wardens, a faction whose weapons are generally described as gimmicky and not as useful as their colonial counterparts. Evidence of bias also comes in the form of colonial buffs immediately following the recent 8 month long colonial win streak. 

For the sake of keeping things as concise as possible I will stop here but I'd like to note that these are not all of Foxhole‚Äôs problems, these are just some of the biggest and most relevant that come to mind.

In conclusion I would highly recommend against buying Foxhole, Anvil Empires or any other game touched by Siege Camp.

I have 122 hours in the past 2 weeks, 120 hours = 5 days, problems may arise for you as they have for me when it comes to managing game time. 

If you are new or going to restart playing the game, I recommend doing so at the start of a new war. Early war is Foxhole at its simplest, this is the best time to learn how to fight, work together, and figure out the general flow of the game. As the war goes on, territory changes, and technology advances. When first your only option to kill a structure was with mass grenade charges, you could instead use: artillery, tanks, rpgs, gunboats, smoke screens + explosive charges, and more. 

Foxhole has become perfect at extending your attention span for its game. There are clear objectives to complete, many routes to do so, and always more to do. 

It has cool moments, sad times, frustrating defeats, and dumb asses. 

Personally my most satisfying moment as been running in with no gear, serpentine movements through machine gun fire, punch the guy with a machine gun, steal gun, massacre enemies from within their own battlements. 

I am sure you can find something equally or cooler to do.

[h2][b]March 26th edit: While making some parts less tedious, the latest update also added things that make them worse. These devs only know how to sidegrade problems elsewhere, I guess. 

Oh, and Siegecamp - ever heard of splitting your assets into smaller files? Having to rewrite the entire 15GB pak for every 15KB update is murder on SSDs and wastes even more player time. Maybe hire even one person who knows what they're doing, please?[/b][/h2][h2][/h2][strike]March 8th edit: the next update has been revealed to address many of the player-hostile issues like aggressive base decay and transporting concrete. Depending on how Devbranch goes, I might change this to Recommended - this is a big step in the right direction![/strike][h2][/h2]I've been sitting on this review for about a year in the hopes Siegecamp would stop wasting time and polish their game. That's only gotten worse with 1.0 and communication with the playerbase continues to be extremely lacking, so here we are. [h2][/h2][b]This game's devs do not respect your time.[/b][h2][/h2][i]No matter which faction you're on[/i], Siegecamp continues to ignore extremely basic design issues in favor of adding yet more broken nonsense. There isn't a single feature in Foxhole that isn't either tedious, severely-unpolished, or outright too buggy to be fun - building is an hours-long timesink into arcane sorcery that can often be undone by five minutes worth of functionally-unfightable arson with zero risk, manufacturing is inconceivably boring for most players and too-short factory expiration to public means it's often not possible to produce e.g. gsupps during a casual session, infantry combat is plagued by esoteric aiming rules or RNG-based weapons, and other activities like artillery usually boil down to a player pressing one button over and over for hours without any positive feedback from the game. [h2][/h2]Even the interface is bad? Features that've been present in games for decades, like sorting the world squad list (which containing hundreds of squads and is impossible to browse) or searches on any of the many listed interfaces, are completely absent in Foxhole. The chatbox will close itself while you're typing if you click on it, players will randomly be counted as offline and can't be messaged or invited to squads, the voice chat is almost guaranteed to get an unfixable error requiring a game restart at least once per session - usually preventing you from getting back to where you were due to queues, and the list goes on and on.[h2][/h2]If it weren't for out-of-game communities almost no one would play Foxhole. Its social aspects alone ought to have a big appeal, and if not for the blatant quality of life issues I'd be pulling all of my friends in even if my preferred faction lost every war... but as it stands I'll be warning everyone to stay away until the devs acknowledge that the game needs polish more than they want new guns or barely-functional "features" to make gameplay even more of a second job.

Had this for awhile its a real mixed bag folks giving it a no based on my experience as a solo player.
[b]Toxicity:[/b]
This was something that I was really worried about when I first got the game most reviews were complaining about this, but the player base wasn't that 'toxic' from my encounters. I mostly played Colonial (green man) they tend to have smaller clans that work together in coalitions and from my experiences do a whole lotta public stuff. The Wardens (blue man) tend to have larger clans that tended to gather and spend their resources on those larger clan operations during the weekends apparently there are civil wars going on who gets to harvest at the rare resource nodes. The only time I've really seen toxic elements is while building, especially as a newer player since poor building placement can really mess things up for your side.

While both sides can be annoying at times, if you hate people spamming CUM or talking about femboys/techmaids then don't join the Wardens it personally drove me away from the faction and I liked almost everything about it weapon/aesthetic wise.
Colonials apparently have large numbers of Furries but I haven't seen any so I cant comment on that, the players talking about that stuff might be talking about out of game fan art or it might be a big meme about being nicknamed Collies.

[b]Optimization:[/b]
The game can at times feel like it isn't super optimized. You can run into some real lag even on the lowest settings when players have large construction in certain areas. Facilities has made this feel worse as you need to build lots of them due to dev vision of specialized facilities trading with one another, not so great for performance power generation seems to be a big part of this. 

[b]Asymmetry:[/b]
Factions have some shared neutral gear but most gear you use will be faction specific, Colonials have recently been buffed as of 03/30/2023 (MM/DD/YYYY) in regards to their lunaire grenade launcher allowing it to destroy buildings more efficiently. Colonials had been asking for something like this for longer than I have been playing (~4 months at least) so don't expect quick balance changes. 

Colonial:
As a mostly solo player I think the Colonials have the better infantry gear in the form of the bomastone grenade a very long range and causes bleeding which forces Wardens to use lots of medical supplies.
They also have a large variety of rifles each serving a purpose close range to longer range all of those early game rifles take the same ammo making logistics better. 
Wardens:
The Wardens on the other hand have more specialized gear, a heavier longer range rifle the Loughcaster (my favorite), a light SMG that uses different ammo great for close quarters or at night fighting, a short range revolver rifle that does a lot of damage but once again uses different ammo. Vehicle differences do exist but I cannot comment too much on them beyond wardens vehicles tend to have more armor but lower hp and might have extra guns that use different types of ammo from the tanks main gun.

[b]Do I recommend it? Will you have fun?[/b]

Yes: If you are willing to join a clan, join their stupid discord and participate in their attempted operations then I suppose you will have fun...provided you and your clan can get past the queues and are in the right timezone my warden experiences have been massive 10+ person queues in which I could be forced to sit in for 30 minutes as I attempted to participate in the organized operation. Even if you manage to get in you or clan members could disconnect at any time and be forced to sit in the same queue all over again.

Yes: If you have a group of THREE or MORE friends that are willing to play the game with you then I can also recommend the game and will vouch you will have fun. Why? Because almost all vehicles require three or more people to function properly and that is not even counting the gathering, processing, construction, AND DELIVERY of the vehicle and ammo. You can also do partisan activities which consists of blowing up the people trying to deliver supplies to the Frontlines. I mostly stuck to using mortar weaponry/vehicles when I could get teams together. Just be aware you probably wont be able to do anything at night if you are in a tank.

Yes: If you are willing to herd random players into actual plans, this takes a special kind of person though and if you are on the shy side it wont happen. You could potentially push a frontline this way but all my experiences with this stuff has been early game with disorganized mammon rushes where some random will gather a bunch of people together to suicide charge enemy fortifications with anti structure grenades. 

No: If you want to do anything combat related as a solo player for vehicle reasons mentioned above and because as infantry your will spend most of your time looking at a 10-60 second death timer while fighting over a stupid bridge that will not change hands until an organized clan rolls in to push the front forward. If you are not on a bridge then you are waiting in queue for the fun regions, if you are not waiting in queue then you are undersupplied because using the weapons + respawning in this game relies on logistics slaves driving across entire hexes to put shirts guns and bullets into your base and guess what? They sit in almost the same queue you do. The charm really wears off quickly once you 'get' combat and can actually get kills.

No: If you want to do logistics AKA a boring second job for no pay. They are basically the slaves of the game who sit there playing a terrible grindy Old School Runescape esque mining and moving simulator so people on the front lines can have all the fun. The only upside to this is you get commends from other players (ONLY IF YOU DELIVER SUPPLIES TO THE FRONT) which will increase your rank in game which is mostly cosmetic garbage, I wouldn't bother with it especially since rumor has it a rank reset is apparently coming.

No: If you want to build, building is akin to logistics you are once again playing a slave forced to sit in place with a hammer or shovel holding down the left mouse button for minutes at a time while other players have fun. The worst part by far is the maintenance which involves doing the slave logistics stuff as mentioned earlier but you are only building supplies to stop your stuff from decaying into rubble if you are far enough behind enemy lines and the war lasts long enough then you may be doing this for an entire month or longer.

No: If you cannot tolerate reporting players that can have up to 30 violations only to have them get banned for a few days.

The game has its strengths and weaknesses.
But since its the only one of its kind I decline to not recommend it even if I had some major bad experiences in my last 100 hours (mostly interaction with toxic clans and players).

Strengths:

- Very unique, niche game 
- Strong team play (also for solo players)
- Casual, but addicting
- Fitting graphics
- Masses (250+) of players on a single map, thousands on the whole world map
- Wars go from 10-60 days and then everything resets
- In general a nice community
- Dozens of different vehicles and buildings
- Dozens of weapons, gear and other stuff
- Lots of cool mini features and functions
- Faction vehicles are not 100% mirrored and also some weapons differ, making it interesting to switch sides from time to time

Weaknesses:

- Servers (Been a major issue since early "early access")
- Clans can get toxic if youre single player
- Players can get toxic due to sandbox and building features
- No real tutorial: Which can be frustrating for fresh players 
- No real tutorial: Which can be frustrating for veterans when interacting with new players
- Music and sound lack a bit in this game in general
- Lots of bugs relating the terrain (getting stuck, cant build etc)
- Due to world wide 1 server expect some lags when interacting with other players
- Shooting feels a bit janky due to server issues and world wide mixed players (high ping)

Still in general its worth playing it. 
Last words: 
I really recommend avoiding toxic clans as much as you can, as they can mass report you if they do not like your behavior or play style (ultimately resulting in bans).

A whopping 700 hours in this game. When I first started playing, I considered this something new, fresh, and exhilarating. Though it remains an enjoyable and thrilling experience, the development studio has been slow to address issues, though this has recently improved. My The Good, The Bad, The Ugly review follows.

Tldr version:

The Good- Exhilarating war with a role for everyone. The players really make this thing unique and fun. Real life band of brothers vibes on every front. MOST players very welcoming and friendly to newbies. Whether you are a grunt in the meat grinder, a medic treating the wounded, a truck driver, or a salvager, you've got a role and respect since everyone contributed to the war effort.

The Bad: Grind for Logistics mixes EVE Online with Factorio. If you have the stomach for that, it's still unsettling. Balance issues remain that strike deep and harm the grand wars. Still buggy with an unhealthy dose of lag in many regions. Region queues, while necessary, can wreck your game when your squad or friends are in zone, and you can't deploy to join them. You can go elsewheren to die for your side, but it's best played with friends.

The Ugly: Cheesy, albeit mechanically possible, work arounds sneak by developers in betas. Players find them quickly and exploit them until patched.

Longer Version:

The Good: Fill a variety of roles, fight in amazing battles, join squads and regiments and coordinate either small skirmishes or massive tank battles. Or die in the trenches under heavy shelling and machine gun fire. Those aspects were incredible, and still are. The players, though, they make it a truly incredible experience. From shouting for medica to save them and thanking their madnrushbtheough bullets, to Logistics players dodging ambushes and mortars to deliver critical supplies, to the sounds of the Battle Bus zipping troops with grenades to the front, to shouts of Valhalla! Mind blowing and incredible.

The Bad: Have you ever been to Deadlands and rubber banded in-between everything? What about seen a tank commander flying cross your screen as if transported from a game of Quidditch? Ghost obstacles that block you but never render. All of this remains problematic. There is very little attention to these bugs.

Balance remains a key concern, but are slowly moving in the right direction. Avoiding the dev bias remarks each side tosses around, there are remaining balance issues players have voiced for months and years. I recall, during the 1.0 announcement (you can find it on YT) , a dev laughing about how his changes would make the balance team upset. It wasn't tongue in cheek. It was real. Not something that builds trust in the community and, frankly, should have been reprimanded.

The Ugly: Cheating players that join one side to spy or sabotage it (alts) remain an issue. Region queue issues are killing the experience, especially as one side losses players as the war progresses towards defeat. The disruption of the modding community was a hard pill to swallow and shows the overall lack of thoughtful solutions to some of the issues regarding cheaters and balance.
