The persistent world, the logistics system, the scale of the game are all very cool, but what really breaks this game for me is that the underlying core shooter gameplay is quite basic and simply not very fun to play. The game as a whole feels like a huge Rust server that has the playerbase divided into two teams that fight each other, except that the combat in Rust is quite fun, in comparison to Foxhole.
CUM PEOPLE BAD

Is the game good? Yes. 
Is it fun? Yes.
Can you sink 10s of hours into this game each time you open it? Absolutely yes

But it's very niche. The gameplay is fairly slow for a solo player and you can't get much done without at least cooperating with others. Sometimes that means you'll have great experiences on the frontlines with natural leaders taking charge on the mics and the newer players following orders, and the whole game becomes a well oiled war machine simulator. Other times that means pure chaos in silence as your enemies encircle your bases and your friendlies are only able to spam nades with no comms being called.

If you are a player that is looking for something where your actions truly matter in day-to-day activities and you want to work with others on achieving common goals and you view the dedication required to the game as a positive, then this game is right up your alley. On the flip side, if you aren't able to at least dedicate a few hours each day to fighting/gathering resources/building, then you don't really get to see the macro picture of the game which is where the complexity and fun is really at.

If you're a perfectionist that sees issues and just has an itch to fix them, this game will ruin your life. Every front is rife with so many imperfections that you will get stuck in an endless loop of hole filling until you're driven into madness. 10/10 war realism, 10/10 gameplay. Game is like a massive football game that you can watch from foxholestats.com and participate in whenever you would like. Don't buy if you consider yourself impatient and addicted to quick stimulus games like overwatch or apex.

It takes a little bit to get used to the (frankly not really hard) controls, then you are ready to go into your battle.

As always the main objective is to incapacitate the enemy, while keeping a keen eye on your ammunition.

If you run out of ammunition, or the base runs out of supplies, it is your task as a live soldier, to create new ammunition from any type of scrap materials, and refine it. You are to go to where the enemy has their encampments, where you will take out any enemy soldiers, either with live fire, (if available) booby traps, or with your grenades.

On the way there, you take a lookout for any hostile squad, or unit.
If you encounter any hostiles, you take them down, with no aimed shot, at best you are running adrenaline, so keep a cool head and steady your rifle, or handgun, smg, and any heavier weapon, mg, or artillery weapons, canons, and armed patrols.


When you are being overrun, it is your main objective to hold your grounds.
When you cannot hold ground, your objective shifts from this ground, and you will fall back.
Take special care of your rifle, and ammunition, and preferably don't let it get wet (although you can swim in the game even with your rifle).

Take your spot, or hide in concealment. Your area is your last stand, seek out theirs, and find where they are hiding, steal their satchels, and ammunition, at their camp you are being hidden, and remain focused.

If your main area in battle expertise is staking out the opposition, your squad is recon. If you like to ambush your opponent, camp in a section which has enemies passing through, also take special eye if you are sniping for their higher ranks, so they can have them (bullets).

When you run out of bullets, or you are in close proximity, use your melee weapon, or your small caliber handgun, which has more shots.

Firing ammunition should only be practice in the firing range, or where your enemy was hiding.

If you don't want to have a strike on an empty base,
first read battle practice, then read your elections.
If so, then maybe one day, also you will call yourself Supreme Commander.

Now go forth and build us that base.
Carry strike initiatives, and defend your main territory, as well as your squad (of rookies).
You are going to utilize equipment, carry your medics, and operate your squad as a single unit.

So, carry on your soldier, and make uncle Sam proud.

All medics will carry out routine duties, that are always mandatory, and your squad is saving the men and women, that are fighting for our glorious nation, where we can live in peace, with no front aforementioned, had they not struck.

Your job as a soldier is to reconcile this.

Devs need to seriously reconsider their vision for this game if they want to keep their casual player base.

foxhole has the potential to be an absolutely incredible game, it's unlike any other i have ever played, and i SINCERELY wish i could recommend it to customers. it can be a real blast. i have made friends within both factions, committed entire days to important battles that will define the entire war in player-built organizations, and have overall enjoyed at least a portion of the hours i've spent addicted to this game.

however, the game is managed by a team of developers that are completely out of touch with the community, and almost every update makes things worse rather than better. more and more emphasis is placed on the grind than the entertainment, and more and more player labor is required to do increasingly complicated logistical tasks. the introduction of facilities made an already tedious logistic process into something far too complex for casual players, essentially requiring player formed regiment membership to learn and work with the system. even within regiments, logistics have become a complicated bureaucracy full of toxicity and arguments over materials and location. casual players will struggle with facilities (which have been made ESSENTIAL to logistics and even putting up a fight in the war) due to no adequate tutorial, difficult to understand systems and a relatively heated environment.
  
there is a horrible system of "asymmetry" that results in the very weapons the factions unlock throughout the war defining the way the fronts will shift and not player ingenuity alone. and because of this asymmetry, complaining about an objectively unbalanced weapon your faction cannot have that makes combat frustrating will cause people from the other faction to make fun of you and cite how your faction has weapons they cannot adequately deal with as well.

whenever they finally make tweaks to make things more equal, it tends to do the opposite and removes the "edge" one faction has over the other, making the other asymmetries in the game so much more apparent. this is why both factions will complain about dev's having bias for the other, it's because there are periods where they will nerf one faction likely multiple updates in a row while only buffing the enemy, keeping the fundamentally broken and decisive system. alternatives between factions is good, allowing for unique playstyles depending on what flag you wave, but some materials are just objectively better from one faction to another and there's no denying this.

performance can be absolutely god-awful in busy regions, and the queues to even get in to combat get unfathomably long. there's very little accessibility options; for example, there's little accommodation for those of us that suffer from colorblindness. language barriers provide a real and unintentional challenge that makes gameplay more interesting, and the ways in which we as players work around it is so fascinating and entertaining, but lack of built in communication methods has led to some racist attitudes in the community that may (can't personally attest as a native english speaker) make new players feel unwelcome. 

overall, foxhole has so much potential that just continuously gets torn apart by its own developers. the game has become less and less fun the longer i've been playing.

Great concept but has a major flaw. Their choice of game engine limits the number of players to 200 on a server (up from a default 100).  Their map has several servers (regions). There are several sub-regions within each region so if you have more than 200 players on a single server they cannot fully play in every area within the region. So fighting two wars in the same region is a pain in the ass despite the map intending on having wars on multiple fronts within a region.  To make matters worse is these areas need resupplied, which requires players to enter and exit the region, but with a limit of only 200 players (most of which are fighting) it makes it difficult to supply the war efforts.  Basically this logistical heavy game, which requires multi-regional access is in need of major solutions.  Until then this game is nothing more than a queue simulation trying to be a game.  So if you enjoy waiting hours (yes sometimes an hour) to actual do something in the game besides pew pew then I'd wait to play.  With this game being so close to gold release I would not hold my breath that they fix something that has been an issue for years.


Edit:  After years of development the game suffers not from it's own design, though there are a few technical issues, such as above.  More so it suffers because the core concept behind the game requires players who are like-minded.  This is as close to a military sim game as  they come, which requires everyone on a side to come together to win the objective. The problem is developers want to ensure that solo players can do anything but individuals doing whatever they want hinders the core concept behind the game.  Name a real life military where individuals can do whatever they want.  This isn't just limited to individuals, companies are also guilty of doing their own thing and not working together with the rest of their faction.  

tldr: Cooperation in a game that requires all to work together is lacking but that's more on the player-base than the developers, but the game developers also do encourage that type of behavior by designing a game that ensure solo players can do everything in the game, resulting in weak defenses, weak logistics, and weak morale, leading to player retention issues.

As a social experiment, it's amazing. As a game? Eeh. Eeeeeh.

For those unaware, Foxhole is a giant war where everything, from the guns you use to the tanks the other guys have, came from raw materials that were gathered, refined, and then built in factories and put on a got dang truck and driven to the front line. It's astounding that it works at all! It's a testament to humanity's natural inclination towards cooperation and construction, with people building massive and complicated factories so anyone can get raw materials and refine them into usable stuff.

But it's... too much. Back when I played a lot, you could usually find places where there was somewhere to refine material, somewhere to build things, and somewhere to store them all located close to each other. The ability to really pump out stuff was further back, in specialized buildings that would make lots of stuff at once, but you could usually find a hub in every one of the big hex map areas that had the ability to put together supplies. It was honestly really fun being a small time logistical driver, going around and gathering raw materials from fields, making a bunch of useful stuff with available materials, storing it up, and then responding to front lines who needed supplies. It was a genuinely unique experience, and one that I really enjoyed.

But no longer. Now not only are the buildings to do everything scattered to the winds except in the very first hex, there's now even more complicated steps to produce things that require player built structures. Driving around and collecting things to make sure you've got a stockpile of bandages in case a front needs them went from "easy" to "requires multiple hex journeys," and that's like a 15 minute drive each way. Doing nice things like "leaving the materials to build trucks in the garage" went from being something that required a couple extra minutes to your entire play session. It's just too much, man. It's not fun.

Well, what about the shooting? I'll be honest, I never liked it. It's top down, and you can't see far. You die easy, guns are strange, and since it's core thing is that supplies have to be moved around, it's not like you're always gonna have what you want. The enemy has artillery that's pounding you? Building artillery isn't pressing a button, it's getting a bunch of different materials from different factories, putting them together in a different factory, putting the piece on a truck(with a crane), and driving it to the front and unloading it(with a crane). Then you need ammo, which is a similarly complicated process. Their guys using automatic weapons? It's not a matter of changing class, you have to have those weapons in your base and have ammo for them. It's entirely possible that your side hasn't actually got the technology to even build something similar yet, because there's a research system. The enemy have a tank? Oh buddy, don't even pretend you can just go pull your own. Making one takes literally hours with all the shit that goes into its production.

If you're part of a gigantic clan who plays all the time, the game probably can be fun still. War is a massive logistical and industrial affair, so small groups can't realistically contribute much to it. There's a reason armies are big. But people usually play games to enjoy themselves, and much of the experience in foxhole is frustration because of just how difficult it is to DO anything.

Pros & Cons from the average gamer, if your one of those people, this is how you will likely feel towards the game.

PROS -- Positive elements of the game.

‚Ä£ Cool concept, every soldier is a real player aside from AI occupied structures.
‚Ä£ The entire war is shaped by the players themselves.
‚Ä£ The frontline combat is interesting and entertaining.
‚Ä£ The frontline combat does feel real, and it can be intense.
‚Ä£ Feels like what an actual war would be like in real life, considering all elements.

‚Ä£ Logistics is relaxing and easy, and you feel your contributing significantly in doing so.

CONS -- Negative elements of the game.

‚Ä£ The game is too competitive, if you see someone say it is user-friendly, sure but not in a social sense. Logistics players are too entitled to the effort they put in to admit that maybe they need help.
‚Ä£ The wars take too long, I do have a pretty long attention span but most of this game is literally just meat grinding on the front lines, once in a blue moon does a special operation happen.
‚Ä£ AI structures, although good as the current amount of players cannot hold the entire front line themselves needs to be nerfed. Mammon rushing is a solution but usually there are not nearly enough to make a dint in the enemies front.
‚Ä£ Get's boring quickly due to the persistent nature of the game, as most front lines don't move for days.
‚Ä£ Can become easily frustrating if your logistics are fail to supply at an adequate standard.

Overall, the game is not really interesting at all, only recommend to retired veterans, people who have a lot of free time and war-sim enthusiasts. But I love the concept, the concept is amazing, just wish a lot more was going on in wars and you didn't always feel like you struggled to even get by.

---------- Edit (Feb 24th 2023) (~1500 hours in game)------------
Foxhole is a fantastic concept for a game and there is a lot of fun to be had playing with friends. However the game appears to be designed for attracting new players with shiny toys rather than making a quality experience once the game is already purchased. The developers clearly either do not play the game themselves to have an understanding of the games problems, of which there are many, or they don't care. Why should they care? the devs make money when the game is purchased and do not have a subscription. It doesn't matter if a player plays for 5 hours or 5000 hours the devs make the same amount and this shows in the game's QoL updates, of which there are none or at least no meaningful ones.

One major issue is with the building mechanics. Pre 1.0 update the game's engine couldn't handle many structures in the world at once so the devs try to limit building by making maintaining buildings as time intensive and annoying as possible. If you have a build to upkeep its like having a second job just to keep it from undergoing decay. Trying to keep a build alive for 4+ weeks is hell. In the 1.0 update however all this changed and not for the better. The devs added facilities which are industrial bases players have to build to get access to many of the games vehicles, many of which were previously available for far less effort. Unfortunately the game engine still can't handle building in large amounts so maintenance hell is still in place but with twice as much stuff that needs to be maintained. This just ends up with laggy servers and miserable players trying to keep a base alive so their clan can have more than basic tanks. Facilities could have been a great feature if the game engine could handle building but it can't so maintenance hell continues as the servers desperately try to cull the number of built structures. The devs added a feature their engine STRUGGLES to support as the main feature of the 1.0 update. I can say with absolute certainty not one dev of this game ever built and maintained a base, facility or otherwise, for the duration of a foxhole war.

Oh also it has a lot of griefers / alts (players who buy and account to play on the other team and grief) who don't get banned.

---------- Edit: (March 20th) ----------
The devs have addressed some of the issues listed above. Changing review to positive.
they managed to limit the amount of cheats, so now have my recommendation! :)

Overall a waste of time. The game is often buggy, laggy and crashes. The controls feel clunky. Often when climbing over obstacles you have to try multiple times and be a just the right angle to to get over it. The aiming feels bad. It was fun at first but it gets old fast, especially in the front lines you can be playing for hours and feel like you're not making any progress. If you have a lot of time to kill it might be fun, but if you're in an adult with things to do, I think other games might be a better fit. Most of the time everyone does their own thing and doesn't really work together strategically. This game as potential but I feel it has missed the mark overall. The game is very complex with lots of moving parts and difficult to pick up at first. Overall this game has potential but would have to fix control issues, stability and have a more team centered approach to the game.

This game might have had more potential as a singleplayer title, or even if servers were player-hosted instead. This game is a disaster as a MMO, this comes in part from the way the game is designed to be community driven, which you could be forgiven for thinking would be a great thing. However the end result is the following.
- Enemy Alt accounts on your team destroying or giving supplies to the opposing faction.
- While it is supposed to be a community effort having your "allies" walk in and take ALL the supplies you spent hours making for your regiment gets old quickly.
- The time difference between how long it takes to make items compared to how rapidly they are lost is terrible.
- New players do not tend to stick around for some of the reasons listed here.
- Burnout has and always will be a big factor in this game as you have to pretty much no-life the game before you can even feel like you are actually influencing anything. This is why you will see entire regiments take breaks every other war.

This game has so much potential, but after many hours of playing, I caution you not to waste your time.

 It takes hours to days to weeks (real time) to get anything satisfying done, and there is very little reward for the hours to days long grind that logistics guys and builders are subjected to. You cannot manufactured goods sitting or they will disappear in crazy short times compared to how long it takes to amass resources.

it is insane that they make people do nothing but click a mouse for hours to days on end to produce resources. Making things does not require clicking but often takes hours to days longer. It is boring, unrewarding, and receives the least recognition in the game despite having the most impact on gameplay. Most players won't be bothered so shortages exist almost always.

Fighting is difficult and unsatisfying unless you have equipment you cannot even build yourself in most cases. there is no official organization so logi doesn't get done effectively and you fight on a front with mismatched ammo more often than not. Players are not friendly for the most part and will yell at you before they help you. 

Everyone has an opinion on what should be done, nobody agrees and things fall apart rather quickly. This exists among solos, opposing clans, and within clans themselves. People are petty AF.

You will spend 2 hours grinding or waiting for 15 minutes of thrill.

It is all way too tedious and rewarding this type of game format 

And finally, you will pay money for this game only to find that you can never actually play it how or when you want to because of the stupid balance system. Anywhere that matters will have a queue at any respectable time, and it takes 30 minutes to an hour to get in a hex with fighting in some cases. You can get into other hexes, but you will find that either they are not supplied at all or there are no soldiers there. you get kicked if you sit too long in a vehicle waiting even though you are in a queue. once you are in you cannot get back in easily if you are a logi. resources are often waiting at the border while the soldiers starve on the front. Stupid. 

Bottom line. This game can be a great experience. It has some amazing moments. You are rarely going to experience the best this game has to offer, and ever more rarely will amazing moments happen to you personally. You will essentially just bear witness to large clan achievements where each clan member plays a significant but minuscule part. You shell a base to death, there's got to be a guy who does nothing but pack and unpack ammo which takes forever. You will be packing and unpacking everything you make longer than you will be fighting with it.

Zerg vs. Zerg simulator, except each Zerg has a brain. Chaos combined with small organisational hills, trying to somehow win the game by capturing territory. 

Don't touch built up oil fields, facilities and tanks of other players without permission. A lot of people tryhard and spend hours and hours building those things. As long as you know this as a rule, you'll be fine.
The game will burn you out.

Very deep, steep learning curve but if you have a mic then there are 100s of people willing to help you.

Great game with a huge future.

Don't let the simple graphics or odd choice of going with a top down, isometric pov fool you, this is possibly the most realistic war/military simulation available today... and by that I mean 99% of the game is frustration and boredom.

Imagine sitting in a trench or bunker for 10 or 15 minutes at a time just staring at the empty field between you and your enemy's trenches while nothing happens. Or dying if you so much as pop your head up in sight of the 5 guys doing the same on the other side. Imagine almost never having basic, essential things like ammo or grenades and having to scavenge enemy corpses because their side does have those things. Or spending hours driving a truck around to gather raw materials and then waiting 10 minutes for the queue in the factory to clear so you can finally produce supplies for the front and drive them up.

I think by automating more of the production process and making the setting up of supply chains more engaging, rather than requiring players to spend their time driving back and forth and starting the war with some simple weapons unlocked the game would benefit immensely. As it is now, it's basically just a chore to play.

Played since early 2018 with relatively frequent updates. Very good game.. From things I love to things I hate -
Many comments say the dev team locks themselves away - at least in the personal experience of me and people I talk to, they have been very interactive and their dev streams are frequent. They're open about plans in the game and have decent long-term goals for the health of the game. Updates won't generally happen mid-war (unless it is truly gamebreaking) but thankfully there's no commitment to any given war.
There's a decent variety of roles to fulfill with no real expectations - you won't get locked into a certain playstyle. Combat feels intuitive - generally you don't want to run into a fight by yourself without knowing the area. I would compare gameplay to some older MMOs, there are "grinding" parts that are more of a social experience and there are "active" parts that require a bit more awareness. You can have fun with either depending on your outlook but obviously there's no reason to do things you aren't enjoying. Frontline roles include medical teams, infantry, tank divisions, and mortar teams. Backline roles include resource collection, production, research, and distribution. So in essence... Real war frontline and logistics. No air support (and to my knowledge no plans for it), navy exists but is plain, but land options are plentiful.
The map has a lot of terrain variety that I think works in its favor. Every area feels like a unique fighting experience with different problems to solve. Snow freezes vehicles and people, so you need fires. Mountains block mortars and create more restricted pathways for fights. Open areas are more vulnerable from sneak attacks. Cities have upper floors that people can shoot from. Bridges... act as a vortex for players that don't know better. I am a sucker for dynamic terrain and opportunities to use it to your advantage are plentiful.
Some minor community issues that I think can be ignored but could be a dealbreaker - some groups can be aggressive, especially to newer players, but on the other hand there are many more groups that are welcoming. I would not look at Reddit or 4chan or any other out-of-game group as a metric for what in-game is like. 90% of my interactions have been either positive or neutral-leaning-positive, but that isn't to say I'm a representative of the average.
The two teams are technically balanced though not identical - asymmetrically. There are waves of strength bursts on either side and occasionally it feels like it's just a research race, especially with high value technologies like some of the late game vehicles.  No strong sense of "snowballing" present, though. Colonial weapons and tools are generally cheaper but slightly worse, while Warden weapons are usually stronger but take a lot more resources. This works well for some things but does not account for the relatively even number of players, that will grow and shrink over the day - having fewer weapons is a much bigger issue at larger populations, and having weaker weapons becomes an issue in a small defense. You can always steal from the enemy if fortune permits.. but there are better ways luck as a mechanic could be used. This imbalance also applies to the aforementioned terrain, though I personally feel like the challenges presented there make for a more interesting battle.
Barring actual gameplay and social aspects... At least as of reviewing there are some server issues that I think could be resolved - the game is segmented into hexagons, and travelling between hexagons involves switching servers which creates problems in more populated areas. Some glitches go in your favor, some out of your favor, but I think at least they are predictable enough that there are no surprises after the first time something happens.
I love this game very much and I can recognize why some people have issues - some issues moreso than others - but I would nonetheless recommend the game. Don't go in with wrong expectations, and show some discretion thinking about what you want from video games. You'll know pretty quickly if you don't like it so if you're on the fence you could always buy it and refund it after discovering your feelings. Or you could just not buy it too... I only have $2 on steam and $0 in real life so if I had to choose between buying it right now and not buying it right now well I guess I already made my choice.

The concept of an MMO war with full fledged wartime logistics is a prickly system to create in a game, and they have somehow successfully curated the systems, motivations, and community needed to make an in-depth, rewarding, and generally enjoyable, MMO based logistics and building system integrate perfectly into a game centered around a persistent war. It's wizardry at its most believable.

With that stated, it has one blaring issue: Server Queues...

They are often dodgy at best, and can frequently cause a failure for entire operations that you and your regiment(s) have been preparing for days. Being unable to provide logistics and manpower to a region because it's queued for 2 hours is... frustrating.

This is one of the deepest games I've played.  There's great front-line infantry gunplay (deeper than you'd expect from a top-down shooter), rich vehicle battles, artillery, stealth missions into enemy territory, plus a really interesting backline logistics system that supplies all of this stuff.  It really does achieve the goal of so many open-world MMOs: to motivate players with the organic world of the game itself, rather than arbitrary quests.  I just drove a truck full of materials from Foundry to Blemish not because a questgiver told me to, but because I know my fellow players in Blemish need those materials to craft guns and medical supplies for the front line.  I hear the desperate calls for supplies from the front line, and I know what I'm doing matters.

The social element is incredibly important, there are so many things in the game you can't do solo, working together in small groups is crucial.   Probably the thing I like most is that everybody's equal, no player has more power than anyone else, and the game doesn't reward you for being greedy or selfish.  Everybody is working together toward a common goal.

There have been some serious issues, though.  The release of player-built factories ("facilities") in 1.0 was interesting, but really went against the cooperative spirit of the game, giving players good reasons to hoard resources and lock them away from the public.  The game's most vocal players on social media tend to be jerks, prone to paranoia, witch hunts and crocodile tears and the usual drama you see in any multiplayer game's discord and subreddit.  But my biggest complaint is that the developers don't engage with the community much.  When problems and issues are pointed out, we rarely hear from the developers that they're looking into the problem, or planning a solution, which leads to more infighting and paranoia.

As I write this, the game's Steam review is "Mixed": that mostly reflects a coordinated review-bombing by the player base intended to get the devs' attention about real, serious problems with griefing and hacking in the game.  And eventually, the devs *did* respond, with a new update that improves game security and addresses most of their concerns.  Their response was so thoughtful that it really changed my mind about the future of the game, and I hope other players will change their reviews in light of this.

In short: play this game.

Almost a year ago I got this game, it looked... different, something new. And holy shat it was.  For the massive Pros...
DO YOU LIKE TO BLINDLY FIGHT FOR YOUR COUNTRY, GRAB A RIFLE, A BANDAGE, 2 CLIPS AND CHARGE...
The game is extremely patriotic for whichever faction you choose, you will find each one has its own slurs for the other, Warden's/Fembois/Sticky White Nutty liquid drinkers/Baby Eaters, Colonials/Goblins/Furries and other harmless name calling. Don't take it to heart, as you have a whole faction that backs you into bullying the other side. You will find propaganda is used almost constantly throughout playing which only adds to the immersion.

DIFFERENT PLAYSTYLES! 
Are you a calm and reasonable person? Do you like to Farm and play games like Stardew Valley? 
Or do you like to Drive a truck for hours, back and forth, supplying bases with equipment? Then LOGI is for you!

Are you a fellow scumbag? Do you enjoy destroying things with ease? Do you enjoy hurting the person I described above? Then PARTISAN'S are for YOU!

Are you a simple person, liking things go boom? Do you want to experience the true horror of WW1, as you are shelled for hours by Rockets and Shells? Do you enjoy watching your friends die in front of you, as the poor medic behind you is set on fire?
Then FRONTLINE SOLDIER IS FOR YOU!

Are you a leader? Do you enjoy planning things and bossing others around? Do you enjoy big rolling lumps of metal going against other large lumps of metal? THEN TANK COMMANDER YOU ARE!


For the cons...


When you get this game, first join, there is little to no tutorial, there are youtube videos like HelpingHans who really does help you understand different mechanics, but just like most things in life, you'll learn through mistakes, very costly mistakes.
THE NEW PLAYERS have to understand, that usually the higher ranks consist of 2 people, the toxic veteran, and the helpful veteran. If you meet the toxic one, don't be discouraged, keep playing and you'll have some experiences that you won't forget.
Cheating, is not as much of a problem as other things, but it does exist, through the use of mods players can use different mods or exploits in the game to gain an advantage through different means. The devs are currently working to fix this.
And the big con, you'll find that many vets and other players get annoyed at different things due to balance or the extreme rigour that doing logi is. The devs are always working to maintain balance but the War can always droop to one side as Logi towns and Resource fields are taken over, tech is progressed, and Towns being supplied. The other problem is player count, whenever there is a big update the servers are split into 3 different wars, which effectively splits the playerbase. 


To sum it up, I do recommend getting this game if you have the time to learn it, otherwise wait for a sale. It is truly one of a kind.

I am updating my review after multiple changes were announced, and while I won't go into them here, suffice to say these changes should solve or at least abate most, if not all of the major complaints I'd made in the original review. It will take some time for the community to lose its paranoid toxicity, but I am now generally willing to recommend. [h1]I will be leaving my previous review below, as to better prepare new players as to the community they will be joining for the foreseeable future, and as a reminder of the mountain of negativity the same community had to level at the devs to get ANY response, let alone changes[/h1] Foxhole, where to truly begin? Foxhole is a 24-hour semi-arcadey war-sim, where every grenade thrown, round fired, litre of fuel burned and weapon held was made by the effort of other players. Having played for some time over it's lifespan thus far, Foxhole CAN be a very fun, but a rising epidemic in-game has massively impacted every part of the game, and makes the game hell even when you are trying your best. The problem is unscrupulous players using alternate accounts, "Alts" to sabotage the opposing team without repercussions. The epidemic of Alts has created an environment of paranoia, fear and hostility throughout the community; with much of the hostility towards new players, whom are often mistaken for Alts due to simply lacking the game knowledge to avoid playing poorly and losing materiel. however, the fear of Alts and more general sabotage has resulted in anyone, of any experience level or playtime being targeted for harassment for even the most minor of perceived infractions, failures or mistakes. To make all of this even worse is the lack of ANY communication from the devs, with not even a cookie-cutter "we hear your concerns!" to show they are working on a solution. Some circles in the community believe that the devs inaction is a result of greed, as even known Alt Accounts are rarely, if ever, given a permanent ban; This light punishment is fuel for a conspiratorial fire that argues that the devs are avoiding perma-bans to encourage alt-ing by demonstrating that alt accounts are safe from permanent repercussions. If and When these concerns are addressed, I will update this review; until such a time, however, I have one concise statement to sum up my review: [h1]STEAR CLEAR[/h1]

I keep playing this due to the huge scope. The multiple tasks one can do. The stress of watching the frontline change. And the thrill of being outmatched or helped by players who know how to play better. The game has seen quite a lot of updates which, in general, have increased its complexity, also the challenge, the graphic quality, the fluency of game, remaing extremely fun. Unfortunatelly, as it relies on cooperation, it suffers a lot from people who just play to annoy others. Sometimes in harmless ways, others really abusing the system and ruining the experience. I have seen people who quit the war (or even game) due to abuses from others. Alt playing, sabotaging, stealing of materials or vehicles. If you are not very resilient and willing to deal with setbacks, this is not appropriate for you. If you take a less strict attitude, it is an excellent experience, specially if you play with nice people.

A summery of this game for new players.
Foxhole is a very one of a kind experience, that I have seen no other game do. The amount of different ways that you can play this game and help the team out is awesome, and has a role for any kind of player. You like action, get a gun or tank and go to a front and fight. Do you like chill gaming sessions, grab a truck and harvest some resources, or craft some supplies deliver them to a point of interest. Want to mess with the enemy, get behind enemy lines and try to steal stuff or just cause chaos. 
There are so many more ways to play this game that it will be able to appeal to any kind of person. 

The game isn't perfect though far from it. There are many frustrations, people creating alt accounts to hurt the enemy team while on the enemy team, building being so fickle with how you can build in certain places (if at all), the voip errors making where you can't communicate with people, and many more problems. 

Would I recommend this game. Yes, this game is just too unique and fun, you will not find another game with the same type of game play as this, and while the issues are annoying they are not bad enough for me to say that you shouldn't play this game. Give it a try, play different roles to find what you like, and remember to ask in chat, in game if you have a question or need help.  The community over all is very helpful and kind to new players (usually). 

I hope you find foxhole as fun as I have.
P.S. There is a lot more good things, bad things, and roles you can play that I didn't mention. This game is up and down a lot of the time but truly a one of a kind game.
With every update game becomes better and better then, upthumb from me.

This game has such incredible potential. It's a truly unique and amazing concept with incredible depth and an almost completely player-driven experience.

That said, the developers seem hell-bent on squandering the amazing work they have done so far. 
There is complete and total lack of communication between the developers and the players, with the developers not breaking radio silence until major update announcements. There is a refusal to even acknowledge know issues, and plenty of anecdotal cases of players being banned for reporting bugs under the "no exploiting glitches or bugs" rules.

Lets talk about bans. This game has no anticheat. No. Anticheat. Whatsoever. The only moderation avaliable to the game is the ability to mass-report, which gives a 3 day temp ban. This game is plaugued with griefers, alts (those who use a second account to sabotoge the other team or steal intel), and other bad actors that the community has no way of dealing with effectively.

So you see someone dumping hundreds of hours worth of your teams work into a river, look at their activity and see that destroying friendly vehicles is the only thing they have done this war, check their ban log and see they have been banned every three days for the past four years... and come to the gutting realization that there is nothing you can do.

Don't let the 1.0 label fool you, this game is unfinished. Bugs, clipping, performance, balance, QOL... and none of the issues are even acknowledged by the devteam. DO NOT BUY, not until Siege Camp studios pulls their head from their asses.
------------------------------------------UPDATE----------------------------------------

Update 52 is a good step in the right direction, and addressed a lot of things the community has been concerned about. That said, my review remains negative due to the continued poor communication. It's obvious that the devteam is listening to the community, but they are continuing to refuse even the most basic levels of community managment and interaction.

I can't say I agree with every decision the devs made, but this game is so much fun. I've always wanted a war game with a little more "open-endedness" in the sense of how you can contribute to winning. This game is just that. A massively-multiplayer sandbox war game. Besides the towns and settlements, almost everything is player-made from player-gathered resources. It's one of those games. And it's great. While it is far from perfect, this has easily been my favorite multiplayer game I've played in the last 5 years. Worth every penny.

Look out for the streamers, and honestly the devs are kinda blowing it currently. That being said, still met some of the best people in this game since I started playing and would still recommend to everyone.

*********************

Update - 3/8/23: This game has changed so much since I first started playing, and I don't play it anymore really mainly just due to life. But despite the saltiness that comes with the blind faction loyalism, the blood-from-stone feedback loop the devs have largely operated on over the years, the Foxhole reddit exclusion zone of high schoolers too angry and horny 90% of the time to have civil discourse combined with a very noticiable lack of moderation skill by the dev team--AND--quite frankly, just some really stupid decisions they've made, I still will always recommend everyone try/buy Foxhole for the single most unique gaming experience I've encountered on a multiplayer scale 

To Siege Camp, AKA CLAPFOOT: Look, I like your game, but I strongly disagree with many aspects of how you built the game, and I don't think you guys have always made good decisions regarding it's development. Just because you have made smart decisions for Siege Camp, doesn't mean that translates to smart decisions for Foxhole (and sometimes have a direct inverse relationship.)

All that being said- Thank you Siege Camp. For providing a vehicle in which I had a meaningful 108 days of time spent in your creation and all the great experiences and people I had the privilege of encountering throughout it all.

As much as I hate the way you guys operate, I'm sure if you ever release Anvil, I will be the guy who sighs before unzipping their pants upon booting it up.

P.S. 
Fix the texture gaps on your 7-year-old maps, Matt, like c'mon man. If those were your kids, they'd be in 2nd grade by now.

This game takes some work to get into but is overall worth it. To get the most of out of it I highly recommend a mic and a desire to use it. I also suggest finding a reputable clan. It's also got a learning curve. Most combat is pretty straight forward but digging into the logistics and building mechanics takes some doing. Building especially is full of pitfalls for new players. 

You'll find a community that cares deeply about this game. Often that means you'll find people that are glad to help out or direct you but sometimes you run into people that need to touch grass. Griefers have always been an issue in this game, because of this new players are viewed with suspicion.  However the update just announced at the time of this writing promises to provide the devs with many new moderation tools to help with these issues.

Once you get your feet under you this game is unique and often fantastic. You can choose between a ton of different play styles, all offer opportunities to effect a front and earn the thanks of your fellow soldiers.  That warm feeling is what keeps me going with this game.

I first tried this game back in 2016 and something about it made me buy it 2017, after that I played on and off for few years and by the time of fall 2020, I had only 130 hours. Then I found my place in the foxhole, a group I have spent almost 2000 hours with and learnt/tried most of the things in Foxhole with that group. In these past few years I have seen best and the worst of the foxhole, the community playing part on both. 

In Foxhole you can hop on and hit the frontline to test your skills against all sorts of opponents and use both your factions weapons and those which have been taken from the enemy, or go to backlines to do some logistics and chat about the most random things while scrapping with some people you have never met before. 
Ofc us veterans can be rather short-tempered at times and we can be rather harsh towards new players making a mistake that we have seen few hundred times already. That is on us, but I have been also trying to help wherever I can and try to teach new players that seem to need help. There are some unspoken rules within the community which some have had to learn the hard way. Also the fact that the home island's training courses are obsolete makes the player to player interactions even more important.

Foxhole still has that little something that makes it unique and has kept it's charm over the years. Player driven logistics, true persistent warfare, after the war starts it's goes on 24/7 till either side wins. Game where everyone can find their place in the war machine and help the team with their efforts. 

Now that devs have been teasing us about the future Naval update and have addressed the issues with alting, building, facilities and partly logistics I am looking forward to see what future holds for this game.

Great game, honestly one of my top 5's. The immersion of playing as just one cog in a machine of thousands; working together, communicating, seeing honest-to-goodness supply-chains come together through team spirit, coordinated pushes into enemy bases, tanks rolling over enemy line while supported by infantry and artillery fire, the list goes on. Many real-world World War I and II tactics actually work in this game, and it makes for an experience like no other.
The proximity chat adds another layer of immersion and community that is sorely lacking in today's gaming industry. You'll hear allies calling out enemy positions and emerging threats as the battle evolves, injured soldiers shouting for medics, and machine gunners pleading for ammo as they use their last clip as sparingly as possible. The further away someone is, the quieter they are, so coms are (usually :P ) not too crowded. Another added bonus of the voice chat is that when¬†you start playing and have no idea what you're doing, just ask. There's always someone eager to help out.
As you've probably seen already, every item and vehicle (and many structures) are created by players. There's something special about passing by a¬†factory that's in full swing; cranes loading and unloading cargo ships, raw materials being¬†fed to factories that spit out rifles, bullets, uniforms, diesel, petrol, gas masks, tanks, and¬†a constant flow of trucks bringing the much needed gear to the front line.
Because of this, every battle matters. If your faction fails to defend a factory, then your side looses not just everything that wasn't evacuated in time, but the ability to effectively hold that region without straining surrounding territories. But again,¬†you're just one cog in the machine, so fights manage to feel meaningful without also putting too much pressure on any one player. It can be a hard balance for a developer to achieve, and I think Foxhole's scale helped Siege Camp to nail this. (Not to subtract from their ability/achievement)

Foxhole is a¬†unique game that offers a one-of-a-kind experience, and I could go on for quite some time about all the things I love about it.

Foxhole is a game that provides a unique MMO-style experience; an isometric war game with two factions fighting in a persistent campaign where every item except the pistol and the hammer you spawn with are crafted by other players. From a gameplay perspective it works quite well and can be an extremely entertaining and engaging experience. Where Foxhole really misses the mark, so much so that I generally do not recommend it to anyone I socialize with, is in its community.

Foxhole has well earned its reputation for having a toxic community that attracts many of the less savory members of the greater gaming community, and it has this reputation for one simple reason: Lack of community management by the developers. Either because the developers don't see the issue with it, or don't care to deal with it, extremist and highly toxic individuals were allowed to flourish in the game for quite some time. So much so that highly inappropriate conversations could be witnessed in global chat channels with surprising regularity. Eventually the developer decided to take the Reddit approach to community management and offloaded the responsibility on to the player base - Now with an upvote/downvote system and comms rating for global chat channels (but not voice comms or local chats) every player in the game gets to decide who may and may not speak in these channels. Too many downvotes and your communication rating gets downgraded, and your ability to use global text channels removed. As these channels include Intel and Logistics channels, this means your ability to play the game (and assist other players as well) may be impacted. Furthermore, automated conduct report bans were also created allowing players to temporarily ban players from the game outright. As a result the visibility of the more extremist elements were reduced, but only ones which are on the truly extreme end of social acceptability. In truth, what this means is that only the most extreme forms of racism, discrimination, etc. are vilified and handled by the community, while lesser forms of discrimination, general toxicity, and occasionally even some degree of racism are left to flourish. In other words you can be an ass in Foxhole all you like as long as you don't cross the line, or piss off the wrong clans (if a clan decides they don't like you and their members are willing to report people if told, they have the power to ban you from the game with mass reports.)

What this means in practice is that while Foxhole may be a downright wonderful game experience minus some balance issues and some creative decisions that result in some less-than-fun experiences for some, your social experience will be another story entirely. In an MMO-style game social experience is important if you want to do things other than just shoot at the enemy, which is only one small piece of the game. If you choose to keep voice communications on, and you actually make use of the text chat, you WILL with 100% certainty encounter people who will tell you that the way you play the game is wrong; they will tell you aggressively, loudly, and occasionally even with a teamkill thrown in that they are better than you and that if you don't listen to them you are wrong (despite themselves often not being very good at the game.) You will encounter other players who suffer the same event with regularity. As a player of the game since its earliest days I still encounter individuals of this sort often multiple times per session often trying to harass other players over VOIP, and occasionally even myself. However, because there is no community management of VOIP conduct, and little to no visible moderation of the game done via the developers, this means that the only way to avoid it is to not use VOIP at all and hope that ignoring these individuals doesn't result in them attempting to abuse the aforementioned community regulation systems or outright gunning you down. With regards to the communication upvote/downvote system getting banned from global chat channels can happen even to well-known and respected members of the community, and has in fact happened many times since the introduction of these self-managing community systems.

So while from a gameplay standpoint I find the game to be a unique experience that players of other intricate, collaborative games like EVE Online would quite enjoy, I can't in good conscience actually recommend it for the lack of community management. Especially in today's online world, community management is an extremely important part of any game of this sort and is not a responsibility that should be offloaded onto the game's own community. When the social experience plays an important role in the goings-on of this game and one's ability to extract the most out of it, I also can not separate this issue from the rest of the game and simply say "it's a good game but just turn off the chat and VOIP."

There are a lot of people who will tell you that the community management systems aren't actually that big of a deal and the community isn't "that toxic," that the likelihood of you ever being mass reported and banned is quite low and "most of the people saying that actually deserved it and lying about how they got banned." In some cases they'd be right, however they conveniently leave out the part where it absolutely can and does happen, and they leave out the issues that aren't quite as severe. Is everyone in the game a toxic, racist jerk who will teamkill you and tell you want to do? Absolutely not. Are you going to get regularly communication banned or game banned for just trying to play the game normally? Extremely unlikely. Can it happen? Absolutely. The developers also do offer a way to report abuse of these community management systems, but should people really need to file such reports in the first place? Furthermore, the community in my experiences places little trust in abuse reports, as the issue remains ever present and as of War 83 several high-ranking players have had to adjust their approach to global communication to avoid being given poor communications scores for things as harmless as helping coordinate logistical movements, or providing updates for the faction's technology level.

For those reasons I do not recommend this game to others, and will continue to not recommend it until the developers commit to internal handling of community management, or a hybrid approach with far better handling of the existing mechanisms and better handling of abuses of the system.

As a final note, I want to make it very clear that in my entire time playing Foxhole I have never once been banned, received poor communications, or anything even remotely close to either. I am not an aggrieved party salty about being punished for some misdeed. I'm just a long-time player disappointed with the state of the game and its community at present.

- Addendum: The developers also have had, and continue to have, a very lax approach to handling same-team griefing and people using alternate accounts to grief the enemy team. Again, because the responsibility for these issues was offloaded onto the community some vectors for griefing cannot be investigated or handled appropriately, and methods the developers actually do introduce for mitigating these issues are subpar. While this is especially relevant at the moment of writing this addendum (Dec. 2021) it has been a prevalent issue for years just like the toxicity problems.

- March 8, 2023: Developers continue to utilize community-based moderation despite severe issues with griefing and players running alternate accounts to sabotage the other team. While they have, in response to negative reviews, finally added some automatic countermeasures to make griefing harder, they have continued to eschew adding real moderation systems. The moderation systems in place have continued, leading to rampant witchhunting and in-game toxicity, especially toward new players.

I have 1300 hours in Foxhole. It is one of the best and most unique games I have ever played. Unfortunately, alts (people buying second accounts on the enemy faction to sabotage) and griefers (own teammates sabotaging to troll) are absolutely ruining the game, and this problem is only getting worse. 

1. The developers need to implement active moderation in-game

2. add more tools to catch alts and to mitigate their harm

3. actually start permanently banning players who alt, grief, and constantly break the rules

4. communicate with the community on this issue for more ideas on how to fix it and so that we don't feel unheard and powerless

I cannot recommend this game until these solutions are implemented to mitigate the damage that alts and griefers do. Alts are ruining many people's motivation to play because they can waste so many hours of hard work while doing so much damage in so little time.

In this game there are two factions: The Wardens and the Colonials.
Wardens are defense oriented: Better terrain, heavy armor, and winter gear.
Colonials are offense oriented: Flatter terrain, mass produced tanks, and mud/rain gear.

The Wardens are a mix of EU and US players mostly split between large and medium sided clans.
Colonials are a bit of a mixed bag - US, CN, and Russia as far as I can tell - mostly fragmented into smaller groups.

Wardens are horny weebs. Colonials are furries. Take your pick. You'll die all the same.

ALSO: COMMEND THE LOGI. THEY MAKE SUPPLIES SO YOU CAN WIN AND HAVE FUN.


EDIT as of 2/11/23.
While the core gameplay is still quite fun, remember that all the equipment you use in this game is produced by logistics players. Logistics is often a mix of base building and truck simulator where people run around the backline collecting material to send to the front. The recent facilities update has put a lot of strain on the backline players to the extent that you'd have to no-life the game to maintain anything you build. That kind of commitment requirement isn't sustainable.

EDIT: The game has expanded tremendously over time. I came back after nearly 4 years away and went from knowing everything the game had to offer(a pretty large amount of content) to feeling like a new player with all the new toys and systems that were added.  

The reason i quit has been made more vocal recently, griefing and building decay/inaccessibility being my personal nails in the coffin (seriously i made a thread about it back in 2018!). The next update looks to FINALLY start to address many problems that the game has long had, including both of these, while also adding A LOT of quality of life improvements.

You should absolutely give this game a try. Even with all of its problems there is nothing like it currently.   

Ask questions. There is a lot to learn and it is very satisfying to do so. This game offers so much to teamplayers and there is so much depth to be had.  

More updates are planned including a massive naval update from my understanding. The game is still very much being actively developed.

Not recommended for people who refuse to even try to play cooperatively.

One more positive for me.  The international community in this game is amazing.  The amount of tolerance, especially considering the type of game, is great to see.  Naturally there are still people with hate, but overall it just doesn't matter. it's simply wardens vs colonials (or blue vs green) It's easy to forget that all our languages are just different ways of saying the same things.
                                                   Old outdated review below
TLDR:  This game is well worth the money IF you can make time for it, handle the semi more than occasional griefer, and love a team based war game. 

  I highly recommend you watch a few tutorials as the servers are generally hectic nonstop, and new players asking questions can be missed.

Pros: 

-Sandbox warfare take over all the towns to win
-70v70 (looks like they're aiming higher!)
-Scrap, Build, Fight, Drive, Logistics, Scout, Plan.  If you are a war nut this game has it.
-Extremely Active development
-Very well put together for an Alpha
-Line of Sight
-The map has recently been updated and though confusing at first, It really looks/functions great.
Cons: 

-Griefers (mostly kept in check but can really effect a game without anyone even noticing)
-Clans..They are not all bad but they generallytend to take what they want because they think they are the reason that the game is being won.

-Buggy...As a new player you likely won't notice too many bugs as they are relatively small things but the more you play the more consistant and obvious they become.

-Camera Angle...You will accept it or hate it after getting used to it.  Currently this game requires corner panning (looking at the corner of your screen for maximum view distance)  You better get used to doing it or else you will be dieing and yelling ALOT.

-Ranking System through commends...Easily abused to make your friends a very high rank.  commends are earned while playing the game basically..receive enough from other players and your rank increases.   Though seemingly asthetic, alot of newer players will follow/listen to/send all the group supplies to some of these inexperienced high ranking people for hours.  This can literally cause a game to be lost.

The game requires time if you want to make an impact.   If you have a group/group of friends it will probably be WAYYYY more enjoyable, though solo play you can still be very helpful/effective.

Ultimately this is a team game and you cannot win alone.

You may spend 20 minutes making materials, another 20 minutes turning them into weapons/ammo/respawn supplies and someone might steal your truck holding it all when your back is turned, If you spend your day scrapping/making supplies and watch them all get wasted this can be very discouraging and make you feel like your day has been wasted.

The negatives are enough to drive you mad but when the game is grief-free it is an absolute blast and i could not recommend it more.

Several types of tanks, artillery, naval, defensive, and infantry equipment to choose from. 
Allows the ability to respawn multiple times after a number of seconds if you die. 
Additional features are added regularly.
10/10

I am absolutely thrilled to share my thoughts on the amazing game of Foxhole. As a proud Chinese citizen and devoted gamer, I have to say that Foxhole is one of the most fantastic games I have ever played. It not only delivers a thrilling gameplay experience, but also highlights the Chinese spirit of perseverance and determination.

The struggles of the Warden faction in Foxhole perfectly capture the essence of Chairman Mao's Long March, where our people were able to achieve great victories in the face of seemingly insurmountable obstacles. The game's representation of the Warden faction's efforts to overcome their enemies through cooperation and hard work is a testament to the Chinese spirit and makes me proud to be Chinese.

I commend the creators of Foxhole for their recognition of Chinese culture and history, and for crafting a game that showcases our country's great achievements. It is truly inspiring to see the Warden faction pushing forward with such bravery and unity to achieve their goals, much like our ancestors during the Long March.

Playing Foxhole has not only been an immensely enjoyable experience, but it has also taught me a lot about China's rich history and culture. I urge all gamers to try this game and join me in celebrating the incredible strength and resilience of the Chinese people. Thanks to Foxhole, I feel more connected to my heritage and more proud of my country than ever before. #ChineseExcellence #WardenFaction #LongMarch #ChinesePride #Cooperation #Determination #Foxhole.

Amazing concept. Terrible Execution, with an even worse community behind it.
I thought I would find something I am excited to engage in and feel good to make a meaningful difference for my team. After playing for both sides I cant decide which I hate more. The wastefulness of one side or the snobby and toxic attitude of the other. You are always fighting everyone in this game. The enemy faction, allied regiments, and even high ranking players demanding total compliance with little to no explanation of how or why. Arrogance runs rampant and you have to look out for a knife in the back from "Friendly" clans in your faction. 
Not to mention the seemingly ZERO dev support and utter infuriating game play in regards to movement, inventory management, and base building. Just go play a shooter where your bullets at LEAST go where you are pointing your weapon.

Please consider why there are a lot of people with negative reviews (myself included) that have poured hundreds to thousands of hours into this specific game.

We care about this thing so much but the Devs have not improved or indicated a dedication to the fundamental problems that are causing such a reaction in the communities of Foxhole.

Respect for players is what we are asking. In the form of respect for time in doing game tasks (building and logistics are still in dire need of revision). Respecting players by protecting items that players have poured multiple sessions and hours into creating from simple griefing and protection from alt-account activity alongside stronger action on shutting down cheaters are all in desperate need.

Game balance is its own can of worms that the Developers at Siegecamp -need- to revise. Their central premise is asymmetry at every possible point which has caused a vitriol in player reactions to what is stronger than the alternative at specific components and the wider whole for one team over the other (and which festers anger and hate between groups and causes bad faith communications between sides when discussing game balance).

Foxhole is an amazing game and idea, but the Developers have truly lost their way currently with how they rolled out its Inferno 1.0 release. We truly want to see the game succeed. It is a wonderful setting for stories to be experienced but it is being squandered in how much further it has a vibrant community and eco-system to realise all the systems in place.

If you do buy the game, always ask questions in voice/world chat for assistance from your team. Group up with public players or bring your own and ask how you can help. There will be a 100 ways and you will get to experience a hell of a War simulator (just remember to take breaks).

The game offers an experience unlike any game that is even remotely similar to it in concept. 

Now dear reader, you can find many an in depth review about mechanics and various nuances in the game on other reviews so I will not attempt to retell these things when others have done a far better job that I

So what will I say, well you can see there are some people who are very unhappy with the state of the game. I am hear to encourage you to ignore them. Does the game have issues? yes certainly, many are rather unavoidable given not only the scope of the game but also the fact that it is developed and managed by something like 10 guys. The fact it actually works at all is a massive achievement and is testament to the commitment of the dev team. 

Many feel the game is unbalanced, this is not actually true. we just had a war which lasted 52 days, during which time we had a stalemate of several weeks. The only reason that is possible is because the game is actually well balanced. The Wardens however are dominated by a monopoly of large clans who are generally elitist and strategically unimaginative. They also have a tendency to become very defeatist if things don't go their way, like say a few major advances being held back or even routed. The truth is fellow gamers that the recent review bomb of the game happened at exactly the same time that the Wardens began to lose. This is obviously very sad for the warden players who enjoy the game and continued to play out the end of the war. Props to you guys it was a hard won victory. The issue with the warden string of losses is actually a cultural issue for the big sweaty warden clans. Obviously they are not all like this and even most of the actual players in these clans are pretty reasonable people. The issue is that their culture is dominated by whiny man children who make a lot of noise and spread low moral. 

I've read a few things about the new facilities being and issue with big groups claiming resources and monopolising the access to all the good toys. This is a warden issue, I have never experienced that last more than a single day when a Colonial group attempts this, which they no longer do because we don't tolerate it. several collie clans make public facilities where people can trade resources they collect for the tools they which to use. Furthermore, setting up a small facility is not even hard to do, you must simply have focus production on what you intend to build. When the moment comes when you want to try different things, switch out the buildings you no longer need for the ones you do. It's that simple.

This is a cooperative MMO war sim, play cooperatively

The current state of game balance leaves much to be desired.

To make a long story short, both sides have a distinct doctrine - The Wardens favor armor and specialized tools (and tend to have better armor and worse infantry) while the Colonials are meant to have a strong infantry doctrine but slower and more generalist tanks.

The last three wars have had significant nerfs to Colonial anti-tank infantry equipment while strengthening the warden armor arsenal.  The tech tree (Both sides have a tech tree set from the beginning of each war) has also favored earlier Warden anti-base armor while the Colonials tend to find their anti-tank later and later in the game.

While I'd like to think this is a temporary issue that will be worked out, it getting worse across multiple wars is starting to drive Colonial players to the Warden side, making the issue worse.

Given this is a two-faction game based entirely around PVP, balance issues aren't really something that can be ignored - In it's current state, I can't recommend new players get into it.

03-05-2023 Edit: Given I haven't played the game for months, I can't speak of whether the above problems of game balance have been rectified, but given what I've heard from friends still playing, I don't have any interest in going back to Foxhole for a few reasons.

 - Poor Dev communications with players, and seeming disinterest in what the players actually think of balance changes and features.  

- Little to no testing with rolling out significant changes to both frontline and rearline balance.   

- Questionable development roadmap in general.

In short, whatever the store page may say, you're going to be treated to the Early Access experience of paying for the pleasure of constantly testing new changes in general, with a devteam that's indifferent to your opinion, unless you happen to be an influential streamer.  

I don't want to be overly negative on Foxhole - Conceptually, it's an amazing idea, and I did get a fair bit of enjoyment out of it, I dig the WWI-II setting vibes that are inspired without being straight ripoffs of the real world, but at the end of the day, for something that people pay for, you'd expect the devs to pay more attention to their community - Especially since it's that same community that gives their player-driven game any playability at all.

I really, really, really don't want to give this game a thumbs down, as it is one of my favorite games i've ever played. However, I simply can't give it a thumbs up in its current state. Balance is a big issue in this game, and rather than making an attempt at actually balancing the game the devs instead just swing the balance pendulum back and forth. One side will have a win streak and suddenly the devs will nerf something on the winning side while simultaneously buffing something on the losing side, give more favorable tech to the losing side, give less favorable tech to the winning side, etc. It does happen to both factions, however, devs do generally seem to have bias towards one faction over the other (won't say which).

Quality of life is almost nonexistent in this game, building, logi, and maintaining structures are all tedious. With 1.0 they introduced a plethora of new and very destructive toys, putting further strain on builders and logi. 1.0 also introduced facilities, quite possibly the worst mechanic that has ever been added, it adds a whole new level of grind and tediousness to the game; building and logi were already pretty bad before the update, yet doable. Solos and small groups are discouraged from playing with the new (and old) toys as many are locked behind the aforementioned facilities. People will say "bUtT ITs a TEeM gAMe U haVe 2 woRk 2gEthUr!!!!" yeah, you do, and that is still achieved no matter what you do. You are always contributing even if its indirectly, and also small groups are still groups, we should be able to have access to the cool stuff without the game being a full time job.

I don't want the devs to rework the current system, rather i just want them to add some quality of life changes to make it bearable. On top of all, sometimes big clans will "claim" resource fields and make it hard or impossible to access those resources unless they are kind enough to allow you to access them. You also risk clans mass reporting you because you do something they don't like. Both factions are largely swayed by their respective community groups where all the (mostly major) clans organize, vote, and decide the outcome of the faction. I wouldn't mind those points so much if these clans didn't simply prevent/ make very difficult for non big clans to do their own work.

However, it's not all bad. This is such a unique game that gives an experience like no other (basically Battlfield on steroids). Massive battles with hundreds of people on the same battlefield, tanks of all sizes spearheading attacks, constant artillery shelling creating no man's land or weakening enemy fortifications for easier assaults. There is a role to fit every play style, medics for support, heavy gunner to suppress enemy push, basic rifleman, tank crew member for epic armor combat, partisan for those who would rather sneak behind enemy lines and disrupt logistics, and so many more. This game has so much depth and so much to do it can keep you entertained for hours; with it being as epic or relaxed as you make it.

I have no plan to stop playing this game for good anytime soon because it truly is an amazing concept and amazing game, but until some of these issues are addressed i cannot give this game a thumbs up because they are pretty big issues in my opinion.
The fanbase loves to complain. It's fun with friends and to play when major events are happening.
