I played war 100 from the warden perspective. Also this was my first war as a new player. I am the target audience the devs want in their game. I will add and adjust as time goes on. Firstly I do like the game and I do like that devs keep content flowing in. It just needs to be refined more. Dont let this review stop you from buying the game and finding good people to play it with. Just right now there is a good chance devs will see this review as the foxhole community tries to bring change. So here is my experiences, in various cliff notes. I really just wrote down my thoughts on a word text file as I noticed things playing.


Main complaints
AI are too short of range or ineffective. Even after being overhauled. They are basically a two hit kill for tanks. Even building 30 does not last long. Or only a single ai returns fire instead of all when one is attacked. Terrible...


Bunker decay is wayyy too high for how much materials and time it takes to build them. After a couple weeks people just stop bothering with them. Leaving the backlines defenseless as everything has decayed away. Its impossible to defend when everything withers away rapidly. I saw many adopt a bunker signs in empty fields as people leave the game or move areas. Only for these bunkers to never be supplied by other people because its so time consuming to do so, even for clans. 


Bigger vehicles get blocked by smaller ones. Like a bicycle can stop a tank or a tank cannot push a jeep/truck. Battle tanks can push things so it makes no sense this does not apply to other vehicles. 


ALTs are pretty terrible. I have witnessed them multiple times in my first week scouting out defenses for future coli pushes. Torching down bases in the backlines. Taking tank gunner seats sitting doing nothing. Dumping items out of factories. Driving vehicles into water like partisans. And the list goes on... Its been terrible and I know when a major coli push is going to happen by the sheer amount of alts running around prior. Its a problem on both sides and it needs fixed! Its very easy to tell an alt apart. They typically have no rank or very low. Then they run around doing things like experienced players would do. When otherwise new players stand around confused asking for help. The sea of new negative reviews about ALTs ruining the game is very justified. I watched multiple clans just drop their shovels and walk away from game after being griefed by alts a dozen or so times.

AI also just turn off on the front line during low pop hours. Because not enough people (10) set a spawn zone in a town hall or bunker hosting the AI. Doesnt matter how well you build something when the AI just turns off because low population across the entire map. I spent hours bringing supplies and building up to an area to stop infantry and tanks. Only for it to all be destroyed by a couple dudes with mammoth grenades; since ALL the ai was off from low pop. Wow what a game mechanic... And Im not the only one this broken feature has ruined the game for. I personally know a dozen people who quit playing after all their work gets sidelined/destroyed during low population hours. They wake up the next day thinking their effort meant nothing spending a full day building defenses only for it to be lost from not enough people online in that area to defend. Which shouldn't that be the point of AI? To defend when no one is around even with all its other shortcomings! The warden side loses all its progress in the early mornings. That took days or hours against real players to capture. Im sure the coli players have a similar experience in areas. Seeing all your hours of work just zapped away not from players earning that area. But practically giving it away to whom ever walked in. Is about the biggest punch in  the face this game gives people. And this is a prime reason people quit playing.


Remaining review

The voting system to allow building in towns is just trash. Its a pain to get people to vote just so a town can "unlock" things like standard defenses or the ability to repair seaports. meanwhile a small crew of partisans can come over and satchel anything in a very fortified area within a couple minutes easily. Crippling that town for multiple real days awaiting people to vote! Its trash and unlocking town assets should be a far faster timer overall. Dependent on how long that town was held prior and other towns around it. Because right now only voting seem to make any quick difference and good luck getting votes without clans doing it. 


There is no way to prevent people from stealing your vehicles. There is only a 45 min squad lock that half way works. While some vehicles let people still steal them with a squad lock and others just lock the inventory. It is so painful spending hours either building vehicles or stealing them from the other faction. Just for some fresh spawn with a wrench to grab it walking by because you parked it in your base. This is by far one of the biggest issues in foxhole. Squad lock needs to last "at least" 24 hours and completely lock anyone from tampering with it. While also showing who locked the vehicle to report any grievers. 


Coli advantage of putting out more vehicles for less cost as their manufacturing faction bonus. this is fine I dont dislike it. But the wardens are suppose to have harder hitting vehicles with more armor. Where as on the battle field the only thing that matters is numbers. The wardens with supposed better tanks for higher material costs is not something I could see myself fighting coli tanks. we typically have two to three tanks while the colis have five up to nine. I would be fine with this as balance. Except the warden tanks take about the same amount of hits and repairs as the coli counterparts. Wardens also have less or no additional slots in their tanks for spare bmats. In practice and what players typically bring for the front lines I dont see much difference between the factions in tanks. If anything the coli have far more useful options with either range or bigger guns for less cost. Wardens rarely have any tanks in public storage even in late game. Meanwhile reddit shows us posts of 100s of tanks in coli public use. Its pretty insane of a difference when the warden tanks hardly have an advantage against such numbers. In general I rather all tanks just be a little better against other tanks in specific roles as a counter. When you hit another tank there is no meat behind it. It takes multiple tanks hitting a single tank to make progress. Or the tank simply backtracks and repairs coming back in a couple mins. This lasts for hours... Both sides have an all or nothing balance in this area. In conclusion, warden tanks are line tanks. They need players to form tank lines to be effective. Coli tanks are generally well rounded to either be alone or in a line with the bonuses of cheaper mass production and spare slots for bmats. Which makes defeating their 5,10,20 tank groups very difficult. Its not untypical to see one or three coli tanks just drive up to a town hall or bunker destroying quickly. They can take enough hits from most anti tank to destroy these buildings before dying. 


As other reviews have pointed out. There does seem to be a dev bias at play in the game. Like its not untypical for it to start snowing on wardens when colis attack a nearby hex. At first we all thought "oh cool weather it must be like this across the map" and as others spawn around realizing its not snowing anywhere on the coli side in the north regions. We think ahh that is strange. Then it happens again, again, and again... Then there is wind changes. Devs like to change the wind when certain coli targets in an important fight are damaged. I personally seen wind rotate 360 degrees on a flag within 1 hour in the fight for Iris from Reef. Long term players/spotters never seen wind change so rapidly.


That is what I have written down so far. I will add or remove segments as time moves on.

TLDR: If you value your time, SKIP. This game does not respect your time nor you. Look at my play time. Most of it is spent doing menial things to keep my faction alive, and it's not even fun. Quality of Life is close to none. The balance is horrid, and 1.0 update made it worse. THERE IS NO ANTI-CHEAT OR MODERATOR IN THIS GAME, AND WE SURE DO HAVE A LOT OF CHEATERS. BEST PART? DEVS DONT BELIEVE IN PERMA BAN. 14 DAYS BAN MAX. Devs don't listen to the player base at all in the past couple years, and the community doubt they ever will. This is a dying game, and the devs are killing it so we can buy their new clone game, Anvil. Corporate greed, narcissism, and sheer incompetency.

Do yourself a big favour and DON'T buy this game. NOT EVEN ON SALE. 

With the current state of the game, I highly DO NOT recommend spending 30$ on this piece of garbage game. The update 1.0 that put the game out of Early Access did more harm to the game's balance more than any other previous update. Warden faction is expected to advance while they are a defensive faction. Their weapons are objectively inferior to the Colonial because to an average player (which is the main bulk of this game's pop) Colonial weapons are more intuitive and easier to use. Warden got a lot of gimmicky weapons and tanks, and they aren't even a good gimmick. 

According to the dev's "The Vision", Warden is supposed to be a defensive faction with expensive but more superior gears while Colonial is supposed to be an offensive faction with cheap and replaceable gears. This concept sounds good in theory, and I know there are games that successfully implement this concept (Company of Hero 2 for example), but in practice? They failed horribly. A phenomenal disaster that made worse with 1.0 update. Every single supply or building is made by the player themselves. They have to grind their life to fuel the war machine of this game, and it's an astoundingly boring job. I am a logi man, and I hate its core mechanic. I wouldn't mind if it is neuron stimulating or autopilot approve, but no. You have to hold Left Click for X amount of time. THERE IS NO "TOGGLE LEFT MOUSE HOLD" OR "TOGGLE W KEY" OPTIONS. This may sound like nitpicking, but when the overwhelming majority of the game's logistic and building requires you to hold left click and/or hold W, you would expect these quality of life option to exist, but nope. Have fun holding W for 30 minutes straight sailing from backline to frontline. Hell, it takes forever to pull supply from public stockpile, and the enemy can ruin your base that took 3 hours to build in a matter of minutes via flamethrower or artillery. There is no incentive for players to do any of these works but "we must help the war effort." 

When the other faction can out produce you, you are fighting an uphill battle in every way. Don't believe me? Here's some math on two faction's bread and butter tanks, which need a type of rare and scarce resource:
5 crates of Colonial's Mass Production Tanks = 25 Tanks = 1416 refined materials
5 crates of Warden's Silverhand = 15 Tanks = 1626 refined materials
25 crates of Colonial's Mass Production Tanks = 125 Tanks = 7080 refined materials
25 crates of Warden's Silverhand = 75 Tanks = 8130 refined materials

Have I mentioned devs love to put props like tree randomly in the middle of the road? Or the fact that there are so many stone walls that bleed into the road, which can stop your vehicle on the spot? Oh, how about a Snow mechanic that makes your vehicle freeze while the other faction gets Rain, which only makes you carry less things as infantry? Oh, and Warden faction gets a parka but no raincoat, but your enemy get both! Why? Who knows! 

Oh boy balance. This is the most unbalanced state of the game by far. Warden's best infantry weapons are captured Colonial infantry weapons. If you think I'm overstating, check this game's wiki on "Harpa" and "Bomastone" and you will see a glaring issue. There are a lot of unbalanced stuff going on here, and it is always one sided, until the dev's sledgehammer shift the pendulum, again.

Facility. The worst mechanic introduced to this game. Logistic is already tedious, but facility made it worse. We used to have 3 type of raw resources, but now we have 5 raw resources + 8 new resource type. To summarise Facility, DEVS TRIED TO ADD FACTORIO, BUT THEY TOOK ALL THE FUN AND INTERESTING PART OUT AND LEFT US WITH EVEN MORE GRIND. All of your fun toys are now locked to the facility. Worst part is that you cannot solo building and maintaining a facility without playing this game like it is your 9-5 job with no break or vacation. Even clans on both side detest touching this mechanic, but we have to use it or else we are handicapping ourselves. 

Oh yeah, you cannot store your Upgraded Vehicle, Battle Tank (18hrs to make, and is 3rd most expensive thing) or Super Heavy Tank (48 hours to make, and is 2nd most expensive thing) in your Private Stockpile. Yep. Now you have to park it somewhere and pray that no one steal it (spoiler: they usually succeed). Have fun watching your hard earned vehicles disappeared when you log back on the next day. Every other vehicle in this game you can put it in your private stockpile for safety, but apparently devs are too lazy to code these in.

THERE IS NO ANTI-CHEAT IN THIS GAME, AND NO, VAC IS NOT ENABLED IN GAME. THAT IS A LIE. YOU CAN PUT ANYTHING INTO YOUR MOD FOLDER AND IT WILL GO. DEVS DONT BELIEVE IN PERMA BANNING PEOPLE TOO. AT MAX, YOU WILL HAVE 14 DAYS BAN. THERE ARE MANY CASES OF GRIEFING ACCOUNTS HAVING 10+ VIOLATION LOGS, BUT THEY COME BACK A COUPLE DAYS LATER. THERE IS NO WAY TO VOTE BAN OR KICK THESE CHEATERS ALSO. YOU CAN REPORT THEM, BUT THAT FUNCTION DOES NOTHING. CERTAIN GREEN FACTION'S COALITION HARBOURS MANY CHEATERS IN THEIR CLANS, AND THEY ARE OFFICERS OF THESE CLANS. THEY ENDORSE AND SUPPORT CHEATING. 

Stating the Obvious: Yes, both side cheats, but one side is doing it a lot more and in the open, including major and prominent clans. I mean I don't blame them when there is nothing stopping them. You can shame these people on Reddit all you want, but that won't stop them from continuing their illicit means. Submitting a ticket does nothing. It's an automated response of "We will look into it."

One of my favorite game but at current time i would like people [u]to wait[/u] until buying the game. 
[h1] The Good [/h1]
The game is for now unique in of massive multiplayers, a lot of mechanics involved through multiple types of gameplay & usefulness to the war. The lack of cosmetics is good, everyone looks the same because nobody is here to boost your own ego with non-necessary good looking.
I like how the game looks too. There is a lore which progress (okay it's a bit inconsistent but it's fine now)  and has an integration ingame in a smart way.
The top down view is refreshing and makes the game a bit more tactical and cinematic.
The constant influx of new content from the devs team.
Logistics, well sort of, having to craft stuff is fun, knowing you can win by cutting the enemy logistics is fun oo.
[h1] The Bad [/h1]
If you don't speak english which is the lingua Franca on foxhole currently you will not appreciate a good part of the massive multiplayer and will cause trouble to your surrounding, i cannot tell how many times i did a mistake and someone in the VC alerted me or how many times i could succesfully explain something i was doing. But if you tell someone he's doing a mistakes and he doesn't understand or have its ingame VC off, it's gonna make you angry and you will think he's a spy.
Performances issues: There is definitvely some.
Censoring: The chat is censored and you cannot opt in or out, it sucks, even stupid words like coom is censored, want to do the welcome to the coom zone meme? Thrust a 68mm into your posterior this is a christian server. And this despite this game being crude on a lot aspects with a mature community.
Th
Growing servers issues: Lag spike(i think it's client side but not sure), rubber banding, ghosts, glitched nukes. not everyday but when it happens it will ruins your day.
[h1] The Ugly [/h1]
Years old unfixed bugs, you can't do a gameing sessions without seing some bugs anywhere.
The maps are great and are overall upgraded overtime (slowy) but there is tons of invisible trees, bushes, bushes that are rocks, rocks that are bushes, flying trees, invisible moutains, moutains you can cross through like it's an illusions, holes where you're stuck until someone end your misery (or if you can use the !unstuck command).
At the current state building is qualifiable of psychological torture with the introduction of fire, game balance problems with productions of maintenance for bases you build.
Communications tools are...lacking, there is a VC, you can put map post (with extremely brief words), there is a chat with multiple tabs, well there is in fact 4 chats. There is 4 supported alphabets, western(english), cyrrilic(russian), korean and chinese. And it cause trouble because personally i would like to have a way to communicate about partisans in my logi map to other people which don't read my alphabet.
Devs communications plummeted to a less-than-bare-minimum, there is no community manager anymore, i don't know the reasons but i can guess the community must have badly treated them. 
The community toxicity is a point you might heard a lot about. First there is the outside of the game, Reddit: do not. Then there is the Foxhole Discord Server which you should be careful because recently a good and well known content creator (mainly doing drawings) got doxxed for reasons? And i read devs talking about how they received death threat on a common basis. That said usually regiments/clans don't have such problems from my experience.
And the ingame toxicity where you get yelled at because you did something wrong, and this part is caused a part by me, i don't know how but the game turned me into a toxic vet. That said, i'm overall not a majority and most of people are nice.
Queues and Queues bugs: Queues are here because you cannot overpopulate the ennemy or because servers have hits their generous limits. It's painfull, sadening sometimes because you can't play where you want and with too much of your friends and fellow regiment members but great... when it works fine. Officialy devs never talked about such things as queue bugs and when asked on reddit, the answer is :there is no queue bugs. But when your side is queued, there is 35 people in it and there is 50 people and not queued in front, you know there is a bug.
Too much content directly: The 1.0 update introduced a huge tons of content, i was really into it, until i tried the dev branch, which lasted 2 weeks (extremely short for this amount of content). Where there was obvious issues that despite the community trying to communicate were left ignored and later on the release costed a lot of potential new players to quit. Devs finally reached out with some hot fixes but it was already a bad giveaway and some people already left. And still to this day, half a year after the release, some major issues pointed by the community have still not being considered by the dev team as a problem. It will be fixed by a way or another, but when? that's the irritating part, maybe some qualities of life improvement will never come or in a year. Maybe devs will throw off foxhole to focus into Anvil. I've seen devs stopping serving a game i loved in the past or just abandoned it unbalanced until the community left and then moved out to new projects. And i feel like with the new game they are about to pre-release, it might be the case. Foxhole is there from 2017, only less than 2K players on average at a time playing it.
Grief: Grief wasn't a much thing until recently when its a good way to break a stalemate. take another account, go into the enemy faction, act as a saboteur. Get caught? banned 2 days it's fine and it's not even your main account. Did not? great you have weakened the enemy, done recon, caused moral trouble to the enemy. 
[h1]What i would wish for the game to be worth its 30‚Ç¨[/h1]
Ensuring one account per personn, at least doing some effort towards it.
I want the return of competitive/Skirmish foxhole and alternative modes other than the only one available.
More devs communications.
Less tedious logistical tasks, less soul eating driving, less assembling waiting time, more communication tools.

I'll update in the future

Yup, most of the points raised in the recent negative reviews are valid.

But I've been having a blast with this game.  After having this game in my wishlist for ages I went for it & the amount of time I've put in is obscene.  There's nothing else like this on the market & it caters to so many different playstyles.  If I get bored I just hop to another role & it completely changes my experience, while still working towards the same goal.

Back to the negative reviews.  They're mostly from passionate players that don't have any other avenue to voice their complaints.  Not to say their complaints aren't valid, but situations are rarely as simple as any internet post claims they are.  With a fully playerdriven, collaborative, large scale game like this, you're bound to have a few bad eggs that try to ruin it for the rest of us.  Any measure the devs would implement would likely hurt legitimate players more.

If this game was truly bad, the person leaving a negative review wouldn't require the 3000 hours they put in to realise.  

Pick it up, avoid the drama, expect a tiny bit of griefing & enjoy this phenomenal game.

Great game and concept, shitty dev team and execution. The game is addicting until you get over the honey moon phase and realize how many simple QoL fixes the devs refuse to carry out. Would not recommend until they implement some QoL and balance updates.

As it stands I wouldn't recommend it to new players - it will be fun at first but as soon as you start doing some serious stuff, then some serious problems appear. Even though the problems in other reviews are often very exaggerated, it is often just painful to see a lot of your work being wasted, or see situations when you die and which you nor no one from your Regiment is able to explain as someone has some sort of exploit mod installed. Doesn't happen often but happens.

The anti-cheat system is non-existent and just needs to be implemented. Full stop. Even if the cheats do not exist then at least the players should have some confidence that they are not being cheated.

Alts are a problem - I would solve it with making use of the in-level ranks system so that perhaps the new players don't take the more expensive tanks and drive it alone in the middle of the enemy bunker base. E.g.: you need to be OCdt to enter Super Heavy Tank. Or perhaps you need to advance to level X in doing damage to the vehicles to level your way up to mid or late game tanks. I don't know but the number of times I have seen stuff stolen just because a Corporal can't be bothered to walk and then just drives something very expensive in the line of AT launchers is just too much. Is it an alt or a newbie - no clue, but the number of fire trucks disappearing just before major fires is just ridiculous (event though they were parked in the same spots for weeks).

People are cool and helpful. Of course there is some tribalism, but less so than in many other games, and generally speaking you will always find someone to help you out.

I would wait with buying this game until:
1. At least some re-balancing
2. Introduction of anti-cheat system
3. Solution to alts problem

There were some big updates last year and I think that things need to settle a bit before fighting on the front line will be a bit more enjoyable.

developers not addressing glaring issues such as:

I believe that after exactly 25 months after purchasing the game and almost 3,200 hours played, the time has come to say Enough.This game has eaten its tail. Developers focused on new military equipment and new mechanics, which were probably intended to attract players in practice, however, they became cumbersome and led to the need for even more grind, ignoring the fundamental problems. 
Developers have no ideas on how to solve the fundamental problems with server queues. This is important because the game is divided into about 30-40 contiguous regions, with battles taking place in a maximum of 6-7 of them at the same time. And each region has its own small pool of slots. On the one hand, the developers expect players to cooperate what's more they encourage it during developer streams. However, on the other hand, they do nothing about the problem of overcrowded servers, maintaining an opaque queuing system, priorities, unexpected reduction of server bandwidth, which often leads to a situation where in order to join a region that is at the front, you have to wait even more than an hour at the border. This applies to both ordinary gray soldiers and logisticians who carry the necessary equipment to the front lines, as well as special forces who carry out a massive raid on the enemy's rear, which must move quickly and unexpectedly to avoid detection. So what if the landing barges reach their destination, if the ships with equipment are stuck at the border of the regions waiting for a turn and are intercepted by enemy units while waiting? What about the fact that a coordinated action of 50 or 100 players, which they prepared sometimes for several days, will be deprived of any chance of success. After all, the game instead introduced another type of tank, the production of which will take several man-hours, which in no way can be effectively protected from thieves from their own faction, who very often are actually players of the opposite faction who bought themselves a second account just to sabotage their opponent. I have had enough.

This game was a great deal of fun in alpha 

- minimal grind logistics driven by communication and collaboration (If anyone remembers Quarter Masters, instant refining)
- player-driven technology system (offered factions a strategic choice between teching weapons, equipment or armor)
- cross-faction voice chat (for some people it was half the fun)
- fast-paced, decisive combat (with cheaper equipment, people weren't scared to charge into battle with tanks or high-tier weaponry)
- balanced factions & maps (differences were cosmetic)

Since alpha, its been a slow and steady downhill. Even though many new and amazing features were added, previously thought impossible, and at times the game felt like it improved a lot, every iteration ended being an overall downgrade in terms of fun. The larger the game world got and the more features were added, the more time each war sucked out of your life, to the point that unless you are a time millionare don't expect to actually get anything done in foxhole. 

Sure, you can still experience the same amazing moments in foxhole as you could back in the alpha days, as well as many new things that were the result of the recent updates, but these short periods of having actual fun are now so far in between the moments of grind, waiting and general boredom that its hardly worth your time. 

I have this formula to summarize the problem:

Rate of Fun = Total Fun / Time investment

While each update added to how much fun you could have playing foxhole, the time investment required to have said fun has been increasing way much more. This has gotten so bad with the recent updates that many players including myself have had the final straw and decided to quit and also drop a bad review on the way out.

I've been dreaming of the day trains would be added to logistics. Sure you can now drive a trainload of supplies and munitions to the front, if you happen to have a couple days to spare to first mine and build everything needed to drive and supply said train, and that's with a clan, of course. Sure, you can drive epic armored vehicles (flame tanks, multi-turret heavy tanks, landships) into battle, if you have say a week to spare to build up to the point you can produce/upgrade them, and then maybe have a little bit of fun before you lose your tank to something stupid like rng, noobs/alts, or realize that the game is so poorly balanced that most types of armor are total garbage. 

And don't get me started on the faction asymmetry. Unlike in most asymmetric games where thousands of games are played for designers to find right balance between the factions, foxhole's developers test out their ideas for asymmetry precisely 0 times, hoping to simply guess the balance right. Since the developers do not play their game very often and don't really understand how valuable range, hp, damage, cost, speed or ammo capacity is, they have no chance of getting it right. Often I will see imbalanced items where one side has a range advantage or damage while the other has extra speed or ammo capacity (range being the single most important aspect in most situations, being difficult to compensate with any other buff). The end result is that each side has equipment and vehicles where the other side has a flat out better option which makes everyone unhappy. And since the asymmetry currently favors one side towards the endgame, the outcome of each war is decided in advance.

Finally, there is the problem with alt accounts, cheaters and population swings. Foxhole was built on the idea that no one man should be able to single-handedly decide the fate of the war. But with how much grind is required to build certain things, should those certain things fall into the wrong hands weeks worth of effort could be lost. Entire clan facilities go up in flames, or whole regions lost because of the work of one alt. If you are working to sabotage your team you can have a massive impact on the war. Another major problem is, certain times of the day/week will see more players for one faction then the other. This is primarily the result of discordification / twitch effect / national clans resulting in times where it can be extremely unfun to play the game. Players on one side facing massive queues preventing players from joining a front while players on the other side is getting stomped on all fronts by sheer numbers. I'm not sure what's the solution to this problem, but it needs to be addressed somehow.

If I can have one advice for the developers, I would say it would be best to take a step back and re-evaluate everything. The technology behind foxhole is amazing, but the actual game is (now) terrible. I wouldn't mind paying again for foxhole 2.0 with the exact same technology but better design. Maybe a new map and different factions without asymmetry or carefully tested asymmetry (you could easily find many volunteers among the community). Regions could be smaller but built with more care. This would reduce lag, improve combat and make logi less of a grind. Wars could be designed to be shorter too. People need to experience victory more often, not less, and nobody likes waiting weeks to unlock something they really want to build.

That's All

This game is one of a kind and if you're looking for an mmo war game to sink an unhealthy amount of hours into then you've come to the right place.

Very unique MMO war game that I think some people get way too emotionally invested in because that's what it calls for to "win" at times. I don't really see the imbalances some others say are at play here, there is some asymmetry to the factions but from what I can tell there are pretty clear strengths and weaknesses that can be exploited for each side. In my view, it comes down to getting others healthily invested in the results and, if the review bombing is any indication, that's no small feat.

I will say that I think the Logi and Building roles do need some love. I'm not into Factorio or base building games typically but the time it takes to farm resources and get supplies to the frontlines is frankly cripplingly boring. I'm not sure if it's a matter of better understanding the mechanics at play here or needing to coordinate better, but that seems to be a general consensus of the community and something as important as supply lines and town maintenance for a faction need to feel more rewarding than they are in my opinion.

Fun game, you can easily get quite invested in whatever role you get into. 

Logistics seems to be the most rewarding. Collecting scrap for the refinery, making resources, using that to make supplies / weapons / ammo, delivering to the front lines by truck / boat. This will get you commendations fast!

However doing general combat or being a medic saving / healing people for hours on the front line you'll be lucky to get a single commendation, as people have to go out their way to click commend on you. 

Would be nice if the developers make improvements; 
- To general controls and make it feel less 'clunky'.
- Improve the shooting mechanics / line of sight camera controls.
- Improve server performance queuing into regions (takes 20+ minutes at peak times to get into regions, then suddenly 'Connection to server timed out'). 
- Please do more to encourage / stop the players who don't seem to want to play as a team in a team orientated war (locking vehicles / stealing vehicles, team killing etc).
- Make a more user friendly tutorial / introduction for new players rather than dump them on a island with signs to read.

I have enjoyed some time playing Foxhole, however there do seem to be some glaring issues the devs need to focus on to help propagate a healthy life of the game. At less than 100 hours I'm probably not too qualified to go into specifics. However I think I can speak from an important viewpoint of a relatively new player who also is willing to look at the problem from both sides (player vs. devs).

Community communication and interaction is essential. Both players and devs need to be up front and honest, but also civil and kind. It's clear a lot of the community wants to like the unique game mechanics offered, so it's important to work WITH the devs instead of BLAME them. This is of course means the devs need to work with their community as well, providing many outlets for communication and acknowledging problems which have been vocalized.

I do have a personal complaint regarding the maintenance of buildings/fortifications. If you want players to be excited about playing with complicated bases and logistic systems that are both massive time + team sinks, there has to be a more reliable system to engage with. I love logistics in games, but I just can't get into it in Foxhole. When I think of Factorio, Satisfactory, Dyson Sphere Program, Mindustry or many others, those games have great positive feedback loops. I'm not asking for more complexity, but I would love to work toward a better balance of complexity versus practicality. As it is, hours and hours of work offers very little to feel great about, and it can be lost SO easily.

For context:
This game is sectioned by wars, as of writing this we are at war 100, wars can last from a week to a month and a half and I joined in at war 74. I joined the side of the Wardens. I enjoyed the prospect of fighting off the invaders at my homeland, hoping to repel the green-men back to where they came from. This was my experience back then, but hearing from my fellow Warden comrades, the Colonial side was favored by the developers; this was something I could not fathom. "Developers picking a favorite? Yeah makes sense"...... "The developers cause things in the game to turn the tide for a win on the enemy side?! What?" Is what I thought when I was informed this by many, many people, and now I come to believe this. Here are examples:

Example 1: In war 100: we captured Ferimor (A key subregion) and maybe an hour after we captured it, the game started to snow (which is a weather effect and can cause negative aspects like frozen vehicles and freezing to death). "Yay!" I thought, thinking I can finally have some time to build up a base until the snow subsides, but one issue. The snow was only in the city of Ferimor, and snowing on the side of The Wardens. The snow was NOT ontop of the Colonials which were right outside of Ferimor, causing us to become weakened, and after a few days of battke, we lost Ferimor. Then, a couple MINUTES AFTER Ferimor was recaptured by the Colonials... The snow all of a sudden just stopped.

Example 2:Two weeks after Ferimor was lost, a surge of brand new Russian players entered the game, and due to their lack of experience, inadvertently caused the mass loss of ground for the Warden cause. TO STATE: There is no problem what-so-ever with new players, but the fact that little of them spoke English or even had Voice Chat enabled, made it incredibly hard to teach the do's and dont's. So, we were pushed back to "The Linn of Mercy" region, which consistent battle for the important Logistics town "Ulster Falls" took place, with Colonials and Wardens alike switching ownership. After Wardens Ulster for quite some time, we were able to unlock the Seaport (unlimited supply of storage) and just a few hours after this building was unlocked, it started to snow just like in Ferimor. The Colonials pushed through and captured Ulster Falls, and again... JUST LIKE THAT... The snow stopped.

Example 3: During the defense of Ferimor, a ""Server reset" was established, just as we began to heavily fortify Ferimor. It worked as 1.You get disconnected with a message that your spot in the server will be saved | 2.DC happens and you must wait an unallocated amount of time for the "Reconnect to server" button to be highlighted | 3. You must wait five REAL minutes after reconnecting in order to play again. The Hexes are all independent servers, and just the Region which Ferimor is located at had this "issue" and servers have a max population, so when half of the Wardens (and I also assume Colonials) got disconnected, people from other Regions walked in, and the people whom got forcefully disconnected were unable to hop back in due to mass queue times.

Example 4: The developers update weaponry overtime, and give both sides different variations with different accuracy, damage, and others. The 94.5MM Anti-Tank gun was added to the game. The Wardens received a 94.5MM emplaced, non-movable anti-tank weapon, whereas the Colonials received the same exact caliber, but in a push gun variant which can also hide in plain daylight in the snow. Artillery is also a thing, and the most powerful movable artillery is the 150MM artillery guns which have a set max range. The wardens max range: 300M, the Colonials max range 350M, meaning there is no possible way of counter artillery.

To conclude, there is an obvious favoritism for one side in the game, which i have no problem with. Everyone has a favorite child, but when you intentionally cheat by using developer commands, give one side much better equipment, and play around not IP banning alternate accounts, it shows little to no care for the community. I am not calling for a "Death to all Colonials", If anything, I would wish for the makers of the game to allow their "Persistent War Game" stay "Persistent" instead of playing ArmA 3 Zeus and controlling what happens on the battlefield.

Great idea of a game, that suffers from lack of competition. Fantastical semi-oper world with persistent warfare, without any individuality for a player - everyone is just a cog in a war machine, but implementation varies from a system to a system - from good to absolutely braindeadly bad, community can be both great and bad, but I haven't got any problems, and it's really fun and engaging in organized group of nearly any size for most of the activities, it runs well on nearly any hardware. 
But developers are probably the least communicative I've ever seen for a videogame, and that is on top of existing problems: most major are alts and griefers, that ruin enjoyment for everyone without any permanent repercussions, but we also have occasional stability issues, that led to extremely quick population loss after release of 1.0 version, holes in the maps, outright bad working mechanics, like getting out of rough terrain, balancing issues. Also, feedback is generally ignored, even when they introduce questionable and huge design decisions.
Overall, it's not a bad game, but right now (update 51) it's extremely hard to recommend due to long-existing problems, that developers do not solve nor even address.

I used to have a positive review of this game.  The developers communicated with their community, they gave biweekly dev streams, and any problems we would have with the game would eventually be fixed.

However near the end of early access these positives became rarer, dev's communicated with us less, problems started to escalate more and more, and our feedback was starting to feel more ignored.

I decided to give the dev's until their full release out of early access before giving my new opinion, because I still had faith that the dev's would eventually return to how great they were in the past.  But the inferno update (1.0 full release) finally arrived and not only were the mass of problems still around, the update broke the game in several different ways.

Issue's that we have had for the longest time have been ignored, and the player base is outright sick of it.  The game is currently plagued with cheaters that buy new accounts just to sabotage the other team by making the public new player experience miserable.  The game is littered with bugs and lacks any form of quality of life while having the most grindy mechanics that don't respect players time in the slightest.

Understand, that as a new player you will more than likely have a great time playing, but it will be all dependant on other players throwing hours and hours of their life away working with the games horrendously grindy mechanics just to give you that experience, while also having to constantly deal with these cheating players who sabotage all of their generousity just to either troll or help their "real team" win.

Maybe someday this game will be great again, there is a large amount of potential, but the dev's need to actually start listening to the playerbase again.  We don't want new content, we want the content that exists to not feel like torture.  We want quality of life and ways to protect ourselves from griefing.  And we want the game to not feel like playing 12+ hours a day is a requirement to get anything done.

Until then, give this game some time before joining in, show the dev's that several new players would rather wait at the gate for quality than rush in immediately.  Maybe your restraint to try this game out could be the incentive for the dev's to finally fix the problems the game faces.  We want your experience to be as great as ours was, but we can't promise you'll have that experience if you join now.

Unfortunately I would not recommend the game in its current state; Siege Camp does not seem interested in fixing actual issues with the game like griefers/alts, unstable servers and voice chat, bugs, hacks, poor balance, and unnecessary grind and systems that encourage burnout
The game still has a lot of potential and is fun for awhile but I would advise waiting for it to improve before jumping in

This is not to say the game doesn't have issues, but I have yet to find any. Good game and even better ptsd simulator

Been playing foxhole since 2018, since then the devs have released insane content that they once said would never be added.

The devs have been a little quiet since the inferno release which has been becoming normal in the past years, though I don't mind it as the updates have become increasingly more filled with content, balances, and bug fixes. One thing this community sadly forgets though is that every war is a playtest and we are always bound to encounter some retarded bugs that do eventually get fixed. 

We complained back in 2019 about logistics so they added flatbeds, containers, freighters, and cranes. We continued to complain about logistics and every year they add more shit like changing the GSUPPs and shirts to their own queue in the factory and creating a MPF (Mass Production Factory). Recently they made one of the biggest updates yet by releasing player built facilties which took a load off of logi as it allowed coordinated groups to mass produce ammo, petrol, tank variants and other shite. 

In the update they also added trains which allows us to move insane amounts of resources, tanks, weapons and logistics over long distances with ease. At first there was no way to manage the tracks but once we complained they fixed the entire problem by adding cabooses.

(I'm not saying logistics is perfect but they've done a lot to make it way easier then it was before.)

Fire mechanics got added which was fucking awesome but also incredibly overpowered and annoying to deal with, they rewrote the entire fire mechanics system in a month to balance it out for us.

Foxhole is usually quite fun, you can take up tons of different roles from ferrying logistics to keep the front alive to sneakily  partisanning the enemy logistics to choke their own fronts, the only true big problem is alting which right now the entire community is focused on alerting the devs about so hopefully they will fix it, the devs DO listen to us you just need to be fucking patient.

I'd recommend foxhole, it's fun but do remember that teamwork gets the job done your not gonna be able to supply an entire front or build an entire mega facility by yourself consider joining a regiment or getting some mates to join you and work together :)

I had so much fun with this game, but the multitude of issues affecting it have become too much to bear to the point i haven't touched it in months. Clans are horrible and toxic. Alts and other forms of cheating is rampant, balance is non-existent ‚Äî Same old stuff you've been reading in other negative reviews. What a shame.

TL;DR Great Game for casual play(once in a blue moon), but if you expect to play more than once a week, go find something else to do instead.

The Current 'biggest' problem is ALTS/GRIEFERS, despite being such a disproportionately small fraction of the community, the impact they have is massive. What they "DO" is not nearly as bad as the paranoia that their actions cause down the line. Have I even run into an ALT? I don't honestly know, but I definitely feel like they have affected every front I've fought on for more than an hour.
And that's the true problem with them... There is no acceptance of the enemy doing something cool/interesting/badass anymore. I don't see the enemy using one of our vehicles and wonder "How long did it take to steal that", or "Did they gas our guys out of that earlier?" No, the first thought is, "Fething ALTS."
It wouldn't take me an hour to find someone grumbling about ALTS in local chat. Be it actual alts, or Griefers that love the attention, it really doesn't matter, ALT is the only slur used. You can try to ignore it, but eventually you'll find yourself agreeing that such and such definitely happened because of an ALT.

What might the Developers have to say about this? Well..... SILENCE....

Why don't the players self moderate? With what tools? THERE ARE SCREENSHOTS ON THE REDDIT OF PEOPLE WITH HUNDREDS OF TEMP BANS, who have hopped back on after the slap on the wrist of an hour long ban.

And Self-moderation has other problems as-well. Cyber-bullying is not an uncommon occurrence. "Big" streamers treat randoms like absolute garbage, and false report them for not following their egotistical demands. Clans fight over limited faction resources, leading to relatively common Civil Wars.

And yet, this game nearly kept me forever, because it is exciting being the only remaining medic in the midst of a push. Being the one that forces a breakthrough by will and revolver alone. Being the partisan squad running in a Silverhand, shouting 'Death before Dismount' as you duel one of the enemy tanks hunting for you, running out of fuel on the return trip and having to sneak back to your own lines to grab fuel... This game breeds stories like this, ask anyone with more than a few hours, and they will tell you 'About that time that I/We/They----"

All anyone wants is for this game to get better, for the developers to show that they also love their own game as much as we do. And if they don't, well, I wish them luck regaining any of the players they've abandoned when their next game enters Early Access.

The game is really fun. Unfortunately, there's a lot of griefers and people who use alt accounts. With that said, the community as a whole is very helpful to beginners, and during my playtime I've met a lot of friendly people.

First thing, I participated in a single war, and I had great fun.
The game itself is a bit shaky but generally fun if you're not a min-maxxer or a sweat. And here is the problem.

The community is one of the most vile, toxic, unhinged, unbearable and unpleasant I ever seen. To be honest, there are a lot of memes about League of Legends having a terrible community, but Foxhole's one, phew... It's not literally everyone, I have met players that were absolute joys to cooperate with, very new players friendly, playing effectively yet not being sweats. But they are a minority.
A quarter of the players do not communicate and do not listen (ironic for a game where communication is very important). Another quarter are egoistical and egocentric. They are better than you, you have to follow their orders, and if you disagree with them they will ask their clan to mass report you. Another quarter are just toxic.
Griefing is also an overly present problem. Someone doesn't like your bunker? Fuck you, it'll get blown up. Someone wants to get the machine gun? Here, a bullet to the back of the head so you can drop it. 
Large clans are just like megacorporations. You and your friends made a facility around a field of scrap? Fuck you it should be ours, get mass reported. You need some petrol to refuel your logistic truck? Pfah, you peasant, just refill it with diesel (petrol is high tier fuel, diesel is low tier fuel).
And lastly, people from the other team will get another account on the opposite team with the sole goal of griefing, and that's devastating when a wall mysteriously blows up just before a major assault.

I like the game, it's nice, it can be better but the game itself would have a recommend. However, the community, with strictly no sign of moderation in my 60 hours, is a HUGE turnoff. I really want to launch the game again but the simple idea of having to fight against teammates more than against enemies tires me

First off, let me say that I have never played a game like foxhole, I love the game and while I do not have that many hours in it I have sunk many more than my playtime into learning about the world and experience of foxhole and I managed to get a couple of my friends to play it and we have shared experiences going tanking and battling together.

However, I cannot recommend this game to people, even on sale, because as much as I want to do things as run an artillery operation for a few hours I cannot ignore the problems present within the game. For starters the devs do not communicate. At all. They might occasionally pop up when excited for a new update but outside of that they are silent and do not listen to the concerns of the community in the slightest, one example of this was the L.O.G.I strike where a large portion of the player base either stopped playing or played different aspects of the game to try and get the devs to introduce quality of life features for logistics players. First off what other game can have a portion of its player base strike in order to get the devs attention! but also the fact that they had to do this is astonishing and shows the devs lack of communication. Especially considering it took multiple wars for the devs to even acknowledge the strikes existence (not aware of the exact time frame but it was around a month from memory). The devs still to this day don't listen or acknowledge the community at all and it shows. There are other concerns from the community such as ALT accounts which can ruin the joy of the game and while I do agree that alt accounts are a big problem I haven't seen any and so am not the person to talk about it.
What I can talk about is their recent update which launched foxhole out of early access. Inferno introduced many exciting features, many of which were absurdly unbalanced but thats a different discussion, the one I want to have is that it basically stopped me and my small friend group from being able to play the game properly. With the recent update the game has introduced facilities and many features are now locked behind them, the problem is that facilities require a huge amount of effort to maintain and effectively locks me and my friends from a massive amount of content. During our last tanking run we noticed a captured mortar tank, My friends immediately went "that looks fun" and I began laying down what i would need to make one, I should also say that logistics is so tiresome that in these operations I will do all of the work of making everything and driving it to the front letting them log on just to experience the actual joy of using the tank or whatever, then I realised that this mortar tank which had been in the game for years was now locked behind facilities meaning unless I spent a good amount of time looking around for a public facility that would let me make this tank we couldn't do it. This is applied to many things including things such as rocket artillery and many variants of tanks such as the mortar tank that would have been fun to mess around with.

With recent events in the community and the pushing out of an artist who reminded me of the joy of playing foxhole and helped me get the motivation to organise our operations and just how split and scummy the out of game community can be I have finally decided to post this and stop playing until the devs finally fix their game. I have to say I don't think they will. If you made it to this point congratulations, just know that I will miss this game and the memories it has brought but I cannot bring myself to keep playing this game.

Oh boy, where do I even begin with Foxhole? This game is like a never-ending rollercoaster ride, with moments of pure adrenaline and moments of pure frustration. But hey, isn't that what we all love about gaming?

First of all, let's talk about the train. Now, I've ridden some trains in my life, but nothing quite like this one. It's like a party on wheels, with players hopping on and off, shooting at enemies, and just generally causing chaos. But don't get too attached to it, because as soon as the enemy team realizes what's going on, that train is going to be a flaming wreck.

Speaking of flames, let's talk about the flamethrower. This thing is like a giant BBQ on your back, except instead of burgers and hot dogs, you're cooking up enemy soldiers. There's something deeply satisfying about watching your enemies scream and run around while they're on fire, and the flamethrower is the perfect tool for the job.

But let's not forget the real star of the show: the foxhole itself. This game is all about digging in, building up your defenses, and holding out against enemy attacks. And trust me, there's nothing more satisfying than hunkering down in your foxhole and mowing down wave after wave of enemy soldiers.

Overall, Foxhole is a wild and crazy ride that will have you laughing, screaming, and maybe even crying a little bit. But if you're looking for a game that will keep you on the edge of your seat and constantly surprise you, this is definitely one to check out. Just be prepared for a lot of trains and a lot of flames.

Foxhole is a fantastic game [i]concept[/i] that could pioneer a new genre, entirely held back by: nonsensical or broken mechanics that never get fixed, la la land devs that pay no attention to feedback, and irrational balance changes. And worst of all, a crippling alt problem where players buy second accounts, join the enemy team to grief it, and deal far more damage than any honest player can make up for in that time. A problem which the devs refuse to address or even punish with a permanent ban. Foxhole is an absolute travesty of what it could be.

Conceptually one of the best MMOs out there that focus on the sort of WWI/Inter war/WWII setting type of warfare. However the execution by the developers is abysmal.  Often MMOs are grindy, but be prepared to except an intensive grind experiance for certain "roles" that borderline feel like a second job with the investment requirements.

The Good-
1.Not very demanding graphically or performance system wise. Probably can decent on lower end PCs but wont on absolute potatoes.
2.In-game community interactions. Fairly easy to join a group.
3.Fun and semi realistic moment to moment gameplay.

The Bad-
1.Poor community moderation tools that are open to be abused
2.Little to no developer interactions towards the community on important issues 
3.Poor game balancing decisions from the devs 
4.Overly factionalist community. Dont expect common consensus on many balance talks
5.Requires extremely high amounts of time committed if playing solo
6.Bugs glitches and exploits galore

The Ugly-
1.Mundane tedious and overly grindy mechanics
2.Extremely bad moderation for alts, griefers and hackers by the developers
3.Overly luck based mechanics. RNG is virtually present in all aspects of the game

Nearly 2,500 hours in game (that's like playing 15 weeks 24 hours a day), have played off and on since 2017. Never left a review as the game never needed one. It needs one now. If you are on the fence because of negative reviews, look at the amount of hours the people leaving negative reviews have played. I bet Foxhole is one of the longest played games in the negative reviewers profiles, yet they still leave a negative review because they feel the Dev's do not immediately respond to their concerns. That should be enough for you to make a decision if the game is worth $30 or less. What other game can you play for that long, and your only real gripe is that the Dev's haven't addressed some outstanding quality of life fixes.

Granted the Dev's are not very responsive, and I personally do not like some of the newer features, but nothing is game breaking. Very playable and you will get hundreds and thousands of hours of entertainment from this game for the low price of $30 or less.
If you REALLY ever wanted to play as a cog in the machine of a 4X game, this game is for YOU!

Foxhole is a rough jewel, a unique and interesting game concept with complex mechanics where a player will find they can do nearly everything in this sandbox military game. From logistics to combat, stopping by to transport and build defensive structures to support your faction assets, you can find a lot of different kind of gameplay.

In this game a player is but one cog in the great war machine, for better, or worse.

And after having played for few years, in the current state I can only say it is for worse.
The game albeit interesting in its asymmetric warfare system, suffer great imbalance from one update to another, for one faction to another. It has always been the case so far, but it became an even worse issue when the content added brought so much length to each war and grindiness in the game.

It sorely lacks quality of life tools, and when the grind is so bad, - even worse since the addition in 1.0, the game become painful. Player base tire and population vary so much in a single war due to burnouts that it worsens the imbalance.
Hours and hours of work can literally burn in mere minutes, you won't even get the rewarding feeling that "it held well even it fell" because... well no one was there to defend, and the IA defences can't do much against PVE. There is nothing rewarding in that.

Developer do not moderate (or there is so very few things done that it make no difference). There is no anti cheat, no actions against abuse. There is no proper voice moderation nor text chat regulation. Nothing against bots, nor against alting, and griefing is only punished by "player justice", whether it is justified or not.

I sincerelly hope that the game evolve in a better direction and that I can change this review to something more positive.

On the other side of the coin, they seem more interested in adding new items, vehicles and structures. Revisiting this review with the current state of the game, leaving old review intact (update under the line):

There's a lot to like about the game, but also a lot to hate.
To a new buyer, I'll lay it out simple:
Playing the game solo is unlikely to be satisfying. The game centers around a persistent war (24/7) where vast imbalances in population per side and per region are actively exploited to overrun one side or the other. You are entirely dependent on what the rest of your team has done in the last few hours, as well as the number of players currently present, to stand a chance.

For someone who doesn't care, or likes being roped into big clan ops or plays with friends: You will catch a lot of flak for playing badly, but many clans are happy to take you in and teach you.

In general, there are a ridiculous amount of weird mechanics and clunky UI actions that nobody can really walk you through. As someone who enjoyed the logistics aspect of the game immensely, there are just too many grindy, buggy, needlessly complex mechanics involved in getting your stuff to the frontline. Scrapping is entirely unrewarding and unrewarded. The existence of seaports and depots is not explained ANYWHERE to new players, despite being the beating heart of backline logistics and bulk manufacturing. This leads to every new player making their own truck and then abandoning it 20 meters from a place where it could be safely stored instead of being stolen by partisans. The seaport UI is confusing, loses track of the container you're filling, the "anti-griefing" delays on pulling from public stockpiles serve solely to grief the well-intentioned solo public logi player, seaport 'pad' capacity is griefable, limited and often very stressful for new players accidentally blocking the entire seaport because they can't figure out what to do. Sailing a freighter is quite simple, but the drowning mechanic isn't explained anywhere. Disconnecting when switching regions is a very common occurrence sadly, and combined with the """"fun""""" winter mechanics, routinely leads to freighters freezing over at the border (because the driver reconnected at a town 5-10 minutes walk away, the freighter froze over already) with no way to defrost them, losing you up to 15 or 25 tanks, or hundreds of crates of supplies.

The amount of people playing to actively grief the other team is staggering and entirely ignored by the devs. They'd rather you buy the game, play your 2 hours and be unable to refund while all the bases around you decay because someone stole all the supplies and despawned them overnight. They prefer the money made from people buying the game on throwaway accounts to grief.

Many of the combat mechanics are entirely unexplained and unintuitive. The camera is angled-topdown, but aiming for height is nigh impossible. You must shoot the ground in front of a prone player to hit them. A player crouched behind cover can basically never be hit except through random chance. A downed player who was encumbered can halt a pushgun's ability to be moved entirely. Pushguns in general, through their 2-or-more-man crew, require a lot of coordination to use with strangers and are de facto ignored by new players despite their damage output and low cost meta. Clans hoard 100s of tanks for weekend ops/recruitment sprees/unknown reasons, leading to the frontline having 0 armor support through the entire week. Not all of these issues can be solved by the devs, as they are also a result of the social construct of clan/regiment behavior, but the devs are not helping either.

=======================
Post 1.0 Update:
Devs didn't want facilities to feel mandatory to win and wanted to integrate them into the existing logistics and base mechanics.
We're 6 months past 1,0 release and they are still largely separate systems that still largely conflict with each other for maintenance and priority.

Facilities are needed to make all end-game tech, such as (super) battle tanks, Tempest Cannons (train SC) and most of their specialized ammo.

Devs are adding meme vehicles like a grenade version of the worst AC in the game, and a tripod grenade launcher.

Worst of all, the devs do nothing at all about the rampant alting problems. People spend days, weeks building bases, facilities and masses of tanks and a few alt accounts disable defences and grief tanks and facilities in a single night to take multiple hexes and meta concrete bases in a single night.

The devs cashed out after 1.0 and are working on a new game, have a history of horrible Community Management, player interaction and moderation (such as giving a 1 week slap on the wrist to a moderator using his powers to teleport his team to respond to invasions).

Without serious attention this MMO will die to people getting another copy of this 25‚Ç¨ game at $1.62 (Argentinian regional pricing) just to grief with another account.

There is no other game like this, not even by a margin. However, with a player-driven game, there are too many opportunities for bad actors to family share to another faction, or grief for lols, for this game to be fun anymore. I have witnessed cheaters gunning down enemies through Fog of War where they shouldn't know where they are. I have seen this directly affect the opposing faction, and lead to an easy win. Let it be known, there is ZERO effective moderation from Siege Camp to deter these bad actors from ruining the game for everyone else. Until there is a meaningful developer response, my review will stay negative.

Okay, that's enough!
This game starts as a beautiful war imitation game where you can be anyone. You can play as normal soldier with gun, sometimes with really heavy gun like rpg or mortar. You can be a medic who's saving lives. You can be a tanker who destroying enemy defenses and enemy tanks. You can be an artillery man and crush enemy from distances. BUT NOPE.
