Who am I to foxhole? A longtime community veteran. I have, in the past, run a "Military Academy," where I organized with other vets to create videos, guides and the like in multiple languages for new and returning players alike. I have a lot of long lasting and deep connections to players on/in both factions.

Foxhole is a game unlike any other. It's a game that one can easily sink hundreds, if not thousands of hours into. There is a thriving community online of players and "retired" veterans alike who still communicate with one another about the game.

Years ago when I started playing, if you'd have asked me if I enjoyed the game, I'd have given a resounding yes. This game is everything a war gamer could ever want, and more, for the first 20 hours. Then you start to understand some of the issues affecting the game, and for the first little while... It's fine. You learn to love the jank. You learn to work around the issues and play the game for what it is.

However, a couple years back, for various reasons (some of which I find justified, others which I do not,) the developers [b] outright and explicitly stopped communicating with the community[/b], they dropped their community manager, and now only communicate on exceedingly rare occasions and through the foxhole official discord, despite having their own website and their own subreddit where communication would be much more visible and effective.

This has led to a downward spiral of community toxicity. I don't think it's right, but I understand where it has come from. The lack of communication and in game moderation from the developers has lead to the players becoming increasingly factionalized and aggressive to those in their own faction they perceive as griefing and people of the other faction at large over perceived developer bias affecting game play. (IE, a buff to one faction is never properly explained, leading people to make snide comments about dev pet factions, etc, rather than the devs getting ahead of the buff/nerf with data and explaining the WHY)

Another issue this has lead to is a feeling that the developers are out of touch with the reality of their own game. They continue to make the systems around logistics and building increasingly difficult, complex and time consuming. A single person can no longer effectively do anything they want. While this does encourage team play, it also encourages factionalism, tribalism within each faction, and hardcore resource hoarding and toxicity. The devs are creating systems that no-one asked for, while neglecting quality of life updates that the community has been begging for over [b]literal years[/b]

Foxhole as it currently stands today is still a fundamentally functional game. However, over the years certain systems have built up to the point that they have become miserable and unfun to interact with. Logistics and building have become increasingly complex, well beyond anything anyone in the community ever really asked for. The solo player is relegated to frontline combat or [b]hoping[/b] that they can find a squad or clan or group participating in the activity they would like to do, otherwise they will find themselves ineffective.

You can absolutely still have fun in this game, and I still often do, but I have long since stopped recommending the game to friends as I genuinely believe the game is no longer worth the time and energy one needs to invest to find that fun.

I've been playing this game since 2018. Suffice to say, with almost 4,000 hours, I've got a fair amount of experience with it. I paid a lot less than $30 for it and feel like I've ripped off the developers with how much time I've spent on it. I've no clue how they aren't bankrupt, because most games of this format are subscription services for a reason.

HOWEVER, I can't in my right mind recommend this game to any of my friends, because while the concept is unique, 85% of the game-play is holding W or LMB.

Back in 2018, you could hop on, grab a tank or some artillery shells, and be on the front line in 15 minutes. If there were no tanks, you did about 15 minutes of work, and came back 12-24 hours later to collect your tank, and be on the front line in 15 minutes. If there were no artillery shells, you could make artillery shells for about 30 minutes, and be on the front line in another 15. Logistics was a factor, but it was an interesting and unique step no other game had.

Fast forward to 2023, and none of that is even remotely possible. There are very few additional steps, but timers upon timers. You want a tank? Wait 6 hours for a component node to re-spawn, mine for a couple hours, not get enough because there's not actually enough to go around, repeat, refine the components for another 2-3 hours, build the tank, and then after spending another 30-40 minutes loading and getting the equipment you need, you spend another 30 driving to the front line where you're likely to get one or two shot killed by someone who spent more time slaving away than you did.

I can't lie to you and say that there isn't plenty of good fun to be had. Once you get over all of that logistics the combat can be fairly enjoyable. But unless you're willing to commit 6-8 hours a day on this game with at least 3 other people over the course of a month, all you're going to be is fodder for the people who are.

I would stay away from this one until the fun toys are actually accessible. As is, it fosters an incredibly toxic environment where players compete with their own team more than the enemy. Some because they want to win that badly and feel the need to control everything, others because they want the big toys and don't want to share. Without a friend group big enough to compete with 15-20 people for resources, you're never going to get anywhere near half the content in this game.

Lack of any dev transparency is very disappointing. Alting has been a constant issue for years now, but devs are more likely to ban RP'ers than blatant alts that keep coming back every other day. QoL issues are also given a backseat in favor of simply adding more content to burden the players. The grind is gotten so bad there are actually services from ppl getting paid for grinding for others by the hours because of how tedious and unfun it is for most. Very fun, helpful community. Easy to start playing so many roles to learn, thousands of hours of playability. When I first logged in, I had no idea what to do, but just asked in local voice chat and in the first hour I was a decent rifleman and then medic. Eventually joined an open squad and playing with an organized group makes the game exponentially more fun. A successful bayonet charge, burned down a town, and even the production and mass logi convoys were all a blast.
I still love the game, but devs are just making it harder day by day

I wish I could recommend foxhole. It is a unique game with a unique premise and the thought of being involved in a large, MMO type war where teamwork is more essential than any piece of equipment is thrilling.

However, it is clear that Siege Camp were capable of coming up with a good concept, but have no idea how to implement it. This is an MMO with NO MODERATION OR AUTOMATIC BAN SYSTEM. Think about that. This is a game where you can literally buy a second copy of the game and go fuck around on the enemy team with no consequences. This leads to absurd instances of being killed by your own team, watching people from your own team sabotage equipment by running it into the ocean, sabotage buildings, lock vehicles that are needed, destroy your own teams vehicles, report on your teams positions, direct artillary fire for the enemy team, the list is endless. In addition, none of these actions will get you banned because the developers HAVE NEVER IMPLEMENTED ANY MODERATION SYSTEM TO HANDLE CHEATERS.
Surprise surprise, avoiding interaction with the community and ignoring issues will lead to an upset community.

The game is honestly incredible. The idea of a constant war where everything is harvested by players, produced by players, built by players, and ultimately destroyed by players is amazing. No other game I've played manages to pull off what Foxhole can with its scale and dynamics, and all praise it receives is well earned.

All I have said is what I recognise as a relatively new player, and unfortunately I don't think this would be the case if it weren't for having a great deal of assistance whilst learning, and whilst I continue to learn. I was lucky enough to have an experienced friend who ensured my experience was as good as it could be. From what I've both seen and heard from other new player however, a persistent problem is the labelling of newer players as alts, ruining their experience.

Another part of the problem is the lack of an effective way to deal with said alts when they appear. I feel these are part of the same problem, with experienced players too quick to label anyone acting differently as an alt or a griefer due to the abundance and repeat offences of alt accounts.

I enjoy this game, more so with every hour I spend playing it. The community is one of the most dedicated I've come across and there's a genuine sense of comradery from both teams. I love it and recommend it, my only fear being the current dilemma may not be healthy for its longevity.

Foxhole is a very unique and special game. Blending elements of shooters, MMOs, and other strategy based games into title that has no comparison. Foxhole has so many different types of game play to offer that it is nearly staggering. From participating in massive tank battles, spending days perfecting base designs, to sneaking around enemy territory, foxhole has so much to master. As such it is no surprise that myself and many others have sunk countless hours into this game and its community. 

Many will point to the games community and developers as a point of criticism, and while much of that is valid, every large community will have bad actors. Ultimately, foxhole has allowed me to create friendships that have lasted for years and I wouldn't trade any of my time playing this game for any other. Like any game certain mechanics are lacking, back line logistics remain complex and arduous, but none of those activities are requiered. I can always hop on foxhole knowing that if I want a simple hour of fun I can go to a front and play infantry, or if I want to get into the weeds of more complex strategy than I can rely on my clan to provide fun and engaging operations, one of many clans present within each foxhole faction. I have not spent more time playing any game more than I have with Foxhole and I dearly recommend that others try it out. 

Joinsom.com and stay foxy!

This is a game that took a bold concept and put together an incredible ecosystem for players to cooperate and work together in. I made great relationships in this game and had a terrific time with the friends that I made. 

Regrettably - for the years that I have played this game on and off - the developers have consistently determined to make sure this game cannot meet its potential. Their lack of attention to the community is insulting, the lack of community and in-game moderation is tearing the game apart, and their inability to take even the most basic steps towards balancing the game destroys its potential.

Hopefully someone can take inspiration from the initial work that this team did - but stay away from this developer unless there is a significant change in the way they do business.

I have never had so much fun and enjoyment in a game before, I enjoy every aspect of the game except for building, just because I am too impatient for it. 

I could sit here and make a list of pros, but it would be miles long when I have only a single con against this game. 

The community is absolute dogshit, they would sooner blame absolutely every loss, partisan attack, skill issue build, inexperienced new player, all of it they would sooner blame on alts than there being a skill difference between them and their opponent. 

It is a nerve grating issue, when actual cheating alts are very rare compared to the amount of new players that join everyday.
They made the game unfunnier than in alpha and beta togheter with all the grind mechanics.

As of right now, i would not recommend buying this game. Even though i love it, its in a terrible state right now.

Main problems:

1: Basically no in game moderation, people will say slurs in world chat or admit to buying a alternative account to sabotage the other team. And they wont be banned. Most they can get is a slap on the rest from the rest of the players.

2: Little to no communication between the devs and the community as a whole, we get dev streams very occasionally but those mostly just show of shiny new toys, not fixes to issues players actually want.

3; Bugs, theres not many of them but they happen very often and have existed in the game unfixed for a long time. Stuff like voice chat for whole regions or specific players stopping. Very important weapons of mass destruction like nukes being very buggy, etc, etc.

4: Massive balance issues, there are many things in this game where one side simply has something the other doesnt that is insanely useful. Along with this many vehicles and weapons are simply worthless, the ares, the stockade, snipers, all outlaw variants, shotguns, etc, etc. All of this of course contributes to my next point.

5: Toxicity, the community has a lot of toxicity in it, largely because of the game itself. Balance issues, many game mechanics like facilities being for no reason incredibly annoying and draining, alting causing distrust among players, the insane amounts of time and energy needed to maintain defenses and facilities. Which take easily hours to make the stuff to maintain them. If you get invested into this game it demands that you treat it like a part time job.

6: Servers are often unstable, with entire servers going down out of nowhere, as well as lots of lag.

TLDR: I love this game, but please dont get yourself invested in it.

This game is great in concept and execution, it really is. I wish I can give it a positive review, but until then my review will remain negative until the developers are willing to address some core issues that the game has had, which have been exacerbated in the past few weeks in light of the new updates and War 100.

Much of the game is essentially locked behind hundreds of man-hours. Unless you are part of a regiment or have the charisma to convince dozens of friends to play with you to build facilities and bunkers, there are some things you will never accomplish as a solo player. While this isn't necessarily a bad thing, with cooperation being a centerpiece of the game, the grind of maintaining the facilities and resources needed to access much of the features that are usually locked away is about roughly the same as getting a second job.

Additionally, the developers have complete radio silence over the issue of alts and griefers in the game. Although an in-game report system exists to report griefers and alts who destroy hundreds of hours worth of work and progress, at most they receive a slap on the wrist with a three-day ban, before they're back to cause untold amounts of damage with it. There are serial offenders who've been banned dozens of times, yet they continue to destroy resources and sabotage the game. The developers have not given a single statement about any of this, regardless as to how bad it is for the health of the game.

Due to the above, this review will remain negative until Siege Camp does something about it.
While this game is not for everyone, those who take the time to figure it out, link up with others and have fun will have a much better time then those who just complain the whole time.

TLDR: This game is can offer an experience that no other game out there can. If you are interested in supporting a month long effort to defeat an enemy team across a huge map then this is the game for you. Large group battles where it takes a team effort to win. Plenty of roles to fill and things to do. 

The major issues are a distant developer team, Queues to get into front line battles during most days, Tedious building and harvesting mechanics. This game WILL eat your time and life if you let it, especially if you try to play solo.

However, This game is fantastic and creates great experiences. More Info Below: 8/10

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Front-line gameplay gives you the opportunity to use a large variety of tools to fight or disrupt the enemy team. Use a rifle to kill opponents, Machine guns to kill and suppress enemy defenses, Mortars/Tanks/Artillery to destroy enemy fortifications. Play as a medic to heal your allies, Recon and build watchtowers for map awareness. There is so much, and that's just the surface level. Hopefully you can get in before a Queue hits during peak time!

If you don't want to do that then join mid or back lines to supply the war effort. Build fortifications or vehicles. Harvest resources that a player will need to transport to the factories to produce equipment which in turn, needs to be transported to the front.But, Most of the actual "work" here is driving with WASD and left-clicking.

Be aware, This game attracts very hardcore players who take things way to seriously. Team-killing and verbal abuse can be an issue. But these experiences are few and far between. On the flip side, these hardcore players are a major part of the war effort and can be so kind as to offer free powerful vehicles and invite you to their "Operations" with all their provided gear. 

If you are more casual then there are still plenty of things to do. Spawn in to a region and shoot some enemy for a bit, quick harvests in the back. try to sneak around enemy front-lines to stop their harvests/transportation. Be prepared to usually spend ATLEAST hour to start and finish something.

All in all, great game with some limitations. You cant find an experience like this anywhere else. Buy it already.

A group of friends show me the game, looks nostalgic but with a complexity and strategy incredible dependent on the player base.
It got a grab on me that i put about 300 hours in 2 months.

You can be anything: 
from the base of the Logistic (scraping resources, refining basic materials), 
to advanced logistic (refining rare materials, building vehicles and supplies for special ops) 
or saciate your bloodlust on the frontlines (fight for ground and the tug of war with any weapon or tool avaiable).

INCREDIBLE for any player to make a team effort and plan massive ops, to the random joe picking a gun and runing to the sound of bullets and explosions on the distance.....

BUT (A MASSIVE ONE)

They changed a great deal of the crafting (most of the fun stuff now needs incredible amount of time and resources to be able to achieve)
ALTs (player with a secondary account on the oposing enemy team to spot weaknesses on the defence grid, stealing anything from resources and vehicles to blocking essential paths.)
They took out the voice chat with the enemy team because their servers suck (massive map, but segmented because the server suck, and cant handle too many players, or too many buildings, or just dies because whatever)

TL:DR
Incredible complexity, but you need to sink too much time for anything fun to use, and the problem with ALTs, grief and trolling is killing the playerbase that still play after a bunch of updates that made the bit of grinding in the game in a shore/second job.

The game is filled with bugs, cheaters, unbalanced, and made incredibly difficult to play in smaller groups or as an individual. The devs don't seem to care about many of the longstanding issues plaguing the game.

A genuinely frustrating experience, only made worse by the developers being incredibly passive aggressive and incompetent
doing logistics is physically painful to the point where the players literally had a strike over it, and after a few token concessions the devs doubled down with this update and made everything even worse

As time has passed, the developers have gone from being passive aggressive to not dignifying the community with a response at all
they just mangle things at random in a soundless void because they're bored and think its funny, and the actual players just get to suffer through it with no hope of improvement
actual issues, be it rampant alting ruining hundreds of manhours of work, things not working properly if at all, or things just being horribly horribly unfun and toxic, are entirely ignored by the devs at best and get you banned for bringing them up by their few remaining sycophants at worst

This game is legitimately true garbage and god help you if you buy it
Best game ever. 10/10

For a game that got out of early access and into 1.0, this game is NOT 1.0 ready now don't get me wrong, this game is absolutely amazing in terms of design and concept but there are glaring issues that have yet to be addressed that have been a problem since the early access ever since I started playing back in 2017/2018.

The biggest elephant in the room is alting, where players buy another copy of the game to grief and steal the opposing faction that their main account is on, this has been a problem on both teams for such a long time that there has been a major detriment and contributes a level of paranoia that any new or low rank player could be someone on one of these alt accounts. This has caused a negative experience to those who are in the crosshairs of being accused of an alt and is more than likely to stop playing due to this experience. Cheating is also an issue as you could be walking in the middle of the night and be shot right out of nowhere with pinpoint accuracy, you can see in the store page it says "Valve Anti-Cheat enabled" but that is just a joke there is no such thing and cheaters can just go without a care in the world.

The second problem that has arose in the past couple of years is game balancing and testing, this has been brought up into the spotlight ever since the developers went away from symmetrical equipment for both sides and instead went down an asymmetrical tech tree for both factions with each vehicle and equipment having their pros and cons in using them. The developers have done such poor job in working out a balance for these equipment, often to one side curb stomping the other until they either release a hot-fix to balance equipment or wait out 1-2 months for their next update. 

The last and final problem that I have with this game is the developer communication between the playerbase, they have live streams to help showcase [spoiler] THE VISION [/spoiler] for a major update that they have been working on. These updates usually try to remedy a problem for a certain team or certain aspect in the game that in the end either causes more problems or is just poorly designed. The facilities that been added in the newest update gave new depth to logistics but at the cost of more time investment, this game can be extremely grindy especially into building/maintaining these new facilities or bunker bases. 

This game that I have played for the past couple of years are some of the most fun I had in a video game and the experiences that can't be achievable in any other game. Foxhole is an absolute gem when I first started playing but since then it slowly start going into a downwards spiral, the community at its best is one of the best communities out there, but factionalism and paranoia of cheating/alting has already left its mark on this community and the mishandling of this game has not helped it since.

Fun for the first few hours, but once you scratch the surface it becomes an extreme grind. Moderation is nearly nonexistent, resulting in excessive griefing that is absurdly apparent when one war (a "round" for those unfamiliar with the game) often lasts longer than a month in recent times. That's 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, until victory is achieved. Critical moments are frequently ruined for both teams by trolls that go unpunished by Siege Camp.

The game has also become extremely grindy, and while I respect the lack of a "pay to win" model, not everyone can spend 12+ hours per day in game to experience all that the game has to offer. Building literally takes days of effort, and the more recent addition of facilities is even worse. When you consider that all of this effort can be ruined by a bored griefer on the internet in a few minutes you can see why the community is burnt out and fed up. The game needs a huge overhaul in terms of moderation, quality of life for players, and communication from Siege Camp to overcome the current hurdles. Until then, I simply cannot recommend Foxhole to anyone who is curious. You may be impressed at the chaos short term, but will be extremely let down if you survive longer than a few hours to see what lies beneath the surface.

While it's a really fun game based on teamwork with other players on your side, the contact with devs is almost non-existant, both teams are infested by alt accounts (people buy additional instances of the game to grief the other side, which is bannable, but due to lack of any moderation, most alt accounts don't even get banned) and lack of the quality of life updates make it so after some hours into this game, you'll essentially get more and more frustrated by these issues. While this game sure is a good game and has the potential, due to the lack of fixing the issues I pointed out by devs, I'm not going to recommend this game to other players currently.

The game is actually great except the recent Alts that are ruining peoples hard work, logi is basically a second job and needs more QoL (hence why alts really make an impact by ruining peoples effort and work) and Devs seem to have this "we don't give a shit" kind of attitude with their lack of support/communication about these things. No Dev blogs or anything. Just radio silence...

This is unique game and quite fun, wouldn't be playing it so much otherwise but they gotta get this shit together or it's gonna die. Clearly feel the shift in vibe these past few days in game.

Foxhole is unlike any other MMO I've ever played.  You really feel like you are one very small part of a large war.  I know some of the recent reviews have been negative, but I think many long time players of this game lose sight of the unique fun parts of the game after awhile.  Yes the logistics can be grindy at times, but getting supplies to a crucial front at the right time to see your side push or successfully defend feels very rewarding.  Front line combat can sometimes be frustrating because it's hard to see the impact you have as one of dozens of soldiers on a front, but it's fun get to know and work together with the other people in your faction even when things are not going your way.  People do complain about toxic players, griefers and alts ruining the fun, but I've found the vast majority of Foxhole veterans are positive and welcoming to new players because the realise that teaching new players the ropes help their team win.

What is this game?

It is a top-down shooter set in a technological era that seems to be between World Wars one and two. Victory is achieved for one of the two factions when they earn 32 victory points spread out across the many hexes of the map. The technology between the two factions is asymmetric and there are pros and cons for selecting each faction.

What‚Äôs good about this game?
Your gameplay experience will vary depending on where you want to devote your time. Will you be a frontline soldier, selling your life repeatedly to gain an inch of ground, or to throw back invaders? Will you spend hours alone in the enemy backline with a wrench, causing as much havoc as you can by destroying enemy vehicles and robbing them of their resources, cutting enemy supply routes and harassing other players in the resource fields as a partisan? Will you devote your time to learning the intricacies of fortification and bunker building to preserve the backline or reinforce newly-gained enemy territory as an engineer? These tasks can all be extremely rewarding and leave you with a sense of accomplishment depending on your individual tastes. There‚Äôs something for everyone in this game. Various levels of gameplay are available to help make sure there‚Äôs a place for just about every kind of play style you‚Äôd want to partake in.

What‚Äôs bad about this game?
Ultimately, the cons of this game derive from moderation being abandoned by the developer as they hide behind the excuse of this game being ‚ÄúCommunity Driven‚Äù. Being reported by a certain amount of people, regardless of the truth of the accusation, will result in a ban. Any time you make a comment in the World, Intel, or Logistics chats your comment can be down-voted. The result of continued down-votes from other players is a ban from these faction-wide chats. This problem is further exacerbated by the fact that with the age of this game, veteran players have essentially become a collected group of separate cliques that can muscle their clan-mates into exploiting this mechanic to silence and remove players who don‚Äôt like the way you play the game. That private stockpile you‚Äôve built up to run to the front line? Gone since the timer on it will expire before your automatic ban is lifted. Want to coordinate with different fronts to see what vehicles or weapons would help them the most? Well that‚Äôs unfortunate, because yesterday you got into an argument with a prominent member of a large regiment and they‚Äôve decided you don‚Äôt get to speak anymore.

There is no better example of this than the players who actively police the technology progression system. Using game mechanics to vote for or drum up support for technology in game is vilified if you‚Äôre not voting for the technology that‚Äôs been agreed upon in a Discord group. This merry band of self-important narcissists (Self-proclaimed ‚ÄúTech Maids‚Äù) routinely abuse these moderation mechanics to silence people who express discontent with their technology hoarding. 

If you get this game, avoid confrontations with members of large regiments. Use the materials you earn through your work for your benefit. Do not say anything about any of the materials you've collected, and use the technology materials you earn through mining resources to vote for the technology you want as an individual. Install OBS and record chat history so you can prove you've not violated terms of conduct if you receive a communications ban. 

This is coming from someone who's spent their entire time in the Warden faction. If the Colonial experience differs, please share.

I would recommend playing this game if you choose the Colonial faction regularly.

As of 2/23:

Man, is this game awful.


So since the 1.0 Update, the game's gone even farther downhill. The addition of the Facilities that they added has led to a new reason for people to use alternate accounts to grief the rival faction. The vast majority of tanks and vehicles are locked behind using facilities in order to produce, as well as someone producing the materials to make the upgrade. These materials also require facility structures in order to produce. 

Well since that's the case, if people grief facilities then they can prevent the faction's vehicle from being produced. Destroying defenses with friendly fire so they can get into facilities with tanks, taking the vehicles out with one account and giving it to their main account in the other faction, blocking defenses using vehicles so they can just waltz into a facility and wrench your vehicles you worked hard to produce, it's all just a massive CF. 

The BEST part about it though is the developer response.... Or lack of one, I guess you'd say. 

You can do all of this with literally no penalty as long as you get out of the region before people report you. Even if you DO get reported and banned, it will be for a maximum of three days before you can just come back and do it again. 

Y'all, I cannot stress enough that you SHOULD NOT BUY THIS GAME. Some people are going to keep playing. If you see their reviews change and state that these issues have been fixed, then come and play. If not, steer VERY FAR AWAY from it. Anything you produce can literally just be pulled from storage depots or from your parking lots and dumped into a lake. All your time and effort gone, and no effort from developers whatsoever  

This game has pretty much been abandoned in order for Siegecamp to produce another game they're working on called "Anvil". Stay away from it, too. I cannot stress how little the developers care about offering you a quality product.

Now, I wouldn't even recommend buying it on sale.

As a player with over 2,500 hours in-game, DON'T BUY THIS GAME.  I cannot in good faith recommend this game TO ANYONE in it's current state. 

I started playing this game back in Early January 2020, and thanks to it I've made many great friends, had fun with many people, cried tears of joy and anger all the while feeling like I was a part of a large scale war.

Nowadays the game is a second job, full of grindy mechanics that don't allow for you to access half of the games content, bugs that break the immersion, a queue mechanic that wastes your time and forces you to wait to get into battle or deliver guns/ammo, and unreliable servers that will sometimes boot you out into the main menu, regardless of what you were doing.  In addition the lack of tutorials and explanations of game mechanics make this game much more complicated than it needs to be ( and for the record, the tutorial area has not been updated since I started playing the game).

The developers don't interact with the community and refuse to fix the problems that have been piling up, instead maintaining radio silence while issues such as hackers, cheaters and people using alternative accounts further exacerbates the problem.

Like I said at the start of my review DON'T BUY THIS GAME.

Foxhole is a game that relies upon player-player interaction as everything you see or do is player made and/or built with extensive time sunk. With each update, more and more features are added that simply do not value the aforementioned players time. 

The most recent update added facilities, an unique design, but with VERY poor implementation. For a game that has been years in the making they tested the game-breaking facilities (as shown by the HUGE dip in players in the past handful of months) in only a couple weeks on the dev branch. Facilities have added a monotony of maintaining buildings that place needed items such as upgraded tanks, artillery, and other actual fun items like Battle Tanks or Super Heavy Tanks to where only a small portion of the player base will actually enjoy them. 

For $30, this game will provide about 100 hours of actual fun gameplay if you run with a squad of friends or in-game regiments. After the 100 hours? You'll be lost in the litany of poorly designed bases costing fronts, game-breaking bugs such as queue bugs that wipe entire regions, and the toxic cesspool that is the community surrounding this game. There is a reason why the game was released to 1.0 in October 2022 with 10k players and with only one-third or one-fourth of those players still playing. 

Recommendation: buy this on a sale with friends and enjoy the time you have, but don't sink your teeth in because the devs do not care about the veteran players.

Edit: yeah. Still either play 10 hours straight by accident or refuse to play for 3 weeks straight.

Edit: The last edit was at 100 hours of play. I now have nearly 1700. I am known for my work in the builder community. The games balance is all over the place, and not just in the intended asynchronous ways that the devs think its at, but some pretty glaring issues. 

Lets start with late game anti structure. 

150mm artillery, The guns between factions are identical, however the colonial one has more range whereas the warden one has a blast shield that helps keep the gunner alive (by roughly 1/3rd chance) within the emplacement. Cool difference, recently modified, but slightly overtuned towards colonial favor.

250mm Siege tanks. 
Chieftain and ballista. The ballista comes with a total capacity of 11 of these hard hitting "mortar" shells whos entire purpose is to crack whatever its shooting at the sacrifice of the tank and its crew. Its slow, but holds quite a bit of ammo.

The Chieftain, while quicker, holds a total of 6 shells, but also has a 12.7 Machine gun to go with it. Good vic to kill border bases at 2am for the 5th time that night.  if this was the only difference, we'd be okay, everything would be fine. BUT: Post 1.0 update, Chieftains require T2 facilities and the silverhand as its base vehicle, requires silverhands to tech in order to produce, and no fast way to do so, not including the extra infrastructure requires to turn silverhands into chieftains. 
The Ballista? Unlocks two entire tiers earlier, and can be made in the MPF. If you wanted Scorpians (also known as the infantry support tank) (also a really fun tank) You would have to go through a cheaper, but yet similar process to turn the siege tank into a support tank.

What this means is the colonial big boi of concrete killing comes out two tech tiers ahead of the warden medium boi of concrete killing. This can be up to 4 or 5 real days of one side having siege tanks before the other gets the equipment to effectively defend themselves from them (the other tech tier, if you dont know what im talking about, thats okay, just know its a struggle for awhile) 

Infantry equipment. In my personal opinion, colonial arms are easier to learn and use, lowering the requires skill floor to use effectively, while warden has a higher skill floor and ceiling, meaning more tricky to use, but once mastered it is more rewarding. This is okay and fine, but my biggest gripe is the handheld anti-personnel grenades. Harpas, with less standard range is more likely to instantly down an enemy may sound good, you vastly underestimate the extended range of the instant bleed Bombastone with a much wider blast radius. And as easy it is to throw two of these grenades (with the damage saturation of 4 harpas) colonials also get 25 per crate compared to 20 per crate wardens get. For the same cost.

Another piece of infantry equipment is the Catara, its just 12.7 handheld light lazerbeam of death. this is your typical salt from wardenman. yada yada yada i dont have numbers it just makes me the deaded.


Alright now onto universal issues instead of "that side has better toys than my side >:[ bs"

Fire. 1.0 update included the lovely aspect of setting things on fire. If you have ever built anything in this game, you know it literally going up in flames and nothing you can do about it, even with a fire truck or two or three or seven at times. Oh and dont ever count on buckets of water saving you. The amount of damage 3 people, regardless of team, two with flamethrowers and 1 with a machine gun for suppression, can destroy entire bases, facilities, and towns if the response time is slow, or its perhaps middle of the work day Europe and 2 am United states and not as many people are online to notice the issue. 3 people can take out days worth of work done by dozens of people. 

Speaking of work of the many undone by the few.
Alts.
Some of you may know what an alt is. If you dont im going to explain it. It is when you use another account to play the game. This is sometimes beneficial for you, or even explicitly something developers want, in some games it allows you to do multiple classes or crafting recipes or whatnot at the same time to help progress your character. Sometimes it allows you to do 1 task by yourself instead of needing a team. In this game some people use them to have more factory queues or even solocrew a tank. 
THIS IS LOOKED DOWN BEHAVIOR HERE. 
and heres why. Not only does it give you an advantage over your enemy in many scenarios, or just deny your faction queue slots without having the player presence to justify it, But mainly, it is used for the cases of sabotage. People buy other steam accounts or just buy a brand new copy of the game and have their level 1 no rank guy go around as the other team, taking stuff, and throwing it into a river. Destroying defenses, despawning things from bases, disconnecting bunkers to slow the rate of tech, teaching tanks to swim, using trucks to block AI defenses (allowing the enemy to come closer than they had any right of being and killing whatever needs deading). But since on the map it doesnt show up as an enemy, unless you are in close proximity and catch them in the act, you just notice everything from your base gone, 15 trucks parked perfectly in front of garrisons, the 15 tanks you had prepped for the operation you and your buddies had planned for an hour from now have went missing, your base now has grown engine rooms and t1 pieces off the back (making it much much weaker for you newbies out there, please dont add pieces to someones base without their permission).

Okay so we catch an alt in the act. what now? Well you can try to voteban, where you have enough people in region to report them. but thats only temporary. What does the developers do? Nothing. Even the ones they have gone out of their way to ban, its only a year long ban and you see these accounts, come back after 372 days, and go back to doing all this damage. 

And its always interesting to see an invasion of your territory happen, but all of your staged counter artillery, and ammo, flatbeds to move the ammo, Extra guns, Quick Response Force tanks, all go missing just right before the attack.

Or the PVT who knows all the tricks required to acquire and steal a stored Super Heavy Tank, that some group has gone out of their way to store as secured as possible, and starts driving it towards a group of partisans who just appeared in your backline at the same time.

But theres 0 investigation of foul play by the developers or any sort of team. I dont personally think a developer should be dealing with these types of reports but maybe a community manager or someone. Anyone at this point. 

War 100 has been particularly bad. At least from the warden perspective. Able shard seemed to have a less amount of Alt behavior since 1.0 but thats to be believed that the people who like to see the world burn went to what was considered the new player friendly servers where there is less "tools" in place for handling griefers and alts. Those servers are now gone. All condensed back into 1 shard (or server).

As a concept, this game is amazing. Persistent warfare, players having an actual impact, and some pretty cool gameplay makes for an exceptionally attractive product. The entire reason that I have as many hours logged in this game that I do, is because of the Clan I joined and continue to be a member of. Without a solid group of friends, this game is absolutely miserable. 


 Unfortunately the game is at the same time a product of a Dev team that refuse to communicate with the community in any meaningful way. There are significant issues that consistently get ignored by said Dev team, much to the detriment of the players of this game. Cheaters, Griefers, and Alt users continue to destroy any potential enjoyment the playerbase may have. 

 The Developers removed In Game Moderators due to corruption and abuse on their part, and never replaced them. Instead they have a system of reporting players through a support ticket, which unfortunately goes ignored these days with the same troublemakers coming back over and over without ever being addressed in a significant way. 

 This is further hampered by the Dev team's choice to make everything about the game as disrespectful to players' time as they can. They seem stuck in the same mindset as most Mobile Game Developers (The company used to be named "Clapfoot" and published Mobile Games) in that they find "Gacha" mechanics interesting and utilize a lot of time-gating via overly complicated systems that do more to punish players for their hard work with even more hard work even to do the most simple of tasks. 

 The fact remains I may play this game more after this review, because friends that I enjoy spending time with still play it. However, I will never under any circumstance recommend you give this company a single cent for this game or ANY OTHER they produce. Don't let the name change fool you, this is still the same awful Dev Team that will produce "Anvil" or whatever they name it. 

 The only good Developer is Julian, the Art Dev. The rest are garbage.
A mess, and rushed.

Developers are currently totally failing the community. And this is not new. The big problems of the past were blatant game bias that made days of work useless, and factional imbalance that made one faction totally useless to play as because the other was so strong. Devs totally failed to address the systemic issues of this imbalance, and did not communicate with the player base whatsoever. 

The 1.0 update, the full release of foxhole, only made these problems worse, and opened a sore for new ones. There is no practical system to deal with alts and griefers that can ruin days of work in minutes. There are no independent or active moderators at all to deal with the most blatant griefer. Blatant griefers are NEVER permanently banned, and will log back on hours or a day later to ruin player experience again and again. Logistics have been revamped that now lock some of the funnest aspects of the game behind ‚Äúfacilities‚Äù that only the strongest clans can operate efficiently. The only way one can get the full experience of foxhole is to join a clan, solo player power is dead, and the game quickly grows boring or painful for solo players, especially for new players. Speaking of new players, there is no complete and integrated tutorial to truly reach new players the ropes of the game, the devs expect the player base to do it for them. Mistrust is high and the game has lost the magic it once had because of an incredibly inept development team. After war 100 (the war we are currently on as of this post), this game is going to be dead for a very long time until the community recovers and/or the devs respond and fix the problems they have created.

In short, don‚Äôt buy this game, it‚Äôs not worth it.

Game has seen a feature creep which makes it highly difficult to build worthwhile vehicles, or participate in manufacturing/logistics without a coordinated group. Like Rust, this game has become a major timesink that requires hours a session to get much out of it, which is difficult to do for people with jobs/students. In addition, the game's anticheat, and protections against alternative accounts used to grief the other team are lacking and there hasn't been any communication from developers on future plans. The fact that the game has become continually more complicated to do things means the time/investment it takes to build tanks and other things is much higher - so the impact from trolling/griefing has risen too. A troll using an alternative account can sink dozens of hours down the train in 30 minutes, and there seems to be hardly any effective systems at detecting and punishing this behaviour. Until developer communication improves and the game becomes more accessible, I would spend your time and money somewhere else.

The devs do nothing to fix game breaking bugs and server issues, some of which have been known for years. They instead add features nobody asked for which increasingly do not respect your time as a player. Updates are released half finished without appropriate bug fixes, QoL, or testing, leading to more bugs and inbalance between the factions. They then refuse to communicate with the community and release shadow patches at random.

Their moderation is also abysmal:
Send a video of a bug to them - perma banned
Write a rude word on the map - perma banned
Step out of line on reddit or discord - swift response
Send a video of a blatant ingame griefer - no response
There are no ingame mods leading to blatant griefing with no compensation. Bugs are exploited and nothing is done for months with no word on if the are even aware of or fixing the problem.

The game can still be fun, it is a brilliant idea and it has a friendly and passionate community, but over the years it has become bloated so that simple activities have become frustrating and it can feel more like a job than a game. 
I cannot recommend the game until:
There are better ingame moderation tools or active moderators.
The devs begin to communicate with the community.
Basic QoL is prioritised over new features that the majority of people will never use.
An updated tutorial is added for new players.

I don't want to disparage the developers, you have a difficult thankless job and there are aspects we the community do not understand about what is happening. PLEASE TALK TO US THOUGH. People are toxic because they have been yelling into the void which has left them jaded and confused.

I reviewed this game back in 2017 and gave it a positive review. It was incredibly fun back then, especially in a group of 3 or more.

However, now the thought of booting up Foxhole gives me a feeling of morose fatigue. 

- Logistics work, my favorite activity in the game, now means isolation from the main combat loop as well as a tremendous amount of busywork. 
- Building defenses requires expert knowledge and is unbelievably tedious.
- As soon as concrete is available, progress along the main front slows to a crawl. 
- At any given moment, nearly all fronts are stalled along bridges or other natural choke points, with very little for people at the front to actually do.

Some fundamental design decisions will need to change before I play this in earnest again, or recommend the game to others.

Spend time gathering materials and building facilities. Then have a single player with a wrench break in and kill everything while offline. Don't buy this game you'll end up wasting your time just for another player to get a dopamine rush off of killing your stuff.

Alts run rampant, sinking valuable supplies and vehicles that take hours to produce into the ocean. The dev's refuse to do anything about this. QOL updates have been needed for quite some time, and still, the dev's refuse to do anything.

The game was fun to play until the 1.0 Infenro release. That release, and the additional patches, made the game more grindy and turns it into a second job you need to play 24/7 to not lose your hard work.
Currently I do not enjoy the game anymore. It was certainly worth my money, as I played 1277 hours, but now I conclude this chapter.

The developers themselves along with the game DO NOT respect you. They dont respect your time nor do they respect their community. They frequently go radio silent for an entire year just to drop a half baked update that is no-where near ready and then dip out for another year. 

If you've seen a bunch of recent reviews of this game recommending against this game they are justified. There is frequent use of alternative accounts to sabotage the opposing team. After a boiling point it has come to this where the community can't take it anymore.

If you are a person who's looking to buy this game, DONT BUY IT. You will definitely have a better experience paying the $30 on something else.

Game has a lot of potential. In a lot of ways it's a really cool game. However, the devs are uninterested in fixing any of the quality of life issues with this game. This game is incredibly grindy and burns through players like water, because building in this game is both extremely frustrating and is like a second job. Game has a massive cheating issue as well, which is problematic because it takes a lot of work to make anything cool in this game, so to have it destroyed is rather demotivating. The devs only give out single day bans so these cheaters flagrantly continue their actions, in public, and don't get a permaban.

If they fix the cheating and the building and logistics gameplay I'll change my review to positive.

Conceptually Foxhole is one of the best games I've ever played but that concept isn't the reality. It has the potential to be revolutionary but I don't believe it can achieve that with the current attitude of the developers. In this game there is a serious lack of moderation or effective tools for player moderation (players can vote temp ban but no matter how many times this is done the offender can come back and just grief again the next day) there is a ticket system that often does not get listened to by the devs. On top of the standard griefing you would expect in a game like this there is a phenomenon known as 'alting' where players from one faction buy alternate accounts and join the opposing faction with them, they then set about ruining hundreds of hours of other innocent players time and all that can be done is to hopefully get enough votes to get rid of them for a bit, however, often this alting goes under the radar because the activity logs we have to check aren't sufficient. The issue with the alting not being addressed ever by the devs has lead to a lot of paranoia towards new players by the veteran player base and can make the experience of being a new player miserable but the devs don't care, they don't communicate and frankly they profit from the alting so their silence is deafening. The devs do not respect the players time investment in this game, logistsics and bulding (as important as the combat) are tedious and dull experiences and were only made worse by the factorio esque updates in 1.0 where we received a whole new logistics system (that soft locks causal players out of half the vehicles in the game btw) instead of the quality of life for builders and logi that we've been asking for for nearly 2 years now. 

tldr: dev man bad, dev man likes to profit off of their player bases misery and refuses to communicate with them.

As you can clearly see I've played this game many many hours. 1.5k at the time of writing this. I would absolutely love to recommend you the game, but I cannot honestly do that.

The game is a unique creation that, for me, filled a hole left by HeroesAndGenerals. Persistent battles and RTS. It filled the whole so well i never once considered going back to HnG after discovering this. Not only is there a persistent war and an RTS element like in HnG but there's also base building, backline sabotage, naval landings, strategic ballistic missiles and many others. It is in essence an incredible creation.

However. And this is the part where i'll explain why i don't recommend the game.
The biggest problem of the game at the time of writing this is the problem of alt accounts. Basically explained, nothing stops bad actors from purchasing multiple accounts and using those accounts to join the enemy side and wreck havoc. Drive vehicles into water, take screenshots of vulnerable points, screenshots of intel, modify bunker complexes to make them worse. There's many ways to damage your team and it is done en-mass. There is no way of efficiently getting rid of these bad actors at the time of the writing of this review.

Another considerable problem is the huge cost in time of many aspects of the game. Building a decent base can take real life days, and maintaining them can take a couple of hours per day. This is not necessarily a deal-breaker however seeing how wars can last months, this causes people to burn out and leave the game. A slightly less punishing way of building and maintaining what is built would alleviate this problem. 

My personal last problem with the game, thou compared to the others it is a minor thing, is that the developers of the game basically don't ever communicate with the community at large, nor do they take a stance, pro or against when it comes to contentious subjects such as hacking, using of exploits, 3rd party software use and others.

All in all this could be an incredible game, the love of my life game. But as it is now, it simply isn't. Thank you for reading

Foxhole is not a sustainable game.

In every war since the mid-70s the mood swings in the community hive mind have gotten more violent. Developers are in a catch 22 where if they ignore the playerbase it whips people up into screaming hysterics, and if they do communicate with the playerbase then people will go out of their way to whip themselves up into hysterics anyway. The shortest, most banal messages from the developers are gathered, with both sides employing troops of specialist schitzos to over-analyse, decrypt through 14 dimensions of possible subtext, and eventually use as evidence in echochambers to claim that developers favor the other side. 

The devs aren't little golden angels either though. They sit in their ivory towers adding piles of powercrept equipment while the fundamental problems of the game remain. The devs seem to exist in a reality where they're developing a game for the player base they *want*, rather than the playerbase they *have*. Discussions and accusations of cheating will get you banned from the forums while the cheaters themselves, even when caught and removed from the game dozens of times(!) are given a temporary time out before they can play again. You'll have the same account come back again and again and again.

A few dozen wars ago these people were few and had the discretion to cheat sneakily but these days they will openly and brazenly cheat in full view, despawn equipment and drive vehicles into water in a busy logistics town or sabotage a big base a few moments before a big clan operation. They expect to be caught and votebanned and don't care, they're just trying to do as much damage before that happens and their cheating account goes on a 48h cooldown. 

A significant section of the game relies on what is essentially slave labor. Playing logistics is a full time job and you can spend literally fourteen hours a day waiting for production queues to finish so you can drive X to Y or gather more resources. The timers for production is set up to be short enough to be inconvenient to set it as afk in the background and long enough that it's boring to wait in your truck. About 300 of my 550 hours were used to do logi full time until I realized what a total sucker I was being played for. Literally unpaid labor and the game relies on convincing enough no-lifes to do it so that everyone else in the community can have fun (or dump the production into a lake - see above). Without these people, btw, there would be no game. I quit when I realised I was one of a significant number of people who were feeling compelled to do this task because nobody else was doing it and it needed to be done for the game to function.

At its best, Foxhole could be one of the best MMOs out there. It truly breaks new ground and the emergent gameplay can blow you away. But it's in the process of collapsing. Until some huge, systematic changes are made, pass this game over for now.

Currently the war is 100, the longest game on record. People are trying their hardest to win the special number war. A huge section of the playerbase is exhausted, frustrated and burned out but it giving it one last hurrah for war 100. War 101 may break the longest game record because there'll be nobody to play it...

After playing this game for countless hours, it's really sad that I cannot recommend it. The concept is great, and it has so much potential. With that being said, there are countless issues that become noticeable once you've become accustomed to the mechanics. 

I'm not going to address every problem or we'd be here for hours - just my main one. The launch of 1.0 introduced facilities, which put a lot of the end game content behind barriers. As a result, you're force to join large regiments if you want a chance to try the cool stuff.

Amazing game, but due to issues like alting, bug abues and other disruptive behavior that the devs wont adress, I cannot recommend it until devs stop with the radio silence and adress important issues.

Dev only cares about $. They have a very active subreddit and discord communities and refuse to engage at all. Feedback has been not been great post 1.0 and the alting situation with griefing logi is awful. Reporting is also broken. System is designed to be abused by malicious coordinating reporting against players who do no wrong and players who openly grief have no repercussions....even after hundreds of reports and temp bans.

Not the game I fell in love with. I feel like a sweatshop worker instead of an integral cog in the war machine.

DO NOT BUY. YOU WILL INVEST SO MUCH TIME ONLY TO GET MORE AND MORE FRUSTRATED.
I like the game, but it has a masive griefing problem and the devs are not only doing anything about it, they ban you if you speak up.

I played almost 500 hours with this game in a relatively short term, so it is obvious that I like it. The atmosphere is amazing, it gives back the vulnerability of a person in war. I like the idea, that you must work together with your faction selflessly, from gathering resources to maintaining the bunkers, and facilities, doing the logistics etc. So overall the game has great potential.
A reason why I give negative feedback is based on the developer's attitudes toward their players.

Despite the community requests, the developers seemingly only focus on adding newer and bigger guns instead of polishing what we already have. One of the biggest problems is Alting, which means a player buys the second game for his/herself, joins the enemy faction, and starts do sabotage action within.
Factions are completely vulnerable to this. There is no in-game mechanics that you can defend against this, and even if you catch an Alt account and reports it, it will get a maximum of 3 days ban. On Reddit, you can find violation logs, which go back years, and have 3 days of bans one after another.

When your faction loses a hex within a day, what you fought for weeks just because all of your tanks and artillery equipment ended in the bottom of the ocean and you weren't able to fight back, you might question that your hours, days of hard work would have been more effective by doing something else..

We have seen many games killed by hackers, and cheaters I really hope devs will pull out their heads from their lower back parts and start to listen to their players and focus on the real problems.

I would have recommended this game in the past, but currently its not worth playing. Call me a review alt the way I'm changing teams

Foxhole is a game like no other. The concept of it has not been done before on such a scale. When you first get the game, you will be amazed. Every single day you learn new things and the game's systems show themselves to be deeper than you thought before. Meeting the same people in a persistent war day after day really creates a unique experience as a war sim MMO.

But the game is in an absolutely broken state. As you become hooked you also notice the cracks, everywhere you look. Certain parts of the game require massive time sinks each day (upward of five hours per day) in order to work. And as you're now hooked, you'll spend more and more time on the game, despite it becoming a detriment over time. The game has lots of bugs, exploits, broken systems... but it especially suffers from a complete and total lack of interest or moderation on the developer's part. The sporadic (3x a year) update stream shows what the team has been working on, and is guaranteed to generate a new stream of players being drawn to the game. But the developers will ignore each and every single part of player feedback that does not have to do with fixing simple bugs. There are no moderators anywhere in this game. Breaking rules, cheating, griefing... It's not only ignored, you will be banned by the devs on all platforms for speaking out about these issues. You'll sometimes sink literal IRL days into a project such as an operation or base building. It's a common occurence to wake up, completely without being able to protect your work from griefers while you slept, and see that people 'alting' (playing on your team but actually helping the enemy by griefing hard) have completely wiped away all your hard work. And when you have video evidence of it happening, the developers will never do anything about it, even banning you from speaking out in the process. 

This practice by the developers is decidedly anti-consumer, and the load of recent negative reviews reflect the community finally being fed up with the bullshit. Despite this being a great game and loving the community, and despite me sinking countless hours into this game, I recommend that you save yourself the trouble, and not buy this game. It will frustrate yourself to no end, and become an actual source of irl stress and frustration. Do not buy.

Its tedious, unfun, soul crushing, boring, laborious. Honestly you might as well just go work an actual job so you can at least get paid.

Been playing on and off since late 2018.

There are a lot of fun moments, and the game has grown a lot, but many core problems still persist over several years.

The dev team does not care to moderate their own game fairly, and would rather keep adding features instead of fixing the issues they've created. 

The engine is non-optimal and can't even support the type of game they claim they want. 

I love asymmetry, but there really needs to be some sort of balance. The devs just seem to add things to one side without considering the consequences, and only respond when the playerbase is BEGGING for a fix. 

The alt-account problem is still ongoing after all this time, and the accounts aren't even being properly banned or monitored. 

New players entering the game may find they have absolutely no clue what they're doing. 
There is no actual tutorial, and any small mistake you make will likely result in you being berated/insulted. There's a 50% chance that anybody you ask for help will either just tell you to do something else, accuse you of being an alt-account, or call you a racial slur.

There are many many problems. 

The end.

I love this game, but as of now I cannot recommend Foxhole to someone else in its current state. In a game that demands so much of your time, it is far too easy for bad actors to ruin days if not weeks worth of time in potentially minutes. The developers have come so far in their ability to offer robust and different game mechanics to a niche community eager to explore these concepts, but fall completely flat in giving the players the tools to adequately protect their assets from others  on their own team who would see their efforts burn.

Foxhole is a truly great concept, but at the time of this writing has poor execution due to it's shortcomings in both moderation of its player-base as well as not giving the players the proper means to protect their own assets in a way that isn't akin to a second job. This game does not respect your time already.. This makes it insult-to-injury when hours of work evaporate with no trace as to why. And when probable cause is truly found, seemingly nothing is ever done. It is a MMO with no external authentication, with a different identity being a simple steam name-change away, and the developers have time and time again stayed silent regarding these matters to the point where I could compare the state of things to the Wild West.

I want to get excited about playing Foxhole, but these barriers to the fun have created an aversion that destroys further desire to play. The developers have shown their ability to listen, given enough feedback- so hopefully this gets their attention. My wishes are to be able to return to this review and reverse my decision. I sincerely want things to improve- not for the game to die.
Damn machines taking my job!!

As a veteran of this title with nearly 3800h spent in the game I honestly cannot recommend it.

TLDR:
The Bad:
- no in-game moderation, hardly anyone (if anyone) is dedicated to handling reports, no in-game oversight in cases of cheating.
- developers don't care about the community, interact with it or listen to it.
- secondary accounts are used to enter the enemy faction and can wreak havoc easily with game mechanics allowing that to happen.
- poor new player experience, outdated tutorial.

The Mixed:
- game heavily focused on interacting with people/working with people.
- niche game, might not fit everyone, not really geared towards casual players. (long crafting timers, buildings producing the good stuff need upkeep)
- questionable balancing to say the least.

The Good:
- said niche is rather unique, you are just a single player in the sea of many and need to work with others to achieve anything, giving a realistic experience of being "just a cog in the war machine"
- complicated logistics system is rather interesting, as is the equipment with each faction having entire arsenals unique to them.

The Long Read Edition:
The developers of this game have been ignoring the voices of the community that attempts to highlight the problems with this product, such as:
- The absolute lack of Moderation.
The punishment system in this game consists of other players making reports that might get reviewed and handled... or not, the studio is small so it has a very small (if any) amount of people dedicated to this specific task.
Reports - when spammed in a sufficient amount in-game - can get you automatically banned for a period of time ranging from 30 minutes to about 2 months, making the system prone to abuse, it has been used to vote-ban people before. (allowing groups to target specific individuals or using their numbers to suppress other groups)
You cannot report enemy faction's players nor can you communicate with the enemy faction as the [ALL] chat that allowed it was removed, so if you see a cheater? Send a support ticket and pray.

There are no moderators in-game, there was a system of game moderators that were drawn from the community, however once upon a time one of them decided to become the equivalent of an AC-130 during an enemy operation and unleash hell from above using their ability to fly and spawn any item they wanted.
Needless to say, community moderators ceased to exist shortly after that and devs took on the game moderation upon themselves.
Given how many complaints there are in places like Reddit or even the reviews here, I'll leave you - dear reader - to formulate the opinion on how well they are handling that yourself.
Personally? I would say that I am still waiting for any serious effort to be put into that, but I've quit the game months ago.

- Alting - alting consists of a player buying this game on another Steam account, logging into the enemy faction and harming the other faction via their actions.
For example - alts can ruin days of someone's progress by stealing expensive or time-costly items and despawning (dropping them on the ground until the server cleans them up) them or getting in someone's tank and driving it into the enemy frontline, getting it killed (bear in mind the most powerful tanks can take a literal day to build and supply)
Why? Why not, you won't get punished for it, even when your identity was revealed due to the above report system and moderation issues.

- Cheating - (thankfully) seems to be a minor issue as alting is easier and less risky for a much larger effect.
Before EAC was added to this game, I met a dude that would reduce his respawn timer to 0 and would also blatantly use a wallhack and an aimbot.
I can't tell whether (or if) the introduction of EAC helped in that regard, I hope it did, but if you do meet one, pray that your reports get answered.

- Underwhelming new player experience - When you join the game, you spawn in the Home Island of your faction, where the tutorial area was largely untouched since around 2018, result being that you as a new player can enter the actual game lacking basic knowledge, thankfully there are good people that dedicate their free time to either sitting in world chat or in the Home Island and teaching the newbies actually useful stuff, but that's not always the case and cannot be relied upon.
Personally, I don't mind being thrown into deep water, but I believe everyone deserves to learn the game their way, so a good tutorial is very important.

The lack of communication with the Dev team leads to them adding features that are either completely against what the community asked for or something that the community did not consider more important than more critical issues, like the need for better equipment balance, implementing a system that tackles AFK players taking up server slots and more serious measures being taken against alting and more.

Now this is a mixed bag so it's entirely dependent on how you look at it and individual experience:
- A major part of the game's experience comes from the community - from the minor chats with people to people forming clans and having experiences that draw them closer to each other.
But of course not every social interaction will be like that as the community has severe issues with toxicity and it can range from being great to being one of the most petty and vile.
- The game is rather niche and requires quite a bit of time investment if the player wishes to achieve something "significant".
for example: taking a town can be a lightning fast strike or a WW1 level attrition war with tens of thousands of artillery shells being fired over the course of battle.
This makes the game not particularly geared towards casual players, as just making the resources and producing a decent tank can take hours whereas making a base and upgrading it takes days.
A casual player with say 1-2 hours available each day can get by by doing simpler tasks like playing infantry or joining a clan/receiving equipment for free as sometimes groups make a production run of those and give their surplus away or just hopping aboard a vehicle if the crew finds itself short handed and needs someone to fill a slot.
- Balancing can be hit or miss and the dev team can also be hit or miss regarding how they tackle that.

Now despite the criticism, I would like to point out that the game has good (or also mixed, depending on your perspective) features that can make it enjoyable.

- The game features an interesting and a rather niche form of gameplay with the player character being a minor, individually insignificant part of the world, a "cog in the war machine" that must cooperate with others to achieve anything, for example: to operate a tank, someone has to drive it, someone has to operate the gun, someone has to command (not always) and finally - as is the case with pretty much any combat vehicle - someone has to provide logistical assistance with fuel, repair materials etc, all of which are a result of someone's work, making cooperation and interaction with the community a quintessential part of the game.
- The equipment each faction has is rather unique, while it leads to balancing issues, it is overall interesting with each faction having a relatively unique loadout available to tackle enemy forces with.

Overall, the game has it's moments, but the negatives and how they've been allowed to persist through the years outweigh the positives and thus make me not recommend this title.
