When I first started playing this game. I was overwhelmed at the complexity, the camaraderie and gameplay. Now, at just over 60 hours in, it did not take me long to see the toxicity and lack of developer engagement in this game.

Simply put, they only care about their "vision" of the game.

What this has led to is alting (the act of a second account to sabotage the enemy team), griefing, and faction loyalism to a toxic degree. Repeat offenders are not banned, and the previously implemented player moderation system was abused so horribly that it was removed from the game.

Without commenting on the state of the social media surrounding this game, I will say that initially there is a lot of promise and fun to be had. However, due to the players and lack of developer action, it has devolved into a game that is not fun for players, new and old alike. This was made especially clear with the release of 1.0.

Save your time and mental health and play elsewhere.
"For the War Effort!"

I absolutely love this game, despite it having a hit or miss community---do yourself a favor and find a nice regiment to join so you have a concrete support system, otherwise expect the Clan Man to shit on you a bit.

While the gameplay is fun and in many ways totally unique, every single aspect of this title compounds into an experience where any investment is punished.

If you want to take part in months-long events where weeks of grueling work from dozens or even hundreds of people can be undone by just a single bad actor sabotaging their own team with nothing but features the developers themselves intend, look no further than Foxhole.

If you want to witness firsthand a company that is entirely complicit in allowing content creators, clan leaders, and other influential figures to bully and harass their own teammates, even as far as mass vote-banning people they disagree with in place of real ingame moderation, look no further than Foxhole.

If you want to join a self-destructive playerbase comprised so entirely of vitriolic echo chambers whose unbridled animosity for the opposite half of their own community is so severe they not only encourage all of this to take place, but actively take part in it, look no further than Foxhole.

This is their "vision"

Playing this game is an exercise in masochism, something that has only gotten worse in the last year. Dont get me wrong, I've played it a ton and I think the core idea is super neat. My issue has to do with how the developers have stewarded their game in the past few years and how they address pressing problems with the game. 

The short answer is that they don't. They don't moderate the game, they don't communicate with the community nearly as much as they should, they don't even address or even acknowledge issues that the community unanimously agrees on like alting. Instead they push rushed updates to grab more money, ban people on reddit for "witchhunting" when evidence of cheating and or alting is raised (and no bans are handed out to said cheaters/alters). I dont even think they play their own game or do any actual QA based on some of the interactions the community had with the dev team during the last devbranch prior to the 1.0 update. 

Theyve taken an interesting stance of community engagement, I think the community agrees that they might want to reconsider considering the mounting backlash against this game and likely their next game, since they show no signs of having learned from their mistakes.
Good game, bad devs.

In an ever changing "REAL" conflict game in-which no two wars are the same (abar for shard one and meta players ;) ). you can visit different ever expanding or declining fronts offering players a huge variety of play styles in a differing locations with FRIENDS and strangers forcing people to come together to adapt and over come different obstacles the game throws in your path. Foxhole is probably one of the closest things we have to a "REAL" war game, but unfortunately where this game falls down on its sword, are some of the things that truly set it apart from other games of the same genre.
  
   You can see how the developers have tried to make things move at different speeds with different techniques for instance having to farm then craft then ship goods and supplies slows a front down. making it so unless players are willing to sacrifise their time they will be fighting a loosing battle to those who do but also creating artificial shortages, much like what we can imagine would of been experienced in war times. which then leads me to my point where this game falls down is that most wars start off with a lot of players and end with a lot of players but in the mean time players come and go and this leads to decaying of bases and the constant upkeep of bases with garrison supplies and that then eating into players actual lives as if your not on within a set period of time your supplies go public and your base decays. (again from the developers side i can see the issue where players will farm a lot and then stop playing and those resources are forever in limbo inaccessible by the current player base who may need them)

   Also seeing alot of other issues where players who are either older players who have lost interest or people buying multiple accounts and games being able to "sabotage" the enemy team by joining with no intention of helping but to hinder and costing people hundreds of hours of work with no real punishment. 

 Added in facilities with the last major update which is all good and well when everyone works together how its insinuated but unfortunately players seem to have a main character syndrome and why would i want to spend literal hours of my real life time when i can let the one guy do all the work and piggy back off of the success helping myself to all the proceeds whilst you see the same few people doing the same boring monotonous work over and over for hours everyday just to "maintain" what they've already spent hours building and then eventually dying off never to be seen in the game again for some other poor player to come and take their place. Wrongly assuming this facility update would be able to give those people a break and they've now ended up having to spend even longer doing the same tasks with no real reward other than to upkeep a necessary base.

  Other things that could be much simpler to address like terrain tool usage and leaving trees blocking roads and pathways hindering players who are the ones who do most of the core work in the game.

  Over all its a great game honestly one of a kind! Everything you would want it to do for a casual it does perfectly (gun play, movement, HUD) but it does need some more heads coming together from the development team and the community as ways to address the real issues this game is currently experiencing. I personally don't want do down vote as i see hope and potential and do truely love the game! good luck game developers! please listen to your community! Not all just a few!

Jut check out the sub on reddit.  This same faction was also mocking the other side for bringing attention to the alt problem.  Now that they lost their lead they are throwing the biggest temper tantrum in history.  This is a solid game, alts are like 1% of the problem.  They should be dealt with though.

This game is one of a kind, with persistence being the basis for everything the game provides, making each victory memorable, each role unique and vital to the general team, but persistence requires persistent gameplay, and as it stands much of the gameplay essential to the team is tedious and a chore. 

This game also suffers from having it's high stakes attract those who recognize the many weaknesses the game's moderation, or lack thereof, that allows for the means to 'alt', which allows for people to use a secondary account to inflict substantial damage to one side with little counterplay. 

Overall, the game is hampered by the hands-off nature of it's moderation, and the failure to address long-standing issues that burns out players and sours the experience as a whole.

The game CAN be fun, there are many roles in the game that are exciting and enjoyable for people of all skill levels, but as the saying goes; A few bad apples spoil the bunch.

I've played Foxhole for quite some time now and have put in a lot of hours in ever aspect of the game. The game has enormous potential and because of this you will see a LOT of people around with thousands of hours in this game. Unfortunately the developers haven't been able to make it work. Foxhole is a very intricate game with a lot of complex systems for building and logistics, all designed to support the combat of the game, this is what makes it unique. Unfortunately the developers have not just failed to address their failures to make the systems work without causing massive amounts of burnout, they have outright refused to. 

Every update builds upon existing problems, adding more content and thus more workload. Due to software limitations they cannot make the servers handle more assets than they already do, which means builders have to fight the game itself in order to keep the assets they built alive. Logisticians are at war with the enemy and their own team for control of the limited resources. Both groups eventually burnout throughout a wars duration because the hours and effort they must put in to help their faction are both numerous and boring. 

You might ask why it is people continue to play when the game and its developers don't respect the time of the player. The answer is that Foxhole is a one of a kind experience that most of us love the idea of, and have had a lot of hope for. We all constantly keep trying to bring in friends to experience it with us, because we have put so much effort into this game and have have had amazing moments. Ultimately though, the longer you play the fewer amazing moments occur, and it just becomes a mental and emotional drain.

As a last note, the game has a significant problem with griefers, alts, and plain abysmal behavior by the player base. The cross-faction and intra-faction is not getting any better, and the developers can't seem to find out how to keep people from making accounts on the opposing team to destroy their painstakingly constructed assets in cheap and unsporting ways. As of this time, unless significant changes occur to improve quality of life I cannot advise anyone purchase Foxhole. If you are still curious, I would suggest staying away from construction or logistics for the sake of your time and mental health.

Devs just dont fucking care about you. 0 quality of life, 0 punishment for alt accounts ruining WEEKS of work with 0 effort, immense mental toll on people doing logistics and engineering, due to the decay mechanic and the very limited ways to counter it. A friend of mine literally logs in EVERY MORNING just to check if his structures are stillup, repair anything that might be suffering from decay and only then goes about his actual IRL day. There is no anti-AFK mechanic, leading to extremely long waitlines to enter a region when spots could definetly be open. 

Also devs have just flatout said they like veterans, or even players with +100 hours leaving the game. They only want your money, and the game almost looks like its built for you to stop playing it after that 100-200 hour mark. Until the devs actually start giving a sh*t about their community and start fixing this game, DO NOT BUY IT

TLDR at the bottom. The game has had its ups and downs throughout the year, but the last 2 years have been slowly adding on to the down part and I cannot recommend it in its current state. The game used to be built on the principle of nobody's actions alone were significant, but as a whole they all mattered. Now the only actions that matter are those of organized in-game clans.

These clans have both the capability and the wherewithal to monopolize most of the game's activities outside of holding a rifle and charging towards a trench. Activities that could reliably be completed in a single play session and/or with a small group of 5 or fewer like building a base, building and driving tanks, assaulting a flank, or doing basically anything that is tangible longer than a few minutes has become virtually impossible due to onerous game mechanics being added that can only be surmounted by collective, organized, and large group effort. The time of the solo and small-group player is over. And the game is not fun without that capability without dumping 3-4 of hours into it every day, which people with schedules can't maintain.

TLDR: The game requires either huge groups of players or 3-4 hours of daily play to accomplish anything making it virtually impossible for people with jobs to play in small groups or by themselves. Do not buy.

The game itself is pretty good, it has a few problems but on the whole as a game it's in the best state it's ever been in.
 
What isn't good is the development team. They have pretty much no communication with the players, and haven't for almost the entire time the game was in early access (over 4 years!). Currently a group of dedicated people are griefing both factions, destroying dozens of hours of work, and - get this - there are no ingame moderators. Players are allowed to report other players, but they can only ban someone for an hour, even if that person was caught red-handed destroying a bunch of the team's stuff. There are literally 5 documented cases of ""friendly"" players with over 100,000 "vehicle self damage", a stat which tracks how many friendly vehicles you have destroyed. A vehicle has between 500-5000 health. These 5 people have destroyed, at the very least, 100 vehicles. And nothing is done about it.

There is also a system - because, again, there are no ingame moderators - by which players can downvote your posts in world chat, but this is one of the most often abused systems in the game and is used to silence people you don't like more frequently than not. 

The only way to get permanently banned from the game is to do map art with building or be one of the very unlucky few who the devs actually bother to ban. Everything else - all forms of cheating, using an enemy team account to destroy friendly vehicles and structures - is just fine.

Foxhole has its fun moments, but over the past few years it keeps getting less an less enjoyable to the point of this game being a second job to some without pay. I will change this review if anything changes for the better but I'm not getting my hopes up anytime soon.

Foxhole is a tricky game to discuss. For a lot of people it's this epic PVP warfest that can go for weeks with the front shifting constantly, others it's a grind-fest plagued with griefers and cheaters hampering all the fun. So for me I'll give my won 2 cents from how I've seen it go.

Early to mid-game is this fast dynamic battlefield, people throwing ideas out at the wall to see if it will work. Barges of riflemen running down the shore because there are no gunboats yet, massive zergs of grenadiers rushing bases because there is no big heavy tanks or artillery to fill that role, or massive columns of men trying to flanking bases before AI tech makes them into nothing but shoes and goo. This is the fun time.
But as we go later into the game this stops, lines either stagnant or breakdown to the point a whole hex can be overran because so much time and resources are stretched just to keep the front line intact. Anything other than the highest tech'd resource heavy armor gets used and anything not that tends to stick in the back lines, unwilling or unable to move forward to push a point. The game turns into attrition where the first gun fired might be the only one needed. People get burnt out, others turn to sabotage, fingers get pointed, morale shifts on a dime, clans abandon sites. 
Could the devs do more? Absolutely. Both sides suffer from a litany of issues that can be addressed, people have reported what the issues are, have offered up solutions to help, but there has been no dialogue. If this review tells you anything it's this: It's fun at the start but the longer you dig your heels in, the less enjoyable it probably will become.

Welp, played an additional 3285 hours since my last review xD

Foxhole is a one of a kind MMO, or even a dream MMO for some (like me). Many features of Foxhole simply can't be found in any other games such as the persistent warfare, player driven logistics and free building. It has immense potential, yet falls so short of its expectations.

The team behind Foxhole is an indie team, and no one expects an AAA quality game from them with so little budget. However, Siege Camp (the developers behind Foxhole) simply do not seem to care about player feedback.

Faction imbalances, griefers/alts (ruining your hours of work), server issues and core gameplay bugs continue to exist. Increasingly tedious and time-consuming gameplay loops continue to be added (such as Facilities) that make you spend more time maintaining your virtual base than your day job.

The century war (100th war) only served to exemplify these issues. Fresh accounts with **20 ban records** continue to be free to go around ruining people's gameplay. Server lag/crashes are frequent and the last dev message was 3 weeks ago on something unrelated to Foxhole.

Foxhole has been a blast and I write this review with great pain as I really hope the issues are one day fixed. However, I am unable to recommend this game as of now

Foxhole i love you and i hate you. 

One thousand hours within a single year and only now did my eyes open.

Lets begin at the start. You freshly bought the game. Installed it and fired it up.
Greeted by the option to join either one of the two factions  Warden and Colonial. 
It doesn't really matter which faction you choose and once selected you will enter a game unlike any other.
 
The posibillities are endless for it all is one huge sandbox in which you can do what you fancy at the time. 
Front line warfare, gathering resources, weapon production, vehicle production, base building, trench digging, tank driving artillery firing, or just be good 'ol cannon fodder, you name it. 

You can do anything you fancy for all those things have to be done by someone. Let me explain.
Every iten in the game has been build by either you or another player. Made by materials people gathered from the map. 
Want a box of standard ammunition?  The poduction process goes as follows 
1. Raw scrap material is farmed at the scrap field. 
2. Transported by truck towards the refinery. 
3. Processed into basic materials. 
4. Basic materials are then transported towards a factory.
5. Factory turns the basic materials into what ever product you so desire, this time we choose 7.62 rifle ammo.
6. Receive the crated ammo which is then driven by truck to where ever it is needed. 

As you can see this process is lengthy and very time consuming and requires effort. 
Players spending hours upon hours driving back and forth making items and hauling them to the front lines to be used either by you or your fellow faction players.

Yet within the system there lies a problem. 

Public stockpiles. 
As the name would suggest. Public stockpiles are places in which crated materials and vehicles can be put for later use. 
This is either in a storage depot or a seaport. Both physical buildings within the game of which there are many. 
Simply drive your logistics truck up to it. Click upon the desired items the front lines require and and drive it back for players to use. Anyone of the same faction has access to it. Which also means those who bought the game with ill intent. 

And out of all the hours i have played have i neved seen as much ill intent combined as this latest war.
The problem? Alt accounts.  Freshly created steam accounts, which have purchased a copy of the game to actively sabotage the opposite faction. Is your main faction losing? Then the alts wreak havoc by gathering as much valuable things they can from the public stockpiles only to destroy them by dumping it all into the sea. An act done in less than a blink of an eye with hours and hours of time and effort wasted of the player who created it.  Countless of video evidence has been submitted of acts such as these to the developers. Tanks which take hours to build, Containers filled to the brim with stuff and pallets of artillery shells dumped into the water by non ranked ( level 0 ) players. Accounts that have been reported time and time again for such deeds still free to do the things they do without being  perma banned. The problem goes completely ignored. 

As an all round player doing front line warfare and logistics this is infuriating. Knowing that all the time spend can be just wasted away or handed out to the opposite faction for their own advantage in a matter of minutes when no one else is looking. 

Until the developers come up with a working solution for these problems my review will remain negative, of which i had no joy of writing this. 

For the game is so nice if only the developers cared more about it.
Devman Bad

All that and the game is being a slog after 1.0 with all the facilities bs and make logistic/builder gameplay worse. 

If you buy it with a discount you will probably still get your worth of fun in the first two weeks, but after that you might become a salty person like everyone else eventually.

Reviewer info: 800 hours of playtime before writing this. Rank: Major. Played in both factions. Actively playing as a Warden at the moment.

Let me start by saying that Foxhole is a unique and highly addictive gaming experience. 
It's positives: 
1) Huge scale wars, cool lore, an extremely helpful and newby friendly community. 
2) Entertaining combat mechanics. 
3) Infantry, tanks, artillery, gunboats, trains and advanced logistics.
4) Advanced building mechanics. You can even build fortresses and huge Storm Cannons.

HOWEVER, i CANNOT recommend this game anymore. 

The unresolved issue of alt account griefers cannot be ignored. Both factions have had a number of ''bad apples'' who use their alt accounts on the opposing faction, in order to grief on backline facilities and harass their production. Hundreds of hours of work can easily be razed to the ground in minutes.... Thousands of complaints and reports have been submitted to the dev team but they choose to ignore the issue... Even when alts account get caught on video, they get a 2 days long ban and then they can go back to their evil habits... On the contrary, RPing situations like checkpoints or fist fighting arenas can get you permanently banned...lol... 

In summary, this game has been fun and could be great. However, you should stay away until the devs decide to actually solve the many issues that ruin the experience. At it's current state, it aint worth it....
The game I always wanted but never knew it existed until a friend told me about it.

Some people don't have the time to play truck driving simulator, and even when I do, its boring and feels like a waste of time.

This game is a blast, but the Devs are tone deaf to their community - I do not recommend buying the game until they decide to address issues the community has brought forward (with solutions!) and decide to do next to nothing or a half-measure of moderation/attempt at fixing the game's problems.

-ALTing - buying a second copy for greifing the other team or destroy vital infrastructure or supplies to undermine the war effort.

-Multiboxing - Kinda the same as ALTing but for one team - used to crew an entire tank, push gun, artillery, etc - basically you're playing World of tanks at that point and the fun of teamwork is lost

-Hacking - Several instances have arisen where hackers kill players who are WELL outside visible range (night mostly)

-Logistic problems - Many Quality of Life fixes have been made but facilities and other means of creating supplies is just a pain at some times as well as drawing supplies out of storage - an operation can take several hours to set up for only the tactical advantage to be lost within that timeframe of staging.

-Home Island and training - IS SEVERELY OUTDATED AND NEEDS A REVAMP - needs to force new players to actually learn mechanics and not just jump in and mess about and cause their team more harm than help - let the clans submit training material its not hard to get this right...

-Dev 'solutions' - Some of the solutions devs have pushed are undermined or outright ignored and push a new tank variant in players faces as a bait and switch, only for it to be terrible or overpowered - the return of BTs and their variants.

-Localization - as of today (Feb 10 2023) Russian players JUST got a chance to buy the game and have flooded front lines with inexperience and a massive language barrier between other players. This has resulted in many instances where people shoot each other out of frustration or unwillingness to cooperate, meanwhile devs have raved about language packs and chat filters to allow only certain languages to be read - this hurts the community and you cant cooperate if you cant communicate, I have to learn basic russian now to even get a chance to help these guys

‚Äã

TL:DR - Game GOOD, Devs are the step-father you never wanted, and just simply watch as bad things happen to the community and does very little to reprimand those who/what causes trouble.

This game can be fun. It is definitely unique. And the playerbase is very dedicated. Unfortunately, it is currently marred by incredibly unresponsive devs, a recent update that has gated A LOT of the end game equipment to clans that can have people online 24/7, and it is an MMO with practically 0 moderation. If you want a similar combat experience, play Running with Rifles, if you want a similar (or better) logistical experience, play Satisfactory or Factorio. But in its current state I cannot recommend this game.

The trailers do not show what it is like for an individual soldier. Solos can barely contribute to logistics now, and all the cool vehicles/weapons are something that, once again, only extremely large clans can create and use.

If I had a dollar for an amazing concept let down by a totally incompetent dev team, I might be able to make my own game.

But what a cool concept, right? A persistent war game where you can your buddies can get some  Ã∂rÃ∂eÃ∂dÃ∂ green vs blue action! You fight with player made guns, tanks, etc against teams of people from all over the world 24/7!

Except instead of making their own custom engine for the game they Frankenstein'd another one that doesn't work well with the scale. The people you are fighting? Yeah its the internet so they are incredibility toxic and full of cheaters that the devs outright refuse to moderate or do anything about.

But still fun with friends right? It would be if there weren't constant exploits and greifers throwing away days of hard work, something plaguing the game for years, that the devs still outright refuse to do anything about.

That PvP faction action? Both sides are just a color scheme right? Wrong, devs thought it was a good idea to give different and wholly unbalanced toys to either side. The devs also outright refuse to do any proper balance either through incompetence/unwillingness or listen to community feedback.

To top it all off the devs also rushed the game, a completely unfinished, bugged riddled, and unbalanced PvP product to '1.0' and have outright refused to bugfix/moderate etc but instead add more unbalanced shiny toys as the fugg off to their newest game to repeat the cycle(Hint hint: Don't buy Anvil)

So tl;dr- great concept- trash devteam. Avoid it and all of their future products.

Foxhole is a complicated game, and I sympathise with the devs of a small studio trying to get this novel concept off the ground, but frankly I can't recommend the game in its current state. The game is just a burnout machine, and increasingly so with every new patch. The systems encourage players to play more and more until something breaks them (the awkward logistics, blatant cheating, complete lack of communication from the devs...). What the game chiefly needs is community management and active moderation, both of which are sorely lacking, and would help keep the playerbase and community alive, instead of cycling new players every time there's a sale. You only have to look at the steam active players to see the issue, and read the reviews of others with similar playtime.

If you do play, I recommend tagging in with a casual clan and avoid getting too invested into the wars themselves.

I'll start by saying this game is unique and there truly isn't another like it. You definitely can get many hours of enjoyment out of it, but it is plagued many issues that aren't immediately apparent to a new player.

The idea of this game has the possibility to become incredibly popular, but I don't think the developers are competent enough to lead the way for this emerging genre of persistent warfare. The game is incredibly janky, and engine limitations mean you will have to wait for hours in queues to get into the most active fronts. The map is divided into hexes, and each hex has a maximum capacity of around 200 players. This means there is a hard cap on the amount of players that can be playing and the closer you get to that cap the more laggy and glitchy the game becomes. You will be plagued with frequent disconnects, rubber banding, and desyncs. The engine and servers simply cannot handle large amounts of players which really puts a damper on the idea of "massive persistent warfare." The devs current solution to this problem is to open multiple shards when there is a large influx of players, but much of the community considers the main shard to be the "true war" which leaves you wondering why you're investing so much time on an alternate shard when the outcome doesn't matter. It also goes against the whole point of the game which is to be one massive persistent war. 

There are also many issues with certain mechanics in the game. I'll start with building as it is an integral part of the game, if no one is building and fortifying bases you're faction will get steamrolled. Basically building gameplay boils down to collecting materials and holding down LMB. Infact it is often recommend to turn on click lock while building because it takes hours to build a simple tier 2 bunker base, and once you want to scale up to a concrete base it starts feeling like a second job. The amount of time needed is insane. Obviously the time requirement can be lessened with multiple people working on a base, but currently there is a shortage of people willing to build because the gameplay is atrocious. There are also many advanced building techniques that are not well documented, so it's very easy for new builders to build a base that will most likely die immediately to the enemy. Then there is the issue of supplying your base once it's built. Because of engine limitations, the devs have implemented a decay system to limit the amount of structures in a hex. The only way to prevent a base from decaying is to supply it with a certain item that is produced at factories. Because everybody needs this item for their base, the queues at the factory are often maxed out and it could take hours or even days to get enough of this item to supply the base for a week. If you want your base to operate the entire war this will be your life, collect materials for garrison supplies, add your order to the factory, supply base, repeat. This process causes burnout very quick which is why you'll often see abandoned decaying bases in the mid and back lines.

Next up is Logistics. You'll often hear people say that Logi wins wars and that's cause it's true. If no one is supplying the front line you'll find yourself having to fight the enemy with pistols and no more respawns. While logi gameplay can be very rewarding, it is very repetitive. The logistics chain boils down to farm resources, refine materials, produce supplies, deliver to frontline. While you can do all of these it is generally considered inefficient and time consuming so you'll generally see people only farming and refining, or producing and delivering. The people delivering to the frontlines are always going to be the ones getting commends, but it's important to remember that none of it happens with out the other parts of the chain. Farming resources is much like building, just hold down LMB and watch some YouTube. Some might enjoy this, but for me it turns into a repetitive grind really fast. There's also other often overlooked logi tasks such as, refueling fuel containers, preventing decay of backline base, and refueling salvage mines. There is also the new facility gameplay, but I can't really give an opinion on them as I don't use them, but generally they seem to suffer from the same decay problem that bunker bases do.

Now for combat. Generally I think combat is fun, but there are some issues. The top down perspective of the game is charming, but it can cause issues with aiming at enemies that are behind cover. You can find yourself in a situation where you can't hit an enemy in a trench, but they can hit you in your trench. This is definitely subjective, but I believe grenade spam is an issue as well it's too easy for one player to effectively zone out a massive area with gas grenades. Moving across rocky terrain is incredibly janky because it's hard to get a sense of if you can jump over certain rocks or not. These are just some minor issues, there's also balance issues as well but I won't get into them here.

For the last part of my review I'd like to talk about alts. I truly believe this is one of the worst things in the game currently as it allows one person to completely destroy a factions stockpiles. Basically a player will buy a second copy of the game and joining the opposing faction to sabotage their stockpiles. All the alt has to do is grab a truck full of supplies, or a tank and drive it into water to destroy it. There is very little recourse players can do to fight against it, and the devs have been choosing to ignore it even though it's against the code of conduct. Its been a growing problem over the years and only seems to be getting worse.

Overall I can't recommend the game in it's current state. Even though it is unique there are just too many problems currently to make it rewarding enough for the time invested.

Game is amazingly complex and offers experience that you simply can not get anywhere else.

Oh boy. Where to start...
This game has insane potential and the vast majority of it is being wasted.
Playing in a large environment with hundreds of other players where everything is player-made is incredibile. It can be very fulfilling and very frustrating at times, but definitely worth the time.
Combat is engaging even if the learning curve is steep, but once mastered a few concept one can easily feel like actively contributing to a front. Every faction has his own unique load out with some option more viable than others: someone likes the asymmetry, others complain that sometimes it's too much.
Artillery is amazing. Even just loading shells while under counter artillery fire is lit.
Tanks are very fun. Again some can dislike the asymmetry (with tanks is sometimes more evident for obvious reasons)but playing in a tank line while the infantry is pushing is really something.
Boats are basically non existent (just 2 models, but there are rumours of some future naval update) and not very viable.
Building...oh man. Not only it requires basically a degree in foxhole physics and engineering and a long amount of time, but upkeep cost are out of scale. During long wars is impossible to maintain big bases if you have not a consistent flow of material and people to help out. More than anything you have to come up with anti-griefing solution cause the game doesn't provide anything in that regards.
Why then a negative review? Speaking with more experienced players than me (literally thousands of hours) I realised that the game is affected by the same bugs/glitch/exploit since 50 wars ago. Yeah a lot of critical issue were solved, but a series of long standing bugs is still there. 
The servers of this game are dogshit. No other way to put it. 9/10 times on high pop frontline hex get lags spikes and random dc on both faction. How the hell an MMO is supposed to work without proper servers?
Late game lack some serious firepower.Sure nukes are in game, but spotting rules are just ridicolous (and largely exploitable turn out) and Super Heavy Tank are a joke, more of a resource dump than an effective weapon.
Alting and griefing has seen an exponential rise in war 100, on both factions. There was no addressing the issue by the Devs. Imaging working hard to have enough resources to build whatever you want to build and then seeing a no rank driving your tank in the river. And then reading in local that he has been doing the same for the past days, being banned a couple of days each time.
Last but not least there's a severe lack of communication by the Devs. Don't know why, but i don't think you can maintain a healthy MMO if you don't communicate with your playerbase. Hell, it looks like there isn't even active modding on the server (atm only ABLE server is up). They only communicate when major update comes out, and even then they just address the new content and not others issue that the community brings up.
TL;DR game has potential but is not followed by its own devs it seems. Play it at your own risk because, very unfortunately, I don't think is going to last long. Hope to be very wrong.

Here's an updated review and holy cow does this game have issues.

The Devs aren't great. There is basically no communication to or from the team and very little ingame moderation outside of a horrific chat censor that is impossible to turn off (and censors such classics as "basement" and "therapy"). 

Alternate accounts and above all dedicated griefing accounts are given at worst temporary bans. Blatant griefing accounts (dumping thousands of hours of material into the ocean publicly) can go days without interruption and since the game can be refunded there's minimal financial expenditure or time investment required.

As for the game itself? it's a mess.

Holes in the map everywhere. Hope you set your spawn before you found one!

Nuke mechanics don't work, both of the nukes launched in this war (war 100) have been due to bugs or exploits. There is basically no other way to launch a nuke currently.

Voice comms (essential for playing a team game like this) are constantly breaking requiring restarts and returning you to the home island. This means you often need to wait half an hour or more to get back to the fight.

The building is great! Provided you have hours to actually build anything. Oh and you then need to babysit anything that's not concrete because fire is not balanced at all. And if you want concrete it takes ages of babysitting to get to it and it requires a stupid amount of components (used to make Rmats (the material used to make tanks and heavy weapons)) which take hours to mine and are difficult to obtain at the best of times.


On the subject of building: Gsup/Bsup consumption/production is still an issue. If you want to build anything with actual defences prepare to spend hours each day playing click-a-box in a back line town to print stupid pointless cans of "my building is actually doing something, please don't delete it".

The shooting mechanics are great, but buggy. Its very difficult to actually hit a target in any form of cover and the practice of "shadow dancing" (running around in circles then using quick aim (0.5 seconds of 100% accuracy) to clap people) isn't fun and it doesn't fit. 

Balance is beyond awful.

Colonial super tank is useless and basically nobody will build it.

Colonial heavy field gun (the stygian) will one or two tap anything short of a BT (battle tank, takes 24 hours to build and will still probably be crippled first shot). The warden equivalent (the stockade) is unusable due to limited range and underwhelming firepower. 

There's much more I could write here. Like how the colonials lack a decent early game PVE tool, how the colonial static weapons (aside from the ISG) are awful, how the boma is broken as hell, how the osprey is a pile of trash, but the devs (again) either know this and don't care or don't know this because they do not listen to community feedback.


Long story short: Devman bad. Game fun for few hours but not fun after. Do not buy game. Stay away. Spend money on good titles.

My story first time playing this game: So after install I loaded up the game and selected Wardens as my faction. After messing around a bit on the home island I asked in chat "where is a new player needed what area needs men" and in the text chat "GO FIGHT FOR THE HOLY LAND" and "GO TO ABANDONED WARD IN THE DEADLANDS AND FIGHT FOR CALLAHAN" appeared. So I spawned in grabbed a gun and helped push back the Colonials to Iron's End and we almost pushed them back to Callahan's Gate before they counter attacked and a back and forth battle began before I knew it 8 hours had gone by. My first war was war 87 and it was glorious wish I had gotten the game sooner since I got the game about 2 weeks into 87
Met some really cool people in this game willing to help a new player out especially when it came to the logistics side of the game.
-Pros-
*Theres alot of ways to contribute to help your side win by doing logistics, combat or by building stuff and the thing I like is that no matter what your doing it feels like what you do matters and has impact on the game every little bit helps *everything in this game from guns, tanks, artillery to ammo and so on was built or sourced from other players.
*large persistent war with 30-40 players on each side is cool being on the frontline for the first time theres no experience like it the joys of taking that first town or point with your alliance is amazing.
*the play area is pretty big and there always something going on with 6 or 7 front line zones you'll find combat pretty fast
*taking it easy and doing logistics helping supply the front is also a cool experience

-not really cons but stuff to look out for-
*I recommend watching Moidawg on Youtube and watching some tutorials on the game so your not totally lost on some of the more complex parts of the game 
*this game takes alot of coordination from other players while the game is fairly solo friendly some late game tanks and Artillery takes dedicated clans to build and maintain.
*people complain about alts all the time and I think I can count on two hands how many times I've seen a player alting or trying to sabotage there own alliance don't be a paranoid Badman Larry and think every new player is an alt.
*the community has its toxic and hateful players but by and large the Foxhole community is great, welcoming and friendly.

-CONS!-

The game is fantastic if you've got a few friends to run around with, it's a game where logistics and strategy matter and a week of planning can come together into something truly incredible. Grand strategy aside, it's also has a lot of wonderful emergent gameplay and some of my best stories have come from nights I was just on to dick around for a little while. 

People can get try-hard esk ala Eve Online, but not everyone is that way. Look on the Discord, plenty of smaller casual clans. 

Set boundaries for yourself. as it's an easy game to lose entirely too much time in if you chase the grind. 

All in all, if you enjoy being part of a slow burn, long-running, community experience this'll be a great game for you. If you want some lightning action and quick resolution maybe take a look at another title.

It's a decent game, the issue is it encourages grinding, but then makes grinding an absolute hell:
- There is a bunch of settings and game design choices to ensure that players do not Grief... but they don't accomplish their tasks at all, simply because nobody fears Moderators. - You can never truly work in your own bubble, you HAVE to get other players to just "sit" next to you to accomplish many tasks.
- You have to click every few seconds to accomplish many tasks, which just encourages RSI or downloading an Auto-clicker which is technically against their Code Of Conduct. "This encompasses things such as input broadcasting tools." But literally every player gets one because it's stupid otherwise.
- If you disconnect in a vehicle you get sent to the Shadow realm, and Die in-game.
- If you disconnect more than twice in a minute you get "Too many deployments, try again later" Straight up not allowing u to play.

If you have always wanted to feel like a short-lived soldier in the World War, learn from your own experience what PTSD is and get lost in the constant chaos of logistics, lack of supplies, misunderstanding of the game mechanics even after 100 hours of play and the constant horror of war, then this game is for you.

Foxhole is a massively multiplayer online game that puts players in the role of soldiers fighting in a persistent online world. The game has been described as a "war simulation" that offers a unique and intense gaming experience unlike anything else on the market.

One of the standout features of Foxhole is the level of realism and attention to detail that has been put into the game. Players must work together to capture territories and defend their gains, with resources and reinforcements being managed and supplied by players in real-time. The game is set in a beautiful, immersive world with stunning graphics and a deeply engaging storyline that keeps players coming back for more.

Another key aspect of Foxhole is the social aspect of the game. Players must work together and communicate effectively in order to be successful in the game. There are many different strategies that players can employ to win battles and capture territories, and the community is incredibly active and supportive, providing players with the resources they need to be successful.

In conclusion, Foxhole is a truly unique and exciting game that offers a level of realism and immersion that is unparalleled in other online games. Whether you're a fan of strategy games or just looking for a new online experience, Foxhole is definitely worth checking out.

Foxhole is simultaneously the source of one of my greatest experiences in gaming in the past 10 years, and a great game and great concept marred by several flaws. 

Pulled by peer pressure into the Colonial faction during the last days of War 96, I began my Foxhole experience under heavy artillery fire, spawning in a town base with my fellow Collies. A few things caught my attention almost instantly. This was the first game where people were so willing to use their mics and speak. Men called out for fire support, enemy positions and movements, officers took charge and led desperate countercharges to blunt the Warden advance even as we lost trench after trench, pillbox after pillbox, with nothing but rifle, stickies and Bomas in hand. The war truly came alive for me then, dragged into a massive Dunkirk scenario where we were charged with holding the line as we evacuated the seaport of valuable supplies, and pulled out our vehicles to avoid a complete encirclement and loss. Foxhole gave me stories to tell my friends that I had never had before. It introduced me to its wonderful community of veterans that I had managed to integrate with, and fight alongside in hopeless charges, desperate defenses, daring raids and rousing victories.

Side note: I still remember the first ever armored action I took part in, a six hour tank graveyard just outside The Blemish as an armored car gunner, helping to keep anti-tank infantry off allied tanks. I remember most fondly the hospitality of the random SSgt that took me under his wing and commanded our small detachment of ACs and medium tanks to a resounding victory.

In a game where artillery pieces take two men minimum and three optimally to fire, where tank drivers require callouts from their commanders and gunners to function; vehicle crews and small squads function all at once. Things go smoothly or horribly wrong in a second- tanks can get swarmed, surrounded and ambushed. Infantrymen take two or three shots to kill, and bleeding mechanics keep Leeroy Jenkins-es at bay. You learn first to unlearn the FPS mentality of charge in, take the fight and damn the consequences, then learn again to seize opportunities, be daring and inspire your fellow comrades to turn the fight back in your favor. 

I had the distinction and honor of fighting alongside remarkable men and women all around the world that I would not have had the chance to meet elsewhere, shoulder to shoulder rushing trenches with bayonets fixed, shouting commands in tanks as we took part in massive tank line battles, or simply chatting with as we brought logistics from the backline to a nearly cut off frontline base. There is a sense of solidarity and friendship that I have so rarely experienced anywhere else online with strangers that I found comforting. In the next wars or so I found my calling, as a frontline battle medic. I indulged my inner rambo at times, charging into fire to save downed teammates, picking up weapons off the corpses on the ground to make my last stands with my Collie brothers in arms. As a lesser-picked but valuable role, I never once felt like what I did was not impactful. No matter how small of a cog in the machine I was, I still felt vital, be it to the squad, or to the front that I fought with. 

It's no surprise then that I got heavily invested into the game. During the next few wars, I started to get more serious with the game, learning advanced mechanics and the complicated internal politics of clan alliances, high commands that ran the show from behind the curtain, tagging along risky operations with bigger, heavier toys and staggering logistics requirements that took days to prepare. These operations were amazing, regardless of the outcome, but I also got to see some of the dark sides of Foxhole (that any other community would reasonably face). 

Alting, toxicity, divisions along clan lines, my experiences were consistent with that of many other reviewers. Not only that, logistics and facilities are a drain to do. I remember at one point spending my entire free day farming up supplies and materials for the front, only to realize I would have to spend 10 hours a day, every day, if I wanted to play with the big toys that larger clans could muster. Until then, I could only hope to be lucky and join an open call for a battle tank if I wanted one, or forced my small band of friends to grind with me until we got a battle tank of our own. 

Yes, one could say this is by design. You aren't meant to make the super heavy behemoths on your own and en masse spam them everywhere. If you did want to play in one of those big tanks you could always ask, that is true. This is where divisions and the aforementioned problems come into play though. Big clans won't give you a battle tank for free. You have to be trustworthy enough for them to let you have one. Yes, whereas crewing one doesn't really demand much in terms of credentials or credibility, but if said big clans don't operate in your timezone, you're out of luck unless you really band together people to do just that. I couldn't blame a big clan for guarding their prizes though, these expensive monsters are amazing to play, can turn the tide of losing fronts, but are also made with the blood sweat and tears of dozens of people across weeks. Losing all that to someone that turned out to be an alt, or a numbskull, it hurts. This isn't helped by the long, inane logistics systems. Take fuel production for instance. Nowadays, if you want to bring diesel in to power a facility, you would have to, as a solo player or a small clanman: get scrap with a truck or flatbed, refine into diesel, get a flatbed to transport a fuel container that needs to be filled at a refinery with your diesel and drive down to your facility, to get perhaps 2-3 hours of operation power depending on what you want to do. Following that, there are garrison supplies to queue to transport, basic materials to refine and transport, all of which requiring specialized equipment to efficiently haul their base components to refine, and specialized transport equipment like shipping crates and ships to bring to the designated location. 

This massive investment is possible as a solo man, but rarely done- only highly dedicated players take on the task of producing and running their own facilities, producing their own specialized equipment, etc. You have to join a large clan to play with some of the tools of war then. Now there isn't anything inherently wrong with that, but these commitments stack, and ultimately drain you day by day, if you invest your heart into the war. Scrap gathering is calming, therapeutic, even. I loved hammering away and scrooping with my fellow logimen. But scrap gathering day after day to keep your clan's facilities running feels more like a second job than a game. 

Given all this of course, you don't have to get into the logi game if you don't want to. You can choose to do whatever you want to do- though the tradeoff is that you may not get to play with ALL the things in the game that you want to. That doesn't take away from the fact that I love this game. It's a grind, as all MMOs tend to be, but it's fun, rewarding and the most unique experience I have had in a long time. Though, one job is quite enough for me, so I'm taking a temporary break from the war, and making a promise to not get so involved in the war when I do return. 

The memories I had from this game are something else, as are the wonderful personalities I met while serving in the Colonial Legion and the Warden Army. I hope to return to the fold soon, now as a Second Lieutenant with enough experience to bumble my way through commanding a line or help my fellow comrades learn the game. 

If you remember that this is just a game, and treat your fellow men with respect and patience, you will go far in Foxhole, and this game will be well worth the money and time you spend in it.

Foxhole is 90% work, 10% play. 
Most days both midweek and weekend you're sitting in a queue for 20-60+ mins to get into a frontline hex, even during night shift when the player count is super low there's still a queue.
Constant bugs: lately mass disconnects, 
30 seconds-1 minute respawn timers if you're playing frontline infantry.

You build a base/facility, and are required to feed it Garrison Supplies, which is fine but the devs haven't changed the production/consumption math. They want to force large groups of players to have a shared burden, great theory, but explain why you're trying to force that upon players that do not find that fun, instead of making it easier for the players that choose to do it? 

You play logi, you do everything that's not fun just to provide for your teammates and feel appreciated, you still have to sit in queue just to drop off your supplies and not fight, imagine producing equipment for 1-3 hours, taking a 15-25 min drive, refueling along the way, checking your radio to avoid ambushes, navigating the roadways, only to arrive at your destination and have to wait 10-80mins to enter the zone and drop off your truck load.

Alts/trolls/griefers: are everywhere and rarely punished, in game clans/vets have to pretty much police any poor behavior. The ingame reporting system's worst punishment is a 24-48 ban. And usually doesnt go into effect same day.

1600 hours in, a few years spent playing, amazing concept poor execution and poor management genuinely chase players away in droves. The concept and game play is great, it's fun enough for you to come back everytime there's something new or when you forget why you left. But it's not a game that respects your time, or your fun. The core devs are a bit weird to say the least, and just are not on the same page with the community or the market. Their business model still reflects the game as it was when they released into early access 5-6 years ago. The interest is there, the community is passionate, the game sells, gets picked up by content creators, and while it doesn't actually lack longevity; it punishes you if you and your friends do not make it a second job, which would be fine if it was a subscription based model. But for a game you pay for once, the amount of time you spend putting in work i.e. doing non fun things, like scrap mining, driving, swinging a hammer/shovel in the same location for over 60 seconds if you want to build something, the amount of time you spend having actual fun is minimal. Granted when you do have fun, it's amazing, nothing else really like it in other games. 

In my opinion it's a very min/max game becuz of the time investment required to do anything, once you get a few hundred hours in and you realize how inefficient or wasteful doing the fun stuff is, kinda forces you down the PVE rabbit hole.
I could kill 300 players a day in one life, and have less impact than a guy logging on at 3am for 15 minutes and setting fire to a base that took 3 hours to build.

If you're thinking about buying, I wouldn't. You'll get your money's worth in terms of hours you put in, but you'll spend 20% of your time in a respawn screen, 20% pulling your gear, dying looting in combat, 15% of your time getting yelled at for not knowing wth is going on. And truthfully you log in again after that, either all the map gains you made are either gone or you're fighting in the exact same place 48 hours later. 

Minor gripe, I've been around for 50+ wars, even winning a war doesn't feel as rewarding as it should to be honest, there's no character progression tied to it, no perks, or history log to say you participated in these battles. No medals or commendations, no leaderboard.

Most fun you'll have is after your first few days where you kinda figure things out, but its all downhill from there after you learn how to do everthing else in game. All of it is actually fun, but is it enough fun to justify farming? Probably not.
Pretty good

A truly unique game that is a real treat for anyone interested in WWI or WWII history, team-based games, or factory management. The game has vast, beautiful maps with large scale player-run operations. The game is what you make of it- you can make stuff in a factory, deliver stuff to the frontlines in ships, trucks, and trains, or spend all day simply banging away at the enemy with a rifle. There are tanks, naval landings, a well developed artillery system, massive player-made bases, and the option to play either as a solo (like me) or join a clan to team up for larger operations.

Two criticisms most common in negative reviews are 1) the player base is toxic, and 2) the best stuff isn't available for solo players. There are some toxic people out there (as in any online game) but in my experience with the "Warden" faction by far most folks prefer to help new players than to harass them. If you ask for help and say "I want to learn how to do X"- most of the time someone will volunteer to show you how it works (I do!) People will also trust you more after your first few hours in the game, once they see you aren't a fake account for the other side (an "alt"). As for the "best stuff" being limited to clans- it's true that some of the fancy stuff like trains and supertanks are too big an undertaking for an individual, but you can still drive a  regular tank or take part in almost anything else as a solo. And many clans are casual "play as much as you want" operations.

You can play without a microphone, but for best experience having audio is strongly recommended (especially for combat, less so for logistics players). I'll also note that this game requires a time investment for best results- infantry can shoot each other for 10 minutes at a time, but tank operations usually require 1-2 hours to pick up a tank, drive to the front, fight, and return to base.

So I hope to see you in the game- and don't hesitate to say hi if you do!

You'd have more fun digging a Foxhole in your backyard. Before playing I watched multiple tube vids and took notes (because it takes a notepad to remember which keys to press to effect everything in game). It looked appealing in a 1990's graphics sort of way, but I just couldn't get into the game and feel competent with it. After all the vids and notes, just two and a half hours in and I raised the flag of surrender. The controls are barbaric. The fog of war doesn't belong in this game, but... there it is. Don't get me wrong, it's kind of fun exploring and seeing what people have developed in game, but that's about it. Fights are awful. If the game had been free I might think more of it but, having to buy it, I expected much more than what it is. Yes, someone put a lot of work into the "behind the scenes" mechanics, but game play leaves a LOT to be desired. Now if you want a FREE game with a far better platform for taking ground with land and air battles, one that has excellent graphics and quick travel to the battles (no arduous travel unless you just want that in your game) and FAR more action, I'd highly recommend the FREE game: Planetside2. Watch a vid or two and you'll be competent and fighting in no time... unlike this game, where the only persistent world warfare is in the player's heart as he/she hopes and prays the game will somehow get better.

This game is so addicting and I can't stop loving it, despite its rough edges.

An excellent fusion of factory game, trucking simulator, and slower paced (well thought out) shooter this game merges three genres and thus has something for lots of different people. The persistent warfare means you can always login and contribute to the war effort to whatever extent you want before calling it a night. It also means that your contributions trickle into your entire team's effort, making everything you do part of a greater effort (or completely wasted!). 

This game isn't for everyone but it is certainly a lot for those who enjoy it.

The Good: Persistent large scale war, combat creativity; patience; and teamwork are strongly rewarded, supportive community, tons of different roles and niches to fill
The Bad: It's got a gnarly learning curve, the tutorials are frankly awful, a lot of the UI choices are baffling, many of the gameplay balance decisions feel rushed and are arbitrarily restricting, factory "chores" can make gameplay extremely tedious at times for all but the largest clans.

Despite the bad I love this game and hope the devs continue to support for years... I could certainly see myself playing for that long!
